text: I serve Accent-enhanced dishes to people who are "allergic" to MSG all the time. Sometime after the meal I hand them a can and enjoy the stories they come up with.It makes food delicious. Use it.

This is an odd book, and you should know what you're getting in to.Cons (yes these are before the pros):-This entire book has one actual project in it. To be fair the one project is a neat one, starting with the basics of what the BeagleBone is and going all the way up to using a web page on your computer to control flashing LEDs on your board. But honestly you could jam all that project work into a three-page pamphlet.-Who is the audience? The book waffles between a bare-bones beginner approach (appropriate for a child who's barely used a computer before), and a long-time computer pro approach (whole chapters are just long diatribes on technical errata that a general audience can't wade through). Pick an audience, and stick with it.-Most chapters are purely theoretical, with no immediate application. The chapter on connecting to BeagleBone with your mobile device basically boils down to, "this is beyond the scope of this book". There's a lot of good information in there, but zero that a beginner can use, and no beginner can possibly wade through all the arcane technical bits without some practical applications.Pros:-Covers Both BBB (black) and BBW (white).-All examples and code given are correct, and are given appropriate troubleshooting so that someone with a basic familiarity of code debugging can get the examples running.-Lots of advanced information. The aforementioned section on connecting a mobile device to your BeagleBone covers TCP/IP, and cellular networks, and security, and lots more. Good information- but zero application.Really this book is for a computer professional who has a project in mind but needs a quick introduction before continuing. This book will prep you on safety concerns, voltages, what capes are and what they do, and why you're probably going to want a boilerplate solution for connecting your board to your Android device rather than attempting it from scratch. That's where this book shines. It is not for beginners, and it is not for people who are already familiar with the BeagleBone who are looking for some new project ideas. It doesn't have any.

They're okay. I don't think I'm going to buy any to replace my review bag, but if I was hungry at work and someone had a bag I wouldn't turn them down.Pros:-Good amount of protein. 7g per 180 calorie serving.-Definite blueberry and wheat flavors, doesn't taste like a "health food".-Tastes sort of like oatmeal cookie batter? Like if you made a batch of oatmeal cookies and took them out of the oven before they really firmed up, you'd get these. It's a little odd but not bad.Cons:-Very little fiber, 1g per serving.-Some people have noted this is basically just a Nature Valley soft granola bar chopped into pieces, and that's pretty accurate.If you think you'd like the taste of blueberry oatmeal cookie batter, pick these up. Personally I'm trying to think of a way to get them into the oven to finish baking them. These aren't for me, but they're not bad.

I like these wipes.Pros:-Handy canister. The containers are high quality and work well, some wipes will have problems like the lid pulling off before towels separate, these seem like they're built better.-The wipes are strong, so they don't tear apart during use.-Yet they're gentle, and feel comfortable one face and hands.-No residue! This is really nice, as many competing products leave behind a sticky feeling, or oftentimes wipes will have a little baby powder mixed in so you get that powdery feeling. These wipes are balanced enough not to leave behind a noticeable residue.Cons:-The smell of the wipes is a little odd and chemical out of the canister, but again there's not residue, so this is a minor quibble.Overall highly recommended. It's the quality you'd expect from Purell.

This is an excellent towel set.Pros:-Soft, yet strong. The mat is comfortable yet seems sturdy enough to take some odd poses and slips.-Absorbent. The mat and towel are more than capable of handling the average workout.-Attractive. It's useful to have a comfortable setting when you're doing yoga or any other exercise you might use these towels for, and they're certainly attractive enough to suit your workout.-The floor mat even has rubber contact points to help prevent slipping, which is a nice touch.Cons:-Finish is merely okay. While the edges certainly don't seem like they'll unravel anytime soon, the stitching shows some loose threads in spots, so eventually it will give out. The construction could use just a bit more care.So this is a great yoga towel set. It's certainly a step up from reusing a beach towel. The good looks and the anti-slip feature are more than enough to warrant a look.And to counter some bad science going around, the facts on triclosan:-Yes, triclosan is a pesticide. So is peppermint oil, and capsaicin (the ingredient that causes peppers to be hot). Something can be both a pesticide and also be safe for humans to use, that's why it's called "pesticide" and not "poison".-As of writing, some tests have shown triclosan to cause health problems in lab animals. There is only very limited data relating to tests on humans, and these tests focus on accumulation of triclosan in the body from environmental sources.-So as of writing, there is currently no reason to suspect that using these towels will give you cancer. The major concern with this chemical is that triclosan is widely used on farms, leading to runoff in the water supply.-See your country's governing health organization for further recommendations if you have a concern.

Warning: I cannot find an ingredient list for these cups anywhere. No nutrition label, no ingredients, nothing. These products are produced by Brooklyn Beans, who don't even post nutritional information on their website so far as I can tell. I'm not even sure how that's legal? Giving minimum stars for this. What if someone has a food allergy and has serious health problems thank to the improper labeling? This is ridiculous.The closest I could find was off the website OKCups, which lists the ingredients for the Mexican Hot Chocolate as: PURE CANE SUGAR, NON DAIRY CREAMER (CORN SYRUP SOLIDS, HYDROGENATED COCONUT OIL, SODIUM CASEINATE (A MILK DERIVATIVE), DIPOTASSIUM PHOSPHATE, MONO-AND DIGUCERIDES, SALT, SODIUM CITRATE, SODIUM SILICOALUMINATE, SOY LECITHIN, ARTIFICIAL FLAVORS, ARTIFICIAL COLORS). MALTODEXTRIN, COCOA, CINNAMON, NATURAL AND ARTIFICIAL FLAVORS, SALT, SILICONE DIOXIDE AND CAYENNE PEPPER. CONTAINS MILK MANUFACTURED IN A PLANT THAT PROCESSES SOY.The Brooklyn Bean website specifies that some of its Hot Chocolate K-Cups were mislabeled and do in fact contain aspartame so this may not be an accurate ingredient list. Brooklyn Beans does not specify what products were affected.Really, I'm leaving it at that. Don't buy a food product that won't follow proper food labeling guidelines.

The K'NEX K-Force Dual Cross Building Set certainly has some plusses and minuses worth considering before you buy it. Overall I like it, but see below for details.Pros:-HUGE! It's actually pretty surprising how big this set is when constructed. Anyone who gets this set will be pleased with the result.-K'NEX quality, I haven't had a broken or snapped part yet.-Strong dart launchers. The included darts go a decent distance, comparable to NERF products, allowing for a decent degree of range and accuracy.Cons:-HUGE! Parents are going to want to encourage kids to download and build the smaller sets just because the main one is so massive. It's so big you might actually have to worry about smaller kids trying to use it- the grips are way back on one end of the large launcher so it's pretty cumbersome to wield.-Kind of wasteful. The actual dart shooters are just the little neon yellow bits on the end, the rest of the shooter is just rigging. Anyone who thinks about this enough is going to either just use the dart shooters by hand, or build a much smaller contraption to fire them.-K'NEX instructions aren't as clear as LEGO. I'm a decades-long veteran of various construction kits and I was still left scratching my head a little in places, or having to redo a bit I mounted incorrectly on the first try. Colors in the manual are also very fussy- try telling the dark blue from the dark gray from the black from the dark purple, they really need to work on their instruction systems.Overall this is a very cool toy. A fun dart launcher that's still as safe as any NERF product. The only complaints are that the darts don't have suction cups on the end, and the large kit on the box is so huge it may actually be hard to wield or store. Download and build the smaller launchers- and then you can have to for shootouts- and you'll probably be happier.

This is a nice gift soap.Pros:-HUGE! This bar of soap is maybe a baseball and a half at a guess? It's gigantic, but manageable. Very interesting shape.-The gift box is gorgeous, and generously scented. The soap comes in a bit of Easter-style grass, making it look like an egg all safely nested into its nest.-The scent is strong, but not overwhelming nor unpleasant. I agree with other reviewers that it has a hint of old lady perfume, but in a very nostalgic way, no males who've smelled it have had any issue with it.-Real soap. Sometimes products advertise "real soap" but in practice they're awful chemical concoctions. You can tell this really is soap.-Durable. Although the butter content means this isn't the longest-lasting kind of soap, it also doesn't completely melt in the shower. I expect this to last a decent while.Cons:-The smell is slightly old lady and floral, which might be unappealing for some. Everyone I've handed it to has found it pleasant, but be aware.-Pricey. Obviously this isn't an everyday soap, but as a gift it's great.I like it. This is a wonderful gift for anyone.

This is a perfect kitchen set. No complaints. OXO started with a simple philosophy, put easier to use- large and rubberized- handles on kitchen appliances so they're more comfortable to use. They paired that with good quality products at reasonable prices. And that's my review of this entire set in a nutshell.Pros:-Everything you need for a small kitchen.-The OXO vegetable peeler is one of the best out there.-The spatula is already the workhorse of my kitchen.-The whisk is sturdy, so many cheap sets have painfull weak whisks that cause problems, no such issues here. It's just what it should be for this size and price.Cons:-The measuring cups and spoons feel a little cheap. They work, but they definitely wouldn't take much abuse.-The tongs are a little small, really only working with smaller pans, but if I had to pick between these or paying more I'd take these.-I'd prefer a microplane to a grater, but that's nitpicking.I'd say if you're a single person starting to furnish your apartment, this is an absolute must-have alongside a set of cheap wooden spoons. It's everything you need, and nothing you don't (although I personally won't make much use of the grater). Great quality, good price, and most of the set will remain durable for a long time.

The moment you unzip the heavy zipper on this lovely leather case, you realize that your money was worth it. Smelling the new leather alone is a treat. Every piece is excellent, beautiful, and works wonderfully. I wish I could give this a bit of a star off as I had a very small decorative defect in my kit- and if I'm paying this much I hope my kit is perfect- but that's as nitpicky as I can possibly be about this set.Included (left-to-right):-Small nail clippers. Interestingly, these are completely straight whereas the larger ones are curved. There's a nail file built into the handle.-Nail scissors. Whether you have tough nails or prefer the old-school method, these scissors feel surgical-grade. I like that the spring mechanism pulls out for storage, and a button fastener. Curved.-Large nail clippers. These are also curved and rather gently which I like, these actually don't have a nail file like the smaller version. The back of these clippers has a large pad that helps you hold them, they're gorgeous and very tactile. Also has a thin nail file down the back, although this nail file can only be used while the clippers are closed, whereas the one for the smaller clippers is used when they're open, odd but it works.-Nose hair clippers. Finally, nose clippers that work. Thanks to the fine grade of steel they're thinner so they reach everywhere easily, they work correctly, and they still have enough of a safety bubble on the end so you're not stabbing yourself. I really like these. Not to mention- a lot of cheap nose clippers I've used leave a smell thanks to the metal, and these don't have that issue.-Tweezers. These are beautifully crafted, with a good angle to make them easy to use.-Nail file. With two different patterns, one rougher and one smoother.I'm in love. This set is lovely enough that you'll be thinking about where it's going to go in your will when you pass it on. Top quality.

Wow, get this for your kid.REAL SCIENCE! Too many new science books for kids come with a limited selection of completely pre-fabricated bits, with all the "experiments" 100% planned so there's no real experimentation. This is completely different, the book gives kids a short list of things they need like "milk carton, 4 paper cups..." so kids are encouraged to explore, and try things for themselves, and there's lots of notes on alternate materials you can try- kids are encouraged to experiment and compare the results. Wonderful!All levels of challenge. Most experiments are given in a fairly simple form, then followed by a series of challenge questions or ways to improve the apparatus. An example is the "nephoscope", essentially you take a mirror and mark the compass directions on it. You place this mirror flat on the ground, and use it to see gauge the direction and speed of clouds moving overhead. One challenge question involves the fact that weather reports don't say what direction the wind is moving *toward* but what direction the wind is moving *from*, and challenges the experimenter to reverse the directions on their nephoscope. Questions like these provide a wonderful way to get kids to think critically- for example *why* do weather reports use the direction the wind is from? Good science books should encourage kids to formulate such questions for themselves.REAL DANGER! Science geeks complain constantly about how sanitized modern science kits are. For example, you can no longer purchase an off-the-shelf chemistry kit with strong acids, which limits children from performing many interesting experiments. It's a bit like trying to protect your kid from ever being burned, by getting rid of your oven- there are better ways. There is no such problem in this book. For one of course you're challenged to get your own materials, so the author can list any materials at all- even when they involve high voltage! Yes, this is a science book that includes serious warnings of chemical burns, electrocutions, and lacerations. I'm sure there's a "helicopter parents" somewhere who's hyperventilating at these warnings, but for anyone who cares about real experimental science, this is a blessing. Each experiment is carefully crafted to allow kids the maximum exposure to concepts with minimal risk- but risk is not left out of the book merely for legal reasons. Safety is in the hands of the experimenter (and hopefully an adult who's there to lend support without too much hand-holding).Age range? Nah. This book does not come stamped all over with an age range- nor should it. When I was a budding scientist kid, I was doing a lot of similar experiments in gradeschool. Other kids might not get into this until their teens. The appropriate age range for this book begins when a child is old enough to ask questions (with the help of a guardian of course), and ends when they've gotten too crabby to experience any more wonder. I'd say "5 to 105" is a good range. Parents can benefit too- I know a lot of adults who can't manage to build half the things in this book, when a lot of interested children will breeze right through. This is something parent and child can enjoy together.All in all, this is a wonderful book. If you love your child / nieces and nephews / grandchildren / child you mentor, get it for them today. Then open up your junk bins so they can find some old parts, and maybe even dig out that old radio so you can play with the transistors. Generations of America's best scientists and Nobel prizewinners grew up this way, and your kids should too.

A good mouse with a curious feature set, the MX Anywhere 2 might be just what you're looking for, if you're a very specific type of user. The ideal user for this mouse is someone who regularly connects to up to 3 different Bluetooth-enabled devices (one of which can be via the included wireless dongle), but who doesn't switch their "home" device often (see below), and who doesn't need to use the middle mouse button very often. That's a specific user profile.Pros:-Premium feel. Rubberized surfaces and executive-style metallic accent on the scroll wheel will assure you that this isn't a cheap mouse.-Great battery life. The box promises months on a full charge, and given the size of the battery pack that's very believable.-Generic Bluetooth compatible. Although the device has one wireless dongle in case you need to work with a computer that isn't Bluetooth-enabled, it also connects to generic Bluetooth at the press of a button, meaning you can connect to new devices with the press of a button.-Plug-and-play. Although this is standard on modern devices, it's nice to see there's zero hassle with setup, my computer detected it instantly like any other mouse.-Great sensor. I haven't found a surface yet that this mouse can't read accurately.-USB rechargeable. Connects with an included USB micro cable, and given that awesome life you won't need the cable often. Neat.-Robust scroll wheel. Up, down, left, right, although oddly no middle click, that's on the gesture button. In fact the scroll wheel still clicks, but doesn't seem to register any functions. Weird. Oh wait, I read online (due to the lack of documentation) that clicking the wheel switches between a free-wheeling or resistance mode, so the scroll wheel is either "clicky" like most mice or allows you to throw it for extended scrolling. Weird.-Gesture button. Takes the place of a middle mouse click, and supposedly allows the use of gestures. Not something I'm sure I'll use especially since there's no included manual telling you how to use them (more below), but maybe other people have a use for it.-Back-forward buttons on the left side.Cons:-Back-forward buttons are only for right-handed people. Sorry, lefties.-Lack of documentation. How do you use the gestures? Look online. What does clicking the scroll wheel do? Look online. I wish this had a manual.-One wireless dongle. Should you need to connect to multiple devices that aren't Bluetooth-enabled, you'll be moving around the dongle like times of old.-No spot to store the dongle. This is pretty puzzling, as most any mobile mouse will have a little slot for storing the wireless dongle when not in use. Since this mouse connects with Bluetooth you might not need to use the dongle at all- in which case where does it go? Or if you switch devices often where you need the dongle, you'll have to sort out a way not to lose it.-No wired mode. It's a little weird that the device recharges via USB, but won't connect through USB, so even though there's a cable running from your computer to your mouse it won't work until you also connect via dongle or Bluetooth. Counterintuitive.Overall, it's a bit of a weird package. As a mobile user I certainly appreciate the feel and the battery life. As a power user, I'm left scratching my head about the feature set. Why isn't there a spot to store the dongle? Why isn't the scroll wheel the middle mouse button by default? It's hard to make a general recommendation because I could see some of these issues being deal-breakers, a lot of professionals need a strong middle mouse button and this one is just too cumbersome.If you're a regular mobile user looking for a good mouse, this one certainly works, but so does the bargain Logitech mouse you can pick up anywhere for a fraction of this price. I can only recommend upgrading if you're frustrated having to change batteries (although modern mice rarely need changed very often), or if you have a lot of trouble with different surfaces (this mouse's sensor is definitely a step up). This mouse just doesn't seem to suit a lot of users.If this exact same mouse had a few small engineering fixes put into place it'd be an absolute winner, but as-is, read the feature set carefully and see if it's for you.

This is a really nice bag, even for a tall guy it's perfect.Pros:-I'm a big guy, 6'+, and the bag fits me just fine.-There's a hood you can zip on or off, which is very nice especially if you ever get hit with sudden severe conditions and need to bundle up.-There's a removable "middle layer" which you can sleep on top of, or put over you like a blanket, or remove altogether. This allows for a great variety of setup options and temperature control, it's brilliant.-Quality is good. As some have noted this is a fairly heavy/bulky bag, but honestly the ultralight bags some people are looking for cost multiple times this price- for the price, this bag is gorgeous.Cons:Does come tightly jammed into its carrying pouch, so it could be a hassle trying to get it back in for long-term storage. To balance this, it does have a quick wrap system for transport, which is good enough.Overall highly recommended. For the price, this is an incredibly full-featured bag.

You say feminism isn't a hate movement? Here's a feminist author writing about a terrorist organization that commits violence against men, and feminists are applauding. Color me surprised.You say feminists don't support the SCUM manifesto (Society for Cutting Up Men)? "Dietland is a SCUM Manifesto set to a pop music beat and Plum Kettle is a feminist hero for the modern age.”—Alice Sebold, author of The Lovely BonesFeminists don't want to commit violence in support of their cause? “I've never dropped anyone out of a helicopter. But Dietland resonated with the part of me that wants, just once, to deck a street harasser. At the very least, I wish an incurable itch upon everyone who has catcalled me on the street. I wish food poisoning and public embarrassment on everyone I've heard make a rape joke. I wish toothache and headlice and too-small shoes upon every stranger who has told me to smile.”—Annalisa Quinn, NPR.orgSickening.

This is an excellent knife sharpener to accompany the Victorinox line of kitchen knives, and it has an undocumented trick a lot of people seem to be confused about- combo surfaces.YES IT HAS TWO DIFFERENT SURFACES! Opposite sides of the steel are in two different patterns. There's a ridged "sharpening" side, and a smooth "honing" side. Most consumer kitchen "honing" rods are actually slightly abrasive like the ridged portion of this steel. This results in a less than perfect edge, but it performs a slight amount of sharpening so you can maintain a "good enough" edge for most kitchen use longer in between having to give your knives a professional resharpening. Smooth rods are less common, they perform no sharpening and only help to realign the existing cutting edge- this will only help maintain an existing edge longer, it does not "resharpen" the blade. Professionals often prefer smooth steels because they have an in-house program to get their knives professionally resharpened whenever they need it.Pros:-Long. At 12", this steel should be long enough to safely sharpen any home knife.-Two different surfaces, a ridged sharpening side and smooth honing side.-Adequate construction. Victorinox often use inexpensive plastic handles to reduce cost. They grip well in any condition, and the cheaper price is worth it.Cons:-Honestly I'm sure they could make the handle a bit nicer without affecting the price. It still grips well, but it's enough of an eyesore that I stash it away in a drawer between uses.-Doesn't come with sufficient documentation, leaving people confused about what the different surfaces are for.Overall highly recommended.

Overall a good product, although it is a bit expensive.Pros:-Heavy gauge aluminum. Aluminum is one of the best materials for baking, light and strong and spreads heat evenly.-The "pebble" pattern does seem to help items slide off a little more easily, although a good aluminum pan tends to be fairly nonstick for baked goods anyway.Cons:-Made in China.-...despite being made in China, it's expensive. One secret all good bakers know is that the cheapest way to get a great pan is to go to your local restaurant supply store, where you can find a "quarter baking sheet" for around around a third of the price of this Doughmakers pan as of writing. This will be an even heavier-gauge aluminum pan with thick side walls to make the pan more rigid, and it's what any good baker uses for small batches of cookies or biscuits or whatever.Overall this Doughmakers pan is a fine and attractive pan, but the next time I wanted to bake some biscuits I went back to my quarter sheet as usual. If I damage my quarter sheet or burn something on it, then oh well I'll get another one. This Doughmakers pan is too expensive so I don't want to abuse it like that, and it doesn't offer much of a performance upgrade to justify the cost.

This is an excellent, if fairly bulky, mount.Pros:-Spring-loaded grippy claw holds phones up to 6" screen size or thereabouts. I loaded in my Galaxy S5 (5.1" diagonal) with an Otterbox Commuter case, it fits easily and holds well. The grips have protective foam so they won't scratch your phone, and the foam provides extra grip.-Durable construction. If anything, the base is over-engineered. The "head" swivels 360 so handle any phone orientation, and it also has some freedom to rotate left-right-up-down, meaning it can suit pretty much any position you can imagine. The stem leading to the base even has a hole in case you want to thread your power cord through it for cable management. They thought of almost everything.-Dual mounts. The unit itself has a locking suction cup mount which is large and sturdy for locking to glass or appropriate surfaces. You also get a small base which can attach to your dash with a sticker, and the unit then suctions itself to the base, making it removable even if dash mounted. Very nice.Cons:-Fairly large and bulky. I have a dual-level dash where I can sneak a GPS unit between the two levels if it's mounted directly to the bottom half. This unit is too tall, so I can't do that. The only adjustment this unit doesn't come with is height, so your phone will always be a good distance off whatever surface it's on, this is designed so your phone will fit in even with power plugged in, but it is quite tall.Note on sizing:The smallest and largest sizes this mount can hold are almost exactly defined by a credit card. So long as the width of your device is between the short and long sides of a credit card, it will fit this mount.Overall:So long as you've got room for the overall size of the mount, you won't find a better universal mount on the market. It's strong, attractive, and adapts to most devices. I'd prefer if the unit were shorter or had a height adjustment, but I admit I'm looking for a fairly rare mounting option.

These are decent curtains, but the picture doesn't convey what an "old lady" design these really are. They look more like the lace doily your grandma might have for her china teacups, than an everyday curtain.Pros:-Good quality. The curtains are heavy enough that they don't flap too much in the wind, proven when a storm hit recently.-Let plenty of light through. If what you want is to cover a window without darkening a room too much, perhaps for privacy as much as anything, these let in a very high ratio of light, which is nice.Cons:-"Old lady" design could use some updating.

You can really feel the difference. I suppose the closest comparison I'm familiar with is the DR coated strings, such as the "DR Red Devil". The coated DR strings have a light coating that doesn't really alter the feel of the string very much, but they do slightly protect your strings and they come in awesome colors that are usually UV-sensitive (or, they look great under a blacklight), so those strings are both for protection and looks. The Elixirs focus only on protection, and they seem to do that job better.Pros:-Work like normal strings, I can't hear much of a tonal difference, there's certainly not enough of a muting effect to know this is a coated string versus merely being a difference brand of string.-Feel smooth. Imagine if your strings were made of smooth plastic. It's a nice feeling, and will be nicer with time as where normal strings would start getting a little rusty the Elixirs will still be "like new" for longer.Cons:-None.I see a lot of people complaining about the range of strings included in the pack- there are several packs for light/medium/heavy, and each has its gauge printed on the pack, so this is a case of buyers not doing adequate research. The included range is fairly standard, so do your homework and get the strings you want.

This should really say "decorative towel set". These towels are thin, scratchy, and the designs are obviously going to be destroyed by even light use. After one wash they crack and fade, not acceptable for actual home use.As of writing, the listing is for "4 Distowels" (typo included), which should say about all you need to know. I'm glad this is just from a review copy, because if I'd purchased these on my own I probably would have returned them. Not worth the cost, decorative-only towels.They do work, since they are cotton. And they are pretty before you use them, so two stars just to be nice. But not recommended.

Anyone who thinks the tiny solar panel on this could charge a cell phone, doesn't know much about solar panels. Sorry folks, but cell phones require a lot of juice, so don't buy this if you expect to be streaming video all day. The instruction say you'll need to use the hand crank vigorously for 5+ minutes just to get a minute of talk time, and that's more in line with reality. That aside, this is a great radio.Pros:-Attractive design. The red case has good visibility, all the controls are clear, and the case has an almost rubberized finish, it's a pleasure to hold.-Easy to use. I found the dials easy to operate, tuning into a couple of local stations readily, so the sensitivity is good.-Good reception. I had no problem hearing any station I tried, this is as good as you can expect of any pocket radio.-All the bells and whistles. Sturdy case, all the bands, hand crank or solar, flashlight, and yes even a way to hand crank a cell phone.Cons:-No battery backup. Once the small built-in rechargable runs out you'll have to charge it by hand or wait for solar.Overall:Highly recommended. This is a perfect emergency radio. Get one today.Solar Power for Dummies:It's kind of amazing how little people seem to know about solar. Here's your quick guide to understanding solar on this radio. The solar panel is tiny, we're talking the sort of power you're used to seeing on a pocket calculator- and those don't have speakers for a reason. A solar panel large enough to power your average phone would have to be larger than this device (people make smaller ones, but they don't work very well!). If you've ever used a solar pocket calculator, you have an idea what you're getting here. You should also know you need pretty strong light coming from directly overhead to get decent results. The sun needs to be fairly high in the sky (or the device tilted toward the sun) to get much power at all, and even then clouds or a low seasonal sun will limit the maximum power you can get. Just placing this in a window probably won't do much. You're placing the solar panel flat (not tilted toward the sun), you're probably not doing it at high noon (sun is at a low angle), and it's behind a window (all glass blocks some light, and you may also have a bug screen too). The solar panel is really only for emergencies- you'd have to leave the device outside in the high noon sun for a few hours to get some decent listening time, and then the device isn't fully waterproof! Basically just always leave this radio somewhere where it can get some ambient light, so it'll be fully charged if an emergency hits, but in actual use, you're going to need to use the hand crank almost exclusively.

I ordered the 4-person tent, and WOW. I'm impressed. A tip for beginners: always order a bigger tent than the label shows. A "2-person" tent really means it can sleep two people in an emergency, if you want to be comfortable, you want to order a tent with double the space. Another way to think about it is that one person plus their gear (backpack, food, etc) is basically two people. I'm expecting to have one guest, so two people plus two packs = 4 person tent.Pros:-Instant setup. Really just zip open the bag, toss it in the air, and it lands unfolded. That's it. And it comes from the factory with the rain cover already attached, so it's done. Of course you should stake it down so it resists wind, but honestly you could just throw gear in the corners and you're finished.-Great size. I'm over 6 feet tall, and this tent is HUGE. I certainly can't stand up inside, but it's more than comfortable for 2 large people to sleep in with extra space for gear.-Full features. Includes removable rain cover, which protects a huge area of breathable bug net- this tent should ventilate very well. Has two doors, one is an opaque rain cover, the other has breathable bug net. Also has a small device pocket inside to keep important items off the ground, great to protect electronics from any sudden problems. Comes with all the stakes and tie-downs you need.-Easy to put away, if you're physically sound. It takes some practice and some careful reading of the instructions, but once you know what you're doing, one person can fold this tent up and store it in seconds. Note that you do need to be fairly limber to put this one away as you're dealing with a springy item, so anyone with physical limitations will want to have two people for the job.-Attractive, high-visibility colors. If you ever need rescuing, this is an easy tent to find.Cons:-Cheap zippers. At this price, you do have to be careful, as material may get caught in the zippers and lead to snags. Just be careful and you'll be fine.-No "porch" area. The door opens at a fairly low angle, so if you're getting in or out in the rain you can expect a lot of water to creep into the front. I'll probably remedy this by hanging a tarp, but it's worth noting that you may want to consider holding an umbrella over the door if you can.Overall:Really a brilliant design. It truly does pop up, it's very full-featured for its price range, and the quality is certainly acceptable for a cheap tent. Recommended.

This is a decent product, but I'm not sure why you'd buy it over standard Febreeze.Pros:-Light scent, maybe even a little lighter and more "clean" smelling than the original-Basically works the same as Febreeze, eliminates orders (although it doesn't have "six-hour" protection, it just works on contact)-Spray bottle is very effective, maybe even better than the standard squeeze bottleCons:-More expensive than regular Febreeze. This to me is a killer. Although the "Unstopables Fresh" scent is nice, it's not so nice as to warrant a price increase. I'm going to stick to the regular scent, and save money. They both work equally well.Overall:-This certainly isn't a bad product, and it might be perfect if you think the scent of Febreeze is a little overpowering, but otherwise it's the same product at a higher price. I can't really recommend it.

This Lipton-branded drink squirt is about the same as any other on the market, so if you were looking for Lipton flavor, here it is.Pros:-Convenient. One squeeze per 8oz of water, and you basically don't even need to stir or shake as it mixes well.-Lipton flavor. It's definitely Lipton tea.Cons:-More expensive than making your own, and more expensive than using a powdered mix.-Lipton flavor. I always think Lipton tastes a little off, like a Chinese gunpowder tea or something, I'd prefer a more neutral flavor, something like an English breakfast tea.So there it is. If you're against powdered mixes but need something to spice up your daily water intake, and you like Lipton tea, this is a good choice.

First impressions? High quality, smart storage.Pros:-Although it says it's a soft case, the shell is quite rugged, sort of a rubberized plastic that'll definitely take some beating.-The zipper feels robust, almost to the point of being sticky, but I haven't had it catch so it seems fine.-Comes with both a carrying handle and carabiner clip.-The lid has a padded compartment to store small items, sort of one flap goes over the other so just stuff your item under them. The only downside is the mesh isn't see-through so you have to remember what you threw in there.-I didn't notice on purchase, but the elastic bands for holding things to the bottom are on a pad with hook-and-loop fastener, so this false bottom can be removed if you don't need the straps, gaining a bit of extra space- maybe you can even find another use for the elastic outside the case by sticking it to something.-The elastic bands seem to be decently arrayed, I threw three items in and they're all held securely.Cons:-As said, the zipper is a little tough, so don't expect a speedy open. The zipper does however seem to have a robust construction, so I'm willing to take this trade-off if it doesn't snag.Overall recommended. This is an attractive, sturdy case which could hold a variety of items thanks to its universal set of straps- or pull that piece out if you just need a padded box.

This is a neat product. I usually hate fondant, as bakeries use bad-tasting fondant to make cakes that look great so people buy them, but then nobody really cares about the flavor. This is the best of both worlds. The fondant has good marshmellow flavor, it rolls easily without breaking, and it obviously stores well. Overall recommended. It's just like making fondant yourself, only who in the world makes fondant because icing tastes so much better- until now.

This is a good assortment of basic hand soaps. Each is attractively packaged in a good-quality bottle, I haven't had any major problems pumping any of the soaps. All the soaps seem to clean fairly well, and rinse off easily in my semi-hard water. If I had to lodge one complaint, some of the fruitier flavors such as the cherry smell very sweet. These will definitely leave a scent on your hands and in your house, which can be nice, but I definitely prefer soaps that leave behind no residue at all.So overall, the soaps may be a little overpowering, but they definitely work, so I can't complain.

As of writing, the list price for the 8-plant kit is over $1 a plant, although each does come with what I assume is Miracle-Gro fertilizer. The problem is, you can go to any home store and get whole pre-grown plants for not much more, so it's a little hard to justify the price.The pod selection is also pretty weird. I'd assume the pods are meant for apartment living, but a lot of the plants aren't best grown in pots, so this is a bad idea for apartment dwellers. And if you have space to grow plants, you should just buy seeds and do it properly.I'll update my review after giving the plants time to grow, but I just can't recommend these pods. They're relatively expensive, they don't really cater to any specific market, and they take all the fun out of gardening. They don't even mention how much sun/shade each plant needs! Just seems like this product needs a re-think.

This is an early review covering just the materials presented, as actually mailing off for the completed book is stated to take 4-6 weeks, I'll update if there's anything major discovered at that time.IlluStory is a neat little package. It includes plenty of clear instructions for what to do- and there's plenty of additional information on the website. Included are all the markers you need, plus extra paper, and a business reply envelope. This seems like a very fun activity- in fact, I completed it myself with an artist friend who was absolutely ecstatic, so this is definitely something that people of any age can enjoy. Also noted is that the words can be done with any standard pen/pencil/etc, so you don't have to waste your black marker on words or filling out the author form.Overall the direction are clear, the package is simple, and it's a fun activity. Recommended.

In short, this is a very good wireless adapter.If you don't know much about computers:-Do you want to connect to WiFi, but your computer doesn't do wireless? Plug this into a USB port, and you're set!-Does your computer seem to have trouble connecting to WiFi, even when other people nearby are doing fine? You might want to try this product!-Note that this adapter only comes with software for Windows out of the box, so only get this if you have a Windows computer. It does not work out of the box with Mac, and I'm not at all sure whether there would be Linux drivers.If you're a computer tech:-It's dual-band, USB2.0, does all the latest standards, has a real antenna, WPS button, includes a USB extender cable, and it's plug-and-play on Windows. This is a nice package, although the antenna is a bit weird for a USB dongle, it's not very mobile-friendly.My review setup:-My bedroom is right at the edge of the wireless range in my house, so devices in my bedroom can connect but just barely. I'll be watching something from YouTube and get random buffering on most devices. So far, this TP-LINK adapter has done significantly better than most other devices, right now I'm listening to an audio stream that's had zero buffering issues. Just to further the comparison, for my test I plugged this adapter into a laptop that normally has issues connecting with its internal WiFi. So plugging in this dongle went from a merely so-so connection, to a fairly bulletproof one.Overall I definitely recommend this adapter. This company really thought of everything, down to the included USB extender cable just in case you don't want this this poking out the side of your laptop- and with the big antenna, you probably don't.

A high quality kitchen towel might seem like an odd combination of words to some, but this All-Clad Kitchen towel proves it can be done. Quality construction, sensible colors to match any home, and they work.Pros:-Quality construction. Out of the box this is a product where it seems like not a single stitch is out of place. Really impressive.-Nice colors that hold. My pewter towel is gorgeous, and there's been zero loss of color so far.-Absorbent and durable. The towel has a mixed pattern of absorbent fluffy bits and more tightly woven scrubby bits, making it ideal for any application.Cons:-One of these towels cost as much as your local supermarket brand. However, assuming they're as durable as they appear, that investment might pay off. But I haven't tested them long enough to find out.Overall this is a gorgeous towel, if you're looking to put the finishing touched on a home you'd be hard-pressed to beat this offering.

A good wet wipe.Pros:-Pleasant scent. The wipes give you a fresh, slightly citrus smell without being overpowering.-The tissues are a good size and durable, I've had no problem using them for a full face/neck refresher.-Convenient travel size. Some wipes are packaged in a longer, thinner format which can make them too long to stuff into various travel bags or pockets. These wipes are in a more square format, which is generally easier to stash.Cons:-The resealable flap is a little small, meaning if the package is wrinkled especially as you remove more tissues then it can be a challenge to get a good seal.Overall these definitely do the job. I tend to keep a pack stashed in my car for whatever emergency, and these wipes have been a nice addition to my rotation.
It worked. Replaced OEM cover on my S5, feels even better than the stock one did. Thanks.

It appears as though a few different products' reviews are being jammed together, so note this is for the Turtle Beach Impact 100 keyboard, the base model in the line. In short: it's merely adequate, which doesn't justify the price.Pros:-Allows up to 30 keys to be pressed simultaneously. This is far more than anyone should ever need, but it's definitely sufficient for any game.-Weighted base so the keyboard won't slide around.-Comes with a fairly robust cable with a reusable cable tie included. Nice touch.Cons:-"Smart Guide Keycaps" are a gimmick. The keys don't feel any different from any other cheap keyboard.-The key travel feels far too rubbery for typists. I could only recommend this keyboard if you only ever intend to use it for gaming and never for actually typing.-Wow that's heavy. This is easily the heaviest keyboard I've ever held, it must have weights in the base. Personally I don't see a need for even a fraction of this weight as I've never had a problem with a sliding keyboard before, but maybe somebody out there needs it?Overall, I can't help but feel this keyboard is just a gimmick. It's a cheap plastic keyboard they've tried to increase the price on by putting weights in the bottom and ensuring it can register 30 keypresses at once. I'm sure you can do better elsewhere. Only recommended if you need a purpose-built gaming-only keyboard that you'll never type on, where you need to mash a lot of keys at once, and for some reason you need lead weights in the bottom? I don't know who would ever need that.

The problem with this "Thai red curry paste"? It's not Thai, it's barely curry, and it's not a paste. That's about as wrong as you can be.Authentic Thai curry paste, first of all, should be a paste. It's kind of in the name. This product is mostly canola oil, so it's more of a chili oil. Authentic Thai curry also contains many ingredients not included here, such as galangal and lemongrass. This product is also made from Jalapeño and not Thai chiles. Thai chiles are basically synonymous with Thai cooking, so not including them is silly.So this product just isn't what it's labeled as. It's just a spicy chili oil, nothing more.

It is what it says. This is a nice, heavy baking dish that should be excellent for whatever purpose you have in mind. The dimensions and shape are very standard, so you know exactly what you're getting. The sloped edges will make removing some items easier, if that's the sort of thing you're making.So far this has been an excellent baker, no complaints.

There's one thing that sets Irish Spring apart: The invigorating smell. There's one thing missing from this product: That invigorating smell.Pros:-Has a mild, but manly/musky scent. It's hard to mix musk and mint, as the two can quickly add up to "old man slathered in Icy/Hot". But this product manages to smell masculine without being medicinal.-Lathers like mad.Cons:-Doesn't rinse easily. In anything but the softest water, this takes some effort to rinse off.-Smell is merely okay. This doesn't have the eye-opening smell of original Irish Spring, merely a generic and short-lived musk.There's not really a lot more to say. This isn't a bad body wash, unless you have hard water, but I also don't see what distinguishes it from the competition.

I'm a programmer, so I appreciate any product that can give my hands a break. These exercise balls do the trick.Pros:-Three levels of resistance. Personally, I don't think the level of resistance matters nearly as much just doing the exercise, but especially if you have multiple typists in your household (and everyone is typing at this point) then the selection could benefit different people.-Definitely works. I've been on a major work project lately and I've noticed a marked difference in hand pain since using these exercisers.-Appropriate size. I have oddly proportioned hands, so I'm usually the first to notice if a product isn't very ergonomic. I find these very comfortable.Cons:-The same slightly sticky, pliant nature that makes these exercise balls so good for a workout also makes them dust magnets. It would be nice if they came with some way to keep them dust-free, but I suspect they would rinse well.Overall, recommended. These have certainly helped my relieve my hands after a day of typing.

I'm not entirely sure this product offers much in the way of benefits over regular Head & Shoulders, but it's at least as good as the original- and quite different in terms of scent and feel- so someone looking for an alternative might want to give this a try.Pros:-Same active ingredient as Head & Shoulders.-More "shampoo-like". I think most people are familiar with the standard formula of head and shoulders, which is sets it apart from regular shampoos and clearly marks it as an anti-dandruff product. This "hydration" formula is more creamy in color and form, like other hydrating shampoos. Someone looking for that "salon shampoo" feel instead of Head & Shoulders, would like this.-New, coconut-based smell. Again, this smells more like a "salon" shampoo. It's a bit floral, and a bit more like... well, other hydrating shampoos.Cons:-None to report.Overall I can't really say whether this has much of an effect on my hair, as I'm sporting a very short cut. However, the dandruff formula works the same as it ever did, and the new smell is an interesting change. I'll probably go back to the regular formula, but I could see this product appealing to people who don't like the smell and feel of tradition anti-dandruff shampoos.

Neutrogena tends to be a pretty solid company for basic skin supplies. I've been using their sensitive aftershave balm for a while, and I'm always happy to try new products. I got this one "for a friend" but there are always a few spots I can try on myself. The results are exactly what they should be.Pros:-Good packaging. This product doesn't pretend to be much more than it is, maximum strength benzoyl peroxide.-The formula applies cleanly and washes off readily, I didn't have any residue after a quick wash and a pat dry.-Works as advertised. Benzoyl peroxide is the "big gun" of acne treatment, whereas the more common salicylic acid tends to be for more sensitive skin.Cons:-Maximum-strength benzoyl peroxide is caustic stuff, so be careful. Test it out on a small area of skin before applying it more thoroughly. This stuff can bleach fabric and hair, so please don't get it near your eyes or other mucous membranes.Neutrogena hits another one out of the park. No fake promises, no marketing gimmicks, just a product to deal with stubborn acne. Recommended- if you're not sensitive to this product.

This is the sequel to “Through” which I read a bit ago and gave a 3 star review. I was hoping that the author would clear up some of the oddities in his first book, but this one only made them stranger. People come and go, and there are characters from the first book, but I still couldn’t see the point of the book. The ending in particular baffled and irritated me. Remember, this is only my personal opinion, and if you read the book you may  come to an entirely different conclusion about it.
This is an extremely rugged and durable belt, which I wear almost constantly with my after work clothing. It's wide, but still fits into my pants belt loops. I can highly recommend it.

Holidays at our house include lots of people, so my wife needs quite a bit of cookware and things. This Lenox pan came just in the right time, and she was extremely pleased with it. She was particularly happy that it seems the pan was produced in the USA, which is unusual for many things today. We've had fresh homemade bread done in this pan and it was sensational!

I love candy, and this box just full of my chocolaty friends arrived just in time for Halloween. There were enough little snack sized pieces to give out to the kids, and enough left over for me to enjoy an excellent snack!

I often wonder where authors get the ideas for their books. This book in particular was one of that kind. It concerns an attorney who causes a horrific automobile crash that would kill or maim several people, including his young daughter. Before everything turns out badly, time appears to be stopped and two people give him the option of reversing what happened, but in return he must agree to kill random folks to save his daughter and the other in the accident. When he agrees, everything changes as if the accident never occurred. The plot goes on to detail how this man goes about attempting to not only save his daughter and the others, but also to find some way of getting free of his agreement. The story races along, particularly toward the end, where I stayed up way past my bedtime because I could not wait to discover how the book would end. There are some religious aspects to the plot, but you don’t necessarily have to have a belief system to enjoy the book. I can highly recommend it.

Once again we have the annual addition to the "Killing" series by Bill O'Reilly and his collaborator. This one concerns Ronald Reagan and the aftermath of the assassination attempt on him. As with the prior books, there is a biography that tells the reader how Reagan got to be where he was: the president. His Hollywood days revealed a man who was a big star and then declined, but it didn't stop his drinking and womanizing. His period of early political activity and his hatred for communism are quite detailed. Once he married Nancy, his life turned around, apparently mostly due to her influence. We are also given a biography of his would-be killer and how he came to be at the place where the shots were fired. It's a chilling part of the book, and shows the possibility of a neglect of his potential mental health issues, both by his parents and a psychiatrist. After the recovery from his bullet wound Reagan carried on his duties, but slowly and insidiously the strain on his body took its toll, and we are told of his slow but inexorable descent into Alzheimer's. That part is quite sad. As usual, I'm going to assume that there are those who haven't read the book and will praise it because of who the author is, just as there will be those who trash it because of its author. (I haven't read any of the reviews). That's unfortunate, because this book gives both sides of Reagan the man, being neither a hagiography nor a "gotcha" book. Read it for yourself and see what I  mean.

It’s always a pleasure for me to discover a new author, especially one who exhibits a talent for telling a good story in a quite readable fashion. This book, by a young (about 20) first time author, intrigued me when I read a blurb about it and also learned about the multi-talented young man who wrote it. The plot takes place in an (obviously) imagined world, where several nations exist side by side, but not in an especially friendly fashion. One of the nations, the Salt Empire, plots to defeat its neighbor and to do so has made a deal with a noble from that other nation. Into this thicket travel a boy in his mid teens and his younger brother. They are sent to stay with their uncle by their mother to escape the destruction of their home. Unknowingly, their mother has sent them to live with the very noble plotting to destroy his own country for personal gain. The two boys discover their uncle’s plan, and also learn that he is engaged in the summoning of a powerful force that will assist him in his plot. The younger of the two boys begins to try to learn how to acquire magic of his own, to help to thwart the uncle’s plans. The older brother, who has no particular talent except the ability to clearly understand what happens around him, meets and becomes entranced by a girl of about his own age living in the town of the title of the book. There is a lot of action., some deaths, and a whirlwind story line that races along like a runaway freight train. The author has an unusual insight into the human condition for one of his age, and his writing at times becomes almost lyrical. The book ends in what seems to be the middle of the story, but that only assumes that the author has already planned a sequel. I, for one, look forward very much to reading the next installment.

This very well written book tells of a world order collapsed, with few regular survivors, but quite a bit of zombie-like flesh eating former people (the “hungries”). It opens in a secure location where a team of researchers is searching for a potential cure for the “hungry” syndrome. Unfortunately, to do this they must obtain live children only partially infected with the virus, and dissect them. Not a fantastic way to get a solution! The main protagonist is a young girl who, initially, does not know that she is an infected person, and subject to turning into a hungry at the smell of human flesh. Before this happens, the base is overrun and most inhabitants are killed. The girl escapes with her female teacher, a female researcher, and two military guards from the base. To potentially save themselves, they must travel quite a way to a place called Beacon, which  seems to house other uninfected people. It is a very strange journey, fraught with many dangers, particularly from  the hungries, who can zone in on them because of the trail they leave of the meat essence. There is plenty of action, some quite gruesome scenes, and ghastly deaths before the book comes to an end. I found the ending very interesting, and it appears to be the appropriate one for a book of this type. Granted, this is not a book for everyone, but for those who can imagine a post Apocalyptic future, it’s one well worth reading.

“To Kill A Mockingbird” is one of my 11 most favorite books, so I undertook to read this “sequel” with trepidation, especially considering all of the uproar over the portrayal of Atticus Finch. Having finished it, I can say that I think the editor in the ‘50s who didn’t want to publish it had a valid point. Don’t get me wrong: the plot is interesting and the characters relatively well drawn. It just seems to me that some judicial rewriting could have made this a much better book, but ff course the author never undertook that task. Flashes of the excellent writing encountered in “Mockingbird” show up on many pages, and some of the humor reminded me of the other work. It just seems to me that the author set out a plot and then, not knowing quite how to end the book, just rushed into something that was rather unsatisfactory. I’m not even going to insert myself into the “Atticus Finch is a racist/bigot” dispute going on at this time. He is what he is, and a reader should take a character in the way an author presents him or her. Make what you want of him, that’s the man Harper Lee wrote into the story. All in all, it’s not an especially bad book, but it does pale in comparison to its companion book. I don’t say whether you should read it or not, that decision is up to you. For myself, I’m content that I did read it.

This is an extremely interesting book, at least through most of the plot. A man wakes up in an unknown place that contains unknown people and a whole host of strange occurrences. As the plot moves along he meets others in the same situation and finally comes to understand why he is where he is. I followed the plot faithfully, for it was well written and kept the attention of the reader, but the end of the book just seemed to have been tacked on to concluded the story and I just couldn’t connect it directly to the whole idea of the book. I know the auther thought that this would be self-explanatory, and it well may be, but I just didn’t like the denouement.

This is an extremely well written and exciting book, which gives the reader a new look into the life of Isaac Newton and his fascination with biblical prophecy.  A series of thefts of goods belonging to the famous scientist, mathematician and thinker occurs, and a London art recovery expert becomes involved in trying to solve the mystery and the reason behind the actions. There are several extremely gruesome murders, but they all serve to move the plot forward. The violence moves to London where, it appears, there may be a solution to the mystery, as revealed in convolutes writings by Newton. There are chases, gunfights, kidnapings and other types of mayhem until the art recoverer and an Italian female scientist set out on a  final journey to discover an object which appears to be the reason for everything that has happened. I don’t want to reveal any more of the plot, for it is an excellent one and keeps the reader’s attention throughout the book. Apparently this is the first book in a planned trilogy and I, for one, can hardly wait for the next installment!

Five years after the end of World War II, members of a wartime group called the “Magic Men” are being murdered one by one. A British police inspector who was a member of the group joins forces with another former member, a famous magician, to solve these murders. The plot was quite interesting, and it flowed quite well. The mystery was a good one, but about one third of the way through the book I had a feeling as to the identity of the killer, and it proved to be accurate. I believe that was just a lucky guess, for the author gives very few clues. This is a good beach book. It will give you sometthing well written to read, and you’ll enjoy the plot and the characters.

Ireland in the years shortly after the ministry of Saint Patrick was not necessarily a place in which it was easy to live. There were constantly warring kingdom’s, and the old druid religion still held sway despite some inroads by the Catholic church. This story concerns the theft of the bones of a saint that were taken from the altar where she was at rest. The theft promised to be drastic for the little community of nuns who worshiped there, in an order founded by Bridget. It was imperative that the bones be recovered, and that task was given to a nun who had been a Bard, which was a very respected position at that time, prior to becoming a nun. She works diligently, suspecting, and potentially eliminating, several suspects. Her search for the bones takes here many places throughout eastern Ireland, and many encounters with a wide variety of folks, both pagan and Catholic. It’s no secret that the bones are eventually found and returned to the chapel, but the journey to find them is the interesting, and very readable, part of the book. It appears that the author has left himself open to a sequel, and I am eagerly anticipating it, for I enjoyed this work very much, and can recommend it highly!

Quite a few years ago my wife and I were traveling north on Interstate 61 through the Shenandoah Valley. We stopped for breakfast at a restaurant in a historic building. Sitting down we happened to look up and noticed that several of the beams holding the ceiling were blackened. There was a plaque on the wall which said that the beams were burned by General Sheridan’s troops during his campaign in the valley. When I opened this book I immediately thought of that. Reading a new book by Ralph Peters is always a treat for me. I’ve gone thorough his Owen Parry series, and I just wish that he could continue that line. This book, of course, while fictionalized, is an excellent way to understand the Shenandoah Valley campaign waged by Sheridan against the troops of Confederate General Early. As usual, the story is divided among several different and distinct historical characters. It’s a compelling book, very difficult to put down once begun. As a history major I was fascinated how deftly Peters weaves conversations into the narrative. It’s almost as if he had been there and was taking notes! The reader feels a part of the story, and that’s always an indication that the writing is first rate, which this definitely is! I was afraid that this was going to be the last of a trilogy, but to my surprise and pleasure, in his afterward we learn that there will be at least one more book. I hope that one may not be the last, but we are getting close to the end of the Civil War.

I often went to Boston in the ‘90s and early ‘00s when my daughter was a student in college and grad school there. One of the constants appeared to be the Big Dig, which didn’t appear as if it was ever going to be finished. In his new thriller Joseph Finder uses the Big Dig as a background to his extremely well written and exciting novel. The main character is a former magazine writer out of a job and living in the shabby confines of his family home. When work is going to be done on the house, he finds more than three million dollars in cash secreted in the walls. The obvious questions are :”Whose money is it” and “Why is it in the house”. That’s the beginning of a roller coaster ride of a book that just keeps on getting better and more exciting as it goes along. There are characters in the book that are quite well drawn, and they are believable in the context of the novel. The chapters are short enough that, if you like, you can read a few before bedtime. Of course, to me the book was so good that I almost couldn’t stop reading, and therefore lost quite a bit of sleep! Joseph Finder is one of my favorite authors, and his books always are entertaining and exciting. I can highly recommend this one.

Failure to capture Jack the Ripper has left people in London dissatisfied with their police, and they feel unsafe. Because of the problems pursuing the Ripper the police department has established a Murder Squad whose sole duty is to investigate and solve murders. Into this group comes a young man from Devon, and he arrives just as the body of one of the Murder Squad is discovered in a trunk left at a railway station. The aristocratic head of the squad, for reasons of his own, appoints this young fellow to head the investigation and capture the killer. Investigating is a tedious business, and a constable assists the detective in this “grunt work”. In the middle of the investigating another member of the Squad is murdered and the pressure on the police to solve the crimes amps up greatly. The plot moves along with a lot of gruesome details and action, until the satisfying end. This is the first book in a new series, and I am looking forward to reading the next two books, which I have already purchased.

This story takes place in Philadelphia in 1869, and, oddly enough, I purchased this book in that city. I had not heard of it before, but the cover intrigued me so I purchased it, and am very glad that I did. It is a strange and quite well written book about mediums, both false and (possibly) real. A young reporter is given the task of reporting on these mediums, and it leads him to be involved, involuntarily, with a beautiful medium who is definitely a fake. There is a murder of a medium, and some very strange things happening throughout this book, which certainly kept my attention throughout. I hated for the book to end because it seems that the author (perhaps deliberately) left some plot lines open, so I hope that this is an indication that there will be another book about this young fellow and the beautiful medium.

Thomas De Quincey and his young daughter become involved in a series of murders that have an eerie similarity to ones that took place many years before, and that the famous writer composed a book concerning. He is suspected of possibly being the murderer himself, no matter how far-fetched the idea may be, so he sets out to solve the crimes and therefore clear his name.There is a lot of action and suspense involved from beginning to end, and the reader leaves the work satisfied that this is an extremely well written book. I understand there is a sequel of sorts, and I am looking forward to reading it.

I have always hated clipping my toenails with the small clippers that usually come in manicure sets. Invariably the clippers are difficult to grip and usually slip out of my hands. That's why I finally decided to order these clippers, and I am extremely happy that I did! This clipper is large (but easy to hold) and doesn't slip when I use it. In addition, it doesn't require much pressure, for it is extremely sharp and cuts with little effort. I also use it to clip my fingernails and it works equally well on them. I'm never going to go back to the old manicure set clippers. If you have problems with your small clippers, I can highly recommend this product!

I have always been a fan of musical theater and can listen for hours to my favorite songs from many of the shows. This album seems to have been put together (almost) for me, since it contains several of my favorite songs: Try To Remember from "The Fantasticks", You'll Never Walk Alone and If I Loved You from "Carousel", to name a few. Also it contains one of my all time favorites: Anthem from "Chess". After listening to this album I can add a new song to my list of favorites: Gold Can Turn To Sand from "Kristina". Josh Groban has a truly marvelous voice, and he uses it to its fullest on these songs. This is not an album to play at a normal sound, but should be cranked up to fill your room or your car with the excellence of the singing. I can only hope that Mr. Groban decides to do more albums with songs taken from shows, as I have many more favorites that I would love to hear him sing!

Ok, so there are quite a few books and websites out by vegan athletes. Guys like Rich Roll, Frank Medrano, Brendan Brazier and so on. This is an awesome trend, and has inspired even hardcore meat eaters like my former self to switch to a 100% plant based diet. But while they're incredibly inspirational and even have some recipes and sample days of eating (for that person of course) there has been a big gaping hole in terms of a simple how-to. They leave you hanging by basically leaving it to you to figure out how much of what to eat for your goals.Enter this excellent how-to. It gets right down to business. Simple formulas to determine how many cals to eat and what your macros should be. How to eat and lift to gain muscle with minimal fat gain. How to cut fat step by step, week by week to lower your bodyfat and get shredded. No vagueness, it's a manual. And of course everyone is different and responds differently. But that doesn't mean say try every approach. Marcella and Derek give you a proven method and mention how to experiment based on your results. And it's detailed in how to, not just 'If this doesn't work try reducing calories' it's 'if this doesn't work drop 200 more calories and measure again after a week. If that doesn't work add more of this type of cardio.'I love that it's light on supplements and heavy on real food. I love that it's a no shortcuts or gimmicks method. It's about doing it right for specific goals but also lifelong health. Highly, highly recommended.

I have 2 sets of these and my riding uses are:MTB: Half park riding, half XC. Crashes happen. ;)Cross bike: Gravel and road in sometimes slippery conditions, crashes happenI live in the PacNW, in the winter we ride but it's wet and muddy. These pedals perform very well for this. They don't collect much mud and are easy to clear. They're not the lightest but on the upside that means they fairly durable in crashes. I've crashed them in the dirt and the road, neither have ever caused a failure and I'm still using both sets. They're also cheap enough that if they do fail at some point you're not going to cry over replacement.

They're tire levers, they work and they're cheap. :)My old levels had all snapped so I got these. Timing was excellent because I flatted my cross bike on a trail ride. They performed well getting the tire off and having an extra in case one snaps is nice.

Awesome, awesome bag. Well constructed, rolls well, looks great and a TON of room. For my last trip I packed:Board and bindings.BootsGloves and gogglesSnowboard jacket and pantsMountain bike shoes and socksI held off putting a helmet in for fear of baggage handlers destroying it, but there was room.

Some reviews mention seat height. We got this for our 2 year old daughter (she's tall for her age) and even with the seat slammed it's JUST a bit big for her. Seat height from the ground to the low part of the saddle is 35cm or 13.77 inches if that helps others out there.The 'padding' for the stem/bars is a joke, it's basically decorative and offers no real protection. I'd recommend cutting a piece of packing foam out and putting the velcro cover over it.That aside, the bike is well built! When you look at a lot of the balance bikes available online and in stores you'll find the construction flimsy, especially the use of plastic wheels. That is no good, especially in a wet environment like the PacNW. This has real rubber wheels and tubes, the seat is well padded and the frame is solid. It's not ultra light, but IMO that isn't important for this level of riding. You should be able to get multiple sibling use handing it down.

I've been reading several books in the same vein lately, and this one stands out as one of the more practical to everyday life. The philosophy is excellent and Jay's passion for the subject is evident. If you're leaning towards this way of living her enthusiasm and easy method will likely spur you into action.I have one gripe with the book, and it deals with the very repetitive nature of the chapters on applying the rules to each room in the house. We already went over the system and a single example 'how to' would have ben fine. Specifics on each room could have been a page of bullet points instead of many pages saying basically the same thing as the chapters before. That, after all, is minimalist. :)That came off as more critical than maybe it deserves, because this is the best book on applied minimalism to the average American/Euro that I've read. I recommend it without a doubt!

I was very interested in this book as a way to be more environmentally conscious and thoughtful about what I and my family consume. The book is not preachy in tone at all which is nice, although Korst is clearly passionate and probably takes reducing waste a lot further than most will.I will say that I didn't get as much as I thought I would from it in terms of techniques, as a lot of the suggestions are already common practice where I live (curbside composting, reusable grocery stuff, cook your own stuff, etc...) With that said the mindset put forward is very helpful when it comes to even further reducing the amount of stuff you put in that gray colored trash can as opposed to the other two.Also, I think it's worth mentioning that backyard compost might not be a good idea in all areas even if you have the space. Korst says she had no real animal issues, try it in Tahoe and you'll have a bear and coyote party in your back yard every night. :)All told a good read with good practical and philosophical information. Thumbs up!

I was pretty surprised with these lenses. I got them for winter mountain biking in the Seattle area (overcast and dark of course) and for the cost they are extremely clear and provide a nice sharp picture of the trails. They are also fairly thick, not ultra flimsy like some replacement lenses can be. Very much recommend them.

Awesome grips! Easy to put on and to remove, great comfort without being overly poofy. I have them on my all mountain bike (Santa Cruz 5010) and on my SS XC bike. Once they're on, they're on and won't move. They handle crashes well.Not the lightest in the world compared to slip on styles (ESI chunky for instance) but if you're worried about that tiny weight difference you're either short course XC racing or you have an unhealthy obsession. :)Technically you're not supposed to use these with carbon bars, but the screws that hold the lock rings on are tiny and it's unlikely you could tighten them enough to damage anything before the teensy allen wrench would bend in half.

Super cheap but legit! These are very lightweight Ti skewers and the hardware is light as well. I have these on my cross bike and have already crashed once (pavement, not dirt!) and they help up fine despite being light as a feather. Very impressed, great value!

A very fun book to read, and tragic considering what happened to Kyle later. It's great to get a first person view and the mindset of a soldier in this way. I suspect there is a bit of seal ego involved with some of the bar fight and other stories. Regardless I really enjoyed this book.
I got this as a TV for my man cave to watch while I'm riding a spin bike for long periods of time. It performs great, especially considering the price!

I got these to replace my much loved Canteens. It's tough if you have a narrow head to find glasses that don't stick out a lot at the temples. These don't. The only downside is that they're almost too light. That's a good thing when you're wearing them, but if you push them up on your head when you go inside they have a tendency to fall back down. That's a super minor gripe though, these are excellent sunglasses. They also come in a polarized version if your on the water a lot.

I travel for work frequently and wanted some good headphones for the plane and hotel room. Not interested in active noise canceling, just over ear with good sound so I can listen to movies and music instead of engine noise and chatter. I was amazed even listening to music on my iphone, you can clearly pick out guitars, drums and the bass where before with earbuds it was just 'music' all muddled together.Works equally as well with movies. You can hear all the individual effects like bugs buzzing, footsteps crunching, etc... Very immersive.I'm not an audiophile so I'll describe pros/cons as best as I can:Sound pros :Highs are crisp but not harsh, mid is clearly defined, bass is boosted but not overwhelming.Sound cons: If you're looking for audiophile reference headphones the bass boost will rule these out.Product pros: Very light and comfortable, especially the earpieces. The detachable cables are well designed (rotating plug!). The construction and style is great and you definitely won't be mistaken for a trendy 'beats' wearing kid.Product cons: If there is any it's only that the carrying case is BIG and will take up a lot of bag space for a traveller. I'm grasping for a con here, these headphones are truly awesome. :)

Magnesium is supposed to help with sleep regulation and focus. I noticed neither, but I did notice the massive horse pill size of these, and the chalky/dusty flavor requiring you to have some water hand when you take it.

I actually got this to replace a gulfman solar atomic titanium, because it just flat out looks better. Nice and chunky but very wearable even if you're not big. The red/black looks awesome.Feature wise you've got 12 and 24 hour clock mode, a moon and tide graph, 2 stopwatches + countdown timer, multiple alarms and a travel/alternate timezone.All of this for me works great, and as a business traveller I love the easy timezone switch.I think the watch does have a few downsides.Con #1: The 'comfort' flaps actually made the band less comfortable for me, maybe they're good for larger wrists?
