Luckily they're removeable wit a few small screws.Con #2: No solar, atomic awesomeness! With all the timezone, tide, moon, etc.. stuff you think they'd make step up model with solar/atomic. Oh well.

As a mountain biker, runner and general outdoor guy I live in sunglasses. I got these to replace my oakley canteens which served me well for many years. I have difficulty finding sunglasses to fit me as I have a narrow face, and these are great as they aren't too wideAs some reviews have mentioned they are extremely light. This is great for extended wear. They stay on your face fine too, I've had a few crashes on the bike and they stayed put.The downside to the lightness i've noticed is that when I push them up to my scalp when I go inside they'll flop back down if I tilt my head forward. This has never been a thing with any other sunglasses I've owned. I've actually switched to wearing them on my shirt collar indoors so I won't lose them off my head.Other than that minor issue they're awesome. Look great, extremely clear and the polarization works well.

I was using lock on grips on an AL bar and switched to carbon. Someone gave me a tip to check these out and I'm so glad they did. They're very light, but I must say more comfy than standard rubber grips. Once they're on, they're *ON* and any worries about slippage because of the material is misplaced.That's actually the only real downside of these grips. They are extremely tight and difficult to put on and taking them off? Haha, I'll just cut and buy some new.FWIW I installed them using soapy water and some zip ties through the grip. Slipped them on, then pulled the zip ties out.

My one gripe isn't with the product at all, but with the instructions on the tub. They recommend 2-4 scoops for most occasions and for pre-workout 4-6 scoops. 50 mg of caffeine per scoop, if you don't want to do the math thats 200-300 mg of caffeine! :-0For reference, a 16oz can of blue monster energy drink is 140 mg. If you're doing 6 shots of this stuff you're slamming TWO cans of blue monster, and you serious? Watch your dosing and ignore the instructions. Otherwise an excellent product.I picked this up to use when I was trying out intermittent fasting, as BCAA's are recommended in the morning and before fasted workouts. I started out taking two scoops with some zevia grape soda (double grape, awwwwwww yeah!) in the morning. I found it did indeed help with feeling full and giving energy throughout the morning. Caffeine comes from green tea and green coffee extract.Now that I'm done with IM, I've kept on using it. I do one scoop with water in the morning and one after lunch in a small blender bottle. It mixes well with just the blender bottle, no clumps. Extremely fine powder. Watch out if you mix with soda, as it will fizz like crazy! Taste is awesome if you like grape. I've stopped buying energy drinks because a single scoop isn't as much caffeine and other junk.

I really like the BB. Pressed in nicely to my Kona Raijin. The red ano looks great. The bearings themselves I'm a little suspicious of. Given that these are ceramic bearings I expected less resistance than steel. However there is some resistance when I spin the cranks pretty similar (or more?) to cheaper steel bearings.OTOH this isn't a super expensive product and I have been cranking along through a full PacNW season (we ride year round and it's muddy!) on a singlespeed with one service. Hard to complain about that so I give it 4 stars and a thumbs up!

If you're looking for an inexpensive pair of rings that are still quality, here you go! Good grip, strong and easy to use straps. I was actually able to 'mount' these without any drilling whatsoever in my basement. I simply looped them over a beam with a folded towel between the straps and the bean to avoid rubbing/wear.I've read some reviews of the straps not holding properly. If this is the case you did it wrong. RTFM. :)Although they're plastic mine have *NO* manufacturing stink or greasy feeling that I've gotten with other fitness equipment grips.I've been doing the typical non-gymnast workouts including support holds, dips, pullups, etc... None have caused any equipment issues. Don't hesitate to buy these!

I have this nato strap for a seiko diver that I was hoping to give some life after it sat in a box since I bought a similar style but nicer omega. Figured I'd wear it as a more casual watch. Well, the idea was solid and this strap is of good quality. I just could never get the right balance between too tight or too loose. If the holes were a little closer together it wouldn't be an issue.

I got this as a phone holder for my Jeep. Perfect positioning either for sound system, GPS or even a cheap dash cam in a pinch. Obviously for recording it won't be super steady as it isn't a stabilizing mount nor is it designed to be. But it's a nice bonus.Grips the phone very firmly and releases easily. I'm very pleased with it so far.

First I want to say that I'm a fan of Tim Ferriss' ideas in general. His original book inspired me to go off the beaten path and start working remote, living more the lifestyle I wanted. I'm also a fitness geek and enjoyed the 4 hour body even though I differ on some things with his philosophy. So it was with some excitement that I ordered this new tome.I was a little disappointed to discover how disjointed the book is. I really enjoyed the snippet about learning languages and how that fed into 'meta learning' although the actual method was a little thin. This could be Tim not wanting to give away some secret sauce he'll use for a future book, or it could just be he didn't have time to flesh the idea out in more detail since he had to get back to writing the rest. I googled for more and found that this chapter is little more than a slightly expanded version of one of his blog posts, and I suspect many of the sidetracks the book takes are the same.The survival school part is also a little funny. Tim shows his 'city boy' colors, talking about various boy scout level outdoor skills as if he just discovered fire.With those downsides out of the way, if you can forgive the ADD writing style there are a lot of gems to be found here, particularly how to build a proper kitchen for not a lot of money (or a lot if you want), how to make easy versions of restaurant style dishes and how to keep them relatively healthy as well.As I wrote this review I started out giving it 3 stars, but by the time I'd typed to..... here, I've gone back and given it 4. It really is good if you read it as even the author suggests. In chunks and on the areas that interest you at the time.

Fits the 4S perfectly and is very thin. Just enough to offer some protection without making your phone gigantic. It is very secure, no worries about the phone sliding around. The rubberized matte finish is very durable and looks great! All this, and it's cheap too! Very satisfied.

Finally, a jersey that fits true to size. At least for me, I'm not fat but I'm not tiny like a pro cyclist. A lot of jerseys are either 'race fit' and wear super tight if you're not 125 lbs or 'club fit', meaning made for chunky recreational riders. This seems to be a bit in between, so it won't flap around on a fast downhill but it won't be ridiculously tight for casual rides. For reference I ordered a large and I'm 5'11" 165 lbs.Color is a nice bright red. Cut shorter in front to not bunch up, and the rear pouches are well made. Hard to find any real fault with the jersey, buy away!

A rare item that delivers on all areas.Fit: The phone snaps in TIGHT. No wiggling occurs. All controls are uncovered and useable.Style: The matt black looks awesome and the case is very thin. If you hate a bulky case like I do this is your product.Protection: It's durable and protects from scratches. It's not going to survive a major fall but I'm not a big phone dropper.Price: It's dirt cheap, buy 5! ;)I've extremely pleased with this case, excellent bang for the buck.

It's always a little tricky ordering something online where fit is vitally important. However I'm very pleased in this case with the results.Fit: True to size, snug as they're supposed to be but not excessively so.Padding: I put in HOURS on the bike and these have awesome placement, just enough padding and no chafe.We'll see how they hold up durability wise, but everything else is awesome.

You might be a little put off by the price of this sleeve vs others. However, if you're reading reviews looking to find out if it's worth the money I can tell you that it is. It's very well made, strong quality stitching. The cold packs are easy to use, easy to cut and position to ice the right area. I'm using it for IT band rehab and it seems to be helping reduce the inflammation.It also comes with an insulated pack if you're going to be throwing the ice packs in your car to head out for a run or ride. That's a nice touch.Well worth the $$ if you want a 'premium' compression sleeve with the ability to add ice at will.

This book 'changed my life' so I wanted to throw in my two cents to the review pool. I went from being a fairly typical corporate 9-5er to the top of my field and working from home (actually working from anywhere, sometimes I work from the ski slopes), setting my own schedule, financially well off, etc.. And this book was the catalyst. Note that I said catalyst. I think that many of the more negative reviews get hung up on the book not being some kind of step by step blueprint to fame and fortune. It's about mindset and kicking off the idea in your head that will get you where you want to be. Sure there are some specific tips which may or may not work in your situation. Duh, there has never been a successful person who didn't work from their own unique situation and who didn't overcome their own unique hurdles. I don't think the book tells you that you won't have to do some hard work (especially up front) to get rolling either.For me there are 3 big take home points:#1-Defining what kind of lifestyle *YOU* want in a concrete way, writing out a plan and what it will cost to get there.#2-Thinking creatively of ways to free up your time and energy. You can then use that time an energy to execute your plan *AND* leave plenty for play time.#3-Use technology and cheap professional services as 'multipliers'. One person can do X, one person with a computer and overseas help can do x5, x10, etc...
I would prefer labels that peel off more easily. These really stick tightly and leave a mess behind.

The Breville BBM800XL (hereafter called "the 800") is an elegant bread maker. It has good looks for sure. Mine arrived with no cosmetic defects and was well packed to survive the journey. The brushed steel housing is a bit thin and flexes with just a little pressure. I would think for the price it could be a bit more substantial but that's just my opinion.  I have other Breville appliances and this machine is a nice match.I have been baking bread the old fashioned way for at least 40 years. Although the old way is still best, a bread maker is often a better alternative for me than turning on the oven and heating the entire kitchen on a summer's day.I would like to compare the 800 to the Zojirushi BB-PAC20 (hereafter called "the Zo"). These are not the only bread machines in town, but I do have experience with both. I think people looking for a high end machine would like a comparison.This Zo is a bit heavier. It feels more solid than the 800. The Zo sits lower and is a bit wider. The 800 can wander around while it kneads. This can be a disaster if you are not prepared for it. I found that if I use a damp rag and wipe the feet clean as well as the counter top beneath it that it will stay firmly in place. Things should be clean in the kitchen anyway, right?My 800 worked fine right out of the box. My first two Zo's were duds. Briefly, there was a bad noise problem with two units. The third one works properly. Thanks to Amazon for helping with this.I suppose the main question to answer is how well do these two machines bake bread? I think the Zo is the best performer. Bread from the Zo is evenly browned and well formed.  The Zo has a heavier bread pan than the 800. The 800's loaf is a bit dark on the bottom when set for "medium" crust. It turns out as medium at the top and dark, but not burned, on the bottom. The Zo's two-pound loaf is of "normal" dimensions and fits my bread slicer. The 800 is a wider loaf about 5-1/2" inches wide. The Zo is a bit short of 5 inches wide. The Zo can make a tall 2-pound loaf, though, whose slices do not really fit a normal toaster. They stick out an inch in my Breville toaster. So those are a job for a toaster oven to toast.After using the 800 a few times, I found there to be absolutely no problem with keeping the folding paddle clean. When the pan cools I fill it with warm water and a drop of detergent. A half hour later the paddle is easy to remove from the pan. (I do the same soaking routine with the Zo.) I use a brush to scrub out the paddle, rinse, and that's that. I wish the Zo had a substantial paddle like this. With care, this paddle should definitely last and not wear out around the shaft like the the Zo's paddles.I believe that if the paddle is ever put away without a thorough cleaning the dough inside the slot will harden and cause a problem. So once again, just keep it clean as you should be doing anyway.The 800 is not a quiet machine. The pan is only held down by gravity where the Zo locks into place. While kneading the 800 emits slamming sounds. Since it only has one relatively large paddle, the dough ball tends to get slammed around. It is louder than a properly working Zo. This was disappointing since so many reviews said the machine was quiet. The Zo tends to keep the dough more in place while it kneads because it has two paddles. On the other hand, one defective Zo I had was the noisiest bread maker I'd ever heard and I returned it.It is tricky to remove the hot pan from the 800. It has only a flimsy thin wire handle that flops from one side to the other when you try to grasp it with a pot holder. This handle is about as thick as coat hanger wire. It doesn't latch in a straight up position. It is really hard to get a pot holder or mitt onto it when it is lying down flat in a hot machine. I use tongs to assist in getting the handle up a bit so I can grab it. Even then, I always manage to burn myself. True, the lid could be left open for a long while and let the thing cool first. However, I like to remove the bread from the machine when it's done and not let it soak in the heat. The Zo has two substantial handles which make it supremely easy to remove the pan. Just rock it toward you so it unlatches and then pull it out of the machine. No drama at all.The 800 control panel puts the Zo to shame. It is head and shoulders above the Zo. It is easy to see the settings. It works differently from the minimalist panel on the Zo, but not in a bad way. I find it easy to operate. I think it is the best feature of the 800.The 800 has an excellent interior light. Too bad that most of the time the viewing window is obscured by condensation so that you would have to lift the lid to wipe it clear to see. That kind of limits the usefulness of the light since you've got the lid open.The Zo pauses automatically whenever the lid is lifted and restarts automatically when the lid is closed. The 800 does not care if the lid is open. I just keeps on chugging or baking away. If you want to pause the 800 you push a button. Tie score on that one, I'd say.The dispenser works but I don't use it. You will hear it noisily pop open near the end of the first knead cycle whether you are using it or not. The Zo has no dispenser.The 800 emits beeps that are inaudible to me. The frequency is too high for my old ears. The Zo has lower pitched beeps that I can hear if I am in the same room with it.The 800 has handy posts at the back to allow wrapping the power cord neatly out of the way. The Zo does not  have any kind of cord management.Both machines have delay start. The feature is nicest on the Zo where you have to do no head math at all to know when the delayed start bread will be ready. The 800 lets you set the amount of delay and it is up to you to figure out at what time your bread will be ready.The 800 gets much too hot on the outside while baking. If you should touch it you will quickly pull your hand away in pain. Strangely, the lower 3 or 4 inches of the skirt stay cool so you can safely grasp the machine and take it to another place after baking. The top is still very hot so care is still needed. The Zo seems better insulated, keeping the heat inside. The Zo only feels hot if you touch the view window. (Trust me, it's hot!)The Zo comes with a colorful recipe book with large type. I like it by far over the smallish monochrome book that comes with the 800. I especially like that it describes exactly what each program (Zo calls them "courses") does and spells out the length of each cycle and its steps by using a little graph for every group of recipes. Very handy. The 800 pretty much omits this type of information. It does explain the limits of the custom programs but you don't really get to know the workings of each program. The 800 has a much wider customization range than the Zo. This feature may be very important to some. I am OK with the limited variations available on the Zo.The 800 is a nice machine but I do favor the Zo. I like the even baking of the Zo and I like the more normal size of the loaf. I like that the Zo has two paddles. I can only opine that I think it mixes better. It takes the 800 quite a while to bring the dough together while kneading. The Zo is more thorough, quiet, and faster. Overall, I see no real problem with either machine in this regard. I do think the 800 has to work a lot harder than the Zo to mix things up effectively with only one paddle and perhaps that is why it is noisier.As I've said I have other Breville appliances. I have found their customer service to be helpful and genuinely concerned when I've laid a problem at their feet. Zo, on the other hand, has a somewhat arrogant and off-putting tone in their response to questions. Zo also seems to have terrible quality control. It took me 3 tries to get a machine that works.You will not be disappointed if you buy the 800. The paddles are really not a problem if you care for them. I don't know why they are an obsessive target of condemnation in the reviews. It bakes good bread and it is very versatile. As I've said I happen to prefer the Zo by just a little bit. It mixes and bakes a more attractive loaf. I must caution, though, that in my experience the likelihood of getting a defective Zo are high. Be prepared for disappointment if you order one. However, Amazon will make it right if you want to return it.How about for gift giving? Both are good choices but consider that the Zo comes with a nice booklet and an instructional DVD. If you are giving to a novice baker, this could be helpful. On the other hand, a Zo probably needs to be checked out before you give it as a gift or you may cause disappointment. It's sad that I can't say otherwise, but I had to return two already. For the least fuss, I'd say the 800 is the best  bet. It looks nice and is maybe less likely to be a lemon. As always, these are just my opinions. I don't consider myself biased either way, these opinions are borne from what I have experienced.I would rate the Zo at 3 stars. I give it only three stars because although it bakes great bread it caused me a lot of grief with poor quality. Had I not had quality problems with the Zo I would have given it a 5 star rating.Happy bread making!

I believe that Sensi is the smart alternative to more expensive Wi-Fi thermostats. It keeps the conditioned living space just as comfortable as the more expensive Honeywell and much better than the even more expensive Nest. Sensi has a sparse but effective display. No fancy colors or animation. A glance at it will tell you the status of your system. After the initial setup, just about all the important thermostat controls are in the app. I find that the internet connection is very reliable and reconnects quickly after an outage without user intervention. Since I connected the Sensi with a "C" wire I am able to have the display illuminated constantly. I have foregone that option because the light is a bit too bright for my taste and if I ever need the light I can simply press the button on the top of the Sensi.  I like that the app background is blue when cooling is on and red when heat is being called. I also like being able to set many temperature setpoints during the day. Mine are seldom more than a degree apart but the fine tuning this allows keeps my home comfortable. Despite it's relatively low price the Sensi does not feel cheap or flimsy. Sensi will send e-mail alerts for high and low temperature, high humidity, and loss of cooling or heating. The values are not adjustable but are sensibly chosen. An alert is sent for temp above 99F and below 45F. Also if the temp rises by 5 degrees when cooling or drops 5 degrees while heating. An alert is also sent if the humidity hits 78%. All that needs to be done is to enable e-mail alerts in the app. I miss the filter reminder but I am vigilant about filter cleanliness anyway so this is not a great loss to me.It's very understated appearance does not call attention to itself. I like the Sensi, I've had absolutely no trouble with it.

I purchased mine from a home improvement store. I had an emergency need for it and could not wait for shipping. Too bad for me as I would have saved many dollars buying it here on Amazon. I paid more but it works so well that I still feel good about the purchase.This thermostat does everything I wanted. My two primary concerns are that I want accurate and responsive temperature control and I want Wi-Fi access. I give this stat the highest rating for these functions. No complaints at all on those points as this stat delivers flawless performance. My home is so comfortable now. One more consideration I have is that I wanted a stat that had relays in it. It seems more and more thermostats are relying on solid state components in the switching that can open or short causing components to not run or run "forever." Such design is not acceptable to me considering the cost and importance of the equipment a thermostat governs. Surely relays can fail too, but I think that's a rare failure and I'm willing to take my chances along with millions of others.So many have reviewed this unit that I'll defer to all those many reviews and just mention a few things that I feel I can add that may be helpful to you should you install this device.The first thing is the outside temp/humidity obtained over the internet. If you are stuck at "waiting for update" for many hours simply delete your total connect account. You can immediately re-register with your same username and password. Yes, it's an annoyance but that makes the device update almost immediately. Even Honeywell does not seem to understand this and I've read lots of complaints from folks who have gone around and around with customer support for days and never got this resolved. Try the account deletion "trick." It worked for me. I believe this problem is caused when one first establishes the account and completes the thermostat installation. At that point the device receives a software update and at that point the connection to the temp/weather seems to go out the window.Another point I'd like to mention is setting the temperature differential. If the thermostat is not reading the indoor temp correctly be sure you have given it about an hour to settle down after first installing it. Also do make sure to caulk or fill with insulation the hole behind the stat where the wires emerge from the wall. There can be wicked temp differences from inside the wall to the living space so be sure to address that. Finally, if you do decide you must tweak the temp differential setting only do it one degree at a time and give the stat a half hour again to settle down. The reading usually does not update immediately. If you are not patient you will just be chasing the reading around and getting very annoyed and grumpy. Ask me how I know. If the stat reads low, adjust the difference to the plus side to increase it and do the inverse to decrease it.In conclusion I just want to say that Honeywell knows how to make thermostats and has been doing it a long long time. Compared against the expensive and unreliable (perhaps) newcomers I feel safe and comfortable with this thermostat.

Very strong and robust. These will easily hold up a hammock with your fattest uncle and his can of beer. I use these for my bird feeders. They are clearly designed to be used under much more stress than my bird feeders provide. They have not rusted at all after being outdoors for several weeks. Still bright and shiny as new.
A very nice file. Sharp and cuts well. The handle is a nice bonus and it has a hole for hanging.

I remember a thicker syrup from years ago. I used to love this stuff. It tasted like coffee and it was a nice alternative to chocolate syrup in milk. This syrup now is now a mildly coffee-flavored watery fluid. You have to use a lot to get a coffee flavor going and by then the drink is too sweet to enjoy. How disappointing. On the plus side this can be good for mixing with other things to add a bit of coffee flavor. It could even be good on ice cream if you are a real coffee junkie.

There are a lot of reviews here so I'll just state my main points and be gone.Nest was easy to install since I had a "C" wire. It does jut from the wall more than most thermostats I've seen. I have to be sure to maneuver around it as I walk through the hall where it is installed. The temperature display sometimes reads 5 degrees higher than actual. Then, on next glance, it will have dropped down 3 degrees or so. Eventually it will coast to the right temp over a few hours but you never know when it will go nuts again. That is not helping my power bill at all. I've tried insulating the wall behind it but that did not help. Temperature control for cooling is not good. If I set the A/C for 78 the unit powers on at 79 and turns off at 77. The temperature just never feels right and I feel uncomfortable most of the time. My Honeywell thermostat allowed a tighter band and even had a feature that would randomly kick on the fan to help even out the temp in the house. The difference in the "feel" of the properly conditioned living space is substantial and remarkable. Nest, with all its elegant fine points notwithstanding, is fundamentally a poor thermostat based on my experience living with it.Furthermore, I've decided that I will not trust my system to the Nest. Since installing, I've read too many reports of failures of the solid state switches on the base plate. Many claim their A/C compressors or heaters were run continually or even at the same time. There seems to be a problem with this, but Nest does not address it nor provide encouraging words in support of this design. I have decided I did not need to spend all this money to buy a problem. I'm going back to my Honeywell. It is also Wi-Fi but has actual relays to control the components and not tiny solid state switches. Relays are more reliable, I think, and failures won't necessarily damage my system.

I have no complaints about this cable. The colors are vibrant and easy to differentiate if your color vision is normal. The outer jacket is not form-fitting as the product illustration shows. It is just a typical jacket tube holding the wires. The wire is easy to cut. The jacket is easy to peel back. It has the appropriate markings for well-rated thermostat cable and should meet all codes. I find that the wires are what one would expect from copper wire. I see nothing to complain about regarding this wire. Good stuff.

For the price, I would have expected this fan to be a little more than it is. It is crudely painted and mine arrived with many scrapes and gouges in the paint from shipping. The paint chipped off down to shiny metal. The prominet "Air King" decal on the front shroud is not centered and portions of it are well outside the recess meant to hold it. The 6 bolts holding the rear fan guard to the motor are exasperatingly hard to get started and torque down to the fully seated position. There is no hope in tightening these with a screwdriver. I had to use a wrench on them. I believe the problem is the heavy coating of black paint on the threads. It would have been best if I'd run a tap to chase out the threads first but the manufacturer should have done that and not left it for me. I believe one reviewer suggested that but I neglected to heed the good advice. Snapping the fan guard together is another unpleasant experience. It is a very tight fit.  The instructions tell you to use a screwdriver and not bend the guard. I wish you good luck with that. A large screwdriver bends the shroud like a knife through butter. I ended up using a body shop trim removal tool because it applied a wider area of contact than prying with a screwdriver. The pedestal tube is crude, requiring a wrench to adjust the height while the very heavy fan assembly must be supported. A spring assist would be nice here. Even worse, it is a wobbly fit into the base and leans alarmingly unless the set screw is tightened. Adjusting the height is a two-person job if you value your spinal health. The knob that cinches the motor tilt seems barely adequate for the task. Trying to get the motor level is a trial and error method as the heavy motor sags when released from the grasp. Truly alarming force must be used on the knob to cinch the motor body in place. I could easily strip it while cranking it by hand. This is a poor design and you need to be cautious when tightening it. Further annoyances are that the instructions I received were a poor copy. The illustrations I needed to refer to were barely visible in some sections. Lucky for me I could turn a few pages to the foreign language instructions and see the illustration there. For some reason, a little bag of amber grease is packed with the motor however the instructions say nothing about it and the maintenance instructions say never to lubricate the machine.I've said a few negative things but there are also positives. The motor seems very rugged and powerful. It definitely feels like a powerful motor. I had no trouble with the oscillating mechanism and it seems strong judging by its visible components. The best positive thing is that the fan does move a great volume of air. Also the drone of this fan seems somewhat subdued and not as loud as I had expected. However, it does sound like a shop and is very audible but the sound is not annoying to me at all. I like the 3 speed selections and the ability to turn the oscillation on/off and change the amount of sweep with the use of a wrench.

I put this in my daughter's Subi. It's been working fine for 3 weeks now. How nice it would be if all cars had such an easy to replace blower. Fifteen minutes to install and fit was perfect. My daughter is so happy with her very quiet blower. I'd say this looks to have equal quality as the squealing original blower that it replaced. Great product.

I know from experience that Korky makes a fine flapper. I recently tried using these adjustable Korkys and they are not at all what one would think. I was hoping to prolong the tank draining into the bowl by adjusting this all the way down as the instructions state. What happens, though, is the valve does not stay open any longer than a "normal" Korky for a very simple reason. As the water level drops, the adjustable float can't float so the valve closes. This happens at the same point, perhaps even a bit earlier, than a normal Korky would close. On the plus side, it does work well for adjusting in the opposite direction by allowing the valve to close quite early. So if you are trying to save water by flushing with the least amount of water that does the job then working a bit with this valve should give you the least amount of water to flush. How little water usage you can get away with really depends on your toilet design so the adjustable feature may not be all that great for you but you still have basically an excellent flapper without the float.I'm still giving it 5 stars because it is still a great Korky flapper. The adjustable feature was lost on me, but might be what you want.

I try to buy the best tool I can afford when I have to buy one. This is the one I chose. It is said that 3 feet is all that is normally needed to clear a clog but I am glad that I got the 6 foot version. The first clog I worked on would not clear up with only 3 feet. It took the additional 3 feet to push the clog further down the line where it was sent on its merry way. I'm not a professional plumber but I would say that this tool seems to be to be heavy duty and made to do much more work than I may ever be able to give it. These are not so simple to use as they appear. You have to do a lot of cranking and pushing and tugging. The clog may take several attempts to clear even though you are able to run in the entire length.My only dissatisfaction is with the many sharp edges. You'll want to dress these down with a file or you'll cut yourself or snag your gloves.

It seems people like to review these zappers, but few, if any of them, report their geographic location. That makes it difficult to decide if this is right for you in your particular region. Let me say up front that I am in Houston. Where I live is heavily infested with mosquitoes. There is a duck pond a quarter mile away and the woods and soggy ground are rife with the biting buggers. Too bad none is attracted to this 80-Watt zapper.I use the Octenal, I have the zapper hanging from the first story eave 7 feet off the ground and horizontally 25 feet from my patio as instructed. At night, we zap an occasional moth or a fly or two. We get some mosquitoes but I think they simply blundered into the light. I leave the thing on all day and night and it does, essentially, nothing.So it looks to me that this is a great thing for you if it works in your area. Where I am, it is useless. I've read that Lurex is a better attractant, but neither Flowtron nor anybody seems to make it for this type of zapper. If it is so good, there should be a great market for it but where is it? One would think the manufacturer would be champing at the bit to make the product work on more varieties of bug. This makes me think this zapper is more snake oil than a solution for mosquitoes.

The item was used. It was packed upside-down in the box. The power cord was stuffed into the box. There was no instruction sheet. The power switch did not work and the thing is on all the time when plugged in. The fish do not move but the motor can be heard to be humming. There is a yellow wire nut wedged between the moving plastic fish and the tank wall. Basically, I was shipped somebody else's returned non-working junk.

I expected better performance based on the description. Both of the batteries I received will not charge to the rated capacity. After fully charging and being on float for a week the best one tops out at 80% capacity. The other one is at 60%. This is pretty poor performance for new batteries.

What happened to pencil sharpeners? Does anybody make one that really works these days?Honestly, I am willing to pay the price for a quality sharpener. By "quality" I am talking about a sharpener that keeps the lead centered and shuts off or at least quiets down when the pencil is sharp. I'd like it to handle more than just one diameter of pencil too, if that's not too much too ask.I have already tried and returned 3 sharpeners here at Amazon. All had glowing reviews. I am so very, very disappointed.When this sharpener arrived on my desk I was happy. It is hefty and it looks like it means business.I was also happy to see that it contained two helical cutter units which makes it a lot like the manual sharpener my folks had at our home 60 years ago and is still working great today. I pushed in a Ticonderoga #2 and stupidly let it grind it down about 3 inches before realizing that this thing was not going to stop grinding or signal that the pencil was sharp. Sure, I can pull the pencil out every second and look at the point but that's not very automatic is it? Besides it will be an off-center point anyway, so it really is hard for me to care. I demand a centered-point from my sharpener.You can just keep light pressure on the pencil and grind it all the way down to the eraser. The motor sound does not change. This sharpener is an incompetent thing that leaves a long length of wood on one side of the point. This is completely unacceptable. I had hoped that by having two cutter assemblies it would stay centered. It seems the mechanism is so poorly engineered it is no better than the single cutter sharpeners.This is solid hefty hunk of a terrible sharpener. Because it seems to be ruggedly built, it is nice to know I can possibly use it to grind hundreds of nice pencils to a lopsided point before it finally quits.I'll never know because I really hate this sharpener. I hate it not so much for the incompetent piece of you-know-what that it is, but mostly for the expectations I had that will not be met by this paper weight.I am returning this for a refund. It is awful and I am angry about it. I would like to toss it in my car and take it to UPS myself just to get it out of my house more quickly.

Defective from the start. Installed new fresh batteries and tried to sharpen the first pencil. Nothing happened. Apparently, the mechanism is jammed up tightly. I can't even turn the cutter with my fingers. I suppose they don't test these at the factory. I returned it for a refund.

A bit of an extravagance since the basic Snoot! kit comes with a plastic spray bottle. However, I don't like plastic and much prefer these glass bottles. They just seem a more appropriate container for the product to me.
Quite expensive but it works for me. I'll keep buying it.

Easy to apply so long as you use the cleaning wipe and follow up with a microfiber cloth. I have these on 3 cameras and this is as much protection as can be had while still having a usable screen. I put the one I'm reviewing here on a Sony RX100 III and it works well. This camera makes it very easy to apply as the screen can be swung away from the camera body a bit making it very easy to align the protector.Unfortunately, the first protector I tried was defective. Usually, when you place the protector on the screen it simply draws down on the screen and all bubbles are magically gone. This one time I was left with giant air bubbles and Newton rings. I was able to work out most of the greenish bubbles, one being the size of a US quarter but the Newton's rings remained. I suppose the adhesive was somehow defective. I have put these protectors on another Sony and a Nikon and no such problem.These are from China with HQ in Guangdong province. The glass itself is from Japan. Just saying for those who like to know where there purchases are sourced.

What can I say here? If you have need for this lowest profile driver I have ever found I don't see how you could not love this. The "cross point" heads are actually more of a Reed and Prince type and not truly Phillips. I would rather the standard head had more vertically angled sides so it would hold the slot better. Still, this tool does the job when nothing else can.

Works as expected. By reducing the amount of CO2 used per shot the velocity of each shot stays more consistent. A CO2 cartridge will give about 80 shots minimum in fair weather. This is the same valve that is used in the 2300S.While it is a bit of an extravagance, I do appreciate the benefits it offers so it is worth it to me.

The extender will not give you a stronger signal by "adding" to the base unit signal. If you are NOT experiencing signal drops or disconnects with your handsets, then save your money. Your phone must experience marginal signal strength to the base unit before it will take an alternative route through this extender.As an example, if you are getting a sufficient signal in a room but the strength is not so much as to turn on the ECO boost indicator, then this extender will not change that. Why? It's because your phone is still communicating sufficiently well directly with the base unit. The extender is out of the picture.Now, if you were to travel much farther from the base unit until the signal barely works, then connecting the extender will help from that point onward. This is why so many reviewers report success (because they have locations far from the base unit) and others say it does not help or does nothing. Most likely the latter group already have a usable connection to the base in all their locations so the extender never comes into play.
I used this product for one week. Two tablets in the morning and two in the afternoon as directed with lots of water. Apparently it works for some people, but not for me.

Forget all the hype. This is a toilet plunger that works the same as one you can buy for 5 bucks almost anywhere. I like the metal handle but that's about all I like about this.It does not seal well in the toilet. Each plunge shoots geysers of water in any direction. After a vigorous session of plunging it leaves black marks all around the toilet drain which must be scoured later. It may work better in some other toilets, but I have three that are identical and it works poorly in all of them.I had hoped that for the price that this would somehow be a better plunger than all the rest.

I am always having to straighten out this foot rest under my desk. What an annoyance. It does not stay put. 3M should provide a better method of securing this rest various flooring types. One would think that a company like 3M that manufactures so many products for sticking things together could have done better here. I believe I will hot glue some tack strips to the bottom of this so it will grab onto the rug instead of sliding.The adjustment range is too limited. As others have mentioned, the edges are hazardously sharp.For as much as this costs, I could have made a better one and I wish I had.

I frequently have to deal with o-rings smaller than a penny. This tool is handy for digging them out without scratching the metal groove, housing, whatever.This tool is not very well finished. It has some knife-sharp edges at the working ends that will slice into an o-ring. This is not a problem if you know you are putting in a new o-ring. But, if you are just removing an o-ring to inspect it you can damage it.I had to do some work on this tool to make it friendlier to o-rings. I used a small file to take down all the sharp edges and then I used fine wet-or-dry sandpaper for an all-over smoothing. Finally, I used a polishing wheel to bring the tool to the state that I wanted.So now I can work the tool around the groove and work the o-ring out without damage to rubber or metal. The tool is certainly strong enough for o-rings.The main point is that it will do the job. It should be better finished and I debated on whether to downgrade it for that. I decided to go with five stars since it is not that difficult to improve and the way it is probably is all that many people are wanting.

This is an excellent antiperspirant and deodorant. On those two features it scores big points.It stinks just like aftershave. If this is what the ad copy writers think is unscented they are wrong.I can smell this stuff for hours after I put it on.If you are bothered by fragrances in personal products then you want to avoid this product.

The first kit I received had a bound up 1/4-inch side so I had to send it back. I held off on writing a review because I felt this was just bad luck. After all, I have a complete set of GearWrench automotive wrenches and flex handles and have never had a problem.Well, the replacement set is also bad. The retaining clip for the 1/4-inch side is installed incorrectly. One end of the clip is protrudes about  1/8-inch into the socket well. No tools can be inserted on that side because they are blocked by the clip. I used an  awl to try and push the clip into place with moderate success. The clip is still bent from being installed wrong. I can insert tools now, but they tend to get stuck. I suppose that's better than having them be too loose.I expected to love this kit since none of my other GearWrench tools has ever been a problem. I think these sets I received are not typical, but this is what happened to me.
