Bought a pair of these to use with a 72" Faztek T-slot extrusion which I will use as a heavy duty cutting guide.  The clamps lock down very securely, with the handle on the rear of them adjusting the tension or clamping height.  The screw on the bottom of the clamps fits the T-slot on my guide quite well, and the clamps come with a plastic shim that sticks to the bottom of them (almost like a washer for the screw) to act as a bearing so that they slide easily in the slot.  Also included is a no-mar rubber pad to use with the clamp.  All in all, a very well thought out and well built clamp.As much as I love the clamps, I'm even more impressed with Kreg's customer support.  I discovered the no-mar rubber pads were also a perfect fit for some other locking clamps I own (which never came with pads), so I reached out to their customer support to find out where I could buy additional pads for my clamps.  Customer support was nice enough to mail me some of them at no charge!  I will definitely look at Kreg first anytime I need woodworking clamps, jigs, etc...

This is as much a review on Samsung's support as it is their Gear series of devices.  Short of it though is this - there are multiple things wrong with the watch, and they won't repair any of them under warranty unless I also pay them to fix the screen, which they are demanding $149 for even though it is clear there's no physical damage (the glass is delaminating from the LCD, but there's no chips, scratches, or cracks).~ 3 months:  Bluetooth starts getting flaky.  Have to periodically disconnect it and reconnect it from my phone or reboot it for it to find it again.~ 5 months:  The glass starts to delaminate from the LCD with no clear damage or cause - it isn't chipped, cracked, or scratched.  It began in one corner and started working its way around the edges.~ 7 months:  The Bluetooth dies completely and will not turn back on.  When I'd try to turn it back on in settings, it would pop up a "Processing" message, then turn back off.  So I factory reset the watch back to original settings.  After factory reset, the watch booted to an "Unknown error" screen and would boot no further.~ 8 months:  Watch stops charging, so now I can't even boot it back to the "Unknown error" screen to show anybody.  Fortunately I took a picture first.~ 10 months:  Finally get around to opening a ticket with Samsung and send the watch in for warranty service.  After they get it, I get an email telling me the repair price has changed from $0 to $149, with no explanation.  When I call in (since their website wasn't working), I'm told the "certified engineer" categorized the screen as physically damaged.  In addition, they refuse to fix any of the other issues with the watch unless I also pay them to fix the screen.Samsung has just sold me on either Motorola or Apple (the latter of which I never envisioned as possible, but since I regularly hear of awesome experiences with Apple support...).  Way to go Samsung!... As for the watch itself... Was functional, but clearly still a bit rough around the edges given wearable technology is still new.  In particular, the heart rate monitoring function never worked well.  It was finicky when I was sitting still, and absolutely untrustworthy if I was exercising.  While going up stairs it told me my pulse was in the 50's (I am usually closer to 75 when I'm resting...).  Similar experiences with it other times as well.While I it was a Gear 2 Neo specifically that I got, the heart rate monitoring is likely going to be similar to the others in the line, and of course the major issue - their support - is going to be consistent regardless of which watch you're looking at.

This review got rather long, so figured I'd list out a quick summary at the top:Pro's / Features* Extremely lightweight (under 3 lbs w/ head), and folds very small (about 12")* Comes with a fairly nice carrying bag - not padded, but heavy duty nylon.* Head locks quite tightly despite its small size - my D7100 with a 50-150mm/F2.8 or 18-200 fully extended are zero issue.* Head includes a separate knob for pan lock.* Leg sections also lock quite securely.* Legs can be set to three different angles to account for uneven terrain, get closer to the ground for macro work, etc...* Center column and one leg detach from the tripod and then connect to each other to make a monopod.* Center column reverses for low / macro photography.* Center column does have a hook to hang ballast.* Designed in the UK.Con's* Clamp requires less than one full turn of the knob to go from securely tightened to lifting the camera out of it with my Kirk Arca plate.  This can be a pro or a con depending on how you look at it.  However, it's also not true with their own plate (which requires about 1-1/4 turns to remove)* Not as stable as a larger, heavier tripod.  Partly that's a weight thing, but the long, telescoping center column and many leg sections are a major factor.* With 5 leg sections, it also takes a bit longer to setup than a 2 or 3 section tripod.* Ball stem not totally compatible with RRS / Sunwayfoto / Desmond / Neewer clamps (in no way unique there - plenty of others, like Giotto's or Manfrotto, also aren't).  You can attach them, but the land on the top of the stem is wider than the groove on the clamp.  Will have to machine the slot wider on my clamp.In all honesty, I think you'd be hard pressed to find a better travel tripod at this price point, or even close.  However, between the magnesium version (Vyv) and carbon fiber version (Rick), I'd lean towards the magnesium version.  It's stiffer, tested better for me (side-by-side less impact from vibration), less expensive, and only 2oz heavier.So, without further ado, onto the full review....------------------------------------------------------------------I love having a tripod with me for photos where I need that extra stability.  However, I don't love toting one around.  While I've got a Benro that is built like a tank that I got for a prior holiday, it also is about the size and weight of a tank.  As time has passed, I've found I don't carry it very often - it just isn't worth the trouble of lugging it around, and the most stable tripod in the world doesn't do any good if you leave it at home.When I recently needed to purchase a new tripod for taking macro photos, I decided to splurge on a carbon fiber version of the Vanguard Alta Pro, figuring the weight savings would allow it to double as a tripod for carrying around.  The reality though is that even in carbon fiber, most tripods just aren't right sized to carry as an every-day tripod or go hiking / backpacking with.  I decided to return the Vanguard, get an end-of-model-life Manfrotto 055 in aluminum, and use the savings (plus a bit more) to get a travel tripod.  To that end, I was initially looking at the Mefoto tripods, but the Backpacker model was only rated to 8 lbs (few tripods and heads perform well at their limits) and the Roadtrip model was neither as small folded as I wanted nor weighed less than the target weight I'd had in mind.Enter the 3LT Punks.  It was rated to a higher capacity than either Mefoto, folded as small as the Backpacker model, weighed under 3 lbs, and could be converted into a monopod (one more heavy item I could stop packing!).  It seemed almost too good to be true.  I'd never heard of 3 Legged Thing, but the limited reviews all seemed generally positive and it seemed a perfect fit for what I wanted, so I pulled the trigger, eventually buying both the magensium version (Vyv) and the carbon fiber version (Rick), to try head-to-head, after the latter went on sale for little more than the magnesium.I could not be happier.  It's literally half the size and weight of my Benro w/ a head on it.  Despite the low weight, everything still feels solid - the legs, center column, and ball head all lock securely, with the head also featuring a separate pan lock.It really is worth noting how securely the ball head locks for a head this size.  I have zero problem with it with my 50-150mm/F2.8 or my 18-200mm full extended, even at unusual angles.  I don't know that I'd trust it with its full rated capacity unless you were able to keep it level and the weight centered over the head, but for most reasonable loads it clamps quite securely (and if you were carrying a much bigger lens you could also carry a bigger tripod... this is a travel tripod after all).  I tested it against Sunwayfoto's FB-28 mini head, which is similar in size (just a tiny bit shorter), and the 3LT Airhed is an improvement over it in how tightly it will clamp.I also love the versatility of it.  The 3LT Punks is a touch short compared to its larger cousins, but it's still adequate for portraits, landscape photos, etc...  The center column is reversible, so in a pinch it can be used for macro photos or shots you want to take from a low perspective.  Unscrew the hook on the bottom of the center column to remove the column, unscrew the leg with the leg warmer / foam sleeve, and then screw the column and leg together - WALA! you now have a monopod (I love that I now don't have to choose between them when I'm packing!).That said, it does have some limitations, but there are certain things which one reasonably should expect in a tripod this size.  As mentioned above, its height is a bit limited.  At that height it also does not have quite the solid-as-a-boulder feel that my other tripods do (the Benro or Manfrotto).  Part of that is simply its lower weight, part of that is needing to extend the center column all the way, and part of that is the five leg sections - you'll generally get more stability from fewer leg sections (but then you'll also have a much less compact tripod).  However, you can hook your bag or some other ballast off the bottom of the center column for additional stability.  3LT also makes a stone bag that straps onto the legs.  Or, if you don't need the height, simply lower the center column or don't extend the legs so far.I also find the clamp on the head to be a bit less secure with my Kirk plate than I'd like.  While it's fine with the included plate, using my Kirk plate, once tightened securely (which it does do), a quarter turn of the knob allows the camera to slide, and an additional half turn (so less than a full turn in total) lets me lift the camera off the clamp.  Some people may honestly like that, as it's definitely quick to operate the knob - enough so that a lever clamp wouldn't be much benefit.  But I tend to be a bit paranoid, and without a separate button or lever safety (like my older non-Arca clamps) I prefer the security of having to turn the knob a bit more.  As a result, I decided to keep the head (which is fantastic for this size), but replace the clamp.Which also leads to my last minor quible with the tripod - the ball stem doesn't have the same land width as what has become common on many Arca clamps.  Sunwayfoto and Desmond (looks like Neewer as well but I can't confirm that) seem to have adopted the same cutout on the bottom of their clamps as RRS (and possibly others - haven't worked with some of the other premium clamps), which makes it easy to exchange clamps (and Sunwayfoto makes fairly quality stuff for a budget - I have not qualms with their clamps).  Unfortunately, the land on the top of the ball stem on the 3LT Airhed is not just differently sized, but it's wider than the groove on those clamps.  While you can attach them still, it never feels quite as solid, because it doesn't fit into the groove on the clamp.  In my case, I'm going to be machining the groove on one of my clamps a bit wider to fit this head more exactly.  Still, since it is sold as a package and includes the head and clamp, I can't judge the tripod too harshly for this.The company is also a pleasure to work with.  Prior to the purchase I was going back and forth between the magnesium and the carbon fiber version.  I wasn't worried about the difference in weight between the two (which is minimal), but wanted something that would endure the elements well and would be durable.  They responded quickly, and I appreciated their direct advice without anyone trying to upsell me into the carbon fiber version or some other model.  I also love that the product is designed and engineered in the UK (to be fair, there is a lot of decent stuff coming out of China nowadays, like Sunwayfoto, but I do still appreciate a product that's designed in the US or UK).Now... between the magnesium version and the carbon fiber version...They're very comparable in terms of size and features.  The heads appear identical.  There is a slight, but negligible difference in height.  Likewise, there is a slight, but negligible difference in weight (about 2oz - with the carbon fiber obviously being less).  In cold weather the carbon fiber will feel warmer as it transmits heat less easily.  The magnesium version theoretically should be more impact resistant, though if you dent a leg and can't telescope it, I'd say that's just as bad as cracking it, so I'm not sure how much benefit that really is.The real difference is that the magnesium version is much stiffer.  If I fully extend the legs and center column, hold the head in one hand, and then push on the center column, the carbon fiber version flexes considerably more - less force results in a greater deflection.  I don't have tools to measure that, but it is enough of a difference to easily observe.So I decided to test them head-to-head to see which was more vibration resistant.  I setup a test target (a steel ruler with 0.5mm divisions) on my door, then setup the tripods (one at a time) approximately 9 foot away.  Two legs were firmly on the floor, while the third leg I set on top of a Honeywell air filter running at high speed as a vibration source.  I then photographed the steel rule using a remote shutter release with my D7100 at ISO 100, 200mm, f/8, 4 second exposure, with image stabilization turned off.  I took 3 exposures, switched tripods, and then repeated the test, for a total of 6 exposures with each tripod, with a re-setup in between.After the first test was done, I repeated the test, but this time without the remote shutter release, the aperture opened up to f/5.6, ISO bumped up to 200, and the exposure shortened to 1 second.  Again, I took 3 exposures (but did not re-test - so 3 total exposures per tripod versus 6 with the other test), holding the camera as I depressed the shutter button.Consistently, the magnesium version of the tripod (Vyv) outperformed the carbon fiber version in both of these tests (Rick).  With the remote shutter release, for each trial the best 2 of 3 from the magnesium version outperformed the best 1 of the carbon fiber, and the worst of the magnesium was middle of the pack for the carbon fiber.  Likewise when the remote shutter release was not used.  Without having seen how much stiffer the magnesium version was side-by-side, I would not have expected that result, and even after seeing the extra rigidity, I thought perhaps the flex in the carbon fiber version would act like a spring to dampen the vibration.  At least in these tests though, that was not the case.To be fair, most people are unlikely to setup their tripods on top of an air filter, and I don't know how representative that is.  Most real world vibration sources are likely to have much longer moments.  In many cases they're also likely to be single impulses (such as a gust of wind or a nearby footfall).  However, I don't have a repeatable way to test something like that.  What I can say is that against something like a gust of wind, the improved stiffness of the magnesium version should help (as it did when I didn't use the remote shutter release - the extra stiffness resisted the shake of my hand), and against vibration coming through the legs, I think the test is valid even if the frequency is different.If I can, I will upload a couple photos from the test.  I'm confident I can on the Rick page, but since I previously reviewed the Vyv, I'm not sure I can add photos to it (if you're reading this from the Vyv page, check out Rick).Either tripod is still a great performer, and the mix of features at this size make them great for traveling.  Between the two, without some other reason to get the carbon fiber, I'd get the magnesium version, even if you find its carbon fiber brother on sale for little more.  The weight difference isn't significant, and the magnesium version is stiffer and tested better.In either case though, I think you'd be hard pressed to find a better travel tripod.  If you're looking for a portable tripod that is still stable and very versatile then take a serious look at the 3 Legged Thing Punks.

Bought this exact model vise at a hardware store chain.  Bottom was not machined flat - had a rocker to it which would have required additional effort to level to ensure holes would be drilled vertically.  You could set it down and rock it back and forth like an uneven table.  Even for an inexpensive vise that's unacceptable.  Promptly returned it.  Subsequently noticed many reviews at that hardware store's website noted the same issue.

Does not live up to its rated weight capacity.  With my Nikon D7100 and 18-200 lens (combined definitely less than 6.6 lbs), it is only able to support the camera when it is reasonably level or slightly elevated.  It struggles, but has thus far held it in portrait.  However, at other angles the weight of the camera pulls the ball down.  I have a Bogen / Manfrotto 3009 head that is rated at a more modest 4.5 lbs capacity, and it locks down the same gear quite tightly, even at unusual angles.That said... This is a very tiny ball head, so it is quite portable.  While the Bogen / Manfrotto 3009 is more secure, it is also considerably larger.  Used with a smaller camera or smaller lens the Giottos MH1104 should be plenty secure.  I haven't decided whether to return this head or not yet, but the main factor that might cause me to keep it would be the small size.  The angles where it isn't secure I'm unlikely to be shooting at, especially given this really is for tabletop use in my case.It's also otherwise well enough built.  Still... I can't give it 4 or 5 stars when it doesn't come close to its rated capacity.

I wanted to get a focusing rail for taking macro photos of a diamond I was examining for a potential engagement ring (I was buying it online and they had shipped it to me to check out for a week before making any final decisions).  Given I don't yet do a lot of macro photography otherwise though, I didn't want to spend a fortune on it.  At this price I wasn't sure what to expect, but also figured I couldn't go too far wrong with it either - limited downside at this price point.On the whole, everything is reasonable made and feels solid.  One knob tightens down to lock or unlock the rail while the other moves the rail forward and backward.  I use mine with a quick release plate on the bottom (to mount to the clamp on my normal head) and a clamp screwed down tight on the top.  With two of these you could conceivably have adjustment on both X and Y axis.That said, don't expect to make particularly fine sub-millimeter adjustments with this.  While it's theoretically possible, the teeth and gearing aren't really built for that sort of precision.  If you're using it vertically, you'll also need to hold the camera to keep it from moving when you loosen the lock screw to adjust it, and when you add the holding and multiple screws and such together, you'll probably be limited to precision of a couple millimeters.  For some purposes that will be fine, but for higher magnification close-up with very limited depth of field, it may be insufficient.In my case, I found it easier to simply hold the diamond in locking tweezers and move the object instead of the camera, although only part of that can be blamed on the rail (the other part is that it would have been difficult to find something so that I could position the stone at just the right angle to photograph the inclusions I wanted to note).Given the low price, I can feel comfortable giving it 4 stars for value, but I can't give it 5 stars with its limitations.  If you're looking to make precise adjustments keep looking.  If you want something inexpensive because you're either just getting started with macro or won't use it often, then it's worth considering if the limited precision is not a factor.If I decide to do more macro work, I think I'm going to get a small machinist's table (like a Proxxon KT 70) and mount an Arca rail on it.  With the table, rail, double clamps, hardware to mount it, etc... it will probably set me back $250 if I go that route.  However, it will be a lot more precise than this, but considerably less than two axis solutions from Kirk, RRS, or Novoflex.  If I do end up doing that, I'll update my review to note my results.

I have a couple camera chargers that have require a cord with an IEC C7 connector.  For travel though, I prefer to keep things as portable as possible, and that means eliminating as many cords as possible.  So I set out to find a direct plug-in adapter that had an IEC C7 in as flat a form factor as possible.  Initially I looked a straight models, but then I realized this form factor worked even better.  It was still just as flat when packed in a pouch with the chargers, but the right angle makes it so that my chargers lay flat against the wall when it is plugged in.  Works perfect for what I wanted.

The center column is reversible, so in a pinch it can be used for macro photos or shots you want to take from a low perspective.  Unscrew the hook on the bottom of the center column to remove the column, unscrew the leg with the leg warmer / foam sleeve, and then screw the column and leg together - WALA! you now have a monopod (I love that I now don't have to choose between them when I'm packing!).That said, it does have some limitations, but there are certain things which one reasonably should expect in a tripod this size.  As mentioned above, its height is a bit limited.  At that height it also does not have quite the solid-as-a-boulder feel that my other tripods do (the Benro or Manfrotto).  Part of that is simply its lower weight, part of that is needing to extend the center column all the way, and part of that is the five leg sections - you'll generally get more stability from fewer leg sections (but then you'll also have a much less compact tripod).  However, you can hook your bag or some other ballast off the bottom of the center column for additional stability.  3LT also makes a stone bag that straps onto the legs.  Or, if you don't need the height, simply lower the center column or don't extend the legs so far.I also find the clamp on the head to be a bit less secure with my Kirk plate than I'd like.  While it's fine with the included plate, using my Kirk plate, once tightened securely (which it does do), a quarter turn of the knob allows the camera to slide, and an additional half turn (so less than a full turn in total) lets me lift the camera off the clamp.  Some people may honestly like that, as it's definitely quick to operate the knob - enough so that a lever clamp wouldn't be much benefit.  But I tend to be a bit paranoid, and without a separate button or lever safety (like my older non-Arca clamps) I prefer the security of having to turn the knob a bit more.  As a result, I decided to keep the head (which is fantastic for this size), but replace the clamp.Which also leads to my last minor quible with the tripod - the ball stem doesn't have the same land width as what has become common on many Arca clamps.  Sunwayfoto and Desmond (looks like Neewer as well but I can't confirm that) seem to have adopted the same cutout on the bottom of their clamps as RRS (and possibly others - haven't worked with some of the other premium clamps), which makes it easy to exchange clamps (and Sunwayfoto makes fairly quality stuff for a budget - I have not qualms with their clamps).  Unfortunately, the land on the top of the ball stem on the 3LT Airhed is not just differently sized, but it's wider than the groove on those clamps.  While you can attach them still, it never feels quite as solid, because it doesn't fit into the groove on the clamp.  In my case, I'm going to be machining the groove on one of my clamps a bit wider to fit this head more exactly.  Still, since it is sold as a package and includes the head and clamp, I can't judge the tripod too harshly for this.The company is also a pleasure to work with.  Prior to the purchase I was going back and forth between the magnesium and the carbon fiber version.  I wasn't worried about the difference in weight between the two (which is minimal), but wanted something that would endure the elements well and would be durable.  They responded quickly, and I appreciated their direct advice without anyone trying to upsell me into the carbon fiber version or some other model.  I also love that the product is designed and engineered in the UK (to be fair, there is a lot of decent stuff coming out of China nowadays, like Sunwayfoto, but I do still appreciate a product that's designed in the US or UK).Now... between the magnesium version and the carbon fiber version...They're very comparable in terms of size and features.  The heads appear identical.  There is a slight, but negligible difference in height.  Likewise, there is a slight, but negligible difference in weight (about 2oz - with the carbon fiber obviously being less).  In cold weather the carbon fiber will feel warmer as it transmits heat less easily.  The magnesium version theoretically should be more impact resistant, though if you dent a leg and can't telescope it, I'd say that's just as bad as cracking it, so I'm not sure how much benefit that really is.The real difference is that the magnesium version is much stiffer.  If I fully extend the legs and center column, hold the head in one hand, and then push on the center column, the carbon fiber version flexes considerably more - less force results in a greater deflection.  I don't have tools to measure that, but it is enough of a difference to easily observe.So I decided to test them head-to-head to see which was more vibration resistant.  I setup a test target (a steel ruler with 0.5mm divisions) on my door, then setup the tripods (one at a time) approximately 9 foot away.  Two legs were firmly on the floor, while the third leg I set on top of a Honeywell air filter running at high speed as a vibration source.  I then photographed the steel rule using a remote shutter release with my D7100 at ISO 100, 200mm, f/8, 4 second exposure, with image stabilization turned off.  I took 3 exposures, switched tripods, and then repeated the test, for a total of 6 exposures with each tripod, with a re-setup in between.After the first test was done, I repeated the test, but this time without the remote shutter release, the aperture opened up to f/5.6, ISO bumped up to 200, and the exposure shortened to 1 second.  Again, I took 3 exposures (but did not re-test - so 3 total exposures per tripod versus 6 with the other test), holding the camera as I depressed the shutter button.Consistently, the magnesium version of the tripod (Vyv) outperformed the carbon fiber version in both of these tests (Rick).  With the remote shutter release, for each trial the best 2 of 3 from the magnesium version outperformed the best 1 of the carbon fiber, and the worst of the magnesium was middle of the pack for the carbon fiber.  Likewise when the remote shutter release was not used.  Without having seen how much stiffer the magnesium version was side-by-side, I would not have expected that result, and even after seeing the extra rigidity, I thought perhaps the flex in the carbon fiber version would act like a spring to dampen the vibration.  At least in these tests though, that was not the case.To be fair, most people are unlikely to setup their tripods on top of an air filter, and I don't know how representative that is.  Most real world vibration sources are likely to have much longer moments.  In many cases they're also likely to be single impulses (such as a gust of wind or a nearby footfall).  However, I don't have a repeatable way to test something like that.  What I can say is that against something like a gust of wind, the improved stiffness of the magnesium version should help (as it did when I didn't use the remote shutter release - the extra stiffness resisted the shake of my hand), and against vibration coming through the legs, I think the test is valid even if the frequency is different.If I can, I will upload a couple photos from the test.  I'm confident I can on the Rick page, but since I previously reviewed the Vyv, I'm not sure I can add photos to it (if you're reading this from the Vyv page, check out Rick).Either tripod is still a great performer, and the mix of features at this size make them great for traveling.  Between the two, without some other reason to get the carbon fiber, I'd get the magnesium version, even if you find its carbon fiber brother on sale for little more.  The weight difference isn't significant, and the magnesium version is stiffer and tested better.In either case though, I think you'd be hard pressed to find a better travel tripod.  If you're looking for a portable tripod that is still stable and very versatile then take a serious look at the 3 Legged Thing Punks.

This is a great portable charger.  I wanted a charger that would fit easily into a camera bag or small pouch, with flip-down prongs, would charge AA and AAA batteries without taking excessively long, and had individual charging slots.  This was one of the few available models that fit all of those requirements, but I was initially a bit hesitant because I didn't recognize the brand and there weren't many reviews.  I am however happy to say that this charger works great and seems well made.  The compact size and folding prongs makes it easy to tuck into my camera bag or laptop bag when I travel.  After this purchase I would definitely consider other products from EasyAcc.

I bought these as well as a loupe to use while examining stones for an engagement ring.  My girlfriend wanted a rose cut diamond, which are a lot less common now, so I had to be open to stones which I might need to order online, and in many cases rose cut diamonds are not already certified.  However, I didn't want to make that significant of an investment without examining the stone myself in person, even though I have no formal training in the matter, and I wanted to have the right tools for the job.These tweezers worked very well - just like the ones that one would use at a jeweler.  You push the slider towards the prongs of the tweezer to lock its grip, and the opposite direction to loosen it.  The serrations on the end are actually more like little rounded teeth than the lines or ribs, and they offer a very secure grip - I've included a picture (the picture is of the fine version of the tweezers - I also purchased the medium size TWZ-101.76).  These were probably quite overkill for the limited use I'll put them to, but the quality can't be beat.

I bought these as well as a loupe to use while examining stones for an engagement ring.  My girlfriend wanted a rose cut diamond, which are a lot less common now, so I had to be open to stones which I might need to order online, and in many cases rose cut diamonds are not already certified.  However, I didn't want to make that significant of an investment without examining the stone myself in person, even though I have no formal training in the matter, and I wanted to have the right tools for the job.These tweezers worked very well - just like the ones that one would use at a jeweler.  You push the slider towards the prongs of the tweezer to lock its grip, and the opposite direction to loosen it.  The serrations on the end are actually more like little rounded teeth than the lines or ribs, and they offer a very secure grip - I've included a picture (the picture is of the fine version of the tweezers - TWZ-101.72 - I purchased both those and the medium size).  These were probably quite overkill for the limited use I'll put them to, but the quality can't be beat.

The Vanguard Alta Pro line is extremely versatile.  If you do any macro work, the tilting center column that can be positioned at just about any angle is a great idea.  While other horizontal column tripods can have their columns tilted at an angle other than flat by adjusting the other leg angles or lengths, the Vanguard makes it trivial to adjust exactly how you want it, without needing to reposition the tripod.  Tilting the column is as easy as extending it all the way, pushing a small button release on the bottom to pull it up past the point where the legs meet, and then sliding a lever to unlock the tilt clamp.  The design is definitely one of the more innovative ones out there.The tripod is also notably less expensive than its counterparts from more premium brands like Manfrotto, Induro, or Gitzo.  For less than the cost of the tripod alone from one of those manufacturers, the Vanguard includes a solid head and a bag (which admittedly may not be padded but at least it is included).  The quality of the tripod is nothing to sniff at though.  Nothing felt cheap or loose on it, and I had no issues with any of the releases or clamps.That said, while this is carbon fiber, and it is lightweight compared to similarly sized aluminum tripods (like the aluminum version of this tripod or the Manfrotto 055), it would still be a stretch to call it lightweight or portable.  The 4 leg sections help without really impacting stability, but if you're looking at carbon fiber with the idea of carrying it around, and you can sacrifice a bit of stability, then you might want to consider a backpacking tripod with legs that fold up over the head, such as the 3 Legged Thing Punks.In the end, I returned this.  I was able to pick up a Manfrotto 055XPROB in aluminum at the end of its model life (Manfrotto has a new version of the 055 out now) for significantly less than the Vanguard.  To be fair, the Manfrotto in question is MUCH heavier, doesn't collapse as small, the column only tilts to horizontal or vertical, and it didn't include a head (though I don't need one).  But the Vanguard was already bigger than I wanted to carry anyways (so the weight difference isn't a big deal), and I was able to use the money I saved to buy the previously mentioned 3 Legged Thing Punks Vyv, which folds to about 12" and weighs less than 3 lbs with the head.Still, if you want a solid tripod with great macro capabilities, then you can't go wrong with the Vanguard Alta Pro.  If money were no object, I would have kept it (instead of getting the cheaper aluminum Manfrotto) and the 3LT Punks.

Bought this for my girlfriend as a birthday present.  I'd initially purchased the Picnic at Ascot Cheshire basket.  However, after looking at the other pieces I wanted to include in it, I realized I needed a basket with a little bit more room.  Like the other basket, the Picnic Time basket is excellently crafted and quite attractive.  The basket is large (read the dimensions) and heavy, but if this is the ambiance you're going for, then this basket will fit the bill quite nicely.  Just don't expect to take it on a hike - if that's what you're looking for, there are several alternatives in backpack form.Compared to the basket from Picnic at Ascot Cheshire basket, the Picnic Time basket is a bit roomier inside and I prefer the Picnic Time's lid with the rim of the basket that seats inside of the lid when it closes.  That said, I did like the appearance of the wicker on the Picnic at Ascot Cheshire basket batter - but that's fairly subjective and a matter of preference.  Both pieces have silverware that's a bit substandard - which is the main reason for 4 stars instead of 5.  At this price they could include nicer looking flatware.  I also feel like a basket which will be toted around (even if not very far) would be better served by polycarbonate glasses and melamine plates.

Bought these and the Strahl soda glasses.  Like the soda glasses, these are easily the highest quality "plastic" glasses I've seen.  They are pricier than most, but polycarbonate is much tougher and resistant to impact than acrylic (which is what most plastic glassware is made of).  They're also finished excellently - I honestly think they're more attractive than some actual glass pieces.  In my case, I wanted glassware that I could trust wouldn't break in a picnic basket but would still look classy.  These fit the bill.  They're pricier than most, but you'd be hard pressed to find higher quality "plastic" glasses.

These are pricey for acrylic (or polycarbonate in this case - which is more expensive, but more durable) glasses, but there's a clear difference in quality compared to the less costly alternatives.  Bought these to go into a picnic set as I was worried about glass breaking, but wanted to get pieces that were still attractive.  These definitely are - easily the nicest looking "plastic" glassware I've seen.  Also, as noted above, polycarbonate is considerably tougher than acrylic with much better impact resistance.  You can certainly find less expensive plastic glassware, but I think you'd be hard pressed to find higher quality.

Bought this for my girlfriend for her birthday.  It was pricier than some of the competition, but the workmanship is excellent, and the basket is attractive.  It is a touch heavy, but a basket like this is more about the ambiance and feeling it lends to the picnic.  If you're trekking 2 miles over uneven terrain, this wouldn't be the basket you'd choose.  It is worth taking a close look at the stated dimensions though and evaluating if that's the size of basket you're looking for.  If you want something more portable, they make some picnic backpacks that might be a better fit.  For what we wanted though (a basket for Shakespeare in the park, botanic gardens, etc...) this is perfect.4 stars out of 5 though for the included pieces.  The silverware is ok, but at this price they could definitely do with pieces that look a little less cheap.  I considered replacing them with a different set.  While Picnic at Ascot is not alone in this, I also tend to feel like picnic baskets would be better suited with acrylic or polycarbonate stemware and melamine plates.  I believe they do go that route for their backpack based picnic sets.  Nothing was broken, but if you're going to tote this around (or in our case potentially strap it onto a rack on a bike) it seems like a more durable material might be a better choice.  I ended up replacing the plates and glassware as a result.

Great digital picture frame for the price (really for any price).  The image is clean, bright, and saturated.  The auto shut-off is handy, either to extend the life of the screen, or in a room like a bedroom where this would otherwise be way too bright (just don't put it someplace where rolling over in bed will turn it back on).Also appreciate it being able to do random order for the slideshow.  However, the random order playback is also where I've encountered two deficiencies.  It isn't like an MP3 player's shuffle - it picks the pictures at random, but doesn't ensure every picture is shown once before it repeats.  If you've got a couple hundred photos on it, you will notice it occasionally displaying the same photo as not long before.  It also doesn't remember the order of the displayed photos, so if one pops up that you want to point out to someone who missed it, hitting reverse doesn't pull it back up.Regardless, I am very satisfied with the frame.  I've used Pandigital frames previously, and I'm much happier with the Nix.

Bought these to go in a picnic basket I bought for my girlfriend for doing concerts and plays in the park.  Love the look provided by the real wax, and these were the perfect size (I found a tube they fit nicely inside and so they pack nicely into the basket).The flicker is nice as well, if a bit more subtle than I personally prefer (I know others like the more subtle flicker), and one of the six candles I received doesn't flicker.Also, some other brands are now doing candles with a fake wick, where the LED is a little lower inside of the candle, so that the candle looks more natural sitting out when not lit (the fake wick looks like a normal burned bit of wick in a regular candle).  These have the more common, and not as attractive, fake plastic flame - which looks fine when lit, but is not as nice if you're leaving these out on a table.Still, they're a good value, flicker nicely, and look good with the wax - I have no problem justifying 4 stars for them.

Bought these to replace the porcelain plates that came in a picnic basket I bought as a present for my girlfriend.  I wanted melamine plates that were 8" or smaller in diameter, and whose color and pattern would provide a nice contrast with the placemats and linens that I purchased for the basket.  These fit the bill, but I was initially a bit worried given mixed reviews for other French Bull plates.  However, I'm quite happy with them.The colors, while not quite as bright as the photo, are still reasonably saturated given these are melamine.  There was also a bit of a defect in the print of the pattern on one of the two plates I purchased (which almost like a thin line or run), but it's relatively small and not very objectionable.  Together those are sufficient for me to give the plates 4 stars instead of 5, especially given the price (two of these cost more than four of some other plates I purchased to go with them), but on the whole I'm happy with them, and she loves the splash of color and pattern they add to what I picked out (using them either as a standalone plate, or as a charger for some of the smaller plates I included with the basket).

I wasn't totally sure what to expect from the pictures given there's no decent high resolution photo to be had.  I had sort of expected something colorful and bright though.  The napkins I received feel thin, the colors are not as bright as I thought, etc...  Definitely not worth the $29 I paid for them, much less some of the higher prices from other sellers, and they are being returned.  While it is sometimes hard to find nice colorful napkins, I would avoid these unless you feel confident these are a perfect match for something you already own.

I suppose you get what you pay for.  While this is a serviceable tripod, compared to its more expensive brethren, it is definitely lacking.  Stability of the base does not compare to higher end Manfrotto, Giotto's, Benro, or others.  The head is functional, but there's no way I'd expect to put anywhere near the 15lbs on it that the description here states it is rated for (perhaps if you used it landscape only, with little elevation, and ensured the center of gravity was over the head) - it might hold it, but doesn't feel like it would be very secure.  The latches on the legs also feel cheap compared to the more expensive tripods I've worked with.That said... The tripod with head is less expensive than you'd pay for a decent head alone from a more expensive brand, and about a third of what you'd pay for another head and tripod.  If I were rating it purely for quality I'd give it 3 stars (and many of the cheaper tripods I'd give less), but taking value into account, I feel 4 stars is justified.  I can't justify 5 stars with its deficiencies though.

I bought two of these - one for my new style iPass and one for my girlfriend's old style iPass.  It snaps onto them securely and holds them tightly in place, but they can still be removed if need be.  One nice thing is that you don't have to remove the Velcro on the back as it doesn't interfere with the clip on this.  Only time will tell how long the suction cup will hold before it falls off (most suction cups just need a tiny bit of cleaning of the cup and glass to go back up as good as new though), but that still beats sticking the Velcro on the window (or, in my girlfriend's case, having the sun melt the adhesive so the Velcro falls off and leaves a sticky mess on the window).  Definitely believe these to be a better design than the holders that look more like cups for the iPass.

Bought this to use with one of the Planet Bike taillights to attach it to my Topeak rack.  Originally I had my taillight on the seatpost with the bracket it came with, but I ended up getting a seat pack and a trunk, so I needed something that would attach to the rack.  This works perfectly for that purpose.  The taillight clicks into it securely and comes out easily with a push of the tab.  Picture included (I also made a bracket to hold some reflectors attached to this).

Bought these to keep some hand sanitizer and sunscreen in my bike seat pack.  Ended up being a bit too large for that and bought smaller bottles.  Recently though, decided to try them again, but this time to keep some hand sanitizer and sunscreen in my glove box, bike trunk, carry-on bag (where I could also use them for shampoo or what-not), etc...  They worked perfectly for that and have not leaked at all.  Filling them is easy enough with a thin fluid, but to avoid making a mess (trying to pour into the bottle) or for thicker fluid try using a syringe.

My old bottle cage wouldn't hold larger bottles, like the Camelbak's I had.  These cages, while sturdy enough to hold the bottles securely, can be widened as needed by just bending the arms.  I now have one cage sized for my smaller bottle and one sized for my larger Camelbak.  The bottles still fit snuggly and don't feel like they're at any risk of coming out on their own.  Being all metal, even if it is aluminum, I have greater confidence in these than I do their plastic brethren, but they're still lightweight.

These are great badge holders and the seal is a nice touch.  I don't use these for badges though.  I use them to store thin things that I don't want to get wet in places where I need them to lay flat.  For example, in my wallet I keep some Advil, Sudafed, etc... in one of these - takes less room than carrying around a pill container.  In my bike seat pack, I use these to keep cash, alcohol wipes, bandaids, etc... without fear of them getting wet if it pours or I wipe out in water.

There's nothing like hanging out at the airport, watching your iPad's warning your battery is at 5% as you play your favorite game or surf the net using free wifi to banish the mind-numbing wait for your flight to board and every outlet in sight has a crowd huddled around them with their electronics tethered to them. I hate that. Well, with this little pack, not only will you be set to power up your iPad, and your cell phone, but your laptop (if your power cord is compatible, since it's made for HP) as well, all at the same time. Sweet.When I first plugged the battery into the charger, two lights lit up, indicating it had half a charge. There are four little lights total, each indicating 25%. One light=25% charge, Two lights=50%, Three lights=75% and Four=100%. It only took a few hours to fully charge the battery. Once it was finished, I tried connecting my iPad and cell phone to it. Both devices indicated they were charging and I let them stay tethered until they were fully charged. There was still 75% of the charge left, so not too shabby.The bag the battery comes in is super handy. It's great to shove all you necessary cables in it so everything is all nice and neat and ready for when you need it. It's not too heavy to tote around, about 2 1/2 lbs. This no doubt will come in handy at the airport, on a car trip or anywhere you find yourself with a drained battery and no power source to charge your device with. Just don't forget to charge the battery before you leave the house.

We're big fans of Gravity Falls at our house, so we were super excited to get The Legend of Gnome Gemulets 3DS game. This isn't an arcade game, which isn't my favorite type of game anyway. This is a quest game, with finding objects for Gruncle Stan through many of the familiar Gravity Falls areas such as the Mystery Shack and the Gravity Falls forest.What I like:-Very nice graphics-you can play as Dipper or Mabel-The music is mainly light and whimsical, keeping in line with the series-The dialogue is humorous, again keeping in line with the seriesWhat I don't like:-Too short, easy to win (about 3 hours)-No voice over dialogue from the much loved voice actors, all of the dialogue is in speech bubbles-The boss you must beat a through the game is a variation of the same creatureThis is a must have for Gravity Falls fans, but the regular consumer that doesn't follow the series might be disappointed, except for maybe a younger player. But because of all the written dialogue, the younger player needs to be a strong reader. Because this has such a strong underground type fan base, this game has the potential to turn into a collector's item. Because I adore Gravity Falls, I'll probably play it again and enjoy it just as much as the first time. This might night be the case for every player.

This movie has become a cult classic, and for good reason. The humor is raunchy at times, not in the least politically correct and totally hilarious. It never gets old, and unfortunately, many points of the movie are all too true. Idiocracy is my favorite movie to quote.

I don't like to cook, mainly because of all the cleaning up. Put this little scale really helps keep you from having to lug out different bowls, measuring cups and measuring spoons. When I got the scale I was surprised how compact and unobtrusive it was. It's just a small, round white base with a silicone top. After I downloaded the "Drop" app from iTunes, I chose a recipe and followed the steps. It was pretty easy. I chose to bake banana muffins. Each time I added an ingredient, it told me when to stop. No measuring. Nice. The scale and your phone/iPad are connected via Bluetooth and the scale tells you what ingredients to add as you go along. The fact that they're added by weight means you have less of a chance of messing up your recipe.You can also to make larger servings, and it readjusts for you. It even acts as a timer so you know when to pull those cookies out of the oven. That's pretty cool. Another nice feature is if you're not sure if you have enough of one ingredient (say flour), you can weigh the flour and rescale the entire recipe by tapping a button.There are three reasons I didn't give this five stars. One, it's not compatible with iPad 2 (boo hiss). I had to use my son's iPhone 5, which is difficult to read on such a small screen. I'll be using it when I get a new use iPad for Christmas. Second, I'm not an iSnob, so I also have a Galaxy Note.  The Drop Kitchen company should have considered giving the scale the ability to link up to Android phone/tablets as well. Third, it doesn't have a small screen to use as a regular scale. You have to view the measurement with an iPhone or iPad. Come on, Drop Kitchen Scale makers, for the money, there should be a little screen that allows non-tech Grandma to be able to use this scale in the kitchen when she wants to whip up a special treat for the grandkids. Also, for the cost, they should have thrown in a little matching iPad stand like they have on one of the Amazon pictures. But, I just use a wire book display I bought for like a buck at a library sale. It works great. BTW, the muffins came out awesome.

The ZAGG Limitless has replaced my Toshiba Satellite keyboard, which drives me crazy (I'm using it now). Although I love my little Toshiba laptop and it's really long battery life. But the keyboard is the pits. I suppose to save money, Toshiba designed their keyboard with very shallow keys. It's so hard to use  for anything other than typing in a few words in a search engine. The ZAGG paired up nicely and without any problems with both my Toshiba Windows Laptop and my Ipad 2. You can pair the keyboard with up to three devices.The keys are responsive, clicking appropriately and with enough depth so I don't have to keep rehitting keys to make them respond. The backlighting is very hand when the room is dim or the lights are out completely. The light shines from around the keys and through the actual characters, which are opaque. The one problem I had with the keyboard is not how the keyboard functions, but on the lack of instructions. The keyboard only came with a very simplistic quick start guide.There was nothing about how to charge the keyboard, how long it holds a charge and how to make the backlighting work. I couldn't even find anything on the ZAGG website.Well, I figured it out. First the keyboard needs a good charge. I discovered that once you plug the charger in, there is a small light on the upper right hand side that turns red for low charge and green for a full charge. Once it's charged properly, you push FN and < simultaneously to turn the backlight on/off/brighter/dimmer and FN and > to change the color. The variety of colors is kind of cool: white, blue, turquoise, green, yellow, red and purple. I like the turquoise color. It can, of course, be turned off completely to extend the battery. From what I've managed to find, the battery last 3 months. That's pretty impressive.

My son's iPhone 5 was no longer holding a charge for more than seven hours. I ordered this kit because of the high ratings and the warranty. The kit came quickly. The tools were all high quality, except for the suction cup. The suction cup was useless. Luckily, I had some inexpensive suction cups for Christmas window decorations. The spudger and the tweezers were indispensable and really helped get that pesky screen off. Also, youtube videos really helped with understanding what to do. The hardest parts were getting the screen off (spudger took care of that) and getting the battery that is doubled taped to the case (pry up with the tweezers). Once the entire process was complete, I charged the battery and it held a complete charge for fourteen hours with lots of game and video playing. Sucess.

This puzzle is heavily constructed with large puzzle pieces for small hands. I work with special needs students, and one boy in particular with autism loves puzzles. He jumped right in when I handed the box to him and seemed to enjoy the puzzle's challenging colors (the colors are repeated throughout the puzzle, making it slightly more difficult). It was challenging enough to be fun without too challenging to be frustrating. With 25 pieces, I'll have to move onto more difficult puzzles for him, but some of the other less able children enjoyed the puzzle with some help. The finished image appealed to both the boys and girls. The boys liked the construction scene, while the girls seemed to enjoy the animals driving the vehicles. And the rope on the box for carrying is an added bonus. Overall, a cute puzzle that appeals with some challenges for younger children due to the colors and patterns the reapeat.
These are the same Gravity Falls 2" Figure 6-Pack that sells for half the price. They just have big screw eye stuck in their heads.

I have a bathroom that is super cold in the winter. I usually use two inexpensive space heaters to heat the room when I shower (of course, I always keep the heaters far away from water sources). This usually takes 12-15 minutes. The Vornado heated the room in 7 minutes. Not too bad considering I didn't have to drag out two heaters.Features:-Carrying handle-Thermostat that is in the form of a dial-Power indicator button-High heat (1500 watts) /low heat button (750 watts)-Cord wrapping enclosure on the button (brilliant!)-Easy on/off button-Safety bottom that turns the heater off if it tips over. It works very well.The heater itself is very easy to use. There are not even any written words, just visual indicators to set things where you want it. Once the room reaches the level set, it cycles off and on to keep the ambient temperature at the correct setting. It's a bit pricey, but it heats a large room better than a space heater since it acts as an air circulator. I've bought $15 space heaters at least 3 times in the last 5 years after they died. So in the long run, this does a better job at keeping a whole room warm for a bit more in price. But, I'm sure it will last longer than the 5-year warranty, so it may actually be cheaper over an expanse of years. I have 3 Vornado Vortex fans that are still in excellent condition after daily use (My family all sleep with fans on) over 10 years. Vornado is always a solid choice.

Both my dogs adored this kibble. I mixed it with their regular food (which is high quality, no corn), and they pushed the other food around to get tho the Eukanuba nuggets. They had no digestive problems with the food and they get excited when I open the bag. So two paws up for Eukanuba Excel Adult Dog Food with Lamb. However, taste isn't the entire story.Dog Food Advisor gave it 3/5: The dashboard displays a dry matter protein reading of 26%, a fat level of 16% and estimated carbohydrates of about 51%. As a group, the brand features an average protein content of 26% and a mean fat level of 14%. Together, these figures suggest a carbohydrate content of 52% for the overall product line. And a fat-to-protein ratio of about 56%. Near-average protein. Below-average fat. And above-average carbs when compared to a typical dry dog food. Even when you consider the protein-boosting effect of the flax meal and brewers yeast, this looks like the profile of a kibble containing just a moderate amount of meat.The kibble is considered moderate in meat because although lamb is a quality item, raw lamb contains about 80% water. After cooking, most of that moisture is lost, reducing the meat content to just a fraction of its original weight.So, Eukanuba Excel might be palatable to my dogs, but it still doesn't beat Kirkland Brand that I usually feed them, which gets 4/5 stars on Dog Food Advisor.

These are very comfortable bras, but you should know their limitations.What I like:-Almost all seamless, with only stitching at the shoulders. Seams are evil as far as I'm concerned because they can itch like crazy.-Double thickness. This helps keep things up (within reason, this isn't a push up bra)-No wires. Yay! No wires to poke me. This of, of course, means the bra will ride up a bit and you won't have that extra support many woman want from wires. So, it's a personal preference.-Comfortable hooks in back. The large has 3 hooks, the medium has 2. They don't scratch or dig like the hooks on other bras I've worn.-Color. The flesh color works well under tshirts.-Soft and silky. No chaffing against sensitive skin.What I don't like:-Snug, They run small for their size.  They do stretch, but the 29 inch band on the large would probably be more comfortable on someone who wears a 36. I wear a 38 and the large was too snug for my tastes. The 27 inch band on the medium would probably fit someone who wears a 34.-No padding. I'm not a big fan of tons of padding, but I do want just a bit to keep nipples from screaming, "Look at me."Overall, I love these bras. But, you have to be aware of the fact that they run small, there is no padding and they are not going to give support to large busted women. I run B/C and I'm pretty comfortable with the support they give. The look they provide is a natural profile. Your girls are not going to be cupped and boosted like you're wearing a push up bra. But on the other hand, you won't feel like you're wearing a push up bra, which is a suffering trial I don't wish on any woman. These are so comfortable, you won't mind wearing one all day.

I've read some of Heather Brewer's work in the form of the Vladimir Chronicles. She's an accomplished writer with well paced novels. The Cemetery Boys leaves me with mixed emotions.What I liked: Atmosphere--the writing leans towards a Stephen King feel. There is no doubt Heather was looking for that "Children of the Corn" small town weirdness and she found it successfully. I can see King influences in the writing, and that's not a bad thing. The pacing went fairly well, the story pulled me in, but it was the atmosphere that Heather did a really outstanding job. She created a small creepy town with we-have-a-secret-from-outsiders feel that works very well in the horror genre.Cara and Stephen's relationship-it was sweet and I could relate to the two grasping onto each other in a world that has left them with emotional scars. Despite Stephen's insta-love (which really is more infatuation, and very much the teen way of doing things), the relationship progressed realistically and made for a believable connection.Their encounters were endearingly clumsy and awkward as one would expect with young love.What I didn't like: Stephen as a character- Stephen spent so much time whining about himself and his predicament without much thought for his suffering father that I had a hard time connecting with the character. Throughout the book he was contemptuous of everything and everyone (except his insta-love girlfriend, Cara). I really wished Stephen had been a little more empathetic to his father and mother. I realize teens can be resentful and hostile when displaced, but this is a book and not real life. The main character needs me to root for him, which means showing personality traits worth connecting with way before the end of the book. I actually felt more empathy and interest towards the dad and another character, Marcus.The presentation of the town-I wish Stephen had been more of  an interested observer in the ways of the small town people rather than a cynical, judgemental teen. This put the distrust and dislike of the town immediately on the table and didn't allow it to unfold bit by bit to add to the suspense. If the town's people had been more endearing, quirky and appearingly good-natured, it would have made for a more satisfying reveal. Think of the comedy Hot Fuzz. That reveal was so delightful because of the juxtaposed appearance of the villagers with the reality.The ending-I can't deny I was glued to the last 25 pages. I really wanting to see what happened. Unfortunately what promised to be an exciting, pulse-pounding, monster-revealing conclusion, ended up being nothing like my expectations. I was actually crushed at how let down I was by the ending. The one thing I, as a reader, was waiting for, never happened, instead I was given an anti-climatic, monster and a disappointing, no closure,  rushed ending. It was enough to consider giving the book three stars, but the atmospheric writing balanced it out to four.Overall, the book was a quick, enjoyable read. There was some cursing, but not gratuitously so and mild sexual scenes. Nothing that raised my eyebrows. The premise and the writing style had the potential to make for a wonderful story, unfortunately the execution just missed it. Well worth the read, just be aware the ending may leave you wanting.

These are great dish towels. Not only is the color (I have the wine colored ones) and pattern attractive in the kitchen, they do a great job wiping counters, cleaning glassware, washing windows, washing the car, cleaning eyeglasses, dusting and wiping spills. They are the size of a regular dish towel, which makes them even more versatile. And at about $2 a piece, that's a pretty good deal.Things to know:-from what I understand, the microfiber towels use static to collect dust and lint, so you are not supposed to use fabric softener or dryer sheets. And since they cling to other items in the dryer like a leeches, you may have to play hide and seek to find them all if you put them in a large load of laundry.-if they come in contact with items like wood shavings (thanks to my husband taking them into the garage) or leaves (thanks to my son taking one outside), it's a pain to get those things off. They don't just shake off like a regular towel, it's like little suckers just hold onto the wood shavings and the like and you have to pull them off by hand.

At less than $2.33 a piece, these hand soaps are a pretty good value. Each has a pump and is a little over 10 ounces. The soap lathers well enough, but the fragrance on your hands doesn't last incredibly long. The glycerine does leaves my hands feeling soft, so that's nice.Almond Extract- orange colored, mild, clean soapy smell reminiscent of Ivory soap, with a tiny hint of almond fragrance.Olive Oil- green colored, again, mild soapy smell, hints of olive oil fragrance that is stronger than the almond fragrance in the almond extract soap.Blueberry- lavender colored, a bit too candy smelling for me,no real blueberry fragrance, but overall not off putting.Cherry Blossom- light pink colored, most artificial smell out of the bunch, sort of cherry cough syrup smelling, most disappointing fragrance of the group.Cherry Pie- darker pink, lovely cherry fragrance, neither too heavy or light. They got this one right.Mango Ice Cream- pearl white, delicious, scrumptious mango fragrance with a light undertone of cream. The best out of the bunch. Mango Ice Cream could rival hand soap you get at Bath and Body Works.Overall these soaps do what they need to, clean your hands and leave them soft. Some fragrances are better than others. For a bit over $2 a piece, don't expect expensive smelling soaps like Yardley of London (which is about $6 for 8 oz on Amazon at the time of this review). This is a nice sample pack to try. It's good to know that the Mango Ice Cream soap sells as a bar soap and as a pack of 12, 10 oz bottles here on Amazon. The Mango Ice Cream soap would certainly be worth buying in quantity.

I've had some yellow spots on my large toe toenail. After trying many products, some of which I bought on Amazon, I saw little improvement in the color or thickness of the nail. I didn't have high hopes on Probelle, but much to my surprise, after a couple of weeks of using the Probelle product, the nail color almost looks normal, with the yellow fading. The nail thickness also doesn't seem to be increasing. I did file down the nail to allow the Probelle to absorb properly, so I'm sure that helps. If you use this product, I highly recommend you buy a pack of 24 emory boards and just toss each on after every use. They are fairly inexpensive, so it's no big deal. The Probelle liquid goes on pretty easily with a dropper. It takes about 10 min. to dry, and they you're good to go. There's no smell, it doesn't really feel greasy and the bottle is huge compared to the tiny 10 ounce bottles you get with other products.This is working so well, I might chuck the prescription bottle of medication that gets painted on and stick to the Probelle.*Update It didn't completely get rid of the fungus like I hoped, so I bought a Salon Edge Nail Light. Stuck my toes in it once a day for 5-30 min. depending on what I was doing on the computer. And all my nails grew back healthy and pink. I've worn sandals for months now that my nails look normal again.

This little bar packs a pretty good healthy punch in 140 calories. The bar itself resembles bird seed and frankly, if you're not the type who doesn't care for healthy little seeds and grains such as quinoa, millet, buckwheat, etc, then you may want to pass on this bar. But for those who like the taste of ancient grains, then you should like this bar. The bar only contains 7 grams of sugar, and is gluten free and non-GMO. The bar has a nice coffee flavor that, when combined with the grains and sweetness in the form of honey and dried cane syrup, makes a tasty little snack.The package states that all the ingredients you can see and pronounce. Well, I can't really see everything, like dried cane syrup, but i certainly recognize and can pronounce all the ingredients. I didn't really taste the caramel flavor, but it's not a deal breaker. the coffee taste is so pleasant, you forget you're missing the caramel.

This eye mask fits well and doesn't slide off like other masks. I really like the way the molded mask cups my face. It keeps out the light very well and is comfortable to wear. Make sure you read the description correctly. That's two plugs, not two masks. I totally skimmed the description and was expecting two masks (the picture threw me off). My fault. Still worth it.

I'm a fan of some mineral powder products, others not so much. Some seem to get into the lines of your face and just sit there, emphasizing age. Others (mainly eye shadows and blushes) do a pretty good job of lightly sitting on the skin, adding color without emphasizing the lines. Scott-Vincent's ended up being one of the later. Trying it as foundation was no good for me. The white powder added when you turn the dial (boy that took me a while to figure out) makes it too light for my complexion and trying to scoop up the darker powder without the white powder was just too much of a hassle. So, I mixed up the two colors and tried it as a finishing powder. This seemed to work fairly well. The powder went on smoothly, but at times the white powder left my face splotchy with white puffs, even when I mixed it well in the compact.  It think they should redo the powder colors so one is just a light cream color and not white.Overall the powder performed well, lasting as long as my usual $10 mineral finishing powder, so no complaints there. I only put it on once in the morning. I have dry skin, so my face doesn't require reapplying of powder since there is no shine and it doesn't wear away. I didn't notice my skin looking anymore youthful and unlined than usual, but I didn't use it as a foundation, so that might of made a difference. I didn't use the mask, either there wasn't one in my package or I missed it and threw it away. I wouldn't have used it anyway. It just seems plain silly and reminds me of a creepy skin mask from Silence of the Lambs. The brush is really nice and soft, two thumbs up for the brush. It is rather small and narrow, giving you more control I suppose. Overall this was a nice foundation/finishing powder, but the price, ouch. I'm on a teacher's salary. This was fun to try, but paying almost $80 for foundation just isn't going to happen in my household. Hello L'Oreal and Mary Kay foundations, good to see again.

To me some colognes are like garlic to a vampire--makes my nose burn, makes me sneeze, gives me a headache and sends me fleeing. Axe is one of the worst offenders. So when I sprayed this on my husband I was pleasantly surprised. The scent was lingering, yet subtle enough for me not to recoil. In fact it was pleasant enough for me to want to bury my nose into his neck (he found this amusing). The top notes are a woodsy botanical, without being too feminine and floral, The middle notes add a bit of spice without being too sharp and the base is a rich, deep, mellow fragrance with a touch of musk. But not enough musk to turn me off. I'm a fan of musk to a point and then it just starts to smell too much like a gamey ferret. Overall I thought this scent was a nice combination that worked well with my husband's chemistry. The bottle was a fair size for the price. I highly recommend it.

It's working, After  a week, I'm seeing some small little bits of green budding up. The area I put it in has daylight about four hours a day and then goes into shade. Before I put the seeds down, I raked the area of all debris, pulled up any dead grass that would block the way of the seeds hitting the soul, prepared the soul with a rolling spiky thing (not very technical, I know), put the grass seeds down with a spreader and then put some fertilized dirt on top. I also watered it a couple of times a day.The blue coloring in the seed was a nice feature, I was able to see where I was adding it and how thick each coating was.Now, I'm just waiting to see how strong the grass is. The last time I tried this the grass I bought popped up green and lovely with little effort. However, it was like chia seeds--sprouted anywhere you laid a seed, greened up nicely for about a week, grew thin and tall and all died when it was mowed. I think it was for a short term solution and was meant to grow quickly and hold up only as long as it took to sell your house or some such special event. Hopefully this will take hold and last through our blistering San Antonio summers.

I'm a DIY kind of person, including replacing toilets. When we put tile flooring in all our bathrooms we replaced the wax ring. This led to leaks. After replacing the wax ring with a thicker kind, the leaks seemed to stop. But after a few months the old problem came up again. Replacing wax rings just isn't as easy as it looks on youtube. I'm not sure if it was due to the tile creating an uneven floor or because part of the pipe was now slightly below the tile, but I guess I stink at replacing the wax seal ring on toilets. So, thinking maybe we needed an upgrade in toilets, we recently replaced our toilets with cool-looking modern, stream-lined toilets.The same leak happened again on one toilet. Sigh. This time I decided to go with the industrial-looking Perfect Seal. Success! It was very easy to install, met up with the pipe with no problem and no leaks. I had help, but only because I needed my husband to do the heavy lifting since the toilet is one piece. But really it was an easy installation. There are several videos on youtube to help you out and give you an idea of what to do. So that's always nice. I'm ordered two more to replace the other wax seals just to be safe.

To quote a Pysch episode, are you a fan of delicious flavor? Then buy this. I love smoked foods, but I have neither the time nor the skill to smoke like the professionals. I bought a Brinkman bullet smoker hoping it would give me the smokey food of my dreams. It was not to be. So, hoping to stop giving the local smoked meat restaurant wads of my cash, I continued my search. and it led me to the Oster Smoker Roaster. I received it last week within days of ordering (I have Prime). I bought a chicken and ribs, put water on the bottom of the pan, stuck both meats in (no rubs or anything) loaded the side cups with hickory chips, put it on the patio, set it at 220 and plugged it in (the cord is really short, so an orange extension cord is a must). Oh my gosh! Best ribs and chicken EVER! The chicken was succulent, falling off the bone and oh so smokey-flavored. The ribs were just as tender and the hickory flavor was spectacular. It took about 2 1/2 hours for both meats to be done. I added extra chips about half-way. Towards the end, I lowered the temp and let everything smoke another thirty minutes or so. I may never barbecue again.

My son's school has to have purple shorts as their PE uniform. They have no idea how hard it is to find mesh, boy's purple shorts at the start of the school year. Then Amazon to the rescue. Thankfully Amazon carries purple shorts.  My son wears a 10/ 12 and the mediums fit just right. They are not to thin, so his underwear doesn't show. I orders two so one set of uniforms will always be clean.

This set was a nice addition to my niece and nephew's other set of mega bloks and they seemed to enjoy using the table with all the blocks.What I like:-has a table that you build on-the table legs fold-table acts as storage-set is durable-interchangeable with other mega bloks-easy for little hands to manipulateWhat I don't like:-only one vehicle-the crane is non-working, so it doesn't do much of anything-a few more blocks would have been niceOverall it's a fun addition to other sets. I don't think this would be as much fun as a stand alone toy. You really need more blocks to get the most from this toy.

This comes in handy when you're crammed under the kitchen sink in a tight spot while replacing the stupid leaking faucet and trying to use a flashlight that points anywhere but where you need it. Unfortunatly I didn't have this light when I actually did replace the faucet, but now I can see how the potential is huge. I did, however, need to check for leaks on said replaced faucet and the streamlight worked wonderfully. It directed the light where I need it and shined bright enough to look for any leaks (none, thank goodness). Charging it was straight forward. Take the bottom cover off, push the little metal recharging thing sticking out into the provided ac wall adapter and plug the adapter in. You can also charge it with your computer via a usb prot, although I'm not sure if I'll ever use that feature. The bulb is LED and it is pretty bright on high (70 lumens). There is also a low setting (10 lumens). The battery life states 3.5 hour and 24 hours, respecively.. I haven't tested it since I use the light only on occasion. It is very light weight, so it doesn't weigh my hat down when wearing it. I'm not sure what the red light is for, but it works. Overall, a bit pricey, but it does the job.

This is not for every parent. Either they like these funny little dolls or they are offended by them. If you're like me and get a kick out of these "emo" dolls, then by all means get them for your kid.I hope they find them as adorable as I do. If there was a hip, modern day Tuesday Adams, this is what she would look like.Cleo de Nile and Howleen Wolf are of course, fashionably adorable. Cleo wears a cute, striped, one-shouldered dress with little ruffle on the sleeve and a purple necklace. Her platform shoes are gold, gladiator style, sandles. And like all the dolls, her arms and wrists are jointed so you can actually bend them (try that with Barbie). Howleen is rocking a mini-skirt outfit with bold colors and cat's claws on the blouse. She also sports a pink bracelet and pink wedge booties. Two dog ears sprout from her pink and blue cotton-candy colored hair, with one drooping at an adorable angle.The cafeteria features a lunch counter with decorative pink ooze and assorted foods to choose from. There is also a table and stools with decrotive spider webbing and claw feet. The table is coffin-shaped and the stools are pink spider webs. You gotta love the guillotine sandwhich chopper. It's such a fun and crazy addition. And the coffin trays! Oh my gosh, I almost didn't want to hand this over to my seven year-old niece. But once she saw it, it was a done deal. I couldn't pry it from her excited fingers. However, we did have a nice game of Monster High school lunch together.The only thing missing is the wacky green lunch lady on the box. I know she's not an actual doll, but wouldn't it be great if she was?

I wish I had one of these as a kid. This is like a some kind of cool spy watch that seems to do everything! My niece and nephew kept fighting over it and we had to start giving them alternating time limits. Even my twelve-year-old son became interested (even though he proclaimed it as a little kid toy) and had a turn playing with it. Although he thought it was pretty cool for a kid toy, he soon lost interest. But to be fair, his phone does just about everything the smartwatch does.What I like:-Touch screen that is intuitive for little ones-Takes pictures and video-Voice recorder w/ 5 fun voice changing modes-Sturdy and splash-proof-Analog and digital watch with 50 different faces (great for learning how to tell time)-Stopwatch, alarm clock and timer-Can put special effects on the pictures-Uploads pictures and video via USB-Can hold up to 800 pictures-Pictures are a nice universal jpeg (640X480)-You can download more cames from VTech-Recharges via USB cord-Charge lasts all day (varies depending on game and video usage)-Four games included (the time telling game seems to be the most useful)What I don't like:-A bit bulky.
