The final sequence of airs, nos. 8-13 in D major (tracks 19-24), is absolutely gorgeous from start to finish. The entire programme is beautiful in melody and texture, and Simpson's superb music is played with love, sensitivity and total conviction.The booklet is nicely illustrated and the notes are excellent. I hadn't heard the Chelys Consort of Viols until now, but I hope they will bring us plenty more music of this quality. I've only just finished reviewing another early-music disc and felt compelled to write something like 'I'd give it six stars if I could'. But now it seems I have to say the same again about this one, so it looks as if star inflation is looming! Early music fans are sure to be delighted with this music and, if you are, then I'd also recommend Christopher Simpson: The Seasons, The Monthes & other divisions of Time - 1.

This is a collection of Italian instrumental works from the late renaissance and early baroque, illustrating the art of the wind band. A few of the pieces are transcribed from motets and other vocal works, as was common practice in those times. Composers represented include the two Gabrielis, Palestrina, Vecchio, Malvezzi, Bassano, Salomone Rossi, and a few others whose works have occasionally appeared on other recitals of this kind.Ensemble Ventosum are a French-based period instrument ensemble, here playing mainly cornetti and sackbuts. The best-known of them is the outstanding cornettist William Dongois. Their playing is mostly excellent, although in places lacking in panache or exhilaration. The chosen pieces, which were nearly all unfamiliar to me, range from very fine to a bit on the dull side. Some of the more sombre works, such as those for four trombones with nothing else to brighten the tone, are rather ponderous pieces which I didn't much enjoy.On the other hand, the items that are brighter in mood and texture work very well. These latter include Gussago's 'Sonata undecima' (track 9), its attractive melodies and harmonies enhanced by brilliant divisions from the two cornetti; and Andrea Gabrieli's 'Maria stabat ad monumentum' for cornetto and organ (11) is both graceful and enthralling. The last item on the disc, Neri's 'Sonata à sei', rounds off the programme very nicely – again, a cheerful and enjoyable work that is beautifully delivered here.The disc is well presented, with excellent notes and fine illustrations on the cover. The main drawback for me is in aspects of the choice of works, some of which are of dubious interest. But there also is some fine music here, and it's mostly very nicely performed and recorded.

Johann Hermann Schein (1586-1630), one of the so-called 'three Ss' of the German baroque although there were actually more than this, was an extremely talented and versatile composer. He was one of the early Thomaskantors in Leipzig and produced sacred and secular vocal, as well as instrumental music. I have liked everything I have ever heard from his pen, and this present disc is one of the best.The works of his 'Musica boscareccia' (woodland songs) are sophisticated, beautifully scored and melodic pastoral pieces in the Italianate villanella style. Their lyrical German texts are mainly love songs, addressed to the usual suspects such as Phyllis, Corydon, Tirsi and Delia. If that doesn't sound too promising, don't be put off; for not only are the texts touching and genuinely poetic, but the music is heartfelt, varied and delightful. The soloists are two sopranos and a bass, all three of them excellent; there are usually two singing an item but occasionally all three, and they're accompanied by a varied period-instrument ensemble. The German-based United Continuo Ensemble, although their name sounds a bit like an airline or a transport company, are in fact an extremely talented and stylish bunch of musicians. They include viola da gamba, keyboard, recorder and three more on plucking and strumming duties, with Thor-Harald Johnsen directing with great flair.The nineteen works here, mostly vocal but with a handful of instrumental pieces interspersed, are full of engaging melodies, delicious harmonies and varying, inventive rhythms. This is beautifully crafted music full of poetry, feeling and delicacy. Among my favourite items are 'Concordia zu jeder Zeit' (track 1), immediately winning over the listener with its attractive melody sung in duet by the two beautifully clear soprano voices. Others favourites include ''Unverhofft kommet oft' (5), 'O seidene Härelein' (O silken hair/your tight loops/ensnare trapped hands/with love./No chains of steel and iron/can be as strong./Who would tear your tresses,/tied so firmly round this lover's hand?) (7); 'Mirtillo mein' (9), 'Padouana' (11), Gagliarda-Courente (13), and the instrumental 'O Cordion' (15).Altogether, this is winning, sunlit music, all the more remarkable from a composer who died at the age of 44 after a short life of cruel family tragedies. What's more, these performances are a delight, and the recorded sound very nicely conveys the musicians' bright, bucolic tones. Notes are excellent, all texts and translations are given. An outstanding and heart-warming disc.

This is a programme of Polish baroque music for Christmas, including works by Marcin Mielczewski (c. 1600-1651) and others. It was recorded in a Warsaw church by a substantial ensemble of choir, soloists and instrumentalists, numbering around 40 performers in some of the items, directed by Robert Pozarski.The central item is the 'Missa pro Nativitate' by Mielczewski, but unfortunately it's not one of the better works I've heard from this otherwise extremely fine composer. The Mass movements, for choir, soloists and instruments, are in pastoral style and largely homophonic, with nothing in the way of striking or memorable melodies. While voices and instruments all do their work very well, the choir is too large for the purpose and the direction is ponderous and lack-lustre, while the recorded sound is muddy and remarkably boxy by modern standards, reminding me a bit of the early days of vinyl recordings.The movements of the Mass are interspersed with chant passages, a few motets and some instrumental pieces. The chant sections, sung variously by the lower male solo voices and choir, may be liturgically correct but are far too long for my listening taste, even though they are actually very well performed. The opening track, for example, consists of over 10 minutes of sung antiphon before we even get to the real music; altogether, there's around 40 minutes of chant in this 78-minute recording. Once I've heard these for the first time, I invariably skip them after that in order to get on with the real music.However, there are some decent works in this programme. Mielczewski's motet 'Currite populi' (track 2) is an attractive piece, well performed here by choir and players, but again compromised by the negative factors already mentioned above. The anonymous pastoral Christmas motet 'Parvule pupule' (sleep, poor country boy), which gives its name to the programme, is also very finely sung by two sopranos (female and boy) and beautifully supported by instruments (10). There are a couple of fine instrumental works too (14 and 17), as well as an enjoyable 'Pastorela' for soloists, choir and instruments (18), and a noisy, cheerful closing motet 'Gloria in excelsis Deo' by Stanislaw Szarzynski.Booklet notes and documentation are generally good but, oddly, the texts are given in Polish and English translations but without the Latin originals. Altogether the programme and its performance constitute an honest and dedicated effort by the musicians, some of whom are very good indeed; while the poorly-considered choice of works includes a few worthwhile items but with extended passages of little interest. If you really want to know what Polish baroque composers could do, I would strongly recommend these instead: Mielczewski: Virgo Prudentissima and Adoration of the Virgin Mary at the Polish Court.

This substantial and sumptuously-presented pair of discs consists of two rather different projects. The first – and the more interesting of the two in my view – is a speculative reconstruction of the sacred music performed at that great meeting in 1520 of the kings of France and England and their vast retinues, known as the Field of the Cloth of Gold. It is not known exactly which works were performed for this occasion, but according to contemporary descriptions a Mass was sung, with successive movements from English musicians and composers on the one hand, and from their French counterparts on the other.It must have been a grand, as well as musically fascinating, ceremony – all the more so since both kings, enthusiastic and tasteful patrons of the arts in any case, set out to celebrate peace and at the same time to impress their erstwhile adversaries. For the purpose of the present project, performed by the early music ensemble Doulce Mémoire, their director Denis Raisin Dadre makes some astute choices. The Kyrie is taken from Claudin de Sermisy's 5-voice 'Missa Quare fremuerunt gentes', the Gloria from Nicholas Ludford's 6-part 'Missa Benedicta et venerabilis', followed by a 6-part Credo by the French Antoine Divitis. Then it's back to Ludford for Sanctus and Benedictus, and to Sermisy's Mass for the Agnus Dei, this time in 8 parts. The Mass movements are introduced by an instrumental Pavane by Attaingnant, and then interspersed with plainchant passages, motets by Jean Mouton, and spoken contemporary descriptions of the occasion.This amounts to a substantial and extremely impressive Mass performance, full of variety and lasting 70 minutes. For the French Mass sections, as was the practice at the time according to Raisin Dadre's excellent booklet notes, the voices are doubled by wind instruments, while Ludford's Mass movements are sung a cappella. In both music and performance, then, this Mass for the Field of the Cloth of Gold is unlike the normal unified entity of the renaissance Mass, but the rationale for the alternating multi-national procedure adopted for this programme is clear enough and in fact it works very well. Sermisy's Kyrie (track 4) alone is a magnificent structure, a considerable 8-minute movement in sumptuous sound, sung here with two voices per part doubled by cornetti, shawms and sackbuts. In contrast to Sermisy's Franco-Flemish polyphony, Ludford's Mass sections are in a very different style – his graceful, melismatic lines sung here by voices alone. Divitis' Credo is a fine work too, again receiving a sumptuous performance here from voices doubled by instruments. Sermisy's Agnus Dei is once again superb, and I would greatly love to hear the whole work one of these days. Voices and instruments all do a terrific job, performing with conviction and in excellent style. The recorded sound, in Fontevraud abbey, is superb, with a fine ambience as well as exemplary clarity enabling us to follow each voice.The second disc, titled 'La Chambre du Roy' and recorded in the magnificent Loire chateau of Chambord, offers a selection of the secular music forms favoured by Franois Ier. So we hear a sequence of chanson settings interspersed with instrumental pavanes, galliards and basses danses. The personnel, while still chosen from the Doulce Mémoire ensemble, are partially different here, with single voices for each chanson part, sometimes accompanied by instruments, and the instrumental pieces played by recorder consort with lutes and percussion. The works are well organised, but by no means all of great interest. One of the better aspects of the procedure applied here is the pairing of settings of the same chanson by two different composers, which makes for interesting comparisons.The star composer here, for me, is Pierre Certon, whose settings of chansons from his 'Meslanges' collection are superb; his song of lost love 'Je suis déshéritée' (CD2, track 3) is most beautiful; the performance of the engaging melody 'Tant que vivray' (14), for solo soprano and recorders, is delightful, and Certon's setting of 'Contentez-vous' (29) is absolutely lovely. Here again, it would be great to hear a complete recording of his 'Meslanges' collection sometime. However, I also have to say that quite a few other works on this second disc are nothing special. As for performance, most of the voices are OK, but I don't think much of countertenor Paulin Bündgen; the percussionist is also extremely irritating in places, for my taste drawing far too much attention to himself with unnecessary smart-alec flourishes.Musically, then, this paired programme is a mixed bag, the first part being a complete success while the second is far less so. Matters are almost redeemed, however, by the set's presentation, in the form of a lavish 130-page book with stunning illustrations making it a true visual delight – as well as detailed and absorbing notes by director Raisin Dadre and others, full texts and translations and all the documentation you could wish for.

François Dieupart (c.1667-c.1740), his first name sometimes given as Charles, unlike many French musicians of his time was never a court composer. Rather, he was very much of an individualist who went his own way, and it shows in his music. From 1700 he moved to London, working mainly as a teacher and keyboard performer, and remained there until his death in poverty and relative obscurity. He didn't deserve such a fate - as his published work, admittedly limited in quantity, clearly demonstrates.His most important work was this set of six suites, published in 1701 (not 1717 as stated in the booklet notes). They were scored for recorder or flute and continuo, as in the present performance, but he also published a version for solo keyboard which I've reviewed elsewhere: Dieupart: Harpsichord Suites / Gremy-Chauliac. The suites make very fine keyboard music, but I still have a slight preference for the music in the present format. The six works, each consisting of a French overture and series of dance movements - of the kind now familiar from many works by Bach, Telemann and others - are very impressive pieces indeed. The Overtures in particular have a certain grandeur in spite of their modest scoring, each one both distinctive and inventive and containing thematic elements of the subsequent series of dance movements. The format thus results in a very satisfyingly unified work in each case, and it's not surprising that Bach greatly admired them.The six suites are played for this 1992 disc by Hugo Reyne on recorder, with basso continuo provided by viola da gamba, archlute and harpsichord. Reyne has become better known recently as director of the baroque ensemble La Simphonie du Marais. The small but impressive cast of players includes Philippe Pierlot and Pierre Hantaï. The playing is beautiful, stylish and elegant throughout, with, of course, a starring role for Hugo Reyne on two lovely period instruments - a 'flûte de voix' (tenor recorder) for suites 1 to 4, and a ' flûte du quatre' in the form of an especially fine B flat instrument for Suites 5 and 6. My own favourite movement here is the Overture to Suite 5, and in fact this whole suite is lovely; in addition to the Overtures to each suite, I found the Sarabandes beautiful too.Altogether, this is lovely music in a superb performance and recording. It's getting hard to find now, but fortunately it's also currently available as part of a two-disc reissue coupled with music by Purcell Purcell · Dieupart - Suites for recorder / La Simphonie du Marais · Hugo Reyne. There's also a 2001 recording of these Dieupart works by Colpron, Napper and Sempé on the Atma label, Six Suites, spread over two discs but providing strong competition with the present one. And then there are recordings of the keyboard versions as well. The comparison between the two scorings is fascinating in itself but, either way, this is French baroque music of the very highest quality.

François Dieupart (c.1667-c.1740), his first name sometimes given as Charles, unlike many French musicians of his time was never a court composer. Rather, he was very much of an individualist who went his own way, and it shows in his music. From 1700 he moved to London, working mainly as a teacher and keyboard performer, and remained there until his death in poverty and relative obscurity. He didn't deserve such a fate - as his published work, admittedly limited in quantity, clearly demonstrates.His most important work was this set of six suites, published in 1701. They were scored for flute or recorder and continuo, but he also published them in a version for solo keyboard which is the one we hear in the present recording. The suites make very fine keyboard works, but I still have a slight preference for the music in its chamber ensemble format which is available in at least three CD recordings, including Six Suites and Purcell · Dieupart - Suites for recorder / La Simphonie du Marais · Hugo Reyne. The six works, each consisting of a French overture and a series of dance movements - of the kind now familiar from many works by Bach, Telemann and others - are very impressive indeed. The overtures in particular have a certain grandeur, each one both distinct and inventive and containing thematic seeds for the subsequent series of dance movements. The format thus results in a very satisfying whole in each case, and it's not surprising that Bach greatly admired these works.The six suites are played for this 1999 recording by Huguette Grémy-Chauliac on an absolutely splendid copy by William Dowd of a 1770 Taskin instrument. Her playing is energetic, stylish, subtle and brilliant in decorative facility. I especially enjoyed Suite no. 5, above all its magnificent Ouverture.My own personal favourites among the French baroque keyboard masters include Chambonnières, D'Anglebert, Forqueray and Louis Couperin, and I wouldn't claim that Dieupart's music necessarily measures up to that of these other great masters - not, at least, in these versions for solo keyboard in view of the preference I've expressed above. But there is a fascinating comparison to be made between the two scorings. In any case, Grémy-Chauliac's outstanding performance, her lovely instrument and the excellent recorded sound are such that it would be immoral to give this any less than five stars.

I was prompted to read this excellent book after visiting modern-day Wroclaw and learning about its past – and, in particular, of the terrible ordeal experienced in the final months of World War 2 by the city formerly known as Breslau. There are already a number of detailed and thorough reviews here on Amazon, so I won't repeat too much of what others have written.I agree with the assessments of most fellow reviewers. This is a gripping and terrifying story, told in compelling and sometimes horrifying detail by Richard Hargreaves. The amount and quality of the writer's research are phenomenal; the story is greatly enhanced by his quotations of accounts from so many people, on all sides of the conflict, who were there and who witnessed and suffered the terrors of a great city under merciless siege by the Red Army – and under even more merciless orders from the Führer and his underlings to hold out at all costs.I must admit that, terrible as their ordeal was, I found it hard to work up too much sympathy for the civilian population. They'd been happy enough when the boot was on the other foot as Hitler's armies wrought death and brutal havoc on the peoples of eastern Europe, with little thought that they might eventually find out how it felt to be on the receiving end for a change. Likewise with the ruthless 'Vertreibung', the expulsion of German civilians westwards from what now became Polish territory. It was, of course, Stalin's will that Polish borders should be shifted westwards as soon as the war ended – and inevitably, at that point in history, what Stalin wanted, Stalin got. As a result, many thousands of Polish people arrived in the city from places further east such as Lwów, and treated the departing Germans with considerably more hatred and brutality than they'd suffered at the hands of the Red Army. Human nature being what it is, I don't believe the former Breslauers should have been all that surprised.Even today, the far right in Germany are still harping on about nostalgia for their former Schlesien and their alleged right to recover it and other lands they lost as a result of the war. It's a very dubious point, because the Germans had seized Silesia in the first place, under Frederick II in the 18th century, and other parts of Poland under Bismarck in the 19th century. Be that as it may, they would clearly need to start World War 3 in order to do anything about it. But for as long as people remember the use they made of Polish lands at the likes of Auschwitz, Sobibor and Treblinka, nobody is about to let any of that happen. So they may as well leave it alone.In a final chapter referring briefly to Wroclaw's post-war history, Richard Hargreaves touches on the nostalgia question, but perhaps more objectively than I have just done. The fact is that Wroclaw is now a modern Polish city, although still bearing some of the scars of war and of the quick-and-ugly approach to housing reconstruction under a communist regime in the fifties and sixties. But the city also has a busy and thriving population, one of Poland's great universities, a cathedral and other fine churches, a superbly reconstructed market square (Rynek) and old town hall (Ratusz), and - unlike Edinburgh, 20 miles from where I'm writing this - an extensive and practical tram network. It's a far cry from the misery, rubble, fire and destruction so vividly described in Hargreaves' fascinating study.

Giovanni Girolamo Kapsberger (c. 1580-1651) is mainly known nowadays for his instrumental music, especially for lute. But this Venetian-born composer, of German parentage and moving on to a distinguished career in Rome, was a highly original and versatile musician who wrote in many formats. And, judging from the present disc, he was an outstanding composer for the voice.'I Pastori di Bettelemme' is a musical 'pastorale' in the then modern concertante style, an imaginative reflection upon the story of the shepherds and the Nativity. There are five shepherds here, a narrator (Testo) and an angel, as well as a handful of instruments to accompany the vocal pieces and to provide a few instrumental interludes. Most of the vocal music is for the shepherds – two sopranos, countertenor, tenor and bass – and it is all very lovely indeed, with a mixture of arioso, villanella-like songs and melodically engaging homophonic choruses. Although the atmosphere, as set by the instrumental introduction, is intermittently pastoral in flavour, the vocal music is sophisticated, demanding and beautifully embellished with many virtuoso solo passages.There are a few interspersed pieces by Kapsberger and his contemporary Giovanni Lorenzo Baldano; some of these are instrumental - Paso e mezo, Sinfonia, Corrente, Piva - and others are Latin motets such as the beautiful 'Hodie Christus natus est' (track 11) with lovely, complex embellishments for solo soprano. Later on, the lullaby for the baby Jesus, 'Dormi figlio' (22) for two sopranos, is quite captivating. Instruments used at various points include psaltery, strings, harp, chitarrone, recorder and organ; the instrumental works are judiciously interspersed, they greatly enhance both atmosphere and enjoyment, and they are all beautifully played.Apart from Kapsberger's music itself, however, the greatest assets of this recording are the overall conception, the scoring and the delightful performances by all six singers. On the first point, no director is named in the booklet, nor on the website of the Echo du Danube ensemble; but I would guess that viola da gambist Christian Zincke and psaltery-player Elisabeth Seitz may have had leading roles in the conception of the present CD. As for the singers, once again the booklet documentation lists them all but doesn't indicate who sings what, so I can only list them here - sopranos Constanze Backes, Chiyuki Okamura and Clementine Jesdinsky, countertenor Franz Vitzthum, tenor Christian Dietz, and bass Markus Flaig - and emphasise that they are all wonderful. I would reserve a special mention for the soprano in the part of Primo Pastore, if only I knew who it was!The booklet notes are excellent and all texts and translations are provided. However, there are a couple of frustrating aspects to the documentation. The first is, as already stated, that there is no indication of who is singing which role or item; so the three sopranos can get no credit where it's due, except collectively of course. The second is that the texts are not placed in the same order as the music on the disc; instead, those of the additional inserted works are shown separately at the end, so we have to keep on searching back and forth in the booklet if we want to follow the text – a stupid arrangement, and inevitably irritating to the listener.Musically, however, this is a fascinating disc of delightful baroque vocal music in a really outstanding performance. Full marks without a doubt!

This is a first recording of one of Cavalli's lesser-known late works, not to be confused with the composer's beautiful 'Vespero della beata Vergine' of which a couple of superb recordings already exist, including Cavalli: Vespro Della Beata Vergine, also issues as Cavalli: Vespero Della Beata Vergine Maria. The present work, in my view, is well below par by Cavalli's standards; I found it distinctly prosaic, lacking Cavalli's customary expressive flair and melodic inspiration. Extended passages in most of the fourteen motets consist of little more than choral recitative, with no real continuity or momentum, let alone memorable melodies.The scoring is impressive, with double ripieno and favorito choirs, wind instruments and continuo. Director Bruno Gini uses substantial vocal forces, with each of the two choirs numbering about 15 voices - all this amounting to a total of about 50 musicians. Frankly, it's just too much for the music. The unremitting 'colla parte' accompaniment by cornetti and trombones of all the choir voices, and the equally obtrusive organ playing along with the soloists' 'favorito' sections, all result in a thick, unsubtle texture which deprives the singing of its expressive power. This is a great pity, because the singers themselves - both choirs and soloists - are very good; they simply don't get a chance to be heard at their best. It's true that there's a certain grandeur about it all; but exciting, or even graceful, it isn't.Things liven up remarkably well for the final item on the agenda, the Magnificat Quinti Toni. Some of the above criticisms still apply, but this time there is more contrast in pace and texture, and more effective use of the favorito groups. So it works much better here, and clearly it's a fine piece in its own right.Apart from this last work, however, the disc as a whole is a great disappointment - all the more so since director Roberto Gini has made some fine recordings, including a very good Monteverdi Vespers, and individually his musicians do their work extremely well. The booklet notes are good, and Latin texts are provided but without translations. Cavalli is one of my favourite composers, but I'm sorry to say that this is not among his better works and in the present recording - apart from that Magnificat - the music just doesn't come off.

This is a typically eccentric programme from the excellent early music ensemble Capella de la Torre, directed by shawm player Katharina Bäuml. I must admit I was a bit dubious at first, thinking that this idea of a programme of music relating to water, nymphs and sirens would be a somewhat artificial concoction. Well, actually it is; but, as it turns out, the quality of the music together with the flair and musicianship of the band soon won me over.The selection is a well-organised mixture of vocal and instrumental pieces from the renaissance and early baroque, with a strong but by no means exclusive Italian content. As is usual with this ensemble, a majority of the pieces are unashamedly rescored or rearranged to suit the band's personnel – in this case soprano and counternor, two shawms, recorder, trombone, bass dulcian, lute or theorbo, organ and percussion. As for the works chosen, they include a goodly number of fine pieces which I've never encountered before. Some of their connections to the stated theme are tenuous, but are boldly justified in the interesting booklet notes, supported by appropriate information on the mythology of water gods and other aquatic themes and creatures.The varied sequence of vocal and instrumental works, mostly secular, includes music from composers such as Michael Praetorius, Willaert, Josquin, Morley, Holborne, Gibbons, Victoria, Arcadelt, Marenzio and Ghizzolo. Among items of particular interest are Fabritio Caroso's 'Laura Suave' (track 3), which turns out to be a very charming version of the catchy Aria di Firenze, sometimes known as Ballo del Granduca, from the Florentine Intermedii 'La Pellegrina' of 1589 - so many names! Then there's Anthony Holborne's 'The Fruit of Love' and 'The Funerals' – the latter somewhat crudely scored for the present complement, whereas I much prefer to hear it played by the customary viol consort. Also, the rendering of Josquin's 'Nymphes nappés/Circumdederunt me' (10) is too light-hearted for my liking.Lorenzo Allegri's 'Quinto ballo detto le ninfe di Senna' is lovely (11), and the anonymous 'Les nymphes de la Grenouillère' (17) brings delightfully onomatopoeic frog noises from the instruments. Robert Johnson's 'Full Fathom Five' (18) is beautifully done by countertenor and instruments. There's a decent chaconne-like piece composed by the ensemble's lute player Johannes Vogt, 'Canto' for lute and percussion (21), which thankfully goes well enough with all the old stuff here. And the two 'swan' pieces, Arcadelt's 'Il bianco e dolce cigno' (20) and Orlando Gibbons' 'The Silver Swan' (22), are both absolutely beautiful.While I sometimes find it hard to take the drastic rescoring, and the lack of information or explanation about such measures, committed by Katharina Bäuml and her ensemble, there's no denying that the results here are mostly delightful. The musicianship in this programme is outstanding, with especially fine contributions from countertenor Benno Schachtner and soprano Cécile Kempenaers, both of them not only sounding good but sensitive and highly responsive to the texts, and with faultless English pronunciation where applicable. The booklet is very nicely illustrated with old maritime and mythological prints, as well as some session photos, and all texts and translations are given. The booklet notes are well translated into English by someone with the suspicious-sounding name of ??? (sic).Altogether, this collection offers an exquisite illustration of the power of music to move and to delight. As I mentioned above, I hesitated over it to start with but, once heard, it will certainly be getting plenty more hearings.

Friedrich Wilhelm Zachow (1663-1712), organist and director of music at the Marktkirche in Halle, is perhaps best known (when known at all) for having been Handel's teacher. He wrote numerous church cantatas as well as organ works; and, of the latter, all that survive are included on these two CDs.These are slight, short-winded pieces on the whole. There are around seventy works in all here, most of them lasting only a minute or two each. The majority are settings of Lutheran chorales, with a sprinkling of freely-composed works such as Preludes, Fugues and a Fantasia or two. The chorales are brief, decorated treatments of the Lutheran hymns, not developed or demanding in any way. Zachow's setting of 'Es ist das Heil uns kommen her' lasts just over two minutes – an extraordinary contrast, for example, to the masterly and supremely inventive cycle on the same theme by the earlier Hamburg organist Matthias Weckmann, which brings us around half an hour of stunning music in each of the various recordings available.Only in Zachow's 'Jesu, meine Freude' does the chorale tune get treated to a series of variations amounting to a good few minutes of joined-up music. This shows that the composer was perfectly capable of writing more extended pieces – as also do his cantatas, in fact – and a few of the freely-composed organ works here have the same effect. I can only assume that the requirements of his post, or the expectations of his congregation, imposed limits on the length of these chorale-based compositions. In fact they are unambitious but entertaining works, lively and inventive, with the result that for most of the time you're left feeling disappointed when they stop so soon.Organist Irénée Peyrot makes the best possible case for this unpretentious but enjoyable music, with able and stylish playing on two very fine-sounding late baroque instruments. This set won't take you very deeply into the world of great baroque organ music, but it was a worthwhile project and it's been very well carried out.

This is a beautiful programme of works by two Franco-Flemish composers and associates of the post-Josquin generation, who both made their names and careers in Italy. It's performed by an excellent group of singers, the Ensemble Jachet de Mantoue consisting of five male voices, joined here by a female soprano, and also in some of the works by the cornetti and sackbuts of Les Sacqueboutiers de Toulouse.Jachet de Mantoue, otherwise known as Jacquet of Mantua, provides the main work on the disc, a parody Mass based on his own motet 'Enceladi Coeique Soror'. The motet is also offered here (track 3). As is often found in such cases, the subject matter of the model motet is of crucial significance for the musical content of the Mass itself. As is well explained in the booklet notes, the motet text ostensibly concerns the mythological figure of Fama, messenger of Zeus, a fearsome winged creature who roamed the world proclaiming to all and sundry the intimate secrets of mortals. But it turns out that, for Jachet's purposes, the text is used here as an advert for the highly prized horses of the composer's patron, Duke Gonzaga of Mantua.The motet itself is beautifully sung by a capella voices, its lines clearly stated, easily followed and thus enhancing our appreciation of the following item, the parody Mass itself. The Mass is grander in texture, the voices supported 'colla parte' by the wind players, and this results in a highly effective contrast between motet and Mass. The music of the Mass, taking its cue from its model, is lively and bright in texture. The Mass is preceded and followed by a few motets by Jachet and by Adrian Willaert, and its movements are also interspersed with others. Some of these are of great interest, iincluding 'Dum vastos Adriae fluctus' (13), a tribute to Josquin which contains several quotations from the master's own motets, their sources being helpfully indicated in the CD booklet. A couple of items are played by instruments alone, especially fine being Willaert's 'Victor io, salve' (12), an energetic, triumphant piece. The two psalm settings which end the programme are curiosities which I personally found to be of lesser interest.Like the recent issue of music by Jachet/Jacquet sung by the Brabant Ensemble, Jacquet of Mantua: Missa Surge Petre, the present programme brings us music of the highest quality, beautifully performed, and it represents an extremely enterprising choice and arrangement of the composer's works. The varied combinations of fine voices and instruments work superbly, and it would really be hard to fault any aspect of these performances. Apart from the unfortunate omission of the first 'o' in the word 'countertenor', booklet documentation, notes and illustrations are excellent; texts and translations are given for the motets but not for the Mass - a forgivable omission, I suppose. This recording has been around since 2004, so there are probably only a few copies still available from European sources including Amazon; but it was also re-issued at some point as part of a three-disc set of Jachet's music by the ensemble.

Handel's allegorical semi-oratorio, impossible to classify any more precisely than that, is a marvellous example of music and poetry combined in the expression of man’s place in the world – this, of course, as viewed in the age of enlightenment. With a text by Milton, supplemented by additions from Charles Jennens to cover the 'moderate' element reconciling the first two extremes of mood, the result is a delightfully entertaining demonstration of the joy, versatility and expressive variety of music. Its protagonists are allegorical figures representing Joyfulness, Contemplation and Moderation, but the music of each one is shared among the singers rather than being consistently confined to a particular voice.The present performance, from Paul McCreesh and his Gabrieli Consort and Players, aims to recreate the premiere of Handel's original version of the work. So each of the three parts is introduced by a concerto, as was Handel's practice and his audience's expectation. For Part the First, McCreesh chooses the fine Concerto no. 1 in G, from Handel's set of twelve concerti grossi opus 6. The work, in this lovely performance from the Gabrieli Players, provides an excellent and fitting opening to L'Allegro's vocal music. There are many equally fine moments in the following sequence of recitatives and arias, so I will just mention a few of the musical highlights together with some examples of the outstanding musicianship in this recording. The five vocal soloists are soprano Gillian Webster, boy treble Laurence Kilsby, tenor Jeremy Ovenden, baritone Peter Harvey, and bass Ashley Riches; they are all excellent, with just a couple of minor reservations which I'll mention in a moment.As for the many musical delights, tenor Jeremy Ovenden sings his recitatives and arias superbly, the expression and drama of all the recitatives being an especially convincing feature throughout this performance. L'Allegro's air for boy treble, 'Come, thou goddess, fair and free' (CD1, track 8), is a delight, further enhanced by fabulous instrumental playing. For Il Penseroso's soprano aria and chorus, 'Come, but keep thy wonted state' (1/13), the lovely walking gait, again underpinned by beautiful instrumental work, is superb. Gillian Webster makes beautiful sounds throughout, but her diction is not all that clear at times. Her soprano aria 'Sweet bird, that shun'st the noise of folly' (1/17) receives a magical performance, and flute soloist Katy Bircher deserves a medal for her beautifully observed imitations of the nightingale's song; it's a long piece of 13 minutes, but there's not a single dull moment – a perfect juxtaposition of Milton's poetry and Handel's music.The short bass hunting aria, 'Mirth, admit me of thy crew' (1/19) is another great success, with Richard Bayliss' lusty horn playing somehow making it sound as if there's more than one of him. The closing number for Part I, 'Or let the merry bells ring round' (1/23) is a lovely team effort by treble, chorus and band.Part II opens with the concerto grosso in E minor, op. 6 no. 3; again it makes a fine choice, with ideal tempi for my taste in the Allegro movements and a supremely graceful Polonaise (1/27). The soprano aria 'But O! Sad virgin, that thy power’ is outstanding, enhanced further here by the superbly played cello obbligato. Part II continues on the second disc, filled with as many delights as the first. Tenor air and chorus 'These delights if thou canst give' (2/7) is a joyful movement brightly coloured by a pair of trumpets. Part II closes with an especially effective fugal movement, 'These pleasures, Melancholy, give' (2/10), launched by the organ, then with soprano voice and lower instruments, and finally the chorus joining in to bring Part the Second to a splendid climax.Part III opens with a tour de force for this recording: the magnificent organ concerto op. 7 no. 1 in B flat. Its stunning, chaconne-like opening Andante (2/13) proceeds with vigorous and compelling momentum, superbly played by organist William Whitehead and the Gabrieli Players. Unlike some other recordings, the work is here played on an instrument that is both colourful and beefy enough for the job, the splendid organ of St. Paul's parish church, Deptford. The exuberant Fuga (2/13) brings further delight, and altogether this is an exhilarating performance of one of the truly great concertos of the baroque. For the rest, Peter Harvey makes a distinguished contribution (2/16-17), although I could swear that he mistakenly sings the third word of the line 'Come, with native lustre shine' as 'nature', which doesn't make sense. In fact he does it twice, unless my hearing is failing me; of course I'm open to correction on this point by a more aurally advantaged listener. The well-known soprano-tenor duet 'As steals the morn upon the night' (2/21) is fabulous here, probably the loveliest rendering I've ever heard, and the work finishes with the characteristically Handelian closing chorus 'Thy pleasure, Moderation, give'.Comparing this with other recordings, the one from the King's Consort is also highly regarded by some. It is good, in some respects equalling the Gabrielis for sensitivity and for some of the solo vocal work, but not in either vigour or majesty where appropriate, nor in recorded sound quality. The King's Consort include some of Handel's later additions to the score, but they don't give us any instrumental concerti apart from one drastically truncated piece to serve as overture. The outstanding assets of McCreesh's recording include the excellent vocal soloists; exceptionally fine instrumental playing, especially in the obbligato parts; superb recorded sound; and an overall conception that is enhanced still further by those magnificent concerti. Altogether, the present performance is a delight from start to finish and a real treat for Handelians.Text and documentation are all provided in the CD booklet, and we also get a substantial and extremely informative essay by the Handel expert Ruth Smith, with additional and equally interesting comments from Paul McCreesh. There are also quite a few very nice photos, although I've no idea why they are all of Gillian Webster and one other guy whom I can't identify, but show us none of the other soloists, players or conductor.

Marin Marais, one of the favourite musicians of Louis XIV, was more highly regarded for his instrumental music than for his operas. This is well reflected in the listings of his music available on disc, nearly all of them instrumental, and especially the works for viol. While his opera 'Alcyone' was a considerable success in its time, 'Séméle' was not. I must admit that I hadn't greatly enjoyed the couple of complete Marais operas I'd heard so far on disc – when compared, for example, to those of Lully, Campra or Rameau. So it seems like a good plan to extract the instrumental movements from 'Séméle' and perform them on a single disc.By and large the task has been done effectively here by the period-instrument ensemble Montréal Baroque, directed by Wieland Kuijken. They start with a fine overture, played in vigorous and pointed style, and there are many colourfully orchestrated dances amounting to thirty pieces in all. The substantial Chaconne from Act II (track 16) is an excellent example of the genre, extremely varied and inventive; and the closing piece, Tremblement de terre, is also impressive.The trouble is that, perhaps perversely in view of what I wrote above, I find myself missing the stage drama and context of the works when faced with this succession of thirty mainly short pieces, most of them just a minute or two long and not originally intended to be heard in succession like this. I suppose I'm happy enough to have heard them a couple of times, but I doubt that I'll be taking this CD off the shelf very often from now on.

This is one of a number of sacred oratorios written by Caldara during his time as composer to the Viennese imperial court chapel of Charles VI. Like most self-respecting Italian baroque composers, Caldara was an experienced hand in the setting of texts of sacred misery. The present work, receiving its first recording here, is a sequence of reflections on the death (part 1) and burial (part 2) of Christ, as seen through the reactions of various involved bystanders: Mary Magdalene, Joseph of Arimathea, Nicodemus, the Centurion, and Mary, mother of James.All the arias are melodically distinctive, strongly characterised and benefiting from powerful, independent and colourful instrumental participation. There is vigour, anger and misery aplenty in this score, and by and large it is well performed by Fabio Biondi and his team. This is not strictly a historically informed performance (HIP) - so, for example, by baroque standards the Stavanger Symphony Orchestra are a large band of around 27 players using modern instruments. But their playing is stylish and committed, and the approach is well suited to Caldara's muscular music. Of the five vocal soloists, the two sopranos have decent voices and expressive style, but with too much vibrato for my taste. Outstanding, though, are alto Martina Belli as Joseph, and Ugo Guagliardo as the Centurion. The instrumental Introduzione to part 1 is very fine, as are the two superb madrigalesque choruses which conclude each part of the oratorio.A bit on the short side to fill two CDs on its own, the oratorio movements are here interspersed with a few other vocal and instrumental works, mostly by Caldara, some more appropriate than others. The initial motet based on an Old Testament text, for example, seems somewhat out of place - the above-mentioned Introduzione would have made a better opening on its own. The short Sinfonia by Johann Joseph F-u-x (spelt thus to avoid Amazon's unintelligent electronic censoring system) is all right, but unnecessary in its place half-way through part 1. On the other hand, Vivaldi's well-known Sonata Al Santo Sepolcro makes a very good introduction to part 2. There are many other fine moments, including a superb aria for the Centurion with lovely string textures (CD1/12); a very Handelian melody for soprano (1/17); Nicodemus' aria full of vigorous fury (2/6); a lovely solo violin part for director and violinist Fabio Biondi (2/10) accompanying Mary Magdalene; and Caldara's all-too-attractive and cheerful Sinfonia Concertata (2/15).The present work is not quite on a par with the wonderful Caldara - Maddalena ai piedi di Cristo, especially in that stunning interpretation directed by René Jacobs; but 'Morte e sepoltura' is nevertheless an expressive and fascinating oratorio, and it receives here a mostly very fine performance of committed sincerity; Fabio Biondi's direction is energetic and convincing, and his singers and players respond very effectively to the demands of baroque style and expression. Recorded sound is excellent, as are Brian Pritchard's booklet notes covering background, composer and music. All texts and translations are provided.

Jean Mouton, contemporary and compatriot of 'Josquinus incomparabilis', has not been served too badly on disc - especially his setting of the exceptionally beautiful 'Nesciens mater' - and  yet a great deal of his considerable output remains to be performed in modern times, let alone recorded. The present disc makes a useful contribution to this process. Its title, '1515', refers to an important date in French history for reasons explained in Fabrice Fitch's useful booklet notes; it's enough to say here that it was, among other things, the year of an important meeting in Bologna between the new French king Franois I and Pope Leo X. It is rather vaguely conjectured that music must surely have been performed for the occasion and, since Jean Mouton was a favourite of both king and pope, some of his music may well have been included.Irrespective of the pretext, this is a fine collection of the composer's music, including a Mass, a Magnificat and ten motets. The 'Missa Quem dicunt homines' is a parody Mass based on an exceptionally fine motet of that name by Jean Richafort. The Mass is a four-movement work with no Credo, its first two movements placed at the start of the disc and the Sanctus and Agnus Dei at the end. In between, we have the remaining works - the succession of nine motets in the middle perhaps offering a less-than-ideal arrangement for a CD programme. But there are many fine things, among which I especially liked 'Salva nos Domine' (track 13). Like many composers of renaissance and later times, Mouton produced some of his works in grovel mode, in other words not to sacred texts but in praise of some earthly bigwig - in the present case, one motet each for king, queen and pope.Best of all, however, is the Mass itself, a glorious work in spite of its all-too-brief eighteen minutes. Unfortunately we don't get Richafort's model motet here for our further enlightenment - but, as luck would have it, it's available in volume one of the wonderful 'Leiden Choirbooks' series Leiden Choirbooks 1, and it can also be heard on YouTube, nicely sung by an unnamed ensemble. Jean Mouton's Mass here represents the composer's work at its very best - a master craftsman with melodic grace and profundity to match.All these works are beautifully performed by the eight voices of two fine ensembles - Ensemble Clément Janequin and Ensemble Diabolus in Musica - directed respectively, but I presume not simultaneously, by Dominique Visse and Antoine Guerber. The high voices - one male, one female - lend an incisive edge to the vocal blend which some listeners may find disconcerting; but personally I like it, finding that it enhances presence and clarity while in no way overriding the excellent contributions of the lower voices. Clarity and expression, rather than sheer beauty of sound, are given priority here, and for me they suit the music extremely well. The sound and balance are discreetly rounded off by an organ accompaniment in some of the works, including the Mass - a fact that is nowhere mentioned in the booklet.All texts and translations are included. In spite of the above minor reservations about the choices and ordering of the programme, this CD is a worthy tribute to the music of Jean Mouton and a valuable contribution to the renaissance discography.

Billed as Volume 1 in a series, this looks like an attractive collection of orchestral theatre music from the French baroque and in some ways it is. The Tempesta di Mare Philadelphia Baroque Orchestra are a substantial period band - by baroque standards - of around 28 players. At times their numbers work to their advantage, but at other times not; for me the problems start right away in the first set of pieces on the disc, Lully's instrumental suite for Molière's 'Le Bourgeois Gentilhomme'. Not only is the recorded sound somewhat muffled, but the playing, although in decent baroque style, is all too polite and rather listless, lacking the attack, energy and wit which to me are essential for this music. The movements of the 'Cérémonie des Turcs' section, especially the well-known March, fare much better on the whole; but for the rest, there's more courtly grace than spirit or sparkle. The closing Chaconne des Scaramouches, one of Lully's finest, goes well, although it's over all too quickly compared to the great chaconnes of the composer's tragic operas. Altogether I found this performance a great disappointment when measured against some very strong recorded competition - which I'll return to at the end.Things improve dramatically for Jean-Féry Rebel's extraordinary 'Les Éléments' sequence. The ensemble's rendering of the superb opening 'Le Chaos' description is brilliant, full of energy and commitment, and the rest of the work - especially the lovely Loure & Chaconne movement - goes just as well. This is an extremely colourful and entertaining work; again, there are other fine recordings available of the Rebel pieces - such as the one from Reinhard Goebel - but this time Tempesta di Mare are a match for these, or at least for the ones I've heard. Marin Marais' 'Alcyone' suite is more of a mixture again in the present performance. Again it's entertaining music, but it's not always given the full works and at times is just too genteel. Matters liven up impressively for the 'Tempête' near the end, however, with a starring role for the wind machine and the strings not far behind. The suite concludes with another familiar Chaconne, the orchestra here at their best with a rendering of real cumulative power and conviction.This programme has its good points, then - including very good booklet notes and documentation - but the wimpish rendering of the Lully work in particular is a serious disappointment. I can only think that, for some reason, somebody must have decided that Lully's music didn't need to be played with as much spirit and energy as that of the other two. If so, then this was a bad mistake, because Lully-Molière without the wit is a very poor deal in my view. 'Le Bourgeois Gentilhomme' is, after all, one of the great masterpieces of baroque theatre, and Lully's music measures up to it in every way.Fortunately, the willing enthusiast can rectify matters by considering several other recordings of the work. Among these are Jordi Savall's version of the orchestral music together with two other Lully suites Lully: L'Orchestre du Roi Soleil, available both in its original form and in at least a couple of reissues. Better still, in my opinion, are those recordings which also include Lully's delicious vocal music for the play, the most complete being a two-CD set forming part of the excellent French baroque series from Hugo Reyne's La Simphonie du Marais Le Bourgeois Gentilhomme, comédie de Molière (LULLY ou le Musicien du Soleil, Vol. IV). Fabio Bonizzoni's disc of Lully: Ballets & récits italiens, which includes the Ballet des Nations music from 'Le Bourgeois Gentilhomme', is also an absolute delight. Finally, if you can spare an evening for the full Monty, both theatrical and musical, there are few finer entertainments in the world than this DVD: Le Bourgeois gentilhomme, Comédie-ballet de Molière & Lully / Dumestre, Le Poème Harmonique, Lazar.

The duetti da camera of Agostino Steffani, around eighty in number, are among the most exquisite masterpieces of baroque chamber music. They are scored for voices in various combinations such as two sopranos, soprano-alto, soprano-tenor, with the occasional appearance of baritone or bass; they are accompanied by basso continuo and, in a very few cases, by other instruments. Their poetic texts address mainly the intermingled joys and miseries of unrequited love. Only one of the duets is in genuine dialogue form, with two distinct protagonists answering one another, while the great majority are composed to texts which are actually soliloquies, with the two voices singing to the same words but their musical lines expressing, as it were, different strands of the thoughts and feelings of the enraptured, confused or disappointed lover. The works tend to be in several sections, with recitative passages being interspersed between aria and arioso sections varying in pace, metre and mood.The format offers fabulous possibilities for the expression of complex human emotions, with intertwining voices tracing melodic lines and combinations of delightful texture, delicate counterpoint and extreme subtlety. And the inventive genius of Steffani - for his mastery of melody, texture and expression one of the great baroque composers for the voice - was at its very best in these works which were so greatly admired by both musicians and lovers of fine music in his own time.Until recently Steffani's duets have been sadly neglected through much of the great era of recording, and so far only a handful of these works have found their way onto disc - the two best recordings so far, in my opinion, being the one from soprano Rossana Bertini and countertenor Claudio Cavina Duetti Da Camera and the Archive reissue from singers Daniela Mazzucato, Carolyn Watkinson, Paul Esswood and John Elwes directed by Alan Curtis Duetti Da Camera. So this present recording of seven more duets, performed by soprano Elena Bertuzzi and tenor Alessio Tosi with a small instrumental group, makes a very welcome appearance.One of its obvious assets is that the artists have chosen works which, as far as I know, have not been recorded before - with one small exception which I'll return to in a moment. And, by and large, very fine they are too. The first duet, 'Pria ch'io faccia', demonstrates one of the drawbacks of the present recording, namely that two of the works - items 1 and 7 on the present disc, which were both scored by the composer for two sopranos - have been transposed to be performed here by soprano and tenor. Now, Signor Steffani knew very well what he was doing, and where that included choosing to have the melodic lines of two voices exquisitely close to one another in places, rather than an octave apart, then so be it. For these reasons, I would say that if he scored a work for two specified voices then it ought to stay that way. The theorbo introduction to the first item is also spurious. This work is also the only one of the seven which I had previously heard recorded - in that case sung by soprano and countertenor in a beautiful private recording by the London ensemble Baroque Encounter, but sadly no longer available.Nevertheless, the music still sounds lovely in the present recording, and in fact the two singers both do a terrific job. Ms. Bertuzzi has a lovely voice, as pure, clear and steady as can be, and Signor Tosi's tenor is also very good. Both singers perform in excellent style, singing their words with sincerity and to great expressive effect. Steffani's virtuoso demands place the soprano under pressure at some points, but she copes pretty well. The performances also sound a little blustery at times, lacking the last ounce of refinement that characterises the other two recordings cited above; but there's no denying the two singers' talent, commitment and overall musicality. The accompanying instrumentalists also provide excellent support - Francesco Baroni on harpsichord, Rebecca Ferri on cello, and Michele Pasotti on theorbo.Of the other works not yet mentioned, 'Lontananza crudel' (track 3) is actually of doubtful authorship and is considered by some to be by Giuseppe Antonio Bernabei, son of Steffani's teacher Ercole Bernabei. 'Vorrei dire un non so che' (4) is an especially fine piece, with its intermittent recitative episodes beautifully taken by the two singers, and with the vocal gymnastics of the final bars also very nicely handled by both of them. 'Dolce è per voi soffrire' (5) is another beautiful piece, its delicious opening harmonies typical of Steffani and, I would say, unique to him. Finally, the closing 'Saldi marmi che coprite' (7) is simply a magnificent work. It does suffer here from the soprano-to-tenor transposition mentioned earlier, perhaps even more than the first piece did; the absence of the delicate interwoven textures of two sopranos is a significant loss, and I would greatly love to hear this work as Steffani intended. However, the music is still lovely, the singers are expressive, clearly understand the music and its poetry, and are able to convey these to the listener.The recorded sound is close and has a slightly hard edge to it, but it does also have some depth and ambience and doesn't distract too much from the music, and neither does the occasional distant traffic noise which may be picked up on decent stereo systems. The booklet contains ample information about the musicians and brief notes on Steffani's life, work and the duets in general, but no comments on the individual works on the disc. Texts are not provided, but the booklet directs us to the Brilliant Classics website where texts and translations are shown. The English translations are poor, but we can perhaps make some allowances in view of the label's very reasonable prices.In spite of its faults, then, this is an attractive recording. It makes a significant contribution to the Steffani discography and is very likely to please the growing numbers of his admirers. In fact, I would even suggest that these performers might consider bringing us further volumes, preferably with a couple more singers roped in so as to perform the pieces as scored by the composer. Finally, many thanks to Colin Timms, author of the excellent monograph Polymath of the Baroque: Agostino Steffani and His Music, for some of the above information on the composer's works and the scoring of the duets, both in his book and from personal comments. The opinions expressed here, however, are my own.At the time of writing, the recording is available in CD format from European sources.

Please don't get me wrong - Agostino Steffani's music is wonderful. It's just this performance and recording that are awful, and I already described the reasons why in a 2009 review under Amazon's other entry for this recording: Alarico. However, I've been prompted to take a fresh look at it, and of course to do some more listening, after the sudden recent appearance of two glowing five-star reviews, appearing on both this and the other product page (although in the latter case, I see, they have both been deleted again at the same time today, February 18th 2015), praising this recording in similar and very fulsome terms.Those two reviews were posted by reviewers Magda Levi and Yoav Rothberger, both gilding the lily by adding admiring comments on each other's work. (Stop press: since reading the rest of this, they've now changed their Amazon names to 'ML' and 'A Customer' respectively. Hang on - now they've both deleted their reviews on this page as well, and all their other Amazon reviews!) I'll avoid commenting on the details of the latter's review directly - firstly because, apart from the last paragraph, all the rest has been copied word for word from an entry by Bruno Belli on the website of Luca Casagrande, director and singer in this recording, so there isn't really anything plausible or significant by Mr. Rothberger himself to comment on. Secondly, that reviewer evidently doesn't take kindly to anyone expressing an opinion different from his own, but prefers to resort to ill-mannered language and personal insults to try to prove his point - as could be seen from the comments after the first review I wrote, again on the other product page cited above, although he has since deleted those comments. And thirdly, Mr. Rothberger appears to have a small claque of baroque music enthusiasts at his disposal, who are happy to vote in support of all his comments and to class as unhelpful any comments by anybody else - all, as if by magic, within just a few minutes of the comments being posted. Perhaps a similar fate awaits the present review!This leaves me with Magda Levi's review, which contains substantial passages copied word for word, without any acknowledgment, from Chapter 8 of Professor Colin Timms' monograph Polymath of the Baroque: Agostino Steffani and His Music - from the section entitled `Music and drama in `Alarico il Baltha' '. Ms Levi also has connections with Luca Casagrande's website, having recently contributed some material to it. However, Ms Levi does also add some points of her own to her `Alarico' review here on Amazon, so I will address some of these. In particular, she singles out a number of the singers for fulsome praise - several of whom, to my ears, sound absolutely dreadful and sing wildly out of tune. In my previous review, I tried to avoid causing too much offense by not naming the worst singers individually, and I will repeat that concession here - except in the case of Luca Casagrande, who directs the ensemble and also sings the important baritone role of Pisone. He sings frequently and painfully out of tune, and must also take overall responsibility for this mostly awful performance and recording.Reviewer Ms Levi also makes the point that this was a young cast of singers, around 30 to 35 years of age. Perhaps this is with a view to our making allowances for their youth or inexperience; but are we really expected to make such extreme allowances when we pay out the substantial cost of a three-disc opera set? Besides, I would say that if they can't sing in tune - or at all - by that age then they're unlikely to get much better over the next 35 years.This recording has a few assets - for example, the able and stylish playing by the instrumentalists of the Scarlatti Camera Ensemble, and the singing of such as mezzo Lee Ji-Young (Honorio) and soprano Won Mi-Jung Capilupi (Placidia); bass Marco Democratico (Lidoro) is not too bad either, at least having a decent voice if not great style. The greatest asset of all, of course, is Steffani's music, and I'd greatly love to hear it in a decent recording. But here, I'm sorry to say, much of it is ruined by the poor singing and close, harsh, wiry recorded sound. To take just a couple of examples, Stilicone's beautiful chaconne-based aria in Act 1, Scene 15, `Gelosia, lasciami in pace' is wrecked by poor singing and dreadful sound quality; and the lovely duet between Semiamira and Stilicone in Act 3 Scene 3, `Care Fiamme/ Amate Catene', is ruined by the same factors.It's also worth mentioning that Steffani's roles intended for male altos are sung here by mezzo and contralto - a practice praised by some reviewers and criticised by others. In fact there appears to be a small but persistent lobby, noticeable among certain reviewers both here and on the Italian Amazon website, who are firmly prejudiced against the countertenor voice and on that basis attempt to discredit the work of great singers such as Philippe Jaroussky and Claudio Cavina.Returning to the main business, however, the principal drawbacks of the present recording are dreadful singing, terrible recorded sound and the absence of any sense of involvement, drama or cohesion. And, if there were any argument at all for scoring it with a second star - which in my view there isn't - I'd immediately take one star off again for dodgy practices. If musicians seek public approval for their work, they would do much better to come up with a few decent performances and recordings, rather than produce something like this effort and then try to get their supporters to rig the reviews. Most of us here on Amazon, whether readers or reviewers, are not that stupid.

This is a lively and enjoyable selection of 16th-century Hispanic renaissance music discovered in Guatemala in the 1960s and now held in the Lilly Library of Indiana University. In addition to the more traditional methods of conquest and subjugation, involving death, terror and overwhelming force, the Spanish conquistadores used their rich musical talents and resources to captivate and convert the native American peoples to the benefits of Spanish rule, culture and beliefs. So the music here is mainly of European origin or, at the very least, influence; no composers' names are given in the manuscripts.The programme consists of a variety of instrumental works, chant passages, hymn settings, villancicos and a Mass which I'll return to in a moment. The vocal music is performed by the Pro Arte Singers, directed by John Poole and Carolina Gamboa Hoyos; they make a first-class ensemble, with excellent voices and a fine vocal blend. The instrumental works are played by the period wind Ensemble Lipzodes on shawms, dulcians, recorders and the occasional percussion, with a few additional players joining in at times; again, they are a fine-sounding group and perform in excellent, spirited style. For some of the vocal pieces, including the Mass setting, their instruments double the vocal parts.There are many enjoyable things here, especially among the instrumental pieces, but the most impressive work by far is the anonymous Mass setting. It has no title and is given no explanation at all in the booklet notes, but in fact it is a parody, or more accurately a paraphrase, Mass on Janequin's chanson 'La Guerre'. Janequin's famous piece gave rise to numerous examples of the genre of the 'Missa de la Batalla' especially in the Hispanic world, including those by such as Guerrero, Victoria, Pérez and Capillas - not to mention the French composer's own brilliant self-parodying 'Messe la Bataille'. The present, anonymous example I found to be especially fine. It's a mainly homophonic work, with just a few passages of fairly straightforward polyphony; and, rather than pointing up the melodrama and rhythmic contrasts in Janequin's original, it emphasises the melodic beauty and reflective sadness of the composer's multi-faceted chanson. It's beautifully sung here, with the wind instruments doubling the voices in some passages, and for me it's a definite hit and a fascinating contrast to other works in this genre that I've heard.The Mass movements are interspersed with other works of the kinds mentioned earlier, and the programme concludes with a lively, celebratory piece for voices and instruments, 'Oy hasemos fiesta' (Today we all celebrate the virgin Saint .....), which provides the disc's title. The booklet notes are very helpful on generalised background, but there is very little about the works chosen and there are no texts or translations supplied. According to the notes, the producers 'care about the environment' and so, 'in order to conserve the use of paper', we are referred to Indiana University's Music Marketplace website and to the Lipzodes Ensemble's own site. I couldn't find anything in the former but, sure enough, the latter does provide texts and translations, some slightly expanded notes, but still no mention of the 'Batalla' mass - which is very disappointing, because I would have been interested to read at least some informed speculation as to its origin and authorship.Altogether, I found this a fascinating and enjoyable programme, and extremely well performed. The musicians are somewhat let down by the producers, however, with that facile hypocrisy of the bit about saving paper, and in my view the absence of texts and of some vital information deprive the disc of an otherwise deserved fifth star.

Owen Jones' book is fundamentally flawed for two reasons. Firstly, the title doesn't make sense - not only because 'chav' in the UK does not mean the same as 'working class', but also because the working classes are not demonized, or at least not by the vast majority of British people.Let's take the pejorative term 'chav' for a start. To me, it refers to someone who is probably young, probably but not necessarily male, and who exhibits some or all of the following behaviour: loud-mouthed, ill-mannered, ignorant, antisocial, destructive, criminal, racially prejudiced; abusive of or violent towards others, especially anyone vulnerable, old, disabled or handicapped, to anyone who is of a different race, colour or culture or from the next street, another town or a different part of town, and to supporters of rival football teams. That's probably enough to be going on with but suffice to say that, while many 'chavs' may be working class, the great majority of working class people are not chavs. So the two terms are entirely different.Next, the working classes are not demonized in British society - certainly not in the sense of being criticised, condemned or abused as a group. OK, the author is right about some things - the UK's social and economic system is very unfair, the poor have an extremely hard time, successive governments should be putting things right and have failed to do so. But it's not because the middle classes are lousy and selfish; some of us are, but we're not by definition rotten as a group any more than the working classes are. The author also insists on trying to define exactly who is working class and who isn't, based on such factors as occupation and income, but his definitions don't really work and he ties himself in knots in the attempt. And if the middle class is so lousy, why do so many people want to be in it?Some of the reasons the author gives for his 'demonization' theory are ludicrous. Let's start with British TV comedy, allegedly guilty of singling out the working classes for ridicule. Now, the whole point of comedy is that people get ridiculed - from the preposterously smarmy and devious Sir Humphrey Appleby in 'Yes Minister', to the pompous middle-class prat Captain Mainwaring in 'Dad's Army', to the ignorant, bigoted Alf Garnett of 'Till Death Us Do Part'. When Del Boy of 'Only Fools and Horses' fails to prop himself up at the bar and falls over sideways, is it because he's working class that we laugh? Of course it isn't - we'd laugh just as much if it were the Queen, the Pope or the UN Secretary-General, although they probably couldn't carry it off with quite the same aplomb as actor David Jason does.Having said all this, the author does make some good and well-informed points, and does so in a very eloquent and readable style. Many arguments are well made, but Jones is also ruthlessly selective in his use of quotations and statistics and there are contradictions on almost every page. Many passages seem persuasive in isolation, but the trouble is that the overall argument, in my view at least, just doesn't add up to a convincing case. He comes down hard on cruel and heartless Thatcherism, quite rightly in my view. But Thatcher was given the order of the boot more than 20 years before this book was written, successive governments have had their chances to put things right since then, and some have done so in certain respects. So how long can you continue blaming everything on people and events of long ago?  Even the current UK coalition parties get jeered at when they carry on trying to blame economic troubles on the last Labour government, who left office 5 years ago at the time of writing this review.But apart from Thatcherism, Jones tries to pin the blame for the present ills in British society upon the alleged prejudice, bigotry and all-round nastiness of the middle classes. The trouble is that, by creating and exploiting this sweeping stereotype of the middle class in order to suit his argument, he effectively demonstrates that the most bigoted and prejudiced person around is the author himself. He may not have intended it to be this way but that, it seems to me, is the end result of this extended, hate-filled rant against the middle classes.

The music of this recording was composed by Lambert de Sayve (1549-1614), a musician from Liège in Flanders who worked for much of his career for the Hapsburg dynasty, including the Emperor Matthias for whom the 16-part 'Missa super Dominus regnavit' on this disc was composed.  The Mass movements are interspersed with shorter pieces, both vocal and instrumental, from the composer's 'Sacrae Symphoniae' collection, as well as a few plainchant passages.The vocal music, in a style midway between renaissance and baroque, is sumptuous in texture, and is finely sung and played by the excellent Choeur de Chambre de Namur and the instrumentalists of La Fenice, directed by Jean Tubéry.The Mass movements benefit here from the doubling, and in some cases replacing, of the vocal lines with instruments. However, I have to say that I did not find the music of the Mass, or most of the other works here, at all interesting. It's not profound, original or memorable, in spite of the performers' efforts. Indeed, there is some pleasure to be had from the quality of the singing and playing - but not a lot, I fear, from the music itself. The only exception, for me, is the wonderful, march-like opening instrumental Intrada by Alessandro Orologio, a catchy and exuberant piece which, again, is beautifully played here with sumptuous cornetto embellishments from Jean Tubéry. It's all over in a minute or two, but it so happens that this latter work has also popped up in another recording, of music by Jacobus Vaet, Musica Ferdinandea - Ein Fest für Kaiser Ferdinand, which I found absolutely beautiful.So, in spite of the fine performances and direction, as well as the handsome booklet with excellent notes, texts and translations, I can't recommend the present disc with any great enthusiasm.

This CD offers a programme of sacred cantatas for solo soprano by Johann Kuhnau, Bach's immediate predecessor as Thomaskantor in Leipzig, as well as a couple by Kuhnau's Italian friend and mentor Vincenzo Albrici. The first work, the seven-movement 'Weicht ihr Sorgen aus dem Herzen', is a good example of Kuhnau's graceful, relatively straightforward style, with attractive melodies and a touch of pietism. This cantata's final aria, 'Komm doch, süße Stunde', is especially fine. Soprano Barbara Christina Steude has a lovely, clear and steady voice and excellent expressive ability – her style and vocal quality ideally suited to both arias and recitatives in this music.Accompaniment is provided by the early-music ensemble 'Concerto con voce', with up to nine string, woodwind and continuo instruments. Balance between voice and ensemble, and between the instruments themselves, is just right, and Jan Katschke's direction from the keyboard is stylish,  sympathetic and altogether excellent. Katzschke has already brought us outstanding German baroque recordings of keyboard music by Kuhnau and Weckmann, and for the present disc he certainly maintains those standards.Albrici's cantata 'Omnia quae fecit Deus', on a more imaginative Latin text, is rather more melodramatic in style, its episodic but enterprising character extremely well pointed by both singer and ensemble. Its demanding vocal part tests Ms. Steude's figuration skills to the limit.Kuhnau's closing cantata, 'Und ob die Feinde' - in spite of its opening lines ('and though enemies may plot our misfortune day and night …..') - is a work of light, tripping melodies, and forms a cheerful and attractive conclusion to the programme. The booklet notes are excellent, and all texts and translations are provided. Kuhnau's vocal music may not quite be in the top rank when judged by the formidable standards achieved by the German baroque; but nevertheless this is a most enjoyable selection, well judged and organised, and the disc will undoubtedly be of interest to dedicated baroque enthusiasts. Since we're forced to decide on a star rating, then in view of these persuasive performances I'd say it deserves full marks.

This is a ballet suite by Michel-Richard de Lalande, to accompany a story based loosely on Don Quixote and other fictional and mythical figures. The plot is fairly inconsequential, but provides a good excuse for some enjoyable and intellectually undemanding music. This consists of a series of mostly instrumental movements, played well here by the Ensemble Baroque de Limoges, a substantial baroque band directed by Christophe Coin. There are also a few vocal items sung by a decent soprano; no texts for these are provided, but the well-illustrated booklet provides good notes and a detailed synopsis of the story in English.Among the 41 mostly very short movements are a lively Ouverture, a ceremonial Air de Trompettes scored in bright 'grand siècle' style; a fine Chaconne which, at just over two minutes, passes all too quickly; a characterful Air pour les Chinois, and a vigorous Air pour les Combattants.
