Although this naturally leads into the more experiential views essential to the practice of deity yoga, Mahamudra and Dzogchen, Dolpopa's ideas in the sutrayana context of Buddha Nature and the Two Truths, while agreeing with a small stream of other masters throughout Tibetan history, were unorthodox and unacceptable to the majority in the reformed (Sarma) schools, especially after the Geluk sect became politically dominant in the mid 17th century and tried to impose a rather strict and uniform version of orthodoxy.Stearns' mostly focuses on the Sakya and Kagyu school's reaction since they interacted the most with Dolpopa's Jonang tradition, but it's a bit unclear (not addressed in much detail) how these ideas were received by the Nyingma (old school). It is clear that Dolpopa didn't agree that Mahamudra or Dzogchen 'nature of mind' teachings were complete (Dolpopa's preferred method for enlightenment was the Six-branch Yoga of the Kalachakra Tantra - which as Stearns briefly describes it sounds like a mix of Dzogchen's togyal/trekchod practices and the 6 Yogas of Naropa type tantric practices), yet the Nyingma's view in regard to pointing out the 'nature of mind' in Dzogchen is very similar sounding to Dolpopa's interpretation of absolute truth (if interested see Mipam on Buddha-Nature: The Ground of the Nyingma Tradition). The subtleties can get confusing! However, if one thing is clear from the various schools of Buddhism in Tibet its that mixing traditions, and trying to reconcile differences casually, is generally NOT helpful to one's actual practice. (The 19th century nonsectarian Rime movement was not about a blending or "crossover" in the modern American sense, as about the three underdog schools collecting and preserving the diversity of their various traditions - keeping them distinct and alive.)Clearly Dolpopa Sherab Gyaltsen was a remarkable master, and Stearns does an excellent job of presenting his life and teachings without it becoming overly complex, moreover Dolpopa's insightful criticisms are well worth considering for any serious student of Madhyamaka and Tathagatagarbha. As Stearns says in his intro, "He (Dolpopa) often remarked that the majority of buddhas and bodhisattvas agree with him on these issues, but that the majority of scholars in Tibet oppose him." This book reveals a controversial, provocative and creative side of normally conservative Tibetan culture, rarely seen, and does so through a wide range of material - biography of Dolpopa (p. 9-40), history of the shentong tradition (p. 41-83), doctrine of Dolpopa (p. 85-110), and original translations of Dolpopa's texts and autocommentaries (p. 113-311), as well as extensive end notes (p. 313-411) and bibliographies (p. 413-437).Overall this book makes a fascinating intro to his life, and his somewhat heretical "shentong" view of emptiness - highly recommended.

I bought this book sight unseen so to speak because I like the subject, thought the title might indicate a radical dzogchen presentation, respect that Tulku Thondup wrote a foreword, and that Master Tam was a close student of Dudjom Rinpoche. What I discovered is a bit of a let down. It is a well produced little book that reads quickly and covers a lot of ground in a fairly reliable way, but it also seems very conventional and doesn't add much to the wide range of books already published on the subject (esp. see Natural Liberation: Padmasambhava's Teachings on the Six Bardos, Mirror of Mindfulness and The Bardo Guidebook). Maybe its main virtue is that it is short and makes the subject more easily accessible, and that for the most part it is aimed at a wide audience (not just Buddhist), and emphasizes the need for practical experience - and familiarity before we die... (Sadly, waiting to prepare for one's death until already on the death bed is kind of like starting to save for retirement on one's last day of work...)Master Tam is a Chinese Buddhist scholar born in 1935, and so his presentation understandably follows a more traditional format, but also gives us a nicely different perspective on these Tibetan teachings - often referencing Taoism and Chan Buddhism, along with modern secular metaphors. I kept reading because I warmed to Master Tam's style (casting a broad eclectic net), and really wanted to like his book, but I also found it lacking clear and memorable insights - being more of an intellectual (and sometimes too discursive) survey of the material.This book attempts to explain one of the most well known teachings to have come out of Tibet, Padmasambhava's 8th Century hidden treasure text (discovered and expounded upon in the 14th century by the 15 year old Karma Lingpa), on the "Profound Dharma of Natural Liberation Through the Intention of the Peaceful and Wrathful Deities" - specifically about the 6 bardos, or in-between states experienced in the process of living and dying. Obviously this is an essential subject for ALL people to be familiar with, and obviously the original version was very culturally specific (ie limited). Master Tam's retelling is pretty faithful to the original.So what we get is a traditional Vajrayana approach to a mix of exo and esoteric teachings. Master Tam's tradition is Nyingma (literally "ancient ones" which this treasure text is most closely associated with), but it is also the way Nyingmas adapted to the newer reformed schools of Tibetan Buddhism - a gradual path presentation of general spiritual practice including some profoundly timeless dzogchen essentials. Part 1 introduces a variety of basic concepts necessary to understand the teachings on the 6 bardos, such as 'ground of being', 'buddha nature', 'naturally arising' and 'naturally liberating' phenomena. Part 2, the meat of the book, offers various explanations and meditations that take us experientially through the 6 bardos. This practical aspect is the main redeeming part for me. Master Tam suggests many practices to do, and explains them in a quick yet effective manner. It is probably best for someone already familiar with more detailed explanations, yet is also presented as a basic intro. It reminds me that Karma Lingpa's original interpretation must have been very vague and poetic and designed as basic sign-posts for one's own realization. In this regard Master Tam's traditional yet scholarly approach is subtly revealing.3+ stars

I was awed by Simon Phillips' drumming back in the late 70's when he played with Phil Manzanera's 801 (801 Live and Listen Now) at just 19 yrs old. And yet over the years I lost touch with his work (solo, as well as an in demand session player), and before recently getting this recording I'd never heard of pianist Jeff Babko. So I'm pleasantly surprised by this album from 2000, and glad to be catching up with Phillips' nimble understated virtuosic drumming.While most of these tunes are composed by Babko and Phillips, alone and in collaboration, they sound like they'd fit right in to the 60's Blue Note era - a straight ahead jazz sound that also reminds me a lot of Zappa's early 70's bop/big band recordings (both Phillips and trumpeter Walt Fowler played a bit with FZ). While not especially original sounding the music here is full and fluid and the playing masterful - from both Babko and Phillips as well as Dave Carpenter on bass, Brandon Fields on tenor and soprano sax, and Fowler on trumpet and flugelhorn. The studio recording quality is excellent, but for me the highlight is the final track; an almost 16 minute live version of Freddie Hubbard's "Spirits of Trane", which gives both Phillips and Babko ample opportunity to show their chops.Overall an enjoyable listen. 4+ stars.

It's been years since I've felt this good listening to one of Hiatt's CDs.At this stage in life Hiatt writes and plays with a confidence and authority that is earthy and reassuring and carefree - as if he's happy just to be doing it, and doesn't really care what we think. This kind of relaxed mastery is refreshing in today's hyper self-counscious, ever slicker world of entertainment.He's one of those songwriters you want to listen closely to as his lyrics usually don't follow the predictable (besides the occasional throw-away, like his "Baby's Gonna Kick" and "Old People" here), and this is recorded so we can hear every word. Musically they have a comfortable familiarity that remind me of his work with Little Village, but also hints of The Pahinui Brothers, Kevin Coyne, Buddy Guy, John Lee Hooker, Muddy Waters, Bob Dylan, Tom Waits, old pirate shanties or something from O' Brother Where Art Thou. (My favorites on first impression are "Long Time Comin' ", "Marlene, "Wind Don't Have To Hurry", "Nobody Knew His Name", and "Come Back Home".)This CD must have been recorded really 'hot' because it has an intense in-you-face feeling - like seeing them playing up close in a small club, or practicing in a home studio. The DVD (part of the deluxe edition) of an October 2013 show at the Franklin Theatre ("in downtown Franklin Tennessee") is pretty good too - with fine audio and video - and his band "The Combo" backing him really well, especially Doug Lancio on guitars. Best of all, the show manages to practically span his whole career in just 10 songs (with 2 from this latest CD) - including a killer version of "Feels Like Rain".

Another fine release from the Zappa Family Trust, this soundtrack for the movie (A Token of His Extreme - an excellent, not to be missed, glimpse at how good this band and performance was) is top quality FZ - from my favorite era/band of his - recorded (but apparently not domestically broadcast) as part of a special concert on 8/27/74, at the studios of KCET in LA.As the liner notes note, these are also pretty much (with small additions/omissions) the same performances as released earlier on The Dub Room Special, but in "an entirely different mix." Different enough to be worth getting - especially the way the drums/percussion really jump out as being the heart of Zappa's music, as well as the omission of "Stevie's Spanking" and "Easy Meat" from The Palladium 1981 NYC Halloween show, which is just fine by me, plus the addition of "Oh No/Son of Orange County/More Trouble Everyday" which is even better.Besides being more live music from one of the best bands he ever assembled (the same as on the great You Can't Do That On Stage Anymore - Vol. 2), the highlights here, for me, are his innovative extended guitar soloing on Montana, Florentine Pogen, Stink Foot, Pygmy Twylyte, Inca Roads, Son of Orange County and More Trouble Every Day.My only (very minor) complaint is that the liner notes are pretty sparse, with the printed track numbers not matching those on the actual disc. Overall though, both the performances and sound quality are excellent (perhaps even tightened up a bit due to the more formal TV studio venue). Yet even this slightly more "normalized" performance couldn't get any airtime on mid-70's American TV (although it did play in Europe). Understandably it must have been frustrating for FZ to be continually dismissed and disregarded (even as he pushed conventions to the limit....). Finally it seems (40 years later!) Zappa can be appreciated for what he did as a composer-musician-bandleader-performer, and not just rejected for how he appeared... (Oh, and btw for a MUCH cheaper NEW copy, try Zappa's Barfko Swill website while they've still got 'em.)

Rusty Belle is new to me - discovered via their great contribution to Chris Smither's latest (Still on the Levee) - and I'm delighted. This CD, well produced by David Goodrich, who also produced Still on the Levee, offers a wide range of singer-songwriter/folk/americana music, combining great lyrics, excellent musicianship and a playful down-home spirit.Their style ranges from folk to rock, pop, old R&B, country, and blues. My favorites are "Sad Little Boys" which showcases Kate Lorenz's sultry contralto, "Words That Fit" which begins with a very Smither sounding acoustic guitar, "Change My Heart" (check out their playful video on youtube), "When We Were Older" which is achingly beautiful and would not be out of place on a Mary Gauthier recording (set to a tune Nick Drake could have written), "I'm Alive" (early rock verging on Beatlesque-based on a Richard Thompsonish rhythm) which I just can't get enough of, "The Waves" another Smither-sounding tune crossed with something Paul Simon might record, and  "Sink and Swim" another beautiful song with the lovely harmonies of brother and sister Matt and Kate.The packaging is a bit minimal - lyrics are included (although not that easy to read), but no listing of who's in the band or playing what (not hard to look up on their website, or from viewing their live performances on youtube). The youtube posts show just how these three are able to get such a rich sound out of such minimal instrumentation (all 3 do some form of percussion), and the website gives a short bio, letting me know they are from Massachusetts, formed in 2006, are comprised of Kate and Matt Lorenz and Zak Trojano and that this is their 6th CD. It won't be the last I hear of them... that's for sure.4+ stars.

This is a great little book, just brimming with facts and figures, statistics and upbeat anecdotes that make it clear that the world is (as John Lennon foresaw), "Every day, in every way, ...getting better and better."  So often pro-capitalist books are written by stogy and conservative seeming old men who, while often correct, seem to be speaking to and about an older century. This book by Johan Norberg, a relatively young Swede (born 1973), is remarkable in being for and about a younger generation of humans, which is overall healthier, wealthier, freer, better educated and more equal than any in history. It is about real positive change from the ground up (via the free market) instead of from central planners. Besides surveying the improving state of the world today Norberg also covers a wide range of topics that relate to capitalism, globalization and free trade (as well as simply and clearly defining them).This is the perfect book to encourage an optimism in those just getting started, an optimism sorely lacking in most media, political and academic accounts of life on Earth in the 21st century. This 2003 Cato Institute edition was originally written at the turn of the century and published in Sweden in 2001, and my only caveat in praising it is that it could use an update. A lot has happened in the past 11 years and it would be good to see (in the facts and stats and, Norberg's more mature attitude of today) how it continues to be positive for the majority of humans. It's this overall perspective that is so easy to lose track of - especially given the widely covered economic upheavals and sectarian military conflicts which have for many defined the first decade of this century.Life in the 21st century is full of serious challenges (and Norberg acknowledges these, while documenting how they are generally ameliorated by democracy and capitalism), but we're fully capable of meeting them and adapting and resolving and even, yes, thriving with them. The key word here is "we" - the global group of freely choosing individuals - that is the 100% which is easy to miss in the heated partisan debates. This 100% is what the inherently dynamic (creative/destructive) capitalist market nurtures and is nurtured by. The 21st century will either be the century of individual liberty (which the 18th, 19th and 20th centuries began recognizing and valuing, but only partly delivered), or it'll be much worse than anything we can imagine... My vote is for optimism.

This is a great collection of Chris Smither's songs, rerecorded with more lush, more mature instrumentation, yet it's all done in a way that feels natural and right, like the songs themselves have simply evolved with time.I first heard Smither at a small rural festival in 1992, it was a magical time, and I went home with his latest Another Way to Find You and an earlier It Ain't Easy CD. Over the next 15 years I collected almost everything else he produced. Then years later I discovered I had somehow ended up without any of these recording as they slipped into that foggy whirlpool of property division that is divorce, and I never bothered replacing them, as if they were part of a past I didn't want to try and revive.Today all those years and missing albums come back to me in a flood of relief and appreciation. These old songs (a selection of 24) are familiar yet rearranged and refined enough in the revisit to make them essential even if you have the originals. Being all rerecorded in June of 2013 they have the consistency of his voice and vision and virtuosity as it is "now". And his voice sounds great here, as does his rich and nimble instrumentation, along with some tasteful backing. Each time I listen to these CDs (and I've been listening to them a lot) I hear a new favorite - and it's perhaps most telling that his songcraft really shines through the clearest when someone else is sing them, like on the final track of disc 2 where Kate Lorenz of Rusty Belle does a beautiful version of "Leave the Light On".The material recorded here, going all the way back to 1970 and including something from all 12 of his studio albums (except his 2009 Time Stands Still), is impressive in itself, and the fact that he's put his latest touch on it is much more than just a cherry on top, or a new coat of paint, it's more like finding a cask of his single malt that has sat untapped for decades - so much better with aging. He's also added deluxe packaging (DVD size booklet  with nice and easy to read lyrics), which will make it a bit harder to store with the other CD, but probably guarantee greater notice/play.Although its great to see all these cuts having new life breathed into them, and some are absolutely beautiful, I'm finding I still like some of the stripped down originals more, but that just inspires me to finally repurchase those earlier albums. Seems to me that's the best kind of retrospective - new appreciation for the present and the past. Thanks Chris.

Ropes are like shoes or cars, no single type can fit all our needs. This Type A semi-static rope is great for rappelling and hauling, top-roping with a self belay, AND even top-roping in the usual set up (since it is designed to hold 9 factor one falls). That final use is what makes this rope unique. It also has great 'hand' (knotability, handling and coiling) for a static line, but it does sacrifice some durability in the sheath.My main use for static ropes is for climbing route development where I do a lot of rappelling, hanging on a Petzl Grigri 2 Belay Device, and self belaying with a Soloist, and I mainly use the Singing Rock R44 NFPA Static Rope for this, but this Edelweiss is my second choice - better feel, more versatility, lighter weight (70 vs 77g/m), and yet a little less abrasion resistance (sheath is 35% of weight vs 38%) compared to Singing Rock's 11.2mm. If you don't need the extra sheath strength, or can consistently protect the sheath on sharp edges, or are using it on smooth, less abrasive kinds of rock this is probably the better choice. Other options if you want greater durability is to go with the 10.6mm "caving" rope which is also a Type A rope (rated to 15 factor 1 falls) but has Everdry treatment which reduces water shrinkage to 1.5%, as well as having 37% of weight in the sheath, but only 71g/m weight! Or the (Edelweiss Static Caving 11mm Rope), but it is also a bit heavier than the Singing Rock 11.2mm.Overall 4+ stars for versatility, light weight and quality construction.4/30/15 edit - I've ordered this "static rope" 3 times now and every time I've received the "speleo" (listed separately here on Amazon in a longer length). The pattern is NOT the same as shown in the pic on this page (single red thread), instead it is a closely paired black/red thread pattern. It may be the same rope (different edition?), but I'm not sure any of this matters since the "product description" says it's a Type A (semi-static) rope. Edelweiss does recommend you soak the new rope in water to pre-shrink it before use - the spec sheet says it has 4.2% shrinkage in water (not sure why they don't do this at the factory...). With 3.5% working elongation this rope will stretch noticeably at much over 100' length. If need be to reduce stretch to a minimum tie off to an intermediate anchor point, or just get a fully static rope.

I really like this vocal CD from Artie, his last recording before his untimely passing on 7/20/08. It has tasteful and consummate musicianship as well as good songwriting (all originals either written by Artie or in collaboration with Wendy Waldman, John Sebastian, or Joe Flood - except for the great cover of the traditional folk ballad "Cuckoo Bird"). Artie's vocals aren't very strong, reminding me of some local artists I've known (or the voice of the also great guitarists Kelly Joe Phelps or Roy Rogers for someone perhaps more well known), but it is a kind of style that grows on one - especially with his thoughtful and tender lyrics, strong melodies, and great backup instrumentation.Artie was really a great guitarist, reminding me often of Martin Simpson here - for his skill and understated approach, and he also has some great support from Tony Levin (bass), Gary Burke (drums), Warren Bernhadt (piano), Joe Flood and Kenny Edwards (mandolin), John Sebastian (electric guitar) and Wendy Waldman, Donna Lewis, Amy Helm and Teresa Williams (backing vocals). The sound is more varied and less polished than his acoustic new-age/jazzy instrumental music, my favorite, other than the really strong "Cuckoo Bird", being the stripped down resonator guitar driven "Where the Blues Began", but this is a good thing. The overall quality reminds me of the easy listening yet masterful recordings Michael Franks made in the late 70's (when Artie was still playing Appalachian folk), and yet I'm mostly left feeling I've gotten to know Artie as someone unique, warm and easy going; thanks Artie! 4+ stars.

I've only recently discovered the music of Artie Traum, and as delighted as I am to finally hear this recording, I'm also saddened to learn he passed away in '08. I'd heard his name associated with guitar lesson books and videos for years, but didn't really know his music until listening to his early stuff with Woodstock Mountain Revue (the excellent collection - Music from Mud Acres). This recording finds him 25-30 years later getting together with some friends for some heartfelt duets. The result is wonderful, a range of jazzy instrumentals that combine influences of folk, country, bluegrass, world, swing, jazz, and prog-rock genres, but have a mellow 'new-agey' flavor all their own.Although each tune brings a new partner or group of partners, and slight twist of genres to the mix, the result is we also get to hear just how strong and consistently skillful Artie's playing is - an acoustic guitar style and sound that is crisp and full of swing and romance. Many of the cuts have a bit of magic due to the special guest, but it is Artie's playing and composing that ties it all together. I wasn't familiar with all these friends before hearing them here, but these are a few of the highlights to my ears;Track 1- The wordless vocals of Leslie Ritter and piano of Warren Bernhardt, combined with the acoustic slide of Traum, set the tone with a strong, moody, jazzy number that has the rare combination of driving rhythm and spacious exploration.Track 2- The combined Newgrass and Jazz influences of both Traum and mandolin master David Grisman make for a very satisfying and classical sounding jazz number.Track 3- John Sebastian's down home, back porch harmonica and guitar makes for some great soothing new-age folk music.Track 4- An aggressively fluid and jazzy acoustic guitar duet with Laurence Juber.Track 5- Gently swinging bluegrass/jazz thanks to the great Sam Bush (mandolin) and Bela Fleck (banjo).Track 6- Worldbeat rhythm with the varied percussion of Joachim Lartey and backing of Tony Levin (bass).Track 7- Romantic mellow Newgrass/Klezmer sound with the lovely fiddle playing of Jay Ungar and bassist of Molly Mason.Track 8- Easy listening Jazz with a subdued Levin on bass and Josh Colow on electric guitar.Track 9- More mellow Jazz with Bernhardt's pleasant understated piano playing.Track 10- Worldbeat/Prog-Rock influenced explorations with the electric guitar of Adrien Belew and bass of Tony Levin.Track 11-  Obviously a high point for Artie here, with The Band perhaps making a new country/jazz/rock sound - that works! (I'd swear David Gilmour sounded a lot like this on his '06 solo record "On An Island"!)Track 12-  A beautiful, gentle closing guitar duet with brother Happy.If there is any complaint with this recording its that it is perhaps too consistently slick and safe, but it is on the Narada label after all, and for that kind of smooth and even vibe it's both masterfully played and recorded! Also, if you like this kind of sound, I can highly recommend his later recording without so many guests (Last Romantic), which is even more consistent and soothing. R.I.P. Artie, thanks for all the sweet sounds!

Dave Soroka is the epitome of the great unknown musician/poet. He's the real deal, and yet he's been woefully under appreciated beyond the small crowds who get to attend his shows. He may have better collections of songs, but The Ladies of Summer is the best recorded to date (and only one available on Amazon). Recorded in '99 with the backing of some of Grand Forks, BC's best musicians (accompanying Dave's vocals, rhythm guitar and harmonica), on various guitars, dobro, bass, drums, piano, fiddle, mandolin, slide dobro and wonderful backing vocals ("Tequila Angle Choir"!).The tone is mellow and folky, and the lyrics warm and personal, yet poetic enough to transcend the Sorokaness of it all. If you're unfamiliar with Soroka, a solo performance of his song "Little Lazy" is available to watch on Youtube. It gives a good taste of his plaintive heartfelt singing and playing. 4+ stars.Track listing;Hey BeautyConsuelaThink of Me ComeradoI Ain't Going Down Like ThisFire of La JollaHey DarleneLittle LazyRight Here With MeLook Again Sweet Nora JeanClose Up the CantinaThe Ladies of Summer

Colin Wilson published this book in 1971, a time when humanity was apparently beginning to wake up en mass. Psychedelic drugs had already effected millions (usually for the better), and would continue to effects millions more. Same for Eastern religions and alternative spiritual practices. As they said, it was the dawning of the age of Aquarius, and this book set out to place "The Occult" in its proper perspective, as not just a system of naive pre-scientific magical thinking mumbo-jumbo, but as the "science of the future." In other words, the less obvious spiritual realm that the occult works with, and the less developed human faculties required for this work, will become more obvious and developed as we continue to evolve and increase our vibrational sensitivities. It is what we are growing INTO, not away from, and the sprinkling of historical mystery schools and masters have been the vanguard, and not just the lunatic fringe.By the late 70's I was well on my own way to doing this kind of work along with great numbers of my peers. I took psychedelic drugs seriously for awhile, then moved on to Eastern religions and meditational practices. The whole point of course was to have direct personal experience of the numinous, the unknown, the... occult. Almost 40 years later it is helpful to look back and see it all as part of the process Wilson foretold in this book. Especially since for much of that 40 years I have shied away from calling my practices or perspective, "occult" - thinking instead that referred to something more shadowy and less noble and wholesome. Wilson's book has helped bring me full circle and be able to embrace the larger evolutionary process we're all going through, and helping create.Wilson defines the fundamental proposition of magic or occultism as, there is "a kind of 'psychic ether' that carries mental vibrations as the 'luminiferous ether' is supposed to carry light." (p.52) If this is so then we are already effected by these vibrations unconsciously (as many other types of animals clearly demonstrate), but can also become conscious of them, and work with them. In other words our higher human function isn't just to look to understand the cause and effect of events via objective science, but to search for their meaning, for us, and live with a vivid sense of wonder (what Wilson calls 'Faculty X'). As he says in his introduction, "The higher the life form, the deeper its capacity for registering meaning, and the more powerful its hold on life" (p.31), and then later, "What I am suggesting here, and throughout this book, is that whenever man has a strong sense of the value of something, he activates his 'powers,' the powers that lie beyond the violet end of his mental spectrum." (p. 144-145)There is nothing flakey in Wilson's approach. It is really a thorough reference work by a skeptical yet sympathetic inquirer organized in three parts; 1) Wilson's broad survey of the subject, 2) A history of magic, focusing on the bios of some of its more famous (and infamous) adepts, and, 3) A look into the practices and realms these adepts were working with. Part of the relevance for me is that Wilson may have started as a non-beliver, but by the time he was finished researching and writing this history had a different appreciation and respect for the underlying reality and value of the occult. As such, this book is as much an intelligent critique of the limited approach of modern rational materialistic thinking (the masculine, solar path), as it is an exploration of the non-rational alternatives (feminine, lunar path), really seeking to move us forward out of our current rut, by integrating the two halves of the whole . As he says, "a science - or knowledge system - which has no place for will or purpose is an obstruction to human evolution, and at this particular point in history, a dangerous nuisance" (p.141).This history is a major work and contribution, detailed and complete and yet not dry or merely encyclopedic (reminding me a bit of Murchie's The Seven Mysteries of Life: An Exploration of Science and Philosophy), in fact more of a psychological or anthropological study than merely a history. For an example of the thrust and style of his writing here is a typical passage from page 136;"The first and most important step towards self-transformation is to grasp intellectually what I have explained in the preceding pages: that man was not intended for a lifetime of the 'worm-eye view,' any more than a bird was intended to spend its life on the ground. We have a natural faculty for 'pulling back,' for seeing things through the wide-angle lens, for switching on to more serious vibrations. For human beings, boredom and depression are abnormal - a failure to grasp their natural powers. My powers are wasted as long as my vision is narrow and personal. They are like a boxer who cannot get any force behind his punches at close quarters. And when my will has become passive through 'close-upness,' I fall into a dreamlike state in which illusion and reality are intermingled. I become trapped and tangled in my own narrow values, instead of remaining open to values that are greater than myself. For human beings are intended to 'connect' with values outside themselves and to become unaware of themselves as 'personalities.' "So the overall effect is an intelligent, sympathetic and practical appraisal of the occult, AND human nature. As he says in summary of the 16th century's 'Age of Magic' with the dawning of the 'Age of Reason', "A busy, energetic sort of person has no time for the supernatural, and his temperamental rejection of it makes him feel that his world of practical clear-cut issues is the only real one. It is a healthy instinct. We should bear in mind that nearly all children dislike the supernatural, except in ghost stories. This is not necessarily fear, but an instinctive need to confront a clear, simple world in which they can make decisions and shape their lives. Anyone who has ever loved science can understand this. There is something cold, hard and exhilarating about science... By comparison, the world of the occult is misty and damp, reminding man of his ignorance and encouraging him to adopt a passive attitude towards his existence." (p.276)Wilson obviously had an open and inquiring mind, and wrote engagingly on a vast and complicated subject, one which has, by definition, been cloaked in secrecy and misunderstanding. And yet, for me at least, the best part is that Wilson pulls "The Occult" out of its murky past, broadens and redefines it to seem more vibrant, positive and relevant to the evolution of all humanity, our destiny as just a conscious aspect of the whole...Highly recommended.

I agree with the previous reviewer. This book is refreshingly direct and irreverently anti-PC, intellectually stimulating and yet simply and clearly, even plainly, delivered. In an era that is habitually and institutionally anti-intellectual it is a breath of fresh air, even if it ends up seeming a bit obsessive and even shocking as it tracks the deep groove of what is probably a typical intelligent person's experience in life, of misunderstanding, under-appreciation, and the resulting bitter resentment (which inevitably flirts with madness...).As the author states in his preface, this is a fictional work of an inner aspect of his personality, ranting about things he is fed up with in modern society. And as the back of the book blurb says, it's "A dark portrayal of a thoughtful, intelligent man appalled by the stupidity and conformism of the grotesque inhabitants of the society in which he lives." Is it mentioned anywhere that this is droll British satire at it's finest - even if twisted by the modern world into a rather dark place. Well, it is.If you don't like the idea of such intelligent, brutally honest, articulate, genuinely insightful, occasionally misanthropic and psychotic monologues then pass this one by. The subject is, as the title says, about living an intelligent life, which requires conscious cultivation (just as we are told in the crux scene of Monty Python's The Meaning of Life, just before the corporate board meeting is attacked by the pirate accountants...), and a willingness to go against the social grain of mind numbing conformity and endless distractions. As the author warns, it is a rant, or more like cathartic vent, by a frustrated intelligent person (NOT to be confused mind you with an "intellectual"), and in some ways reads like a self-help book without much concern for the reader's self-esteem.I found all this quite fun and stimulative, which is about what I expected from the Amazon writeup. What I didn't know was how the actual writing would be. It's good. For example;"People don't like to see themselves for what they are, because, in most cases, they are stupid, lazy, shallow, selfish, unprincipled, amoral, prejudice-filled c#&*s with a sad, desperate desire to be respected, or at least accepted, by the other stupid, lazy, shallow, selfish, unprincipled, amoral, prejudice-filled c#&*s they surround themselves with.  It is these character traits that prevent people from becoming intelligent in the first place. The reason they don't become intelligent is that they don't practice thinking about anything in depth - and they don't put the effort into thinking about things, because they simply do not care about being principled and consistent in any way....  I have been lucky - I don't delude myself about that.  I have worked at my thinking skills, but I was born with the character traits that enabled me to develop them.  Initially, inquisitiveness is the key - the desire to learn and the capacity to find joy in discovery. This however, can easily flounder if you do not have determination...  Later, developing intelligence becomes a battle against the stupidity you find all around you. You need a certain degree of immunity from the diseased assumptions of the society you live in. Since most people's stupidity is rooted in their desire to conform, its important to nourish this immunity and nurture it as a source of pride. " (p.21-22)It is a small book, and at less than 100 pages is a fun, often funny, and quick read - my only complaint/suggestion to Mr Jameson is that this could easily be a chapter or two in a much larger more developed work. It might even be interesting to see all his little philosophical tracts combined and woven into something of larger scope. I don't know if his other books have the same "voice", but I suspect they do, but anyway if not, a larger novel could accommodate many different voices. As it is, in this short form I wouldn't call it great fiction (or even fiction most of the time), but it is memorable and thought provoking, and useful!I look forward to reading more of Jameson's books, and hope they continue to take this intelligent (if slightly unhinged) perspective in new and challenging directions.

I got this 1992 compilation (from the first 4 albums by the Woodstock Mountain Revue, which they recorded in 1972, '77, '78, & '81, and all sounding great here) because it includes the original version of Roly Salley's great song "Killing the Blues" (covered many times, but also available in an updated version on Salley's '05 solo album - Killing the Blues), but there are plenty of other songs to make it a keeper. I'm especially glad to discover a new favorite song ("Barbed Wire" by band leader Artie Traum).The sentiment is back-to-the-land Catskill hippies meet Bill Monroe and Earl Scruggs, while the sound ranges all over the bluegrass and folk map, reminding me at times of the Holy Modal Rounders, Jonathan Edwards, Jimmie Buffet, Brewer and Shipley, New Riders of the Purple Sage, John Hartford, Sam Bush, Darrell Scott, Kate and Anna McGarrigle and even The Waterboys.... yet they (apparently anyone in the local Woodstock scene they could round up for the recording sessions) are really just part of this larger late 20th century (real) country folk revival, sharing tunes and obviously just out to have a good time. Most of these 22 tracks have vocals, but there are also 4 fine instrumental banjo/fiddle/peddle steel/guitar/harmonica covers.Highly recommended for fans of down home Americana.

Years ago I heard Killing the Blues on the excellent 8 disc 1995 Rounder Records Hills of Home: 25 Years of Folk Music sampler, performed by Woodstock Mountain Revue (originally from Music from Mud Acres which was a selection from Woodstock Mountain Revue's first 4 albums from 1972-81..., and it also can be found on Rounder's more recent 4 disc sampler Rounder Records Story). Anyway, Rowland (then called "Roly") originally performed his signature song with simple guitar and banjo accompaniment, and its better than any and all of the many great covers done since then. It is so good (plaintively done in heartbreaking rawness but not sappy) that I later bought this collection of his songs (recorded in Vancouver BC in 2003) without a clue what it would be like.This collection, unfortunately his only solo recording - which other than "Killing the Blues" consists of songs written in '01-02, is much slicker than the Woodstock Mountain Revue's sound and covers a broader range of music (not just Appalachian folk), sounding at times influenced by the pop hooks of Jackson Browne or the Beatles (more specifically Paul McCartney) or even Van Morrison-like instrumentation or the simplicity of John Prine. Its always country sounding, but moves smoothly from Nashville pop to pop-jazz to pop-rock to pop-folk country. Especially the version of Killing the Blues which even though done at the same tempo seems much more upbeat than his original version, or even how it's usually covered.The main attraction of these songs is the songwriting itself, although they are also well played (the musicianship is consistently top-notch, while Salley's voice is not pretty as much as unique and expressive in an early Dylan fashion). I'm not sure Salley could be considered a "great" songwriter since he hasn't been very prolific, but the songs he has recored here have a rare quality like some hard earned deep sea pearls, which we can be sure he dove for himself.... Overall a 4+ star effort.

I enjoyed Werner Herzog's quirky documentary about life in the Antarctic, two of the high points being when I recognized the soundtrack as David Lindley's acoustic guitar, and the other seeing Henry Kaiser in action as an underwater photographer and ecstatically jamming on his electric guitar (regrettably missing from this CD). And I'm happy to find the soundtrack CD even better than the soundtrack on the movie (longer, more detailed and varied tracks).Kaiser and Lindley here continue their global cross cultural muse-ical collaboration - but unlike their recordings in Madagascar and Norway, and the diverse human influences there, in the antarctic, while they bring some of those musical influences (especially Lindley with his Scandinavian hardanger fiddle, and Malagasy sounding oud, cumbus, cittern and weissenborn guitar tunes), they are also exploring a mostly nonhuman world of snow and ice covered land and ice covered ocean.I kind of doubt Lindley ever went to Antarctica (this is mostly recorded in the studio in California), and his playing tends to be the warmer sounding, but he also gets nicely into the expansive open ended (yet sometimes pensive) spirit of the place (and that hardanger fiddle sounds so Arctic  - hauntingly cold, brittle, and desolate - in itself). This is clearly Kaiser's project (and passion), but he plays a surprisingly low key part, only really expressing his brooding, dissonant take on that frozen world in the opening and closing long pieces, and this is fine for me since I'm a huge Lindley fan. There is also the occasional backing from other musicians who do a good job of filling out the sound (glass instruments, double bass, percussion, cello and trombone), but mostly the mood is sparse and clean, and an odd balance of dark brooding "otherness" and bright upbeat liveliness (perhaps the essential contradiction of the great underinhabited continent).For those who enjoy BOTH Kaiser and Lindley, this is an enjoyable and rewarding listening experience.

I keep coming back to this CD, satisfied by the songwriting (especially the 7 penned by Robert Hunter and David Nelson, but also the others), and the musicianship (especially Buddy Cage's soaring pedal steel) much more than I thought I'd be. I'd even give it 4+ stars.Of course I listened to the original NRPS back in the day, didn't for a long time, and then decided to catch up with them more recently with their latest 17 Pine Avenue (also featuring a fresh batch of Hunter/Nelson songs), and then got this. And I like this the most since the classic The Adventures of Panama Red! A nice mix of country inflected rock, and some cookin' psychedisized jams.(Barracuda Moon seems like the greatest dance song this morning... like an undulating snake rising on the driving syncopated drumming and San Francisco infused guitar riffs, hard to imagine it not causing anybody to want to uncoil, and a nice continuity (of where they come from) with Hunter adding an oblique reference to the first set of his lyrics The Dead recored, "Barracuda, Barracuda, Barracuda Moon - Fiddler on the heart string give another tune - Barracuda Moon, Baby, Barricuda Moon - Ain't no alligator just a Barracuda Moon" - as well as more obviously to his unreleased 1978 album Alligator Moon. And finally to help make sense of this little tangent, according to The Complete Annotated Grateful Dead Lyrics, "Alligator n. (1920s-1930s) a usually though not necessarily pejorative term probably coined by Louis Armstrong to describe musicians who stole ("followed") the ideas of black players.")My only regret is that unsure of the quality of this album, I made the mistake of getting a used copy in "VG" condition at first which had just enough scratches to not play on my higher end home stereo... so I'm back this morning to get a new copy, and while at it pick up the alternative version (Where I Come From - Radio Mixes & Live Bonus), reputed to be even better than this one!It's great to know muse-ic and the muse-ic-ians who play at the Muse's indulgence may always change, but also just continue to do the timeless multi-hued serpent dance.

As the Camel website says about this new recording, "The Snow Goose has been lovingly re-recorded. Faithful to the original with tasty arrangements and enhancements for stage presentation, The Snow Goose is not only a timeless story of love and war. It is a tale of dignity and kindness lifted to the heart on the wings of an injured Snow Goose through her unique relationship with two humans. Written by Paul Gallico, this short story inspired this beautiful music."This studio recording from May of 2013 (subsequently presented on their fall '13 tour) is a faithful re-presentation of the 1975 classic (same order for the tracks, with some extended bits), with perhaps a slightly more passionate and mature sound - enhanced by the more symphonic arrangements, and a richer recording quality. Only composer/guitarist Andy Latimer remains from the original group, yet they sound like Camel to me! This does not replace the '75 recording (if you don't have that one yet I'd recommend the deluxe '09 edition - Snow Goose), but it makes a fine addition to the story.Note - So far ALL the reviews on this Amazon page are for previous editions of the original recording. This imported one (watercolor painting cover), while expensive, is new and different enough to recommend it to any Camel/Snow Goose fan.

This privacy screen was advertised as 4-way privacy, and I even got feedback from other Amazoners that it is. Well, it is NOT. It only works in portrait mode. I have my doubts and unfortunately they come true.

I should have review the picture on the website. This privacy screen only works in PORTRAIT mode as shown in website's picture, not landscape. And there is no where in the description to tell of this fact. If you look for a privacy screen in landscape mode, look to other product.It works well portrait mode. You have to be right in front of the phone to see what on screen, the curious guy sits next to you on the airplane can't see what on screen. I am not sure this screen provide any drop protection, but it would do well to protect against scratches and bumps. It of course will reduce your iPhone's resolution and brightness, but it's worth the privacy.I gave it three stars because I expected a landscape mode privacy screen. The manufacturer should have spelled that out in the description.

I can't believe I got this bag for less than 10 bucks!! Well, the first bag I ordered was $14,then the price dropped down to $9.90 and at the time of this writing, it is $8.80. Get it quick before Amazon changes their mind! This bag should worth at least $25.The only thing about this bag that I need to get used to is it's a left hand bag (I think) That is, you wrap it over your right shoulder across your chest. But it doesn't matter to me. It's a fantastic bag, with one big compartment to store whatever, and 2 more smaller one that could easily fit gym clothes or a tablet. You could really store a 13" laptop in the big one with lots of room to spare. The bag's designed to hold a water bladder, but I don't use it for that. I could easily see using it as a carryon for long trip. The front one has little pockets to hold pens, paper or passport. A side mess bag could hold a small water bottle or cell phone. There are tons of loops to hold whatever and round carabiner. I have both colors, black and olive, I really like to olive color, looks really cool.As I said this bag is a fantastic buy. You will not regret it if you end up getting two (like me).

This must the best Chromebook you could buy for less than $500. Yes, you could spend as little as $150 for a usable Chromebook or as much as over a thousand dollars for a Pixel, but why? It is a Chromebook after all. Of course, touch screen feature begins to appear in some Chromebook (and costs more), but I failed to see the justification for spending more than $500 for one. Most decent Chromebooks area in $200-$300 range, but this Toshiba Chromebook 2 is much better buy with just another $100 more.To begin with, the Toshiba Chromebook 2 came with HD screen and gorgeous colors. Play a high definition movie on it is a whole different experience. Almost as good as my MacBook Pro, but you are talking about an Apple machine that cost 3 times more. The Chromebook has 3 expansion ports: 1 USB 3.0, 1 USB 2.o and slot for SD card. It also has a HDMI output, so you can also use it as your media player. I bought a 128GB compact USB 3.0 drive and plug it in permanently, so I now have a very nice laptop, no moving parts with a lot of fast local storage space. The features that make this Chromebook a far better machine than other Chromebooks are Intel I3 CPU and Skullcandy sound system. It is fast and sounds awesome in the headphone and external speakers! This Toshiba Chromebook also features backlit keyboard and a really nice trackpad (again, almost as nice as the one on my MacBook Pro – the only gesture missing is three-finger dragging).The setup of this Chromebook was a bit tricky at first. I entered the same network password 3 times, even flipped the switch to see what I was typing, only to have it told me wrong password was entered. Then suddenly it worked and I had no trouble connecting to new network since. Since I already have a Gmail account and Chrome browser configuration, I can sign on and start using the Chromebook immediately.This Chromebook is about ¾” at the thickest part and a weight bit over 2 lbs. Very nice texture outside, 13” screen is just about right for all types of work and entertainment.So why would you spend $450 for a Chromebook when with the same money you can buy a laptop? Simply put, you laptop is much heavier, more software licenses to worry about, probably becomes obsolete in a couple of years and probably comes with nothing worth bragging about hardware. On top of that, you constantly have to worry about virus and upgrades. None of those exists in Chromebook.  I own several laptop devices and tablets, include Windows PC, MacBook Pro, Chromebook, iPad and Android tablets. But I believe this Chromebook is the most practical and my favorite machine for around the house use and road trip. It starts up in seconds and you never have to worry about virus and security. As I mentioned in my other reviews, 90% of the population need only a Chromebook for their daily life and work.

About the only thing bad about this pair of pants is the price. My wife complained that she wants more of these, but did not think $60 is a good price especially she only wears to the gym and sweats in them. Well, I guess you have to pay for quality.The pants is super comfortable, with wide waist band and nice, soft, breathable material. Print pattern is "so cool", my wife's words. She said it looks even better in real life than in picture, and feels really good. This pair got my wife's vote, and she is not impressed easily.

The Boneco Air Purify P500 system came in an attractive package and fully assembled, you only need to unbox, open the front cover, take the plastic wrap off the included filter and plug it in. Then pull the plastic tab off the remote control, then turn it on.There are five fan speeds, with five is the strongest.  I started out at second speed and you can hardly hear the fan noise. At fifth speed, you can definitely hear the fan. I let it run for about an hour in fifth speed, then drop down to third.  At third, you almost can’t hear the fan noise, as it is overcome by other white noise.  It is quiet enough that I put it in our bedroom. The air filter provided enough air circulation that I did not need to keep my ceiling fan on with the cool weather.I can feel the significant improvement in our air quality in the morning. The air seemed cleaner and our allergies seemed disappeared. We sleep very well last night too.  But only one night, so we will see if it really worked in a week.  Our bedroom is less than 200 square foot, below the size specified for this air filter. I would not recommend using this filter for room larger than 200 sq. ft.The system comes with an allergy filter standard, so it is just right for what we need. It is expensive to replace ($99), but for good night sleeps it is a bargain. We finally found an air filter that really works!

The case was shipped with frustration free packaging, but it ended up frustrating me to no end as I found it impossible to take it apart to put my phone in! No instruction enclosed, so I had to go to Otterbox website. The only information I found was in the FAQ section, where it said to peel the silicon back out until it is separated completely. There is no video for iPhone 6 plus, so I viewed one for the HTC Defender case as I think they must be similar. Well, it is impossible to do.The silicon back seems like welded shut to the case and guess I don't have enough finger strength to open it up.I gave up after  about 30 minutes fighting with it, so have no information on its operation.From the outside, it is longer and wider than my Otterbox Commuter case about 1/4" and 1/8" thicker too. And believe me, the Commuter is big enough to feel uncomfortable in my jean pocket, I hate to think how this case fit. You need to have a large pocket or really loose jean to keep the phone + Defender case in your pocket. It is measure 3 1/2" wide x 6 1/2" long and 1/2" thick. It looks like it will protect your phone well.

There isn't a lot of cases designed for Samsung Galaxy Tab S 8.4, Most of them are decent, but nothing worth bragging about. From a personal preference standpoint, I would give this case 3.5 stars, but it meets everything it was advertised for, hence the 4 star rating. Like most cases designed for this tablet, there is no portrait mode so it is a bit awkward to read a magazine. eBook is ok as they can be read in either mode.The cover has a nice feel to it, not slippery so you have no worry of it slipping out of your finger. The inner also smooth so you don't have to worry it scratches your tablet screen. Tri-fold cover provides 2 viewing angles and when closed DOES NOT put the tablet to sleep, so this is a consideration when buying. There is still a gap between the cover and tablet, so stuffs might get into between. Four rubber straps hold the tablet at 4 corners and they look strong enough. If one of them ever breaks, this case would become useless.If you have time to look for a case, there are better options. For me, this tablet case is just another also-ran.

I bought this Otterbox case to be used in my long weekend bicycle rides or when I am on vacation, when I spend a lot of time outdoor. The iPhone 6 Plus is big, and this case made it even bigger! Could hardly fit in my jean pocket, but the protection it provides is more than worth it. I have not drop my phone yet, so can't really say how it performs.  All ports and buttons are at the right places and nice to hold in your hand .Then I discovered an issue with this case. The case comes in 2 parts: a soft rubber  inner and hard plastic outer shell. Very clever design; as if you drop the phone, most vibrations transferred from the hard plastic shell will be absorbed by the inner layer and keep your phone safe. This has got to be the best part of the case. But then when took it into a dry sauna room after a work-out session..After less than 10 minutes, the entire case got heated up so much (and retains the heat too) that my iPhone shut down and display the message "High temperature, iPhone is not available" or something like that. I had to walk out of the sauna, go to the car and put  my phone in front of the AC vent to cool it down. I have use my phone in the sauna before with other cases and this never happened. So the heavier the case, the more heat it absorbs and retain longer.Other than this, I love the case.

This case is a just a simple, minimalist bumper case for your iPhone 6. It fits my iPhone 6 as expected and shown it was designed for just iPhone 6, but I guess it would fit the 6s as well. Nothing special about the case, I would bet that it provides less protection for your phone than other Otterbox cases.The one feature that I like about the case is its clear back. It shows off my gold version iPhone well and does not add that much more weight or bulk to the phone. But of course, with any Otterbox case, you always trade weight and size for extra protection. This case would give your phone more protection than most other cases. All openings and buttons are exactly at the right places.

Well it’s not quite 10 minutes.  But if you think about from unboxing to put on a couple of steaks, it could be around 10 minutes. Get some help from your significant other to lift the grill up, lock it into places and tighten the wing-nut to lock in the braces, then connect the propane tank and arrange the grill plates: it is truly around 10 minutes. If you count installing the side burner and shelf, install the front doors and tighten all the screws, it could take around 30 minutes. Note the 30 minutes; it is a far cry from what it takes in my gas-grill assembling experiences that it often took somewhere from 2 hours to half a day. All grill manufacturers should learn from Hamilton Beach; that no one enjoys putting a grill together. This grill is so simple; the whole thing involves tightening less than 10 screws!The grill was shipped to me in a big square box, weight around 50 lbs. It has some minor damages from shipping; one of the doors was dented and a couple more dents at various places, but generally still works. They could do better in packing and transport. The grill was provided to me free for evaluation, otherwise I would return it if I spend almost $500 and receive a less than perfect product. I used a pair of pliers to fix the dents so the door would fit.Now, about the grill: it is awesome! There are 4 burners with steel plates on top to radiate the heat. Nothing needs to be added. Four heavy iron grates on top, about a couple of inches on top of the steel plates to get the heat up quickly. The burners could be turned on individually to control the heat or just simply use part of the grill if you cook only a couple of steaks to pieces of chicken.  All knobs have igniters built-in, and it took about 5 seconds to light the grill. There is also a large thermometer dial on the grill lid.The grill comes with a generous sized burner. This may be the feature that get used the most, now you have the option to fry without getting the house smelling like a burger joint. The side burner is operated with the same big knob with built-in igniter. A satisfying click to light it up.Despite the minor dents, the grill looks beautiful with brushed stainless steel. Four wheel casters let you move it easily (btw, you don’t even have to install the wheels, they came pre-assembled). It has all features you need and a very decent price around $450.I love this grill and highly recommend it.

This is the best way to make French coffee. The traditional way is to put coffee ground into a special filter, then pour in hot water and let coffee drip down to a cup below. Well, I did that for most of my life. Then I switched to a coffee press. It is better, but not quite the taste I was looking for. So I looked for this on Amazon and found this amazing espresso maker! I used to have this same thing to use when I went camping and still remember how the coffee tasted. Believe me, try it and you never go back to anything you used before.This espresso maker is simple to operate. Put coffee ground in the filter, fill the botton reservoir with water, screw the top part on and put on the stove. After 3, 4 minutes, water start boiling and thick, dark coffee start flowing to the top cup. Wait a few seconds, then you have a hot, rich and thick cup of out of this world coffee.

I was shocked to see how compact this printer is upon unboxing it. It fit neatly on my wife's home office desk, along with her double monitors, keyboard, mouse, phone and a whole bunch of other unamed things. I have a couple of other printers already, included an Epson Workforce 450, but this printer is quicky becoming my favorite one.We use this printer primariy for scanning and occasional image printing, so it fits the purpose well. There are incredible number ways to scan, from scanning to local SD card to cloud, email and computer.. Epson seems to have them all figured out and extremely easy to set up.Settign up this printer took all of 20 minutes using the excellent color LED screen and I had the printer on my wireless network. Like other reviewers said, you need to know its limitations and purposes you get the printer for. I have no plan to use this printer heavily, more in scanning and some printing so it fit my wife just fine. Loading the paper to back feeder seems like a negative point, but to my wife it actually a plus. No complicated tray loading to deal with, just drop some paper to the feeder and done. It is wireless, so you can put it anywhere your netwrok can reach.This is an exellent wireless inkjet printer for light printing and copying, and incredible scanning capabilities. Love it.

This is not your regular old safety glasses. I am not a shop guy, so only need safety glasses occasionally when cut my grass or trim tree branches. But I found a lot more use for this pair fo safety glasses for my outdoor activities. The glasses were designed thoughtfully with features that when wearing it, you would think they are an expensive pair of sunglasses. I have a medium to large face and this pair fits me really well, so comfortable that rival those expensive glasses I had. I worn it for a couple of days now driving to work and one 3-hour bike ride. Especially on the bike ride, I felt much safer that they will protect my eyes from road debris much more than my regular riding glasses. The polarized amber color greatly increased contrast and cut down lots of glare. Oh yeah, they look good too!The only complaint I could have is it is folded big and I don't have a case for it. Of course, it wouldn't fit into your pockets or bike jersey's pocket with all other stuffs I had in it. But I like it a lot, and recommend it for all of your outdoor activities.

It took me almost an hour to put them together. One of the chair's leg was slightly uneven, but I adjusted it by loosen a chair foot. I recommend you to get a ratchet wrench; there are only 8 screws per chair, but in tight space. You can use the supplied wrench, but I think it will take you a long time. And it was pretty awkward, especially when attaching the back.All cushions have nice, rich color and throw pillows provide a nice contrast. I have them in my cover patio, so about the only thing I would worry about is dust. I can see dust get into the chair nooks & crannies and it could be hard to clean. Guess you could wash them with garden hose, but then you have to wait for it to dry before use. I just put a cover on them while they are not being used. The table was easy to put together; all legs fit a certain way, you would know if you put them together wrong. Top of the table is just a plain old ceramic tile, but it is a good opportunity to replace it with something you like.Price is a bit steep, but my wife (an expert in shopping) thought it was a good deal for Amazon's price. I took her word for it. Overall, I couldn't be happier with the chair set.

This is a pretty cool selfie tool. The handle extended out to almost a meter (around 3 feet) and came with a compact Bluetooth camera remote. Collapse it and its total length is about less than 9 inches. The phone attachment is sort of a grip with soft rubber, you can tighten it a bit without worrying hurting your phone. I used it fully extended with my iPhone 6 plus, and I can see I start losing my grip a little bit. Anything smaller than the iPhone 6 plus should work great with this. The telescoping handle bent just a little bit, almost unnoticeable.The Bluetooth remote paired quickly with my iPhone and work great with iPhone's native Camera app. But when I tried it with other camera apps like Manual and FiLMC Pro, it only  turned up the ringer! Wish there is a way to make it works with all camera apps. Regardless, the remote is small and you can practically attach it your keychain. The other useful feature is standard 1/4" screws on both ends of the handle. You can attach it on top of a tripod for selfie with your phone, or attach a compact camera to the top screw (of course, you need someone to push the button it your compact camera does not have bluetooth).It's a feature-packed selfie tool, and I really like it.

The bottles are hefty, but of really high quality. Caps are big and screwed in easily and tight. I put them into a dishwasher to clean them every few days or so and used them to drink water instead of plastic bottles. Feel much better that I don't have to throw away plastic bottle and easy to keep clean. I expect to use them many years to come, that if I don't accidentally drop them on the tile floor!

This must be the coolest invention for grilling! Received it this morning and I put it to a try this afternoon with a thick, juicy rib-eye steak. It turned out perfect, just like I expected. Before the iGrill, I relied on my thermometer to check my steak and of course, this involved opening the grill and stabbing my steaks several times. The same for chicken and pork. Now, all I have to do is select what I cooked and let it the iGrill Mini tell me when. I took the plunge and let it tell me with my first steak, and it came out perfect.Your have to download the app from the app store, then pair the iGrill with your iPhone. Within the app, there are tons of recipes for everything you grill under the sun, and section of presets for what you cook, from kabob to Omaha steaks. But I guess, like me, you mostly will cook steak, fish, chicken or pork and this iGrill will not fail you. I love this, and it is time to retire my trusty thermometer!

This device worked so well that I ordered a second one! I have an old Lexus SUV that was manufactured before bluetooth become popular. Several years ago, I tried the FM transmitter that attached to the iPhone/iPod and they worked ok for awhile. Got a lot of signal interference when going under power lines or some strong antennas. Well, this device love all those problems and more.It was easy. You'd pair it with your phone like any other Bluetooth devices. Then select a radio frequency, best to pick one that is not used in your area. Tune your radio to that frequency and that was it. Play the music/videos on your smartphone or tablets and audio comes out of your car radio like magic! The phone function worked extremely well, making call or receiving call and the music stops and picked up at that spot when the call ends. Sounds of course come out of your car speaker.  This feature could cost hundred of dollars if comes with the car. If I use Siri on the iPhone, I could even use voice dialing. Oh, you can even charge your phone with the built-in USB port!It worked so well for me I ordered a second one for my other car!

I have been to houses that have this type of attic vent and I can tell you, it was amazing even in the summer in Texas. So I was excited to receive this fan and install it in my house.A word of caution: if your house does not have a gable, forget this fan as it is the wrong attic fan. You need one that mounted under the roof vent. And if your house does not have a gable vent, try to get help from a carpenter as it will require cutting hole in the gable and installing a vent or shutter outside. Including the fan, it could cost you around $500 to have a gable vent with fan.  My house already has a gable vent, so I was lucked out.There are plenty of Youtube videos showing you how to install this and you can really do it yourself with some patience. I used a sheet of plywood,cut a hole to fit the fan, mount the fan on and nailed it to the frame of my gable. Then connect the electricity, set the temperature to 105 degree as per the instruction. That was it. It still took me half a day and countless trip to the attic. I did plan a head of time and start early morning while it was still cool. It's still spring in Texas, so I have not heard the fan come on yet. But I am confident that I will see significant saving this summer as some of my friends have.

My Dad finally is convinced that he will need some help walking around on those days that his knees and back hurts. We thought this would be great and he should use it all the times, but the man is still too proud! But he seems to like this rollator, for the simple fact that he could stop, rest and sit on the sturdy seat provided.Assemble the rollator took around 30 minutes for me, and another 10 minutes or so adjusting it to the height he felt comfortable with. He use it mostly in the house and our back yard concrete patio. Occasionally he took it for a walk around the neighborhood block. The 6" wheels are perfect for hard pavement, as long as he stays away from pot holes or large road cracks. Looped handbrakes worked well, and could lock the collator to convert it into a seat, with padded brace for his back. I am not sure if it could use safely as a wheel chair, but I guess if you need it then it would do for a short time.I am happy that this works for him, but also sad to see once proud man has to resort to this kind of aid to move around. Guess we will all be there someday!

This is a very high quality case for iPhone 6 and it is as good as it gets. I don't think you can find a better one out there. If you are looking for one that fits the phone like glove, beautiful color and texture, slim and adds virtually no weight and bulk to your iPhone, look no further.Most cases for iPhone hide the phone beautifully design, but not this one. It actually enhances the look of the iPhone. Yes, price is  a bit steep (~$50), but it is within the range and costs just as much as many lower quality cases out there.

This review is for the 13.3" Privacy Screen.This is a 4.5 stars Privacy screen..The screen felt good quality, thick with good color tranfer. Even with the screen on, I saw hardly any degradation on resolution or color changes. Viewing angle is narrow, I would bet that the guy sits next you on the airplane will not see what on your screen. Some blurry image may be visible in the dark, but in relatively bright light you won't have to worry.The screen covers my 13" MacBook Pro fine, with about 1/2" overlap the display area. I chose the shiny side out to match with the MBP screen. The screen attached to the monitor with 4 small piece of sticky double sided tapes. The screen actually has suggested places for sticky tapes, but when I put the tapes there, they overlapped the corner of my MBP display. I had to take them out, reposition the tapes then attach it again. It is also a bit pricey, cost almost twice of that of a regular privacy screen, that was why I took half a star off. Belkin also provided a plastic folder to keep your screen while it is not being used. Extra 4 sticky tapes provided for future use.But this definitely a high quality, works as advertised screen and I highly recommend it.3/23/15 UPDATE: After using the screens for a few days, I found another improvement that Belkin can make. While the screen fit my 13" MBP perfectly (BTW, I also have the 11.6" screen and it fits my Dell Chromebook perfectly too), it is a bit inconvenient when you need to take the screen off temporarily. Such as when you need to show co-workers something on your screen. Then you have to spend a little bit of time putting it back. If Belkin provides some holders that you could slide the screen in and out that would be great. Rating is still 4.5 stars in my opinion.

I actually spent more time removing the old, nasty ceiling fan than assembling and hooking up the new fan.  I have an old home (25+ yrs) and the previous owner was very creative, he rigged up this contraption that took me more than a couple of hours to undo, including a trip to the attic.The whole assembly is pretty light weight, so you can be assured that any existing electrical light fixture would hold up the fan just fine. Just like all the ceiling fan you worked with before, the fan came in a kit. Some part was put together, but most were not. You have the options to use the short down rod or connect closed to the ceiling. I have some clearance so I chose the down rod option.From then on, I just follow the instruction on the excellent owner guide. Please beware that the installation steps started from section 3. Follow it step by step and you should be ok. It took me less than an hour from attaching the holder to electrical box to turning the fan on, sitting back and enjoy. And I am by no mean a professional, just a handyman wannabe. If you can get a friend or significant other to help, it would be even faster and easier. There was a couple instances that I wished I have 3 hands! The fan light was designed for both one switch (turn light on/of with pull chain) or separate light/fan switch.The fan blades’ rich cherry color matched my wood floor like it was designed for it.  It is balanced and quiet like it was installed by a professional. Brush nickel for the fan housing gave it a look of sophisticated contemporary. Three 60W light bulbs were supplied with the fan, but I don’t think they are bright enough for me. I will replace them when I come by the hardware store next.So this ceiling fan is an excellent choice. Easy installation, quiet, move a lot of air with its five-blades and 3 fan speeds, and look awesome! Price is good too.

iXpand is another ingenious product from Sandisk. It instantly adds 16, 32, 64 or 128GB of storage to your iPhone or iPad, depends on what you buy. Compact and slim, it easily fits in shirt pocket and takes virtually no space in your briefcase.What I love about this flash drive is it frees you from iTunes! Copy photos or videos to this drive using any computer to access from your iPhone or iPad later. There were so many instances that I had to copy pictures to another flash drive, took it home and transfer to my iPad via iTunes. Yes, you have to add another app to your iPhone or iPad but it's well worth it.One thing should be noted is you can only transfer photos and videos from the Photo folder, i.e those that captured with your iPhone or iPad's camera. I could not yet find a way to copy a video from the Movie folder.The iXpand drive came precharged so you can use right away. It can be charged by plugging in a USB port of any computer. Use it like any other flash drive to copy files, and you can access them through the iXPand app, including movies, photos and music. Also remember that the iXpand drive is only a backup device, you cannot copy files from the iXpand to your iPad. Copy to the iXpand is easy and fast; just select the file and specify where you want them copy to.One thing Sandisk could improve on this drive is include a USB extension cable. The drive is pretty wide, more than 1", so may not fit in some tight laptop spot or make the next USB ports useless until you remove the drive. A good manual on the iXpand Sync software would also be nice, I can figure out how after playing with it a bit, but I can certainly imagine some users might have trouble with it.All my flash memory products are from Sandisk and they just last and work all the times, so I expect the same performance from this drive. This is definitely an alternative to paying for the next larger memory size iPad or iPhone.3/15/15 Update: I downloaded a copy of the user guide from Sandisk website and found out that you can copy photo and videos back to the iPad/iPhone, but only to the Camera Roll.

First, this is Dell Chromebook 11 – 3120 (early-2015), unlike the version you would find if you use the Service Tag to find your machine on Dell Support website. Enter that service tag and Dell website would return the early-2014 version instead.I had the Samsung Chromebook 2 Octa 5420 11.6, purchased in the Fall 2014, a couple of months after its release (it is currently being used heavily by my nephew who is in 5th grade), so I am very curious to see the differences between the two Chromebooks. As they both use the latest Chrome operating system/browser, the software is exactly the same on both machines.  The advantages of Chrome is I have the same set up on both machines as there is one single profile; log on the machines using the same Gmail account and you get the same environment. I have not touched the Chromebook for months, but got my same set up when logging into the new machine.I don’t think there are pros and cons between the two machines. They have different CPUs, but performance basically the same. You get the same snappy responses, fast network, quick start up, 8-9 hrs. of battery life and same software look and feel.  Prices are almost the same too. Below are the differences I observed:• Dell uses SD card reader – Samsung has microSD slot that you could add more permanent storage: With Dell, you could hot swap full size SD cards as often as you wish, it takes a little more work to swap microSD card on Samsung. But you can leave the microSD on the Samsung permanently, while with Dell you probably have to remove it when put in your briefcase.• Dell includes ability to lay flat, keyboard and screen open flat – Samsung does not: I can see situations when you want to do this, but not often.• Dell Chromebook is soft rubber: the screen has some flex to it and edges are wrapped with soft rubber so protected from scratches and dings.• Weight:  minor different in weight. I have not weighted them, but at this level who cares about the differences of a couple of ounces.• Look: Samsung Chrome book looks much better with smooth, shiny silver shell. This Dell Chrome book looks like an inconspicuous a laptop like thousands of others.As my review for the Samsung Chromebook, I think this Chromebook is good for 90% of users, especially for students. I once brought my Chromebook with me on a 2-week trip and never found the need for my full featured MacBook Pro. You could actually do 90% of your daily task on this machine. It is the best for browse the net, reading email and magazine, watch videos and movies such as from Netflix. Pack a few movies on a SD card and you are good to go!I love this machine as much as my Samsung Chromebook. It is a toss-up between the two of them.

This is a great phone if you are going oversea and do not want to take your expensive iPhone 6 plus with you. Or you have a small phone and want something bigger without taking a second mortgage of your house. Or you just simply want a small tablet. I won't review Android Kit Kat here, I defer it to other more qualified users. I can only talk about how I used the device as a phone/camera/video plaback device.First thing I saw that is negative about this phone is its speaker. It is very weak, it is actually impractical to carry on a call on speaker phone. The phone volume itself is not that great either, most time I have to use a headset to get clearer voice.
