Nice drape and the same smooth solid red on both sides (none of that nasty white plastic-y backing that most other blackout curtains use) and it IS total blackout.  I used it as a canopy around my bed and I leave my windows open and close the canopy around my bed - hanging from ceiling tracks down to the floor - and I don't even know if the sun is up or not in the morning until I open the curtains and come out.

I have become obsessed with Moroccan and other middle eastern style decor lately, and was searching for ways of duplicating the incredibly rich, multi textured designs of Moroccan interiors as well as Indian temples and other design elements uses on walls and windows.  Without spending a ton for the real thing (carved wood window grills, wall tiles, wrought screens etc.) I took a chance on this roll of border contact paper (essentially that is what the material is, the same stuff you line your drawers with) combined with some window squares (Wall Pops WPP0275 Honeycomb Decorative Hanging Room Division Panels) in hopes they would sort of create that certain feel and look and was really amazed and delighted with the fantastic impact these contact paper borders made on the walls around my windows.  I mean I really am IN LOVE with them - it makes the plain old ugly cement walls look like thick architectural elements of a Moroccan interior covered with beautiful tiles.  I've been looking around the rest of my apartment to think how I can add MORE of this.  Maybe the larger design squares.  And let me say also how EASY it was to roll it on. It's easy to re-position if you don't get it on totally straight at some point, but it sticks really WELL - even if you don't prep the surface (I had lots of built up dust and grime from the city air blowing in my windows on the window sills and peeling paint - I didn't clean or remove the curling up paint or anything - and this stuff just stuck right on top, made everything look clean and new, looks AMAZING and is not peeling off ANYWHERE. It's a revelation in wall paper borders - I was thinking the whole time "this is not your grandmother's wall paper...."
The valances really look sumptuous and top off my bed canopy curtains for a finished look perfectly.

I gathered 8 different powdered sugars available in the U.S., U.K. and Australia, trying to find something without the chalky gritty texture and did a taste test by mixing each into a milk and sugar glaze icing.THE CONTENDERS:{Powdered sugar:}[1] Dominos, [2] Bundaberg, [3] Tate & Lyle, [4] Miss Roben's, [5] Hain Organic, and [6] India Tree{Powdered invert sugar:}[7] CK Dry Fondant and [8]C&H Bakery Drivert (Domino's)THE RESULTS:[1] Dominos (with corn starch) - the one I grew up with. Has a distinctive taste of sugar and powdered dry wall.[2] Bundaberg Pure Icing Sugar (from Australia) (no starch) -  Has a good basic plain pure sugar taste, but fairly crunchy/gritty for powdered, even without any starch. Though I couldn't find what equivalent "X" count Bundaberg is rated, I'm guessing it's something like the coarser "commercial grade" 4X or 6X (as opposed to the finer 10X "consumer grade" typical of Dominos and most other consumer powdered sugar). I read on blogs some people don't like the extra gritty texture, while others claim without the starch it makes a smoother, less clumpy butter cream frosting. I'd have to test that another time. For the simple glaze though I didn't like being able to taste and feel the grit.[3] Tate & Lyle Icing Sugar (UK) (Maize starch) - I ordered this specifically because everywhere I looked on the internet sites where this product was mentioned or listed, it did NOT have corn starch, and instead had "anti caking agent E341". It arrive overseas finally, and sadly, it appears they are now using "maize [corn] starch" and no longer E341 (Calcium Phosphate). I was very disappointed.[4] Miss Roben's corn free powdered sugar (tapioca starch) - tastes a little off, everyone noticed when given a taste test comparison, and the tapioca starch is no less gritty than corn starch.[5] Hain Organic Powdered Sugar (Evaporated cane juice) with corn starch - has a much fuller sugar taste than all the rest, due to the fact that it's the whole evaporated cane juice - a rich hint of the molasses fills your mouth. Tastes great but when you don't necessarily want extra flavor and just want the sweetening - it wouldn't be my first choice. Plus, also due to the fact that it's not as refined, that trace of molasses does give any resulting "white" icing a distinctly golden/beige hue.[6] India Tree Powdered Cane Sugar -  According to various sources and purveyors on the internet, the label (which states it is 1/100th the size sugar granule of regular powdered sugar) means "twice as fine" or 10xx compared with 10x (e.g. Domino's and other usual supermarket powdered sugars). My experience of tasting this was that the texture is most DEFINITELY finer. To the point where I almost could not detect any grit or grain at ALL between my teeth or on my tongue, and the taste is very clean and pure, no chalky or raw hint of anything from the 3 1/2% added corn starch. In terms of taste and smoothness it was almost on a par with the powdered invert sugars (which have no starch), and left all the other powdered sugars in the dust.{Re Powdered invert sugar aka dry fondant: these granulated/dehydrated invert sugars function the same as powdered sugar in glaze icing, but I'm not sure how they'd work in something like a cream cheese frosting. whipped cream, butter cream or royal icing e.g.}[7] CK Dry Fondant - like Hain - there is a very very small hint of the unrefined molasses remaining which means the product is slightly darker than C&H (Domino's) Drivert.  This extra flavor tastes great, but I could see the darker shade both looking at the two powders side by side, as well as in the milk and sugar icings side by side. That was the con.  The pro is the granules dissolved much faster than C&H.[8] C&H Bakery Drivert (Domino's) - Clean pure sugar, very white icing, but takes quite a lot of stirring and resting and waiting for the granules to fully dissolve (they aren't granules/crystals like regular sugar though). It does eventually dissolve however, and as neither of thw two powdered invert sugars/fondants have corn starch, they also result in icings with zero grit.THE FINAL JUDGMENT:For my sugar cookie glaze icing - either one of the two powdered invert sugars/fondants will be the "go-to" product. The resulting icing texture is an amazing smooth mouth feel like the liquid fondant center of a fine candy.For any recipe that absolutely requires the powder form and can't accommodate the extra mixing to dissolve the fondant granules, I would say nothing less than INDIA TREE ever again.  This whole taste test gave me a great appreciation for how vastly superior India Tree's powdered sugar is compared to all the other true powdered sugars.

At first I thought they must really have starch in there but not listing it, then I figured they must just have a low "X" count (not nearly as fine powder as all the others). Has a good basic plain pure sugar taste, but fairly crunchy/gritty for powdered. It probably has to be that way not to cake without any added starch.[3] Tate & Lyle Icing Sugar (UK) (Maize starch) - I ordered this specifically because everywhere I looked on the internet sites where this product was mentioned or listed, it did NOT have corn starch, and instead had "anti caking agent E341". It arrive overseas finally, and sadly, it appears they are now using "maise [corn] starch" and no longer E341 (Calcium Phosphate). I was very disappointed.[4] Miss Roben's corn free powdered sugar (tapioca starch) - tastes a little off, everyone noticed when given a taste test comparison, and the tapioca starch is no less gritty than corn starch.[5] Hain Organic Powdered Sugar (Evaporated cane juice) with corn starch - has a much fuller sugar taste than all the rest, due to the fact that it's the whole evaporated cane juice - a rich hint of the molasses fills your mouth. Tastes great but when you don't necessarily want extra flavor and just want the sweetening - it wouldn't be my first choice. Plus, also due to the fact that it's not as refined, that trace of molasses does give any resulting "white" icing a distinctly golden/beige hue.[6] India Tree Powdered Cane Sugar -  According to various sources and purveyors on the internet, the label which states it is 1/100th the size sugar granule of regular powdered sugar, this means "twice as fine" or 10xx compared with 10x (e.g. Domino's and other usual supermarket powdered sugars). My experience of tasting this was that the texture is most definitely finer. To the point where I almost could not detect any grit or grain at ALL between my teeth or on my tongue, and the taste is very clean and pure, no chalky or raw hint of anything from the corn starch. In terms of taste and smoothness it was almost on a par with the Dry Fondants, and left all the other powdered sugars in the dust.{Re Powdered invert sugar: these granulated/dehydrated invert sugars function the same as powdered sugar in icing, but I'm not sure how they'd work in something like a cream cheese frosting. whipped cream or royal icing e.g.}[7] CK Dry Fondant - like Hain - there is a very very small hint of the unrefined molasses remaining which means the product is slightly darker than C&H (Domino's) Drivert.  This extra flavor tastes great, but I could see the darker shade both looking at the two powders side by side, as well as in the milk and sugar icings side by side. That was the con.  The pro is the granules dissolved much faster than C&H.[8] C&H Bakery Drivert (Domino's) - Clean pure sugar, very white icing, but takes quite a lot of stirring and sitting and waiting for the granules to fully dissolve (they aren't granules like regular sugar though). It does eventually dissolve though, and as neither fondants have corn starch, they also result in icings with zero grit.THE FINAL JUDGMENT:For my sugar cookie glaze icing - either one of the fondants will be the go to product. The icing texture is an amazing smooth mouth feel like the liquid fondant center of a fine candy.For any recipe that absolutely requires the powder form and can't accommodate the extra mixing to dissolve the fondant granules, I would say nothing less than India Tree ever again.  This whole taste test gave me a new appreciation for how vastly superior their product is compared to all the other true powdered sugars.

I gathered 8 different powdered sugars available in the U.S., U.K. and Australia, trying to find something without the chalky gritty texture and did a taste test by mixing each into a milk and sugar glaze icing.THE CONTENDERS:{Powdered sugar:}[1] Dominos, [2] Bundaberg, [3] Tate & Lyle, [4] Miss Roben's, [5] Hain Organic, and [6] India Tree{Powdered invert sugar:}[7] CK Dry Fondant and [8]C&H Bakery Drivert (Domino's)THE RESULTS:[1] Dominos (with corn starch) - the one I grew up with. Has a distinctive taste of sugar and powdered dry wall.[2] Bundaberg Pure Icing Sugar (from Australia) (no starch) - Has a good basic plain pure sugar taste, but fairly crunchy/gritty for powdered, even without any starch. Though I couldn't find what equivalent "X" count Bundaberg is rated, I'm guessing it's something like the coarser "commercial grade" 4X or 6X (as opposed to the finer 10X "consumer grade" typical of Dominos and most other consumer powdered sugar). I read on blogs some people don't like the extra gritty texture, while others claim without the starch it makes a smoother, less clumpy butter cream frosting. I'd have to test that another time. For the simple glaze though I didn't like being able to taste and feel the grit.[3] Tate & Lyle Icing Sugar (UK) (Maize starch) - I ordered this specifically because everywhere I looked on the internet sites where this product was mentioned or listed, it did NOT have corn starch, and instead had "anti caking agent E341". It arrive overseas finally, and sadly, it appears they are now using "maize [corn] starch" and no longer E341 (Calcium Phosphate). I was very disappointed.[4] Miss Roben's corn free powdered sugar (tapioca starch) - tastes a little off, everyone noticed when given a taste test comparison, and the tapioca starch is no less gritty than corn starch.[5] Hain Organic Powdered Sugar (Evaporated cane juice) with corn starch - has a much fuller sugar taste than all the rest, due to the fact that it's the whole evaporated cane juice - a rich hint of the molasses fills your mouth. Tastes great but when you don't necessarily want extra flavor and just want the sweetening - it wouldn't be my first choice. Plus, also due to the fact that it's not as refined, that trace of molasses does give any resulting "white" icing a distinctly golden/beige hue.[6] India Tree Powdered Cane Sugar - According to various sources and purveyors on the internet, the label (which states it is 1/100th the size sugar granule of regular powdered sugar) means "twice as fine" or 10xx compared with 10x (e.g. Domino's and other usual supermarket powdered sugars). My experience of tasting this was that the texture is most DEFINITELY finer. To the point where I almost could not detect any grit or grain at ALL between my teeth or on my tongue, and the taste is very clean and pure, no chalky or raw hint of anything from the 3 1/2% added corn starch. In terms of taste and smoothness it was almost on a par with the powdered invert sugars (which have no starch), and left all the other powdered sugars in the dust.{Re Powdered invert sugar aka dry fondant: these granulated/dehydrated invert sugars function the same as powdered sugar in glaze icing, but I'm not sure how they'd work in something like a cream cheese frosting. whipped cream, butter cream or royal icing e.g.}[7] CK Dry Fondant - like Hain - there is a very very small hint of the unrefined molasses remaining which means the product is slightly darker than C&H (Domino's) Drivert. This extra flavor tastes great, but I could see the darker shade both looking at the two powders side by side, as well as in the milk and sugar icings side by side. That was the con. The pro is the granules dissolved much faster than C&H.[8] C&H Bakery Drivert (Domino's) - Clean pure sugar, very white icing, but takes quite a lot of stirring and resting and waiting for the granules to fully dissolve (they aren't granules/crystals like regular sugar though). It does eventually dissolve however, and as neither of thw two powdered invert sugars/fondants have corn starch, they also result in icings with zero grit.THE FINAL JUDGMENT:For my sugar cookie glaze icing - either one of the two powdered invert sugars/fondants will be the "go-to" product. The resulting icing texture is an amazing smooth mouth feel like the liquid fondant center of a fine candy.For any recipe that absolutely requires the powder form and can't accommodate the extra mixing to dissolve the fondant granules, I would say nothing less than INDIA TREE ever again. This whole taste test gave me a great appreciation for how vastly superior India Tree's powdered sugar is compared to all the other true powdered sugars.

Clear vanilla taste-test of four top brands mixed into four samples of my basic white powdered sugar and milk cookie glaze icing.[1] Wilton - sweet one-note plain vanilla, with a faint chemical edge that tangs the back of my throat[2] McCormick - thin one-note plain vanilla without any artificial extra dimensions or after taste, innocous. Like if the genuine McCormick vanilla had all but one dimension removed.[3] Penzey's - I disliked - the best way I can describe it is a combination flavor with aspects of flower, artificial coconut-pineapple blend, and cheap  mallow filled pastel coated easter candy.[4] Watkins - tasted mostly of a strong filled out familiar vanilla with a second faint note of artificial toasted marshmallow - that artificial marshmallow extra is not something I want in anything I makeIt came down to a VERY close race with McCormick and Watkins neck and neck, Watkins had a lot of points for its fullness in contrast to McCormick's thin plain simplicity, but in the end McCormick won because of what it did NOT have - no after taste chemical or otherwise, no non-vanilla flavor additions.  It may be thin and simple, but it has nothing that takes away from the basic vanilla that it does have, and it doesn't even taste artificial. One pro, no cons.

These are very very thin and flimsy, but if the goal is to provide a lot of plates for a lot of people without spending a lot of money (situations for a crowd that don't need high-end 'plastic china'), these totally do the job. I like these for serving flan - they are nice and small and better than the equivalent paper plates (obviously the paper soaks up the flan syrup).  These would work for pretty much any dessert but especially moister or wetter deserts that would soak a paper plate.
Accurately described, good quality. What more can you say about a harp. It did the job and fit my lamp.

A VERY light mist of holding spray holds my fine fly-away baby hairs in place without darkening my blond hair or making it look greasy or weighed down or wet (unlike many other brands that claim to be light or not darken blond hair). I can get a brush through it if need be.  And it smells GREAT.  Perfect for travel.

A VERY light mist of holding spray holds my fine fly-away baby hairs in place without darkening my blond hair or making it look greasy or weighed down or wet (unlike many other brands that claim to be light or not darken blond hair). I can get a brush through it if need be.  And it smells GREAT.  Perfect for travel.

This is not actually Mica -- Mica is a natural mineral material -- they are using the name "Mica lampshade" as if Mica is merely a color or a description of a type of look but it really is not, it's a material.

I couldn't stand the feeling of the center seam going the full length right under each foot. I suppose if you were wearing ultra thick socks you would not feel the seam through your socks, but my socks (smart wool) must not have been thick enough. Also, I suppose if you're wearing these for extreme conditions like working outside in Alaska you might be more concerned about the performance that keeps your feet warm and dry and less about feeling that seam. I have a real aversion to feeling seams (e.g. I can't just accidentally wear my socks twisted up so the toe seam goes partially under my toes, or even worse, the heel is on top of my foot, while I've notice some people don't mind that a bit!)

I only wish they made it in a larger size (e.g. 18 inch) because I wanted to have all mica shades and could not find one for the larger floor lamp that is just like this one but larger.  I did get a larger one but it was made of hexagonal planes and not really a flare shape as much as this one and also only 16" and it just didn't work.  Would love this exact Urbanest Mica lampshade in 18".  The 12" is perfect for my smaller table lamp.
these are great, long lasting strong batteries for the flashlights
it's good for writing work because it's more of a pen shape than the wider accordian bottles, but for the same reason, it's hard to use more than half of the frosting

it does make writing or detail work a little easier because of being more like a pen shape than the wider accordian style squeeze bottles, but it holds so little and after about half way used it's hard to get the rest out
It's a nice finial.
It's a nice finial.

I don't like the sort of fibrous texture when I chew these - I think the fibrous sense may come from the ground up cranberry (???)  I prefer gummy fiber chewables that are smooth.  This is more taffy like, which is fine, but has a fibrous texture that I dislike.

I think the Mica needs to be a little thicker to diffuse the light of the bulb better - as it is, the bulb glows through in a very clearly defined isolated area - like looking through glass almost, rather than diffusing as a typical shade does.  I think if it was thicker it would diffuse better  I realise mica has special unique properties so it will never diffuse like fabric or other shades, but this needs to be thicker.  Of course it's a beautiful color automatically because it's Mica but I would like thicker.
It's a fine bulb, but I was looking for something of a warmer tone.

It's a fine product, I had wanted to use it to mix in a drink, but it takes a LOT of mixing for it to dissolve (like stirring occasionally over the course of an entire day). It may be better for baking / cooking than a cold drink.  Heating up the drink helps it to dissolve but it's still a lot of work.

Glove is too big and too long - fingers go about an inch longer on each finger than my real fingers which makes it impossible to get a good grip on things, the tips fold over or smush.  I am a 5'9" woman with long fingers who wears a woman's winter leather glove in large/extra large or 8 - but these are really fitted for large and long fingered men's hands.

It's definitely the THINNEST floss I've ever used. I didn't think it was even possible for floss to be thinner than everything else I've tried, but this stuff really does slip right between my tightest teeth.  That is the good.  The bad is that it does shred -- I have to move to a new area on the length of floss every few teeth because it does start to shred, and the little filaments that loosens from the main strand will start to stay between my tighter teeth - which then becomes annoying to try to get out.  So I've had to change my flossing technique - usually I'd get through my whole mouth only changing out the floss once, but I have to go for 3 or 4 strands with POH to stay ahead of the shredding.Not sure if I'll order more or just go back to my Duane Reade house brand after this - it's a bit thicker but it doesn't shred as much, plus I feel it has a bit more of a rough edged grip to scrape off the plaque - whereas the POH is slightly more smooth without quite the edge.

Pretty mediocre, I don't believe the so-called "Mica" is the real mineral, it looks to me more like a plastic mica-esque color.  The stand is somewhat tilted.  I switched out the shade for a different real mica shade I already had.

OK, I'm sold. This really does appear to be the blush of my dreams - the most natural looking, enhancing cheek color of any I've ever tried. Not too dark or light or cool or warm or shimmery - basically just looks like your cheeks might look if you were 10 years old and just came in from the cold.  In the past, I have found that I needed a different color in the summer when I have a tan because what looked good on my pale winter skin no longer looked good or natural on my summer tan, but that was when I used my former blush.  To be determined if this Pale Pink Bobbie Brown Blush will even look good this summer - will try to remember to update then.

THE BAD[1] Too long:  At 36" length, it turns out that make the zipper about 3 inches too long to easily reach down to connect the zipper and start zipping up-- instead you have to bunch the jacket up to grab both sides of the zipper to get it going, then because it's bunched up, you can't just easily zip it up, you have to  zip it up in stages as you smooth and straighten the coat back out again and align the two edges.  The coat I'm replacing is like this and I never realized that it was really all about the few inches of length, but since it bugged me the last few years with the old coat, I don't want to switch to another one that requires the same thing -- I'm switching to the Dawson Canada Goose which is 33".  The coat will still keep me warm and that 3 inches less coverage will not make that much difference except for making the zipping process much simpler.[2] Red is not my type of red. I wear a cool or pure cherry red - not a tomato red.  Red is my favorite color, but tomato red grates on my nerves.  Red that leans towards cooler, maroon, orange, brick, washed out Nantucket red - all of those things grate on my nerve. I only like pure red. In the picture on my monitors the coat appears bright cherry red, but in person it's leaning towards tomato.[3] The pockets where you ostensibly warm your hands are in a bizarrely high location, I am literally putting my hands on my breasts when I put them in the pockets.  The lower pockets, sort of 'utility pockets' with flaps - are equally awkward to put your hands in, given they are not really meant for that, with top opening and front positioning.  Again, the Dawson coat is better designed in that it has pockets down lower where your hands naturally go into the pockets.THE GOODPer the Canada Goose website, this coat is a Level 4 warmth.  I went for a 3 mile stroll in short sleeves in 15 degree weather with this coat, no scarf or gloves or any other extra layer, and I was sweating by the end.  I could probably sleep in a snow drift in this coat.  I'm sending it back and getting the Dawson anyway (for reasons outlined above) which is a level 5.  The extra feature on the Dawson is a fleece layer where the neck closes - and while I haven't received it yet, I predict I will like that better than this Trillium - which has no lining where the neck closes, and in fact while the rest of me was sweating, my exposed chin was an ice cube.

I dropped it a few feet out of my hand onto a soft carpet and the crystal popped right off the post.  I haven't glued it back on yet, though that obviously won't be hard - however it seems like if it had better glue in the first place it wouldn't have been that delicate.

Mica is a beautiful and natural mineral that gives a golden glow to the light that is unlike any other type of lamp shade, for a warm atmosphere in your living space.  This lamp shade is a good quality, solidly made, and the bulb glows through beautifully.  I used it to replace the shade my floor lamp came with.The caveat I would note with any mica lamp shade is that Mica has unique properties in the way the light glows through with an amber color, but it also diffuses the light differently than a fabric or other shade, i.e. you can see relatively clearly where the bulb is located through the shade - and as such it is more crucial than any other type of shade to make sure you get the right harp so that the shade is positioned with the bulb close to mid-point between top and bottom.  If the bulb position is too close to the top or bottom it will be obvious when the light is on, and not look that good.

It is expensive for such a tiny little amount per packet, but I don't think there is any other product out there like it.  I use the Baiden mitten for my body, which is also unique to exfoliation in the same way, by rubbing damp skin you start getting the dead top layer to crumb up and roll off. Baiden make a more gentle version specifically for the face, but as many times as I've tried it as gently as possible, I still end up with some spots (like the eye brow where there is no padding under the skin to the bone) sort of abraded.  The face is just too delicate and fraught with difficult nooks and crannies for the Baiden mitten.  The perfect solution is this packet of Earthen Instant Peel - I actually find that I can get about 3 uses from one packet, it takes so little of the mud-like substance to work.  When I first tried it several years ago before I'd heard of Baiden or even knew that dead skin could crumb-up and roll off like this, I was completely skeptical and thought it was just the earthen mud substance itself that was crumbing as you rubbed it and it dried, I really did not believe that it was gathering dead skin cells - I thought it was a total gimmick to fool people.  I tested by going over the same area several times, rinsing and starting with fresh product, and noticed each time it would crumb up less and less until it wouldn't crumb up at all - meaning it had gotten off every last bit of the dead layer of cells.  Even then I wasn't convinced, I still thought possibly it was just your skin oils combining with the mud that made it crumb up and I was just using up the layer of oil (even though I have dry skin, this is what I thought).I put it away for a year still thinking it was not really doing anything, and then I discovered the Baiden mitten and finally learned that dead skin really DOES crumb up and roll off, and eventually it dawned on me that is what the Earthen product was doing - something in their formula manages to do the same thing with a mud-like substance (I can't even guess how). So I came back to try it again and was now firmly convinced it was truly exfoliating - and unlike the Baiden mitten, there are never any spots that are over-abraded, and it's easy to get into the recesses (like between the eye and nose-bridge etc.)  I had actually noticed for a while that inner eye-socket area was flaky and because of that, the cover stick I'd use for my under-eye circles would not go on smoothly, even using extra moisturizer did not fix it.  Well, I was amazed and delighted once I returned to trying this Earthen product the second time around and specifically concentrated on exfoliating that area - the flaking was totally gone and the cover stick went on smoothly on pristine baby-smooth skin - it really and truly worked!I'm unaware of any other product out there like this for the face - any other exfoliation peel is more likely going to be the harsh irritating acidic type that leaves your skin a little raw and sensitive for a few days or similar until the fresh new skin grows in, but the Earthen product does not utilize any kind of irritation or harshness at all, somehow it ONLY removes the dead layer and if you don't have any dead layers left, it simply does nothing - you couldn't get it to take off the live layers even if you wanted to.For anyone who hasn't tried it before, I recommend using this in the shower after your face has been soaking wet for a while, but towel drying it first, it takes about a minute of gentle rubbing before it starts to crumb your dead skin layer off - if you start with too damp skin it will take longer as it has to dry just a bit before it starts working.

My mother, sister and I make cookie houses for Christmas every year but usually bigger size, ranging from 6 to 8 inches high. The problem is so many cookie eaters are reluctant to break into a house to eat it and the truth is we want people to eat these, not just keep them on display. I figured a smaller house would enable people to feel free to eat them, as they are simpler, appear less 'labor intensive" and are probably the equivalent of 1-2 large cookies. It still took a lot of convincing and encouraging to get people to take a house to eat (while there were cookies available to choose, they still went for the cookies).  With that said, they are so quick and easy to make and decorate, I'll probably make some every year - they may be good to include in the little assorted cookie plates I sometimes assemble as gifts.I would add one thing, the plastic cutter is noted as being heat sensitive and somehow I mistook that to mean it was heat resistant, so I made the cookies both ways, by cutting the dough and baking as is (they spread a bit obviously but can still be assembled without difficulty), or baking large areas of cookie and then cutting after baking while fresh out of the oven and still soft enough to cut into (this makes an exact, clean-line precisely sized house).  After cutting 2-3 three that way for valentine's cookie houses (cutting fresh out of the oven) I noticed the plastic was starting to warp and melt where it had contacted the hot sheet.  Given the necessity to cut while the cookie is hot and soft, it is also by definition also too hot to use a spatula to move it to a cool sheet before cutting without tearing it or blobbing it up - so I would say that they are not heat resistant enough to use this method -- I'm glad I got two of these (one had been meant as a gift), because I'm going to need to toss the melted one and use the remaining cutter in the future, and stick to cutting only the raw dough.  I think the reality is only a metal cutter would withstand repeatedly cutting fresh hot baked cookies from the sheet.  So understand what "heat sensitive" means!I've included a photo, you can see the smaller house with my hand beside it - which is 'hot cut', and in the foreground the closer/larger house was cut from the cold dough and baked (expanding/rounding a bit) - it looks just fine - there were no problems getting the expanded house forms to assemble and it looks cute with it's rounded edges - there is really no need to cut hot.

The glow is spectacularly beautiful, just exquisite.  I can't say enough good things about this.  I ordered some other salt lamps (the loose rocks in the wire basket) and set them all over my apartment, then this order arrived about a week later and once I set it up, it blew the others away and I really wished I'd just ordered a bunch of THIS bowl instead.  It's just beyond.  Also unlike the other salt lamps I ordered which were so poorly packaged it was really a miracle to me that any of them arrived intact, this bowl was VERY well packaged with layers and layers of protection so you will get it in one piece, and the bulb is separate so it's safe from shattering if the box and salt rocks get dropped or shift along the way.The combination of the carved salt bowl, the red bulb, and the loose salt rocks piled on top is really the best possible way to take full advantage of the beautiful properties of the color and glow of light through this mineral.

I gathered 8 different powdered sugars available in the U.S., U.K. and Australia, trying to find something without the chalky gritty texture and did a taste test by mixing each into a milk and sugar glaze icing.THE CONTENDERS:{Powdered sugar:}[1] Dominos, [2] Bundaberg, [3] Tate & Lyle, [4] Miss Roben's, [5] Hain Organic, and [6] India Tree{Powdered invert sugar:}[7] CK Dry Fondant and [8]C&H Bakery Drivert (Domino's)THE RESULTS:[1] Dominos (with corn starch) - the one I grew up with. Has a distinctive taste of sugar and powdered dry wall.[2] Bundaberg Pure Icing Sugar (from Australia) (no starch) - Has a good basic plain pure sugar taste, but fairly crunchy/gritty for powdered, even without any starch. Though I couldn't find what equivalent "X" count Bundaberg is rated, I'm guessing it's something like the coarser "commercial grade" 4X or 6X (as opposed to the finer 10X "consumer grade" typical of Dominos and most other consumer powdered sugar). I read on blogs some people don't like the extra gritty texture, while others claim without the starch it makes a smoother, less clumpy butter cream frosting. I'd have to test that another time. For the simple glaze though I didn't like being able to taste and feel the grit.[3] Tate & Lyle Icing Sugar (UK) (Maize starch) - I ordered this specifically because everywhere I looked on the internet sites where this product was mentioned or listed, it did NOT have corn starch, and instead had "anti caking agent E341". It arrive overseas finally, and sadly, it appears they are now using "maize [corn] starch" and no longer E341 (Calcium Phosphate). I was very disappointed.[4] Miss Roben's corn free powdered sugar (tapioca starch) - tastes a little off, everyone noticed when given a taste test comparison, and the tapioca starch is no less gritty than corn starch.[5] Hain Organic Powdered Sugar (Evaporated cane juice) with corn starch - has a much fuller sugar taste than all the rest, due to the fact that it's the whole evaporated cane juice - a rich hint of the molasses fills your mouth. Tastes great but when you don't necessarily want extra flavor and just want the sweetening - it wouldn't be my first choice. Plus, also due to the fact that it's not as refined, that trace of molasses does give any resulting "white" icing a distinctly golden/beige hue.[6] India Tree Powdered Cane Sugar - According to various sources and purveyors on the internet, the label (which states it is 1/100th the size sugar granule of regular powdered sugar) means "twice as fine" or 10xx compared with 10x (e.g. Domino's and other usual supermarket powdered sugars). My experience of tasting this was that the texture is most DEFINITELY finer. To the point where I almost could not detect any grit or grain at ALL between my teeth or on my tongue, and the taste is very clean and pure, no chalky or raw hint of anything from the 3 1/2% added corn starch. In terms of taste and smoothness it was almost on a par with the powdered invert sugars (which have no starch), and left all the other powdered sugars in the dust.{Re Powdered invert sugar aka dry fondant: these granulated/dehydrated invert sugars function the same as powdered sugar in glaze icing, but I'm not sure how they'd work in something like a cream cheese frosting. whipped cream, butter cream or royal icing e.g.}[7] CK Dry Fondant - like Hain - there is a very very small hint of the unrefined molasses remaining which means the product is slightly darker than C&H (Domino's) Drivert. This extra flavor tastes great, but I could see the darker shade both looking at the two powders side by side, as well as in the milk and sugar icings side by side. That was the con. The pro is the granules dissolved much faster than C&H.[8] C&H Bakery Drivert (Domino's) - Clean pure sugar, very white icing, but takes quite a lot of stirring and resting and waiting for the granules to fully dissolve (they aren't granules/crystals like regular sugar though). It does eventually dissolve however, and as neither of thw two powdered invert sugars/fondants have corn starch, they also result in icings with zero grit.THE FINAL JUDGMENT:[1] For my sugar cookie glaze icing - either one of the two powdered invert sugars/fondants will be the "go-to" product. The resulting icing texture is an amazing smooth mouth feel like the liquid fondant center of a fine candy.[2] For any recipe that absolutely requires the powder form and can't accommodate the extra mixing to dissolve the fondant granules, I would say nothing less than INDIA TREE ever again. This whole taste test gave me a great appreciation for how vastly superior India Tree's powdered sugar is compared to all the other true powdered sugars.[3] For recipes such as cookies and cakes that call for powdered sugar (since color isn't an issue), Hain Organic Powdered Sugar would be a great choice for it's exceptional flavor. Or if I was making cookie icing glaze in colors (and bright white was unnecessary)

I gathered 8 different powdered sugars available in the U.S., U.K. and Australia, trying to find something without the chalky gritty texture and did a taste test by mixing each into a milk and sugar glaze icing.{Powdered sugar:}[1] Dominos, [2] Bundaberg, [3] Tate & Lyle, [4] Miss Roben's, [5] Hain Organic, and [6] India Tree{Powdered invert sugar:}[7] CK Dry Fondant and [8]C&H Bakery Drivert (Domino's)[1] Dominos (with corn starch) - the one I grew up with. It does eventually dissolve though, and as neither fondants have corn starch, they also result in icings with zero grit.THE FINAL JUDGMENT:For my sugar cookie glaze icing - either one of the fondants will be the go to product. It really is amazing what a small space the 100 feet take up, like other reviewers have said.  Also, like other reviewers noted, as you spread / uncoil this strand - there is a point or two you get to where it starts to tangle, and it becomes a combination of untangling a slinky, un-knotting wet shoe laces, and de-snarling long hair after a day at the beach. I'm the soul of persistence and patience with those things, and I scoffed when I read about others getting frustrated with the tangle, but this REALLY tested my patience!!!  You can not be a brute because the wire kinks into permanent knots if you're not careful untangling.  However, I've gotten them all tacked up, lining my entire apartment at the top of the wall where it meets the ceiling - and they are never coming down again.  They look great.  The color is not as warm as my incandescent lamps but it's ok for contrast.  Also, I was slightly concerned that the copper wire would show up against my white walls, but it really doesn't. All you see is the lights.One thing I would note for anyone thinking it would be nice to dim these since they are a bit bright - I have dimmer switch cords attached to all my lamps, so I tried the dimmer on this strand of lights and they do NOT dim. They go from on, to flicking on/off, to off.  No dimming whatsoever.  There are other strands of LED copper lights that do have dimming, but they are shorter strands and don't connect (that I could find), and I wanted one long strand so there wouldn't be cords snaking up my walls every 20 feet.
So much better than futzing with refilling a filter pitcher every day.

I bought this in August and have been delighted ever since. I love how it perfectly blends in with my chrome faucet, not unsightly at all. And even though it's been 6 months, I am still extremely pleased how much easier and better it is to use than the filter pitcher I was using for all these years.  I love how I can just fill up a pot of water to boil for cooking, right from the faucet, where it used to be a plan ahead hassle to wait for the pitcher to filter enough, or just compromise and use straight tap water.I confess I did not change the filter at 2 months, I only changed it tonight for the first time (almost 6 moths).  I noticed the last few weeks the stream was getting slower, and the last couple days the water tasted distinctly off.  I had a hard time unscrewing the old filter, I actually had to get an adjustable wrench and open it wide enough to grab to of those triangle grip corners - I think being on so long it had developed some sort of suction - I really couldn't get it with my hands and even with the wrench it took a few turns before it loosened (like the suction broke?).  The replacement filter screwed in as easy as pie.  Maybe I should not wait more than 2 months next time :)

It's nice and thick, but I didn't realize it would be so heavy, that's why I took off the last star.  That's because I've never had a yoga mat or carried one, I am guessing they are all dense and heavy material so the thicker they are the heavier.  If I had it to do over I would get a thinner mat - my main need was non slip b/c I do my yoga at home and my hands and feet were slipping on my rug, this stops the slipping. I thought I needed extra cushioning too but now I don't think that I really did, my rugs have rug cushions under them, just the anti slip properties of a thinner mat would have been plenty.I don't know if there are yoga mats out there that are thick, anti slip, and also lighter, maybe others more experienced would know that.

I calculated that you have to have five of these gummies to add up to the equivalent of ONE of the Digestive Advantage capsules (which I've taken for years).  Because of the amount of prebiotic fiber in the gummies, five of these gummies gives way too much fructooligosaccharides - i.e. a lot of gas.  I'd prefer if they lowered the amount of "fiber" so you can have 5 gummies to be a true equivalent alternative to the capsules without blowing up your intestines with gas.  I know *some* prebiotic fiber is helpful to enable the probiotics to flourish and populate the intestines, but the ratio is too much in this gummy formulation.
If you like tongue scrapers these are certainly effective and cheap.  I personally learned that I prefer the tung brush, but to each his own, so I still give these four stars for what they are.

As other reviewers noted, the quality of the metal is superior, smoother, more finely shaped, with clean perfect openings for better piping. If you do a lot of cookie decorating and piping, and you value that extra bit of pleasure that comes from using higher end products, this is the one to upgrade your tips to.  It's a small thing, but what's a few dollars more to enhance your quality of life even just a little if you'll be using these for a lifetime?

I already have similar fabric gloves for the oven, without the silicone but otherwise about the same.  They were getting old and stained so I thought I'd get new ones, liked the idea of the silicone grips, and also the longer sleeves going further up the wrist.  However, the sleeves are too tight/snug and make getting them on a little bit of a process - slower by a few seconds - which may not seem like much but when the oven timer goes off and you want to grab the oven mitts immediately and get something out of the oven (or off the stove before it boils over), seconds count.  I didn't want anything that was going to be slightly irritating compared to what was already working, so I'm still using my existing gloves and returned these.

However, the sleeves are too tight/snug and make getting them on a little bit of a process - slower by a few seconds - which may not seem like much but when the oven timer goes off and you want to grab the oven mitts immediately and get something out of the oven (or off the stove before it boils over), seconds count. Fine tasting candy.  Got it to use for decorating gingerbread houses at Christmas time and I wanted only green and red color gum drops. This fills the bill.

Looks good, I will be using this to cut pieces for stiffening the bottom/base of handmade purses - as recommended by various purse making sites I read, and I'm sure it will be perfectly adequate for the job.  I've used this same plastic canvas for other craft purposes so I see no reason why this would not be just right.

This was a great little airplane acceptable sized bug spray that was helpful on my recent trip to India.  One night I found myself sleeping on a 2 inch thick pad "bed" on a floor in a guest house in the mountains of India.  Bugs of every description were flying and crawling and creeping as I tried to sleep, after 1/2 an hour of this I sprang up, turned on all the lights, sprayed my arms, my pajamas, and the full perimeter of the "bed" with this little spray bottle and everyone one of those spiders, winged and creeping insects left me alone for the rest of the night.

An amazing movie. Much darker and more tragic and graphic and severe all the way through than I remembered from watching it as a child.  Definitely more informative of the southern experience of civil war times than I remembered, more than just a love story (which is the only part I did remember!).

I have a lot of issues with this battery case, as compared with my experience of the Mophie. The following is a compare and contrast of Trianium and Mophie for iPhone 6.PROBLEMS:[1] I was used to keeping my Mophie on an automatic setting so that the battery of the case was used first and then when that ran out it automatically switched over to the iPhone's battery, for a seamless experience until the power was all used up.  Mophie HAS the option of first using the phone battery then MANUALLY switching over to the case battery when it runs low, for longer maximum total battery life, if you need that. But in truth I don't need that for just a typical day. I preferred the seamless automatic option without me having to press the button to switch it over halfway through the day.  The Trianium is set with only the option of manual switch over, and to me that is just annoying (and unnecessary) to have to do that extra step halfway through each and every day. So what can (and has) happened is I don't press the charge button when the phone starts displaying the low battery notice, and when I return from whatever I was doing I see the battery completely drained and the iPhone shut down. Now I'm faced with waiting the amount of time the phone takes to charge up to 5% before I can get it back on (a half hour?).[2] I plug my phone in each night to charge.  With the Mophie, the case would blink for a few seconds to confirm it is charging, then the lights would stop blinking and go off the rest of the night.  In contrast the Trianium turns the lights on the back of the case on when you plug in the charger and they stay on the ENTIRE night. Initially they are BLINKING for the hour or so that it takes to charge up the case and phone, then they go to steady once charged, but they are still on and SHINING BRIGHT.  They are BRIGHT lights and being only a foot away from my face while I'm trying to sleep it's a big PITA, now I have to bury the phone in a basket and position the back of the case away so the bright light is lessened.[3] The Trianium case (like the Mophie case) comes around the phone with the edge raised a bit as a bumper, which is of course what you want, so when it's face down the phone is raised up to protect the phone face surface.  However, on the Trianium that thick bumper layer also comes right to the very edge of the finger print button (like a millimeter away?) which makes it just a little bit of a challenge to get your finger to lay flat and recognize the print.  On the Mophie case there is significantly more space between the case bumper and that button (3-4 millimeters?) which is an important improvement in easing the fingerprint recognition. I've posted photos from the same angle to show the comparison.[4] The Trianium case has it's own volume buttons built into the case that you press which in turn press the iPhone volume buttons.  It's hard to describe but they feel clunky and take a bit of extra pressing to activate the iPhone buttons underneath, just clunky enough that I find myself not wanting to bother using the volume buttons. The Mophie buttons somehow have more of a seamless feel, like the case buttons mimic the iPhone buttons in look and feel when pressing.PLUSES:[1] I will give the Trianium one point in favor, the sound SWITCH (on/off) area is cutout so you reach in with your finger or fingernail to turn the sound on or off easily. The Mophie, in contrast, has a case button which only very loosely engages with the iPhone's on/off button underneath so you have to press quite deliberately to actually move the tiny (real) switch underneath, otherwise if you just casually slide the switch (like with your fingernail) to what you think is on or off, you very likely haven't actually switched the real button on the iPhone (which you can tell because the screen confirms with the display that comes up showing the "Ringer" or "Ringer Silent"). This is something I find to be a ridiculously flawed design point on the Mophie especially considering how much everything else about it is much finer engineering.Other than the points above, both cases do the basic job, which is extending the battery life, and generally protecting. I haven't experienced any of the problems other reviewers have noted, such as faulty or unreliable syncing or charging, nor have I dropped my phone with either case to discover whether it falls off or not. The bulk and weight seem to be comparable for both cases.  My preference is hands down the Mophie, the four negatives listed about the Trianium might seems minor but they add up to a lot of niggling irritations I am aware of each day and night, and the Mophie is simply better in those ways so that aside from the on/off switch, it's not calling attention to itself and just works.

It's OK if your only concern is bright light, such as in a bathroom.  But as an equivalent substitute of a warm incandescent living room light, it's not even close.  I tried a 2400k LED which approached similar to incandescent, but side-by-side with an incandescent this 2700k was a lot cooler. It's weird to me that they can call these "warm" - as far as I can tell they are only warm in a totally "relative" sense, i.e. warmer than cooler LED lights, but they really aren't warm at all if you compare them with a normal standard warm incandescent.I don't know what machine/monitor rates these at 2700 and calls that warm or equivalent of incandescent, because my eyes can clearly see a big big difference.  The monitors have a faulty measuring ability if you ask me, since they don't match what the eye sees.
One of Woody Allen's best.

I have a tiny NYC apt. with a tiny kitchen and very limited counter space, but I keep my iPad on my counter at all times since I use it primarily with my cookbook app.  However, the previous iPad stand I used kept my iPad down too close to the counter and it got a lot of splatters and splashes, and the stand took up a bit much real estate.  This Tail takes up a certain amount of counter real estate but it's way easier to navigate other items like cords etc. under and around the "tail", it's easier to re-position as needed because the "tail" can worm it's way into tight spaces, and my iPad is higher up out of splatter zone, and I love how easy it is to change the angle if needed.  This turned out to be the perfect solution for my needs.

If you're just looking to neutralize moderately bad odors such as guest bathrooms, I personally think I'll stick with Lysol Neutra Air. A few of the smellier house guests used it and it really did neutralize, not just mix in with, the malodors.  I thought that the neutralizing concept was so exciting I'd go all the way and get a super powerful version - and tried this OZIUM.  However, unless you have a nursery, or pot smoke, or a sick room, like really severe odors to combat, I don't think you need something this powerful, because the smell of the spray itself is really yucky.  Yes it dissipates (after half hour or an hour I guess?) but meanwhile I avoid the room where it was sprayed exactly they way I'd avoid it if there was simply a malodorous house guest who'd just used the bathroom.  I can hardly say which smells worse in truth, and both smells naturally dissipate in the same amount of time anyway.  Hence my recommendation for moderate smells is something that smells good instantly, i.e. the Lysol Neutra Air - you don't have to wait a second for that to dissipate.  This OZIUM is for severe problems, in rooms where you need long term help and don't mind leaving the room abandoned for an hour while it works.

Better tone than the others I've tried.  Despite the numbers the industry claims are equivalent to "warm" light color (at 2700k or 3000k the others did not even come close to the true warmth of incandescent), at 2400k this was actually almost the same warm/yellow light as the lamp next to it with a real incandescent bulb.However, the caveat is that LED bulbs do not get warmer as they are dimmed, they stay the same "color" they are at full brightness, which creates a hard to describe dim but white light, whereas real incandescent dim by getting warmer and warmer and more amber gold until they are like candle light.  LED may never do that.As such, if you aren't super concerned with the ability to dim down to rich golden amber candle light but generally warm is OK, then these are OK, and most definitely better than the standard so-called "warm" LED bulbs out there (i.e. 2700k-3200k) which if anything are more like the white flourescent color.Personally I've decided the golden amber candle-lit color ambience in my living room is far more important than saving a few bucks on lightening over a lifetime and I'm going to spring for the incandescent bulbs that are still around via loopholes (some of the squirel cage edison bulbs for example).
I didn't see why this book was so lauded, I really didn't.

This is a rather cheaply made product. It is flimsy and plasticky. The outer polypropylene shell is thin and looks cheap. The interior has a plasticky foil lining but there is hardly any insulation in it. The whole thing looks like something you may find in a dollar discount store. It doesn't look like it would stand up to daily use neither.The only thing going for it is the Realtree camo pattern. The print is ok (could have been sharper). It is approximately 9" x 6" x 8" in size, a nice size for a picnic or a really big lunch. It can also be folded up into a thin pack. That said, I don't think it's worth the price.

This is an excellent Dummies guide. It provides in-depth coverage from Android Lollipop 5.1 as well as KitKat 4.4 and Jelly Bean 4.3. It is well written and organized, with clear instructions and explanations in various topics. Each topic is standalone and is easy to jump into. That is, you can simply lookup the things you want to do with your Android phone and jump right into it for the answer. I like how the author makes the text both easy and entertaining to read and follow. There are unexpected humors in addition to the traditional textbook instructions, so it's fun to read and learn about what you can do with your phone. Furthermore, the book is printed in full color which makes screenshots easy to view and compare to the actual screen on your phone.Overall, if you are new to the Android or simply want to find more about the new version 5.1, this book is for you. It breaks down the whole thing into small, standalone tasks that you can learn at your own pace, or just dive right into the specific topics for your answers. There is great sense of humor throughout the text which makes it enjoyable to read. One of the best Dummies guides that I really enjoy reading.

First off, this is my first NAS and my experience with NAS in general is rather limited. That being said, I find this entry-level NAS more than meets my needs for a general file server and UPnP media server. It runs fast and performs well with those expectations in mind.The AS1002T NAS is fairly easy to setup. No tools are required. Hand screws are used to secure the external case and to mount the hard drives inside. For this NAS, I picked up a couple of Western Digital Red hard drives and mounted them in the unit (I first formatted them in EXT4).The NAS is mostly plastic on the outside. However, it is sturdy and well built. The diamond-plate finish in the front panel is stylish. It runs very quietly. It has an exhaust fan at the back but it is no louder than the hard drives themselves. It also runs cool, barely warm to the touch. The 4 LED indicators are just about the right intensity, which works out nicely in my media center as it doesn't cause distraction in a darkened environment.As a file server, the NAS is pretty fast. I consistently get a read speed in the 100 MB/s range over a wired connection in my gigabit network. Write speed is a tad slower, around 90 MB/s, which is still plenty fast for my purpose. I do not use the built-in hardware encryption since I don't have a need for it and it supposedly reduces the transfer speed by more than half according to the manual.It also works great as a media server. It streams my music and videos with any problems. It serves my videos in their native M2V format to my HDTV perfectly. It doesn't need to transcode my videos. I don't expect an entry-level NAS to be able to do so anyway.The NAS is loaded with many apps. There are a FTP server, download center, iTunes server, surveillance center, syslog server, just to name a few. Honestly speaking, I don't know much about these apps and I don't really have a use for any of them anyway. I just need a file server with RAID 1 mirroring and a simple media server. For these purposes, the NAS works great for me.Overall, I really like this NAS. It's simple and cost-effective. It also runs cool and quiet. It serves my basic needs with good performance. At this price, it is an easy recommendation.

This is a beautiful hardcover cookbook with amazing recipes that are easy to follow and lovely to appreciate. There are recipes for meats & poultry, seafood, soups, vegetables, appetizers, breads and desserts. Practically a little something for everybody. Easy recipe is neatly organized and easy to glance through - a short description of the dish and serving size, followed by list of ingredients in the left column and the step-by-step instructions in the right column. Scattered throughout the pages are some of the eye-candy, mouth-watering, gorgeously taken, full-page photographs of the finished products for probably around half of the recipes in the book.Most of these recipes make use of commonly available, everyday ingredients instead of exotic ingredients that are pretty to read about but hard to prepare with. Some of these recipes are simple and easy to follow. Others are more gourmet and yet not too difficulty to prepare for. There are something for everything. Meat & seafood lovers, vegans, soup eaters, snack & dessert fans will be pleased to find a good variety of recipes that they will enjoy.Overall, this is a beautiful cookbook filled with many different recipes to try. My exposure to Portuguese cooking is very limited. As such, I can't verify the authenticity of these Portuguese recipes in the cookbook. That being said, these recipes do look delicious and not difficulty to follow. The book itself is gorgeously written and presented. If you are a fan of ethnic cooking or culinary art in general, you will love this cookbook (I do).

This new SAT guide is a tremendous value for the money. You're getting 1,300+ pages of practical strategies and practice tests plus DVD tutorials and online content. There are tons of materials that are practical and useful for students to improve their score on the new, revamped SAT exams.This book is heavy and substantial, nearly 2 3/4" thick. It is organized into four main parts: (1) Math - a summary review of the math topics, with thoughtful strategy on how to tackle the specific problems and extra practices to drill on, (2) Evidence-Based Reading and Writing - Kaplan methods for reading comprehension, reasoning skills, writing & language and infographics, (3) the Essay - the Kaplan method for the SAT essay, and (4) 2 full new SAT test practices with answers. In addition to this printed book, there is a DVD filled video tutorials and access to an online center with additional study tools, as well as three more tests to practice on.All in all, this book is a tremendous resource for preparing for the new SAT exams. There are many study guides and tools for SAT preparation, but few are complete with everything neatly organized in an easily accessible form. The Kaplan New SAT Premier is easily the best all-in-one SAT study guide in the market. If you are preparing for the SAT exam, this book will probably be your best investment.

I'm really impressed with this anti-fog treatment product. It works great just as advertised. I tried it on my own glasses and put them over a pot of boiling water. The steam didn't fog them up. They remained clear as if nothing was on its surface. It is amazing. Just a drop or two on the glass surface (both sides), then use the finger to spread and cover the entire surface and let it dry. Finally use a microfiber cloth to gently and lightly rub the surface to clean up any smudges (rubbing it too hard could remove the treatment). The included microfiber cloth is of great quality and cleans my glasses very well.All in all. This is an excellent anti-fog treatment product for any glasses and goggles. It works amazingly well. One application lasts nearly the whole day and the treatment is completely reversible. Simply wash it with soap and water to remove it permanently. It works so well that I'll be getting a couple more bottles and going to use it on our snow goggles in the upcoming ski season.

I'm really impressed with this product. It is cooling and refreshing. It goes on like a water mist and wouldn't mess up makeup. In the middle of the day when I can't apply a moisturizer conveniently, a spritz of this spring water would freshen up my skin. I also use it just before applying a moisturizer at night to help seal in the moisture. It is an amazing product.

This is a good kibble for small breed dogs. I like the simple and natural, yet a wide variety of ingredients in this food, with turkey being the first ingredient, then turkey meal, peas, chickpeas, chicken meal, etc. There are also different kinds of vegetables, pollock meal, canola oil, salmon oil, almond oil, sesame oil, and vitamins & minerals. Basically, a dog food of high nutrition value, free of grains and gluten.I have a small dog who is a picky eater. I have tried many dog food and there is only a handful that she would actually eat. I'm glad that I tried this particular dog food since she seems to like it. The kibble size is smaller than her usual adult sized kibble but it hasn't stopped her from enjoying it. So far she hasn't had any bad reactions to it. I'm happy that I could finally add another dog food to the list of food that she would eat.All in all, this is a good dog food, albeit pricey. I can't imagine I could afford it on a continuous basis, had I had a larger dog. Moreover, the bag is not resealable, so you need a container to keep it after opening.

These are decent bubble bath & shower gel. As a shower gel, they produce moderate amount of lathers and clean well but I also have to use more than usual in order to cover my whole body. The scent is very nice. I like the lavender the best, which is the most intense out of the three, with the milk & honey the least intense. The fragrance is intense initially, but dissipates quickly and by the time I finish rinsing, it's all gone.I don't do bubble both often but I tried it with the lavender bottle anyway. I followed the directions and put in the recommended amount. However, I was quickly disappointed by the results. It didn't produce many bubbles and they weren't long lasting neither. Half way through my bath, the bubbles mostly disappeared. The only saving grace was the nice lavender scent at the start of the bath.I do like that it is paraben, phthalate and SLS free, and very well suited for sensitive skin, and that it is also made in USA.Overall, I think they are best used as a show gel. If you like to infuse your senses with intense fragrance during a shower, this will work nicely. Keep in mind that the fragrance dissipates fairly quickly and quite a lot of the gel is necessary for a good shower. It cleans well and rinses off easily. That said, I don't think the retail price is worth it though.

These dish clothes aren't good value for the money. They are thin and the hem is cheaply made. Some threads are loose and unraveling already before I get to use them. I have another set of basketweave tea towels by Now Designs that are better made with thicker fabric and properly done single fold hem. These dish clothes aren't even close to those tea towels in terms of quality and function. These are not very absorbent. They are okay to wash dishes with but useless to dry them with.The only good thing going for them is the blue strips on white which look nice and neat. Unfortunately, they don't look very durable. In fact, they look like those that you can find in a dollar store. For the price, there are way better dish clothes you can buy. I wouldn't recommend them.

This Belkin lightning cable is functionally as good as the original Apple stock lightning cable. I'm able to use it to sync and charge both my iPhone and iPad with any problems. The cable is well built, sturdy and flexible. The purple color is cheerful and the short length is perfect for traveling - both to charge my phone from a power pack and to sync it with my laptop. The lightning connector is quite slim and should fit most phone cases.It is important to note that Lightning cables have an authentication chip inside the connector. Only the original Apple or licensed MFI cables are guaranteed to work. As such, make sure you buy from a licensed and reputable seller in order to avoid a knock-off.

This appears to be a good supplement. It is made of limited ingredients that are very similar to those supplements that we take for ourselves - namely, glucosamine HCI, chondroitin sulfate, vitamin C and manganese plus a few common inactive ingredients. The tablets are scored and easy to halve should the dosage directions on the bottle call for half a tablet based on the weight of the dog.My dog is not in her senior years yet but I wouldn't mind giving it to her as a preventive measure. She seems like to the smell and taste of it and would chew it up without issues. So far she hasn't experienced any reactions to it. We ourselves need supplements as we grow into our golden years. I think our dogs need similar treatment too, especially when we are supposed to take care of them. I like this supplement for its limited ingredients, just the essentials that she would need for healthy hip and joints.

Learn Game Programming with Ruby is an introductory book to 2D game programming for beginners. It is based on the Ruby programming language and makes use of the Gosu 2D game development library and the Chipmunk physics library. Readers are assumed to have basic programming skills in Ruby as there is no tutorial. The book guides the readers through the process of writing four very different games, which cover many aspects of basic game programming that may be extended or pieced together as the basis for more complex games.The book first guides the reader to download and set up their Ruby development kit and libraries. From then on, it shows the readers how to write their first game, expand it, and then writing more but very different games as a way to show different techniques in game programming. The complete source code for the four games can be downloaded from the publisher's website.The last part of the book shows the readers how to package their game for sharing.The book is divided into the following main chapters, which should give you an idea of what the book is about.1. Introduction2. Get Ready3. Creating Your First Game4. Creating a Sprite-Based Game5. Managing Lots of Sprites6. Adding Scenes and Sounds7. Creating a Puzzle Game8. Making a Platformer Game with Physics9. Making a Side-Scrolling Game10. Package and Share Your GameThe book is well written and fun to follow. It's well suited to beginners who want to learn about 2D game programming in general. Ruby is one of the easier languages to learn. It's a great candidate for learning game programming in this book. Readers can focus on how to write games instead of learning how to program in Ruby. All in all, this book is a great and fun way to learn 2D game programming.

It is a norm that notebook computers do not usually come with an Ethernet port these days since WiFi is so prevalent and widely available everywhere. That said, sometimes it is very useful to have a computer connected via Ethernet for setup and troubleshooting purposes. For instance, when I set up a brand new wireless router, I connect to it by hard wire and change its default IP and netmask. That's where this Ethernet adapter will come in handy.While this Ethernet adapter isn't the smallest I've seen, it has a very convenient feature - having the USB connector conveniently tugged in the adapter when it's not in use, so no more tangling cable sticking out.Setup is pretty easy. It is plug-and-play on my Windows 10 laptop as it recognizes it automatically. However, my MacBook Pro, which I have recently upgraded to El Capitan, does not recognize it until I download a driver for it. So it is not plug-and-play on a Mac. At the time of writing, drivers for Mac and Win2000/XP/Vista/7/8/8.1/10 are available for download from the manufacturer's website.Transfer speed through this adapter is excellent. It's significantly faster than my wireless-N network and noticeably faster than my wireless-AC. The connection is very stable and I don't have any problems at all. One thing to note. You'll need to plug it into a USB 3.0 port in order to achieve the 1 gigabit Ethernet speed though. Also, this adapter doesn't appear to work on Wii U, despite what the Amazon's product description says (the manufacturer's product page makes no mention of Wii U compatibility neither).Overall, this is a great gigabit Ethernet adapter. It works great and the price is very affordable. A great value for the money.

These are decent dental chews for small to medium sized dogs. There are three 3-point dental chews in each pack, each of which can easily be broken into 3 separate smaller chews. The chews are covered with nubs that are supposed to help clean their teeth. I usually give dental chews to my dog once or twice a week to help her maintain her dental health. While these chews will work fine as dental chews, they are really expensive (more than $1 per small chew). There are more affordable options that work great.My dog seems to enjoy these chews. They have a strong beefy flavor that she likes. They also seem to be hard to chew as she really needs to work hard on them. I don't think these chews would be suitable for senior dogs with dental problems. For younger dogs, these are quite long lasting chews that would keep them occupied and help clean their teeth.The number one ingredient is wheat starch, so these chews are not grain free. They are made in USA and appear to be quality treats.Overall, these are good dental chews, albeit expensive.

This treat lasted no longer than 15 minutes after I have given it to my small dog. It is advertised as long lasting chews but it is not when it's completely gone in less than 15 minutes. $8 for 15 minutes of enjoyment seems to be rather expensive. The dino shape is cute but I doubt dogs would care for the shape. There are some nubs on the chew which may have some dental benefits. The bacon & beef flavor is strong and seems appealing to her. It is said to be a natural treat but the number one ingredient is wheat. I usually prefer natural treats with no grain, corn, etc. I gave it to my dog anyway and she seemed to like it. I wish it would be more long lasting though. Overall, it is a decent chew but I don't think it is a good value though.List of ingredients: wheat starch, glycerin, pea protein, rice flour, powdered cellulose, lecithin, natural bacon flavor, natural roast beef flavor, dried chicken, natural flavor, oat fiber, potato starch, calcium carbonate, soy flour, thiamine mononitrate, riboflavin supplement, niacin supplement, calcium pantothenate, pyridoxine hydrochloride, folic acid, vitamin A supplement, vitamin E supplement, biotin, choline chloride, inositol, p-aminobenzoic acid, ferrous carbonate, magnesium oxide, dicalcium phosphate, potassium chloride, sodium selenite, calcium chloride, zinc oxide, copper oxide, manganous oxide, and sodium molybdate.

This is a remarkable and handsome watch, very modern and masculine looking. It is substantial in size and weight, with a 45mm stainless steel case and a thickness of 13mm. There are three sub-dials for the chronograph, two of which are silver colored and look striking in the predominantly black bezel and main dial. There is also a date window between the 4 and 5 o'clock position. The bezel has a matte black finish and is fixed (nonrotatable).The watch really stands out on my medium sized wrist. It is hefty and substantial. Very manly looking. I have received a few compliments from friends and co-workers.The watch uses a Japanese chronograph quartz movement, specifically the Hattori Japan VD53. This is a popular and trusty Seiko caliber movement. The battery type is #371 SR920SW.The band length is adjustable, though you'll need some tools to remove a pin from each removable link in the band. There is an arrow marking to indicate the direction the pin will come out from. I usually use a blunt needle and a small hammer to push those pins out. If you're not comfortable, you can always take your watch to the watch store to get it adjusted for a small fee.The watch comes in a very attractive presentation box, which is an oversized, bright yellow Invicta box. Invicta makes some of the most deluxe, highly presentable boxes for consumer watches that I have seen. It looks very desirable for gifting purposes.

I ordered these dong treat bones hoping that they would occupy my dog for a good while since they are advertised to be long lasting. I used to buy rawhide bones until they began to upset her stomach but they were really long lasting. Well, not these salmon dog bones. They didn't even last 10 minutes each. That said, they do have a palatable smell that she was very excited about. When I gave her one, she immediately went to work on it. I do like they are made of limited ingredients and do not container grains. They did not cause her any stomach problems. Overall, they seem good and healthy but are not long lasting at all.

These Oxford NY Classic Fit Gabardine Dress Pants are excellent. They fit me perfectly for my size. They are soft and comfortable to wear. The polyester fabric is light and quite wrinkle resistant. The color is a true deep black and opaque although the fabric is light and thin.The waist band uses a metal hook and a button for closure. It also features a short elastic section on both sides that can extend a little, so these pants will remain comfortable even after a full meal. The zipper runs smoothly with problems. The pocket lining fabric is quite thick and durable. Anyhow, I have run these pants through the washer and dryer once, and they did neither shrink nor fade. It looks like they would be a long lasting pair of pants.Overall, I'm really impressed with these pants. They have the true classic look and yet have some nice features such as the waist band extender. They are nice and sharp looking as well. After having washed them and trying them for the day, I can't honestly find any problems with these pants. So they are 5 stars worthy to me. I would recommend these.

This is just an average headphone at best. The build quality is decent but the sound is mediocre. I'm not overly impressed with it.The headphone comes with a bone shaped silicone cable organizer, 3 different sets of silicone earbud tips (S/M/L) and warranty paper. The angled earbuds and silicone tips are quite comfortable to wear, even for long hours. The earbuds don't seem to fall out easily (if you wear them correctly by pulling your ear a little as you insert each earbud deep into your ear canal). The flat cable is tangle resistant but a little kinky when it's first out of the box. There is good strain relief for the cable on the earbud end but none on the stereo plug end, so longevity of the cable at the plug end could be an issue. On a positive note, the straight plug is small and should fit through most phone cases without any problems.The control box is on the right earbud wire and has three buttons and a mic. Its build quality leaves a lot to be desired. The up volume button clicks when it is pressed but the down volume button doesn't for my review copy. It doesn't look like it is well built. Anyway, the middle button works as expected on my iPhone - single press for play/pause, double press for next track and triple press for previous track. The volume controls do not work on the iPhone. They work on Android though.The biggest problem with this headphone is the sound. It is mediocre. The bass is present but not as bass heavy as the "extra bass" label may have you believe. It is boosted but not deep. The treble is actually pretty good though. It is crisp and clear. On the other hand, the mid range is largely recessed and seriously lacking. Vocals do not sound rich nor full at all. It could really use a boost. The product box has a frequency response curve on it (see attached picture). It has a very noticeable dip around 1-2 kHz.Overall, this headphone is only average at best. For the price, there are other better sounding headphones to consider.

I have been to Manhattan and spent a good number of days exploring the borough extensively but I never thought of visiting Brooklyn.
