I have been using this tape for many years.  I have been purchasing it at a local mega warehouse store, but now I purchase it online because I can get it in a 6 pack for $3-4 cheaper.  I use a great deal of this tape for my shipping and packing business.I am not sure what has happened, but over the past few years the tape has gotten to be flimsy.  When you pull it off the roll it shreds as you pull to tape a small package.  It now takes me much more time than need to process a package for shipping.I spend most of my time unraveling the messy tape situation.  Please see my photo so you know just what I'm talking about.

I purchased a earlier model of a seatbelt harness for my two pet pals Darby & Hampshire.The older model had a fabric loop that you slide the auto seatbelt through.  This often resulted in a tangled mess, and it was difficult to transition from car to destination.When I purchased the newer model of the seatbelt harness for a visiting pet pal, I really liked the new update in the model.It had the auto seat safety belt that merely clicked into place in a snap making for quick and easy transitions.It didn't tangle, secured the pet in comfort, and allowed for easy transitions.  My pet pals could now lay comfortably in their car beds.  I didn't have to stop during long and short trips to untangle them.I was also delighted that I didn't have to order two new seatbelt safety harnesses ($30/ea.), but rather I could order just the new hardware--auto seat safety belt.The belt is made of durable material, metal hardware that won't snap, crack, or break.  The belt is adjustable to extend or to shorten.  Well made and awesome.  I highly recommend!

Title:  Williams-Sonoma Kitchen Library:  Festive EntertainingPublisher:  Time-Life BooksDate:  1998Book:  Hardcover with dust coverThis is a beautiful book that contains full glossy photos of the recipe and a full page of the finished product.The books is divided into 12 sections:IntroductionFestive Entertaining TechniquesPlanning MenuSetting the TableBasic RecipesStartersSalads & Side DishesMain CoursesDessertsGlossaryAcknowledgementsIndexThe book not only contains a host of elegant recipes, but it also illustrates how to set a table, arrange a floral centerpiece, napery techniques, and presentations.My favorite recipes include roasted peppers with herbed goat cheese, sesame shrimp, Greek chicken strudel, and crab in endive leaves.

I have a 5 year old ShihTzu named Hampshire and a 6 year old Tibetan Spaniel named Darby.  Both are pink skinned dogs.The pet salon where I get my dogs groomed ran out of my normal flea shampoo Kenic Flea Rid ($9.99).  The manager said this was also an excellent quality shampoo.This shampoo is good, but my dogs scratched constantly after using it.  I finally got so panicked about their scratching that I stopped using it.  Several times I had to wash it off with a regular grooming shampoo.  The scratching stopped.I guess this pesticide was too harsh for my sensitive skinned dogs.  Remember when you use these products you are apply pesticide.

This is one of the most superior harnesses I have ever owned.  It is made of sturdy and high quality materials.I originally bought their earlier version which had the seatbelt loop wherein you pull the seatbelt through the harness loop attachment.Motivation:While pet sitting a two year old bichon, I purchased the new version.  I wanted to keep him safe and I purchased the new version which has the easy to fit D-ring secure leash attachment that clips into the seat belt lock and clasps onto the harness with the metal D-ring.  I purchased the S/M for the bichon who measures 18" in length.  However, he is not the average size bichon toy size.Simply clip the leash attachment into the seat belt lock and clip it onto the metal ring on the harness.  Easy in and out of the car.You don't have to remove the leash attachment once it's locked in place.  Merely unclasp at the harness and re-clasp when returning.The new version also allows the pet to sit, stand, or lie comfortably, does not get tangled, and stays secure without obstruction or wrappingI loved this new design so much I upgraded and purchased two more new ones for my pups.Product Description:The harness is 100% nylon, wipes clean with a damp cloth, has a D-ring metal attachment, and safety strap swivel claps.  The product is distributed by AlphaKey Pet Products, Beverly, MA via Taiwan.Sizing:I ordered a total of two sm/med for my ShihTzu Hampshire and my Tibetan Spaniel Darby who both measure 16" in length.For this product you will have to measure the girth as well.  I found the XS just too tiny for my 18-20 lb. pets.  I purchased the S/M black harness.  The harness also comes in blue and pink, but I didn't want to have to launder too often so I chose black.With patients and multiple adjustments, I finally got it just right.  It took three of us at the pet shop and some time to get it right.

I have always loved this movie classic.  I've seen several versions of this dramatic comedy, but Elizabeth Taylor is so powerful in this film.  She co-stars with her ex-husband Richard Burton who is a power house actor. I can certainly see why she married him over and over again--what a man!This particular version does however appear to be a bit fuzzy and grainy.  It is also the widescreen version which I don't typically enjoy.  I should have read the fine print.I would look for perhaps a TMC version because they may have mastered it from the master cut rather than from video to video copying.You get what you pay for.

I ordered these reusable/washable waterproof bed pads for my Dad (75 yrs.) after he had two strokes within one month.He has only partial usage of his left leg and left arm.  He has incontinence and requires adult hygiene health care.  He is bed ridden and we have to use a lift to get him into his wheelchair and or recliner.We found the ones at the rehab and hospital to be too small.  The longer pads make it easier for the family and the CNA to change Dad and the soiled linens without removing Dad from his electric bed.The longer the pads, the easier it is to shift the patient from one side of the bed to the other and to roll the linens beneath the patient.  With other pads that are shorter we could not get a solid grip to lift, pull, roll, and tuck.We tidy Dad, shift him to one side, and then roll and tuck the pads.  We do the same for the other side and the bed is changed and fresh pads are in place.  We typically use two at a time, but please don't lump them together or stack them on top of each other.  Create a flat slightly overlapping placement because the other types of placements will cause skin deterioration and what the medical team calls 'break down'.To view this CNA technique, google it on uTube.  It's an awesome skill.  The pads are the key.  If they're too short or too small, you'll have to change the bed linens more often and leaking will be an issue.  We hurt ourselves and that's bad for Dad.We've learned a whole new respect for the CNA's and nurses aides.  Registered nurses and LPN's don't perform this service.  Many refuse to perform this service and look to the certified nursing aides (CNA) so they don't have to get their hands dirty.So to make Dad's life easier, help the CNAs and aides, and to make us more effective we rave about these comfy pads.FYI--You don't want to skimp on these in exchange for the noisy cheap plastic type that crunch when you touch them.  They're uncomfortable and they're are more like plastic bags.These pads are invaluable.

GE Energy Smart 3-Way, 7 year Life 50/100/150 Replacement Uses Only 16/25/32W 600/1600/2150 Lumens Energy Star I purchased three individual packs of these bulbs.  They do not come in multiple packs.  I also purchased the GE 100w replacement Energy Smart, longer life, soft white, multi pack, small size--not three way.I wanted bulbs for my three-way bedside lamps.  These are very expensive bulbs at $16.00 plus tax.I wanted light bulbs that could be controlled according to my usage.  I wanted to have a soft light for slumber and TV viewing, and a brighter setting for reading.These were the most excellent bulbs in the store as it stated they last for 7.5 years.  The package also states that this is based on the 3 hr. per day use.I bought 3 of these bulbs at around $16.00 plus tax = $51.60Thus far, I have blown 2 of these bulbs in the last 2 months.First the low (50) blows then you have to move on to the next strength.  Then that also blows and eventually you have nothing left.There is a warranty but you must include your register receipt and the original UPC container.  How many people retain the boxes for bulbs...what a joke.Pros:Easy to installWarrantyCons:Short life (1-2 months)Oversized for most lampsExpensiveContains mercuryMailing fee if defectiveRetain original UPC box for warrantyI do not recommend.

This was an extremely well directed and well done film.  It wasn't your typical boring cinema-bio.  Meryl nails the accent in a subtle, gentle, classy, and dignified manner. Loved the historical references and historic events that shaped Great Britain.Initially, Thatcher's husband, Dennis, was obviously an extremely confident man who certainly didn't feel threatened by his wife's brilliance and spunk. He appeared to revel in it.Love these lines from the movie--Margaret Thatcher:  "Ones life must matter.  Ones life must mean more than that.  People don't think anymore.  They only have feelings.  What we think we become."For all her errors, this woman was awesome.  The longest serving Priminister (president) in history.  She made history.  Just shows how history can be tainted by the phallic political agenda.  Thatcher's legacy should be studied in American history classes and universities.Thatcher certainly held her own and stood firm in a career inflated by much testosterone driven ego--parliament.  She appeared to speak for the common woman and man, i.e., jobs, unions, IRA bombings, unemployment, economic health, industrialism, economics, assassination attempts.  Her country appeared to be at war with itself.What an awesome speech, "It's time to put the great back in Great Britain."I loved the scene when her assistant drapes her in a classic set of double strand 8-9 mm white pearls--what a lady.  I have always hated those Texas-size and country Barbara Bush pearls.  We may have won the war but it took us centuries to catch up with the Brits...a female president (priminister).Love this line--Margaret Thatcher:  "It used to be about doing something.  Now it's about being something."  This reminds me of a proverb written by Solomon, "Everything is vanity..."This was a fascinating portrayal of Thatcher's life.Who said a woman cannot be a warrior.  Have you ever seen a pride intimidate the king of the jungle when protect their offspring.

Barbara is the quintessential loving, concerned, and supportive mother who embarks on a road trip with the hope of helping her overly anxious, condescending, and narcissistic son overcome his self inflicted solitude.Joyce (Barbara's character) loves life and she is a people person whereas her reserved son is a withdrawn and conservative chemist who loves his mother.This is a charming film that every parent should watch with their teenage and or adult child.  Though Andrew and Joyce (Mom) seem to be completly opposite in their sensibilities, they are actually more alike than they think. They not only form a partnership, but they form an incredible new parent child bond.The dialogue is common place for parental interaction, but Barbara adds oomph to the script.  Her delivery is impeccable.Joyce (Barbara) meets a really hot cowboy guy Ben Graw.  Love this line--Andrew (son): Why do you want to feed me all the time?  Food is love.  Andy seems to open up and come alive as the movie progresses.The movie held my interest and my attention.  The characters became so real to me that I forgot I was watching a movie.  It didn't insult my intelligence, and nor was it typical or boring.  I laughed, worried, and felt empathy for the characters. Charming and lovely movie.I hope you enjoy this charming and light hearted comedy as much as I did.  I tried not to give away too much of the movie.

I had to care for my father, who lived eight hours from us,  during his stroke from June 22-September 1, 2013.  I left my home clean & secure.  I emptied all trash cans, ran the dishwasher, removed pet food, & zip locked opened boxes of dry goods.When we returned home, we found rather large black roaches had invaded our home.  They were mainly clustered in the three bathrooms around the bathroom bowls. Orange County in Orlando, Florida had a major water main break that disrupted a colony of sewer dwellers thereby flooding their dwellings and forcing them to escape to high-dryer accommodations--thru the plumbing throughout Orange County.I cannot believe the number of roaches that had invaded our home.  We are minimalist & do not store clutter.  If it's not used for one month, it gets thrown out.  I allow only three items on any flat surface.  I think that is why we were able to spot each & everyone of the little critters immediately.We immediately went to the 24 hour store & purchased an abundance of pesticides--bait traps, sticky traps, & Raid Max Bug Barrier Indoor/Outdoor 30 oz. container with auto trigger.I nearly drowned every roach I shot with this chemical & all the roaches simply walked away unaffected.  Some even had the strength to climb the walls heading for the ceiling.  I had to chase those speedy little buggies, & I had to take them out the old fashion way--crunch.I sprayed the chemical in the corners of all the rooms & around the perimeter of the exterior of the home.  Upon rising in the a.m., I grab the vacuum with the expectation of finding the remains of the little critters--nothing.I have used Raid can spray in the past & I thought this would be an awesome upgrade.  I spent $10 on this 30 oz. bottle & it was a waste of money.  I rate this spray 5/5 for packaging, 5/5 for order, 0/5 for function,  0/5 for quality = 10/20 (F).  I am socked because this company is known for advocating its right to animal testing.The question that comes to mind is--did they actually test it on roaches?Pros:Auto Trigger blastNo OdorEasy ApplicationCons:Does not kill roachesIneffectiveDoes not kill on contactExpensive

(SEE PHOTO ATTACHED)--The following photo was uploaded to attest to the quality of Vaneli or Van Eli shoes made in China.I have been wearing Vaneli shoes since 1999, and I have over 275 pairs.  I have been wearing Vaneli's since they were made in Europe, namely Spain.I still enjoy these oldies but goodies.  They still look great!  However, the new crop of shoes that have been produced in China are outrageous.Rather than using durable or leather insets like Vaneli's of old, they use something similar to wallpaper.  It peels off and the black mesh underneath sticks to your feet with a sticky glue.I have had shoes that have been nicked at the hill only to discover that they were stuffed with chalk.Yes people, school board chalk covered with a simulated cover resembling wooden paneling from the 70s.I'm dating myself, but if you remember when wooden paneling was popular during the 'Brady Bunch' era you may recall that homes used wallpaper that resembled wood because paneling was so expensive.It is to be noted that the shoes in the photo have only been worn three time and I am not hard on my shoes.I typically walk from the car to the front door of any event, and I always carry walking shoes so I don't damage my heels.I paid some $175 (sale) for these shoes, and as you can see they are slightly worn on the bottom. The proof is in the pudding, but for this review the photo!This is the sixth pair of new shoes that have disintegrated in this manner.  I became so irritated that I stopped shopping at the Orlando store.I guess I wasn't the only one, because the store closed it's doors March 2013.

I purchased the top of the line Samsung refrigerator 11 months ago.  The new refrigerator came with the initial filter.I noticed immediately that my drinking water and ice cube quality had improved substantially.There was such an improvement in the taste, smell, and odor of my water that when the filter needed replacing, I noticed the difference immediately.It was definitely the water filter.  I could not drink the water once the filter expired.  The red light came on and my dislike for tap water revived.I went to the hardware store to purchase a new filter and the price was through the roof.  I also went online to the Samsung website and the price was even more excessive.I decided to check Amazon, and I got a terrific deal on the 3 pack refrigerator water filter.  I saved money, eliminated the use of bottled water, and fell back in love with the quality of my water.Thus far, I have had 3 filter replacements in an 11 month time period.  I'm sure if you have a larger family, you may have to replace it more often.This is a superb product that is saving me money.  I don't have to purchase bottle water and deal with that terrible plastic taste and odor.I also feel safer because I don't have to deal with the possible toxic side effects of plastic.

Lady Anti Monkey Butt Anti Friction Powder contains cornstarch, calamine powder, tricalcium phosphate, and patented microparticle polymer fragrance.I was introduced to Lady Anti Monkey Butt by a friend who purchased it at Walmart.  However, when I went back several times to repurchase they didn't have the product in stock--just the Baby Anti Monkey Butt.I fell in love with the product because of the wonderful fragrance and the smooth satiny feeling.  I also liked that it absorbs sweat and controls friction in private areas and discreet bra areas.I feel more confident and comfortable when I use Lady Anti Monkey Butt.  I cannot start my day without the product.  I live in Orlando, FL and the weather is so hot that just walking from your car to the building causes irritation.It keeps me dryer than many other types of powders I have used over the years.  However, remember it's a powder and whereever you dust you will get a dusting.I quickly hop in the shower to powder up so I don't dust the bathroom.  This has worked to reduce excess dusting of the bedroom and bathroom.The manufacturers claims are accurate and the product is wonderful.  I highly recommend Lady Anti Monkey Butt Anti Friction Powder.  They also make one for men too.

This is the best tasting apple juice on the market, and I buy it for five (5) primary reasons:(1) Martinelli's tastes like the juice I produce from fresh produce when using my juicer, and there are no additives like corn syrup or other sweetners.(2,3) Martinelli's is safe to consume because it contains U.S. grown produce, and it is also processed in the U.S.--Other countries do no have the same environment protection laws that we have here in the U.S., and nor do they have FDA consumer protection laws when it comes to banned pesticides that are known cancer causers--Alar.(4) I only purchase foods and beverages that are housed in glass bottles or containers because I am aware of the dangers associated with plastics--I am well read on the toxic dangers that are caused by long-term exposure to petroleum based products such as plastsic, and the cancer connection between plastics and the manifestation of cancer in younger and younger persons who consume foods from plastic containers, e.g., water, fastfood, processed foods, soda, etc.(5) The glass containers are environmentally friendly, recyclable, and they are collectors items--The bottles are a work of glass art, and they can be repurposed for a multitude of uses--bottle art, rustic art, glass art, vases, center pieces, candle holders, storage (flour, sugar, grains, beans, etc.), home decor, water collection, planters, cookie cutters, emergency water storage, meat tenderizing, liquid storage (paint, fermentation, home made beer), art supply storage, science projects, freshly brewed ice teas, cold coffee beverages, etc.Martinelli's is a bit pricey ($5-$6/1.5L), but the health effects and the avoidance of toxcities is worth the price--cancer is expensive.I typically purchase the product at my local grocer, but with the Amazon price I get more for my money and a better deal.I just wish Martinelli made other juices!

I originally chose this pattern for my wedding back in 1989.  I am so delighted with the delicate pattern and classic style.The sterling is high quality, and I really enjoy polishing it to a fine sparkle.  The pattern is not bulky but very refined and charming.I purchased 12-5PC place settings for $109 each between 1989-1999 from a wholesale fine china shop in Long Island, NY.  The value of these place settings is now around $900/5PC setting.They have increased substantially in value. This is Reed and Barton's finest pattern of sterling flatware.They would not be suitable for engraving because of the delicate floral pattern at the handle base.  Engraving would ruin this pattern.Unlike many sterling makers, my butter knife is completely sterling silver and not a sterling handle with stainless blade.This is something you will want to ask the merchant because it makes a difference in the value of the piece.Many manufacturers are skimping and adding stainless blades rather than the traditional sterling blade.  This decreases the value of the piece.

I first came across this lovely fragrant oil at a whole foods market.  It was a bit pricey ($10) for a 1.3 mL bottle, but I thought I'd give it a try.This is a mild but provocatively scented oil.  Whenever I wear it I get, "What smells so good."I hugged a male friend at the turn of the new year and he exclaimed, "Wow you smell good" and then he wooped it up.After some time, you may become too accustomed to the fragrance, but every one else can smell the aroma.One day I was in the car sweating with the windows down and the sunroof opened when I got a whiff of a lovely fragrance.  I couldn't figure it out--it was me.I also bought several natural perfumes that day, but none get more attention than this little bottle of musk.This little power house is worth the money--it's a head turner.  It also doesn't interfere with my asthma and it won't run people away in a crowd.

I examined both the Level 1 and Level 2 programs for the Ready for Phonics:  A fun way to learn to read for children three to seven DVD series.Both DVDs are 67 minutes, copy written in 2004, and include CDs with worksheets.  The DVDs' use video animation, songs, music, fables, and familiar characters from children's literature to teach phonics and phonemic awareness.The Level 1 DVD covers the following skills--Phonics:Alphabet review (Pp, Cc, Kk, Nn, Ii, Hh, Jj, Bb, Ll, Aa, Gg, Dd, Ff, Mm, Oo, Rr, Qq, Zz, Vv, Yy, Uu, Ss, Ww, Tt, Ee, & Xx)Phonemic Awareness:Sight words, numbers song, words for Numbers, words for colorsThe Level 2 DVD covers the following skills--Phonics:Vowels, long vowels, short vowels, short vowel story, Y as a vowel, & side-by-side vowelsPhonemic Awareness:Word families, 110 most used words, World is Round Song, blends, diagraphs, silent e, plural & bossy rGrammar:Capitalization, periods & questions marksI reviewed this series with the intent of using it to enhance the reading curriculum for my elementary students.The animation is rather dated when compared with other series--School Zone.  The skills are not as thoroughly addressed as I would have preferred.Age appropriate seqencing and repetition are lacking and some skills that are introduced are not thoroughly covered.  For example, at the beginning of the video long vowels are introduced.Yet, the video skips directly to short vowels sounds without providing comprehensive examples, images, nor a review of long vowels sounds.  The video rushes through short vowels and leads directly into word families using short vowel sounds.This perhaps is an excellent series that can be used as bellwork or during transitional periods--dismissal.  I found it rather confusing and it is therefore ineffective for use during the 90 minute reading block.These DVDs may be more appropriate for home use or for entertainment purposes (parents).  However, it falls rather short on educational effectiveness (teachers).  This is a cute series that may be useful with toddlers and preschoolers.

I purchased individual pieces of these pans for baking some time ago.  This pan was new and had not been used before.I recently starting using them and found them to be extremely inferior.Initially I thought that I had overcooked my meatloaf because it developed a thin scorched crust on the bottom.Needless to say, when I washed the pan I found that it was the nonstick coating that had adhered to my meatloaf.We were actually eating the nonstick coating that had dislodged from the bottom of the pan.  The rest of the coating came off in the dishwasher.I also found that the coating is definitely not nonstick.  It was difficult to clean even though I brushed it with a generous amount of olive oil.I rate this pan 0/4 for function, 5/5 for form, 5/5 for appearance prior to use, and 0/5 for durability.I am not certain about the health affects associated with consuming the nonstick coating, but I'm sure it's not suppose to be edible.

I purchased this product just to give it a try because I had tried so many other products to keep my bowl fresh between scrubbing.I wanted a product to keep my master bedroom smelling clean and fresh. I also wanted a product that would reduce the bowl ring and yellowing.I wanted a product that would not be too toxic or have an overwhelming fragrance. After trying several products, I happened upon this product, but I was ready to be dissatisfied.This product surprised me when I opened the box. There is a tube, clips, 2-tablets, and specialized equipment that requires installation. However, the installation instructions are a breeze.When I initially spotted the tablets, I remember the unfortunate damaged caused by those giant chlorine tablets. With this product you will have no such damage.The tubes easily connect to the overflow tube, and the tablets are housed in a plastic compartment so you don't damage your internal hardware. With each flush, you clean and freshen your bowl.The fragrance is so mild you don't smell it. This product really works to keep the bowl fresh, yellow-free, and there is no chemical smell.I give this product 5/5 for function, 5/5 for easy installation, 5/5 for fragrance, and 5/5 for design.

I purchased the Delta Elevated Toilet Seat at a local discount home decor store that sounds like Moss.  I purchased the item for $14.99 plus 7% tax.The product was cumbersome to install, and you will need tools (Phillips screw driver, 1/4" straight blade screwdriver, & pliers) to install it properly.This item is best installed by someone who is familiar with the make up of bathroom fixtures.  This was a super buy.I wanted an elevated seat for the bathroom bowl because I started to have significant mobility issue with my knees and back.  I am also 5'11 and most seats are simply too low for my frame.The product raises the seat to a very comfortable level of 4" and ADA height.  It has locking hardware that must be installed.It also has sturdy support handles that hold weight pressure of around 200 lbs. without sliding.  The front opening provides easy access, and there is ample space between the two handles.I actually feel as though I am not bending at all.  The product comes with a 10 year warantee. I was unable to decipher the installation directions for the locking hardware.However, I positioned the seat over the existing toilet seat and it fits rather well and it stays safely in place.I understand that this is not the mfg suggested recommendation for installation, but I am comfortable with this use.However, I do not recommend this for someone who has a sever handicap or serious balance issues--please follow the mfg recommendations.I give this product 5/5 for appearance, 5/5 for function, 5/5 for durability, and 4/5 for installation difficulty.The product is also light weight and easy to maneuver.

I found this product at a local drug store chain, and I decided to give it a try because it was on sale for approximately 1/2 the original $35 price tag.I also wanted to try the product because the label claims impressed me (i-flex for younger feeling joints, clinically proven joint relief, all natural & glucosamine-free, and improve mobility & flexibility).I also wanted to eliminate my use of over 4 different products that served the same purpose:For 15 days out of the month, I at one time took a popular osteo powder mixture (gelatin, glucosamine hydrochloride, chondroitin, and msm), super collagen (type 1 & 3), and joint support complex tablets (glucosamine, chondroitin, and msm)--costly and way too many substances!The major component of the i-flex is 2.25g rosehip (whole fruit) and gelatin.  I took 3 capsules per night and my pain vanished.  I now take it 2-3 times each month and still no pain.Not only have I been able to reduce dependence on too many substances, but my pain is significantly reduced.I can bend without pain and walk up the stairs in my two-story home without knee, hip, and back pain.I continue to take my calcium, biotin, and turmeric.  I'm not perfect, but I'm doing so much better than when I took all those other substances.

This Lucien men's watch is handsome, comfortable, and after a month's usage is holding up nicely to routine daily wear.  I wish I could say that I was putting this watch through the paces of the glamorous jet set, testing it in exotic locales where a timepiece is a personal status symbol, but for the needs of a regular guy, I'd say this watch does just fine.So far, the best aspect of this watch is its look - it is a very handsome watch with a striking royal blue face against chrome and with a black leather strap.  Interestingly, even though the watch has a leather band, it uses a metal hasp to unlock and expand the band for removal - I may not be describing it correctly, but the result is you can pop off the watch without undoing the little pin that holds the leather band in place.  The result is that even though you're using a leather band, the band won't get the worn-out look so many leather bands get through daily wear - this watch will look new for a long time.This watch is for regular everyday use and does not provide any features for, say, an extreme athlete or world traveler.  The watch has three sub-dials - one tracks the day of the week ("Mon," "Tues," "Wed," etc.), one tracks the day of the month (by number), and the third tracks the seconds.  No stop watch, no pedometer, no heart rate, no tracking multiple time zones simultaneously, etc.  Which is all fine, but before buying a watch you want to know what you're getting.  The watch is also water-resistant, so if you're one of those rare folks who has to have a watch on while swimming, look elsewhere.I'm sure that an aristocrat will size up this watch as a 'value' watch in no time.  It is reasonably priced, attractive, and seems designed to last a long time.

These four short exercise/resistance bands are an excellent low-cost addition to your home or travel fitness regimen.The kid includes four exercise bands, each about two inches wide and ten inches long.  These bands are designed to be stretched about 2.5 times their relaxed length, so they provide for a good range of motion.  These bands are color-coded according to varying degrees of resistance - yellow is 'easy' and blue is 'extra heavy.'  The kit also includes a handy travel bag that easily holds the four bands for convenient travel or storage.  Altogether, the kit weighs less than a pound and occupies virtually no space in your bag - any decent laptop computer bag has a pocket that will easily hold the bag completely full.These exercise bands are an excellent and affordable augmentation to your workout gear, particularly if you like to get in a bit of a workout while traveling.  These resistance bands can be used for a variety of stretching and toning exercises and are excellent for exercises that are hard to replicate with free weights.  A classic band workout is to lie on your side with a band around your ankles or knees.  All you need to do is lift your top leg for 10-20 reps and the resistance of the band will take care of the rest - three sets on both sides three or four times a week (as part of a regular fitness regime) will pay dividends.  While this kit does not come with an instructional/workout DVD, a few minutes on Youtube and you'll find several suggestions for band workouts.What is terrific about these bands is that they are incredibly convenient.  You can take them anywhere - they effectively eliminate excuses from doing basic workouts.  I watched a bit of football over the weekend, and was able to use the bands to stretch my hamstrings while watching the game.  All you do is sit on the edge of the couch, loop the band around the ball of your foot, and gently lift your leg and pull (it's your hamstring, so be careful).  I also fly regularly on business from the West Coast to the East Coast, and I can't tell you how much I appreciate using these bands to stretch out the kinks of a cross-country flight.Other band kits offer five or six bands, but given that I do not make these bands a core component of my workout the four available bands provide a suitable range of resistance.  I do not use the yellow (light resistance) band yet as it provides too little resistance, but it's possible that I just haven't found the right exercise yet.  The light resistance band also might be a terrific aid for anyone doing rehabilitation work following an injury.All things considered, these bands are an excellent low-cost addition to your home fitness regime.  Highly recommended

Simon Toyne's "The Searcher" is my first Toyne novel, but it follows on his successful "Sanctus" trilogy of religious-themed thrillers.  Based on "The Searcher," I have some reading to catch up on."The Searcher" is set in a remote Arizona town near the Mexican border - a tapped out mining town founded once upon a time by Jack Cassidy, a wandering priest who found divine revelation and material treasure in the wilderness.  Set in the modern day, the town of Redemption, Arizona, is hardly a dot on the map but it is the most important place in the world for its townsfolk.In the opening chapters, Redemption may be consumed by an inferno, which is interesting for two reasons.  First, the inferno was caused by a plane crash, and a few of the locals know that someone very very important was on that plane . . . and someone even more important will exact horrible revenge on everyone concerned (or just nearby) if that death is confirmed. Second, there seems to be one survivor of the plane crash.  His name is Solomon Creed.Or so he thinks.  Creed has amnesia.  Creed has no idea where he is or who he is.  But Creed is unusual in that he is almost perfectly white - white skin, white hair, light grey eyes - more a marble statue walking the earth than an albino.  Creed also knows things instantly - how do diagnose a burn victim, the chemical composition of pharmaceuticals, and whether someone is suicidal - without any understanding of how.  And Creed knows that he has been sent to Redemption to save a man.  A man who was buried earlier that day.In lesser hands, this story could be ridiculous bordering on comical.  In Toyne's careful telling, the story of Solomon Creed's arrival in Redemption is a true thriller.  The town of Redemption has a rich, complex history, and Toyne doles out the details with great skill, so the story evolves logically and relentlessly, and developments may occur at critical times but never serve as escapes for a writer who's written himself into a corner.  Solomon Creed is a fascinating hero, bestowed with amazing talents and gifts yet never falling into boring superman territory.  And the supporting characters of Redemption are given flaws and positive attributes.  While there are a couple of true villains, in general Toyne imbues these characters with depth and humanity.  To be sure, this is not "A Song of Ice and Fire" where a villain gets the Jaime Lannister treatment, but "The Searcher" is also only about half as long as one of Martin's tomes.I'll stop now to keep this spoiler-free, but "The Searcher" is one of the most pleasant surprises I've had as a reader this year.  I give this five stars not because this is a book that I want to re-read immediately or is an all-time classic, but it's been a long time since I've read the first volume in a planned series of books that had me so eagerly looking forward to the next installment.  I may have to go back to Lee Child's "Killing Floor."Highly recommended for fans of thrillers.

Long-time Washington Post reporter Dale Russakoff spent years covering Newark, New Jersey, as part of her turf in the paper's New York bureau, and her command of the subject matter comes through in the riveting, maddening "The Prize: Who's in Charge of America's Schools?"  Russakoff uses the attempt to reform Newark's broken public school system to explore how the district broke and why it is so difficult to fix the darn thing.The Newark public school system provides all the ingredients necessary for a standard Hollywood "great teacher saves troubled students" flick.  Years political cronyism, white flight to the suburbs, and broken promises have destroyed the Newark public schools - at the time of this book, total spending on a per-pupil basis was around $20,000, third-highest in the nation, and yet the illiteracy and failure rates were appalling - in some classes, less than five percent of students could read at grade level.  You had a bloated bureaucracy and a system that rewarded seniority over achievement, targets obviously in need of a straight-talking, no-nonsense, passionate hero to come in and save the day with a great monologue or two.And you had the potential heroes.  Newark Democratic Mayor Cory Booker was a national rock star of a politician - a young, Stanford-educated Rhodes Scholar - who was (seemingly) committed to turning around Newark's schools.  New Jersey's Republican Governor Chris Christie, a political star in his own right, also wanted to take his no-nonsense approach to clean house in Newark, both for the good of the students . . . . crushing the local teacher's union was just a cherry on that sundae.  And best of all, Facebook founder and billionaire Mark Zuckerberg announced - on Oprah! - that he would personally dedicate $100 million to the reform effort in Newark and wanted to help convince his friends to pony up a matching $100 million.  The set up was perfect - a bipartisan team of political leaders were going to put politics aside for the good of the kids, and they had seemingly unlimited funds - what can't be done with $200 million?And then, reality hit.  Russakoff brilliantly follows the collapse of this wonderful opportunity under the weight of paranoia, politics, missteps, and competing agendas.  While there is no end to the problems that come in trying to reform a school district as horrific as Newark's, one of the biggest issues was that the school reform movement - led by idealistic scholars and financed by massive endowments and billionaires - tends to be tone-deaf to the concerns of the local community.  In many ways, that's reasonable - the local folks are the ones who the school reformers blame for ruining the schools in the first place.  But this is a democracy, and in Newark the reform movement thought that it could lay out its plan for change and that the locals would simply accept it - and who could possibly defend Newark's current schools?The locals, however, have a voice, and in Newark there is a long history of being taken advantage of or lied to - and there is not a really kind way of saying this - by white people who don't live there.  That describes the reformers in a nutshell.  And the reformers were taking on huge issues. Right or wrong, teaching was one of the best jobs in Newark, with union protections and healthy salaries, so when the reformers make the elimination of tenure a core issue, the locals fight back.  That's just one example of how the tone-deaf school reformers failed to build any grassroots support for their initiatives.  To be fair, much of the opposition they faced was cynical - people protecting their own cushy jobs at the expense of the students - but the reformers have a lot of responsibility here, too.Russakoff is truly a fly on the wall for this whole debacle.  She is there as Cory Booker turns from rock star to political liability.  She is there when superintendent Cami Anderson gets shouted down at a public meeting (and called the devil!).  She is there when a young teacher helps a young boy get up to grade level in reading, only to have it all come crashing down the next year.  And she is there when an idealistic young teacher - who has all the talent and desire to improve Newark's public schools - wrestles with the decision to teach at a charter school."The Prize" is a pretty short book, but it is an essential read for anyone who cares at all about education and the state of our cities.  That should be pretty much everyone.

These Panasonic collapsible 'travel' earphones are a good value for travelers who want something more than earbuds but who are not hard-core music enthusiasts.We live in a day and age when you can spend far more on first-rate earphones than you need to on a first-rate music player.  Part of the confusion is that there's no obvious design feature that allows you to see at a glance that a certain set of earphones is inherently better than another - you've got to put the darn things on to discover how things sound, how much outside sound is squelched, etc.The Panasonic collapsible travel earphones cost less than $30, fold up into a convenient small bundle, and provide a decent sound and are reasonably comfortable.  I have a higher end set of earphones from AKG that beats these earphones on virtually every metric, but they cost a lot more.The sound issues become more apparent if you're closely listening to your music - if you're more of an audiobook or podcast listener, these earphones will serve just fine.If you're spending less than $30 on your earphones, you have to accept that you're not getting the highest-quality music experience.  So the next key variable is how comfortable are these earphones - can I wear them on a long travel day and still feel OK when I get to my destination?  On that score, these earphones are perfectly satisfactory. Each earpiece has a good-but-not-amazing pillow/pad, and the phones are sufficiently flexible that you don't feel like they are squishing your head after half an hour.All in all, a good value buy.

Full disclosure - this review comes from my better half, who is both the jewelry-wearer in our family and also blessed with infinitely better artistic taste than I - so that's good news for you.These "Celtic Tree of Life"-designed silver earrings are beautifully made and substantial - they do not look cheap at all despite their reasonable price.  The size is perfect - big enough to be noticeable but not huge or heavy.  The oxidized treatment gives depth to the design and the way these hang on the ear wire is interesting.Jewelry is obviously a purchase of personal taste, but if you're looking for reasonably-priced 'tree of life' jewelry or earrings that would be great for every-day wear but still beautiful, these would be a wonderful choice.

Charles Belfoure ("The Paris Architect") is an architect by profession and training, and that comes through in his entertaining but paper-thin second novel, "House of Thieves."The good news is that Mr. Belfoure has a command of setting and the ability to create a terrific potboiler of a plot.  As an architect, it should be no surprise that Mr. Belfoure has an eye for detail.  In "House of Thieves," the New York City of the late 19th century comes alive.  A successful architect, John Cross, lives the stereotypical life of a society gentleman.  He is respected and wealthy, but he must be stoic on the outside - a single whiff of scandal will see him and his entire family exiled forever from the good standing among the Knickerbocker families.  His wife, Helen, is brilliant and gorgeous, but John more or less ignores her because society expects him to (and forces both of them into stupidly rigid roles).  His eldest son, George, is a Harvard graduate and seems destined to be a great academic. His daughter, Julia, will be the belle of the New York society debutante scene, and his younger son Charlie is cute and adorable.But all the Crosses have their own sins (get the pun?) that threaten to bring ruin to all.  Worst of all is George's gambling addiction, which puts him in hock to the criminal underworld.  To pay off his son's debts, John must use his knowledge of building design to help the gangsters rob from the elite of New York society.  And, of course, once Cross proves that he's pretty good at it, the gangsters find ways to keep him part of the family . . . or else his will be erased forever.All this is great stuff, and there are other departures from the Straight and Narrow for the other members of the Cross clan.As long as Belfoure describes what people are doing or the world they are living in, "House of Thieves" is a fine, first-rate entertainment.  Belfoure offers a lot of Architecture 101, but he never does so at the expense of the plot or story, and he has a keen sense for the Upstairs/Downstairs life of Manhattan at the time.But, unfortunately, when Belfoure's characters talk to each other, the sand gets in the gears, often painfully so.  Writing dialogue is extremely difficult, and the dialogue of "House of Thieves" is workmanlike at best.  Belfoure unfortunately underlines his dialogue with adverbs, such as:  "'I am so sorry . . . ,' he said apologetically."  He already said that he's sorry - why throw in "apologetically"?  Dialogue is too often used for the recitation of basic facts - the exposition gets old.Belfoure also doesn't quite have a handle on his characters.  The Crosses are a mercurial bunch.  One moment, John Cross is an out-of-shape flabby architect, the next he's putting pistol shots through a window from a moving elevated train car.  Cross learns that he enjoys the thrills of stealing, but at other times he's horrified by what he's done.  I'm fine with people vacillating, but the problem with Cross is that he seems to forget either that he enjoys stealing or was bothered by it . . . he just bounces from one emotion to another.  And this pervades all the Crosses - each of them in their own way finds their way to a double life, and it all goes far too easy for them except for the occasional passage of unease.Supporting characters are for the most part threadbare, and once their use is up Belfoure can dispose of them with unseemly speed . . . the body count of "House of Thieves" is pretty high, but Belfoure is content to rip off the bandage rather than build a more appropriate level of tension and terror.All in all, "House of Thieves" is a good book.  I hope Hollywood pays attention - with a first-rate screenwriter, this could be adapted into one hell of an entertaining movie.  (Heavily adapted, mind you.)

Scott Shane, as a reporter for the New York Times assigned to cover the intelligence community, could probably use his job as the means to launch any number of trashy spy novels loosely based on real-world events.  Fortunately for us, while Shane may write such books in the future, at present he's written a very serious book about a very serious topic - the American use of drone technology to wage war in the Middle East (and by extension, everywhere).In "Objective Troy," Shane explains that while the use of unmanned flying machines has been a military dream for decades, in recent years America has developed the drone into one of its most effective tools for waging war.  The drone is also among our most controversial military tools.  The drone is a near-perfect tool for the modern American military - we can fight without putting our soldiers' lives in jeopardy.  Proponents of drone technology also cite the drone's amazing surveillance capabilities, claiming that we can use drones to verify facts on the ground with an accuracy we could only dream about a few years ago.  Also, the drone is a much more 'timely' weapon because it can launch a rocket from very close range.  In the 'old days,' the rocket or missile was often launched from a ship, resulting in a delay of a few hours between the decision to launch and the strike.  This delay, drone supporters argue, led to an unacceptable number of missed targets and collateral damage.The drone is not without controversy, of course.  The sheer one-sided nature of drone warfare in the Middle East is cause for resentment.  Drones are not invisible or silent - many communities have learned to head for cover if they hear or see a drone.  Drones are also not surgical instruments, and collateral damage still results from many drone strikes.  There is also a misconception that the drone pilots are essentially playing videogames.  Shane observes that drone pilots spend scores of hours tracking individual targets before an attack is ever made, and the drone pilot sees the carnage that ensues.  This process is taking a toll on the drone pilots - it may not be bloody, but it's there.To drive his narrative, Shane chooses two fascinating characters.  The first is President Barack Obama, who successfully used his opposition to the Iraq War to win the White House.  This led many to assume that President Obama would be a peacenik, and that is definitely not the case.  Under the Obama Administration, the use of drone technology has escalated and the body count is high.The second character is not exactly a household name in America, but perhaps he should be.  Anwar al-Malaki, American born and raised in America by America-loving parents, was a successful and (apparently) moderate imam near Washington DC on 9/11.  Over the ensuing years, the imam who initially condemned the 9/11 attacks to his brother grew increasingly hostile to the United States, and eventually became the object of a successful manhunt by the Obama Administration, and a drone strike took his life.The immediacy of these two stories brings the real-world impact of the drone home.  While it is true that al-Malaki remains a bit of a cipher - we know a bit of his story, but not enough - Shane uses al-Malaki's story as well as President Obama's to explain how the drone is no longer a technology that we can ignore.Sure, the military may have tanks and nuclear missiles, but these colossally expensive weapons might as well be science fiction for most Americans.  But drones are cheap, plentiful, and incredibly effective.  If Anwar al-Malaki can convince one of his acolytes to try to bring down an airplane over Detroit with exploding underwear, we need to be concerned about the rise of the drone.

Paul Cleave's "Trust No One" utilizes one of my favorite tools in the writer's toolbox - the Unreliable Narrator.  Writers can have a lot of fun when the narrator of the story is completely untrustworthy, and yet over the course of the story builds the reader's trust, only to pull the rug out from under the reader at the climax of the story.  Unfortunately, the Unreliable Narrator story is perhaps the most susceptible to spoilers, so I will be brief with this review.Cleave's hero, Jerry Grey, is about as sympathetic a protagonist as you might find these days - he's married, with a grown-up daughter any man would be proud to call his own, and a successful crime writer under the pseudonym Henry Cutter.  But Jerry is in the early stages of one of those diseases that you would not wish on your worst enemy - Alzheimer's.  Writing in his Madness Journal - he has good days, but they are few and getting more rare - Jerry writes about his descent into dementia.  Filled with the frustration and fear of increasing gaps in his memory, Jerry's early pages in the Madness Journal are pathetic, bordering on the depressing - particularly since Jerry is living in a nursing home that is maddening in its Pleasantville cocoon of safety and calm.But there's a wrinkle. Jerry, at bad moments, believes that he's the killer from one of his crime novels.  That's one thing. Then, there's the fact that other people around Jerry, including the police, start thinking that he might be the same person as well.Cleave builds "Trust No One" slowly - this is not a Grisham-esque page-turner - but with increasing power and dread.  Focusing on Alzheimer's as it does, "Trust No One" is often a dark book, but it's also a bit of fun as the reader tries to stay one step ahead of Jerry, the Unreliable Narrator who claims that he can't remember what he had for breakfast, but on occasion believes that he actually murdered someone in a manner identical to the murder in one of his books.Recommended, but not the feel-good book of the year.  I reserve the right to up this review to four stars.  As of right now, I'm not sure I'm going to re-read "Trust No One" anytime soon, but that may change.

I'll write this review from my perspective rather than that of my four-year old son, who is transfixed by CybeRex, "the Robotic Battling Dinosaur," complete wtih Batman figure.  Apparently this is part of the "Batman Unlimited" storyline where the Joker has corrupted technology to his own twisted ends . . .That's the logic that leads to Batman riding a computerized/mechanical/t-rex hybrid. That's a tough one for me to get my head around, and when I look at this big blue monstrosity, it looks fairly ridiculous.Still, it's a pretty cool toy. Batman rides the CybeRex like Han Solo on a Taun-Taun, and CybeRex is reasonably articulated with moving legs, tail (with Bat-battle-axe tip) and even the little T-rex arms.  The CybeRex even has a cage attached to his gut for holding the bad guys Batman captures.But what makes this ride alternately bizarre and cool is that if you squeeze a big trigger under CybeRex's tail, Batman lifts up on a huge cannon that slides out of CybeRex's back and you can shoot "battle discs."  That's pretty darn cool.This toy is of pretty good size - CybeRex is around 18 inches long when fully assembled, and the Batman figure is about three or four inches high.  As you can expect, he's not a very canonical Batman - no cape, and his hands are larger than his head. He does look suitably grim, though.The battle discs are not launched with a great deal of force, so it's safe for kids to play with them without hurting each other - you do have the standard choking hazards for the wee ones, and there's a good chance that you'll have to spend some time hunting down the discs after your kid plays with the toy for a few minutes.  But that goes with the territory.Oddly enough, the bizarre nature of this toy - Batman and dinosaurs - can make this toy a great 'bridge' toy if your kid has other superhero toys as well as some toy dinosaurs - these are two genres that don't cross over very often, so here's your chance.Worth a shot, but you can't use it to indoctrinate your kid into the Batman canon.

How does the Vatican walk the "miracle" highwire in our modern age?  The Catholic Church is founded on literally miraculous events, and every year there are scores of believers (and cynics) who claim to have witnessed a miracle - whether a faith healing, a statue of Mary that weeps tears of blood, or the face of Jesus appearing in their toast.  While it would be easy for some to dismiss each of these events as self-delusions or hoaxes, the Church has plenty of reasons to take them seriously - not least of them being that the Church officially believes in the power of miracles.Long-time Vatican reporter, journalist and author John Thavis ("The Vatican Diaries") turns his insightful eye and brilliant pen to these issues with "The Vatican Prophecies: Investigating Supernatural Signs, Apparitions and Miracles in the Modern Age."  His exploration is fast-moving but in-depth - the writing is a master class of direct storytelling, grounded in truth and with a storyteller's eye for detail.  Balanced and thorough, Thavis takes the reader on explorations of some of the key 'miracles' of the modern age that simultaneously trouble and give hope to Christians everywhere.  But given the fact that the Vatican is the most wealthy, most powerful and most influential Christian organization in the world, its "seal of approval" for any miracle is by far the most important.  Thavis explores such thorny issues as the Shroud of Turin, miraculous healings, and the repeated visions of Mary in Medjugorje, Bosnia, examining the complex issues of faith, science, and the Church's desire to be taken seriously in an increasingly technological/scientific world."The Vatican Prophecies" is no rant or screed - Thavis writes with balance, explaining the facts as they are and allowing the reader to draw his or her own conclusions.  The visions of Medjugorge, for example, are examined both through the tales of the visionaries as well as the complex political history of the area - not to mention several other episodes across the world where people have claimed to have seen or spoken with Mary.  The Shroud of Turn gets a thorough investigation, from its murky history to its recent debunking to its current renaissance after the debunking was questioned.Through it all, the Church explores these issues with reserve consistent with a two-thousand year old organization.  It was refreshing to read of the Church's candid statement that it prefers many of these miracles to fade from view rather than become popular sensations.  While you may not be surprised at the ability of people to cash in on these phenomenae, I greatly enjoyed exploring how seriously the Church takes these events and how sensitive the Church is to both its role in our modern world while recognizing, at the same time, that sometimes it is hard to explain why someone is cured of cancer unless you accept the miraculous.Recommended.

I am not normally a fan of biography - it usually takes me too long to get through the "early years" to the time that makes the subject noteworthy. All too often the tenuous links the author uses to connect the youthful prodigy to the accomplished adult are strained and not all that interesting. So you can get a plodding tour of events, but hardly a riveting story.My observations do not hold true for the life of Theodore Roosevelt, whose tale is as fascinating as any real-life American story could possibly be. How could the story of an asthmatic, sickly youth who, by sheer force of will and energy, become a Harvard-educated cowboy, bear hunter, adventurer, soldier, scourage of civic corruption, military hero, governor, vice president, and president - all before the age of 50?Teddy Roosevelt's life is fascinating enough, and Edmund Morris tells the tale exceedingly well. A mediocre author can render dull even the most riveting plot, but Morris elevates the story and keeps it exciting even as he walks through virtually every signficant moment in a lifetime overstuffed with them. Morris finds the valuable stuff in childhood, college, courtship, heartbreak, travel, combat, politics . . . suffice it to say that Morris can go into deep details when he needs to, but can also get you laughing with a one-sentence description of Teddy Roosevelt climbing a mountain so quickly he left his guide gasping for breath halfway up.The study of Roosevelt is essential to understanding America's emergence onto the national stage in the late 19th and early 20th century. Most Americans alive today only know the America of the post-WWII boom, and it is essential to our understanding of ourselves that we were not always theh straw that stirred the global drink. Thanks to Teddy, we were never quite the same country again, and understanding his role in the country's philosophical growth is vital to understanding the idea of being an "American."Highly recommended.

This sleeping pad caught my eye with its distinctive Swiss cheese design and the inclusion of a 'pillow' - all of my previous sleeping pads for backpacking have been the traditional rectangular affairs.  While I haven't had the opportunity for extended usage of this pad yet, my initial experience strongly suggests that it will get used often.The pocketed design of this pad helps to make it very light weight, VERY fast to blow up, and exceptionally small when folded up - all as advertised. But my family usually does the kind of camping that doesn't require back packs be as lightweight as possible (kids still too young for long tramping). Still, the small size and weight makes this convenient when packing gear. Sleeping on the pocketed design feels a little like a massaging pad with pressure points and I thought it was really comfortable. I'm a back sleeper and didn't experience any problems with the holes in the pad as some side sleepers mentioned.Deflating and rolling it back up are both quick and easy.The only negative for me was the pillow. The design isn't bad and it's easy to adjust the firmness by letting a little air out since it has a separate inflation valve. My complaint is that even when fully inflated it is just even in height with the pad and I sleep best with a pillow that props my head up higher than my body. This is a personal preference so the pillow would probably be perfect for someone who likes a lower pillow height.All in all, a fine sleeping pad and well-suited for back-packing.

A five-star review is a delicate thing - should it be reserved for products that are truly "Great," that hit the high water marks across the board for quality, enjoyment, stand-the-test-of-time Classics?  That's a fair interpretation.  For such an interpretation, I should reserve five-star reviews for personal favorites such as "Casablanca," "Shogun," and Tina Fey's impersonation of Sarah Palin.But what to do with a book where you had virtually no expectations or underlying assumptions, being your first exposure to the author, and you find a voice that is (at least to your uninformed eyes), completely original, surprising, and entertaining?  Sascha Arango's first novel, "The Truth and Other Lies," made my cross-country flight from DC to Portland a delight, even though I fly coach and five-plus hours of being treated like a polite sardine wears thin.  Arango apparently has a highly commendable track record of writing for German TV, and his first novel reveals that he will do just fine as a novelist, thank you very much."TTaOL" focuses on one Henry Hayden, an anti-hero right up your alley is you've enjoyed the talents of Mr. Ripley or even the psychoses of Patrick Bateman.  You can't avoid certain spoilers here, as Henry is a chameleon, a villain wearing the skin of an extremely successful, overly decent human being. A successful author of multiple thrillers who shows no signs of stopping, he lives well on his coastal farm with his adoring (and seemingly-adored) wife and dog, and he is also one of those guys who in their late 30s looks like he walked off of a Ralph Lauren advertisement.  Immune to love handles or second chins, Henry eats well, drinks well, and discretely seduces well as he goes from book signing to publishing launch to awards banquets, lapping up the adoration of fans from across the world.And (here's the first spoiler) - he's never written a word.Arango fills his novel with an original cast of characters, each humanized to a certain degree, recognizable yet unfamiliar enough to be surprising.  Henry moves among them with ease at first, but then with greater desperation and fear as events spin out of control.  For a man who has built his life on lies, what could be more horrifying than to have those lies exposed?  For Henry, there are so many lies, and a few of them go back so many years . . .A true page-turner, "TTaOL" flies by - Arango's novel is as chiseled as Henry's jawline.  Multiple storylines and perspectives weave together almost seamlessly, and even a couple of supporting characters who would otherwise scream "FROM CENTRAL CASTING" bring their own idiosyncracies and foibles to the story.  After suffering through some "thrillers" this year hardly worth the title, "TTaOL" came as a refreshing burst of sunshine - there are authors out there who can surprise and entertain you, and Arango has proven that he's one of them.

In this slim book (paperback edition clocks in at a little over 200 pages, complete with appendices that include questions for the author, discussion questions, etc.), Nadia Bolz-Weber explores through anecdotes from her life how we encounter God in our interactions with other people, and these other people are invariably not "saints" in the classic sense.That's fitting, because Bolz-Weber (perhaps we should call her Pastrix, since has written a book with that title) is in no sense your stereotypical Lutheran pastor.  Yes, she gets a lot of mileage out of her look - she looks like a tattooed graduate student who took a year off to follow the Ramones on tour.  But Bolz-Weber also acknowledges that her path to the church followed several years of addiction and questionable decision-making.  That she does so with such candor, humor and insight makes her books worth reading.If you struggle with Christianity because you associate it with the unthinking, eye-glazed, utterly-without-doubt "God is good," "Just do what the Bible says," and "Acting right makes you a Christian" crowd,  Bolz-Weber is the perfect tonic for you.  In this book, she thinks critically about being a Christian in today's world - she confronts her own prejudices (defiantly liberal, she learns to her chagrin that a person she admires is a gun-toting 2nd Amendment fan, and also that she enjoys firing a gun) and struggles (can she find the grace to say a prayer for the lunatic who shot up the Sandy Hook elementary school?) with a great deal of insight.  Fortunately, she's a good enough writer that the navel-gazing doesn't last too long - she keeps things moving, like a good pastor should.Ultimately, Bolz-Weber's message is simple:  Jesus did not come to Earth to live among the upper classes, who have the resources to live good,  charitable lives without much real struggle.  Jesus lived among those who struggled, who suffered, and who had made some very bad decisions on their own.  That is us, and Bolz-Weber reminds us that the struggle for holiness is both human and holy.Highly recommended for anyone struggling with fitting in with the stereotypical Christian church.

These kitchen tools are made of typical silicone and are very flexible and non-stick. There is metal inside the handle of each tool, extending down into the business end of each utensil, giving just the right amount of support. The spoon and spatula have become my go-to tools because of that great support paired with the flexibility that is so great about silicone. I've run them through the dishwasher several times and they have come out perfectly.My favorite feature - the once piece design. Unlike silicone tools that have handles that separate from their handles, causing buildup of crud in the handle hole of the silicone, these are seamless, and therefore perfectly clean, and easy to hold too.My lease favorite feature - the pasta fork. Even though the metal interior extends partially into the fork end, it doesn't extend in to the tines of the fork, and this makes it much less useful than my traditional metal pasta fork. The silicone flops around, making it less functional. It's not completely useless, but I'm going to stick with my metal pasta fork.I'd say that the one-piece design makes this set a great pickup if you're looking for new silicone kitchen tools.

I have three kids, so it's fair to say that we are more than a little familiar with Marvel's Avengers movie franchise.  Given the staggering hype surrounding these movies and their multibillion dollar box office, I am more or less numb to the latest toys, games, posters, clothes, etc., featuring Iron Man, Thor, Hulk, and the gang - much to the agony of my four-year old son, who has a Pavlovian response to all things Avenger.But there is something irresistable about a foot-tall talking action figure.  Reminiscent of the great GI Joe action figures of my younger days, this Captain America action figure is a keeper.  Reasonably articulate (not every single joint is movable, but there's enough mobility to allow my son to pretend old Cap is alive) and with a detachable shield, this is the Captain America from the Age of Ultron movies.  Accordingly, his suit colors is a little more vibrant than the darker, more muted (and awesome) suit from the first Captain America movie.Captain America also talks, and the voice sounds great.  He has twelve different quotes, which is enough variety to keep the younger kids from getting bored.  Officially, this action figure will 'interact' with the Hulkbuster Titan Hero action figure who has catchphrases assigned specifically to Cap, but we don't have that action figure to verify.A perfect gift for the young Captain America fan in your household, this Captain America figure appears to be solidly built to withstand pretty serious four-year-old play.  The detachable shield can get lost, so you may want to make sure this toy doesn't make it out your front door.  I would also not be surprised to see this action figure decorating the cubicles of a few overgrown kids in the office - it's that good.

This is a great iron that I would actually give 4.5 stars instead of 5 if I had that choice. As a reference my hair is pretty average, not coarse or fine, wavy, frizzy if I don't use product, long, and about 50% gray, but colored. I have owned several different kinds of flat irons over the years, and my Remington irons have always lasted until I decide to retire them to "backup" status because they are several years old. I've had more expensive brands fail around 12 months, so even though I've only used this iron for about a month I already love the reliability of the Remington brand. To start, I have to admit I was actually feeling cynical about the Vapor Infusion Technology because in my experience this is exactly the kind of new technology that doesn't work as advertised or stops working pretty quickly. I decided to load the reservoir with the included macadamia conditioning treatment and give the vapor a try, a little worried that it would make my hair look greasy. The result was fantastic! Not at all greasy, all my flyaways were gone, and I didn't have to use the anti-frizz post-styling treatment I usually use. I wash my hair every three days and I worried that by day 3 my hair would look greasy because of the oil in the vapor, but it didn't. The Vapor Infusion Technology has its own on/off button, so I did not use it on day 2 or 3 for my touch-up styling. If the Vapor Infusion Technology fails before the iron gets old I'll update this review, but for now I'm loving this option. I haven't tried using distilled water instead of the provided oil since the oil works so well and allows me to skip my other styling product.The reasons I would take away half a star if I could are for a few small reasons - first, it looks like the Macadamia oil for the Vapor chamber can only be ordered off the Remington site right now, which makes it inconvenient to replace and the instructions don't include any information about what types of conditioning treatments to shop for. Second, I prefer 2" plates for my long hair and I have had to slow down a bit using this 1" iron, so adding the vapor technology to a 2" iron would be welcomed, and last, I'm used to seeing a temperature number on my other Remington irons but this iron just starts with 2 dots, adding one dot for each increase you push. The instructions tell you the temperature range for each number of dots, but I don't want to memorize that. I've learned that 3 dots is my ideal setting, so maybe this is a nit-picky criticism. Because I've seen a couple reviews mention heat-up time I will say that I don't get this complaint at all - I turn my iron on when I start my makeup, and a few minutes later when I move on to using the iron it is hot and ready to go, and stays hot. So, my criticisms are minor and as of right now I'm really happy with this iron!

I am not a technie nor am I a music snob, but I have been looking for better ways to get music from our wireless devices to something besides the earbuds I plug into my phone.  The Polk Omni A1 wireless amp is a terrific tool for this purpose.The instructions took a bit of time for me to figure out, but once we had the basics under our belt the rest was easy.  We do not use iPhones, so we were able to avoid those couple of extra steps.  We've also had a few issues with getting every device onto the wi-fi correctly - our biggest battle seems to be coordinating the sound from our TV with our speakers . . . somehow the Omni wants to channel the TV at random times.  I imagine that these little hiccups just mean that I need to bribe one of my more tech-focused friends to give us a system refresh.Pandora has never sounded better at our house!  My biggest problem with this amp is that it is highlighting the deficiencies in my speakers!  I've run out of synonyms for 'weak' when describing them.

Jeff Shaara has won his spurs over the years as one of the most thorough researchers and storytellers in the genre of historical fiction.  Invariably focusing on America's military history, Shaara has published novels on the American Revolution ("Rise to Rebellion," "The Glorious Cause"), the two World Wars ("To the Last Man," "The Steel Wave," etc.), the Mexican War ("Gone for Soldiers"), and the Civil War ("Gods and Generals," etc.).  In each novel, Shaara follows the same structure employed by his father Michael Shaara in the immortal "The Killer Angels" of shifting perspective from one character to another.While George R.R. Martin may also use the shifting-character perspective in "A Song of Ice and Fire," and both writers produce door-stop sized books ("The Fateful Lightning" clocks in at north of 600 pages), the similarities end there.  Shaara's prose is workmanlike and he spends a lot of time inside the heads of men (usually white men) who are thinking of logistics, tactics, and strategy.  Sure, there are battles and action scenes, but Shaara generally writes with reserve and has grounded his characters in great heaping gobs of research.  One of Shaara's main characters in "Lightning" is General Sherman, and it's clear that when Shaara puts us inside Sherman's head, he's done so based on extensive research into the general's writings, letters, speeches, etc., to get a measure of the man.  As a result, we get a more realistic character than a Tyrion Lannister, and some would say less entertaining.While Shaara's books may on occasion teeter on the dull side, I find his relentless commitment to realism refreshing.  Other historical novelists, such as Conn Iggulden, write with more style and verve, but can also completely toss history out the window - I'm thinking about Iggulden's decision to make Caesar's murderer Brutus the mightiest swordsman the Roman world had ever known.  Shaara would never take such flights from the historical record - instead, one gets the sense that Shaara is holding up a tinted mirror to history - he's not writing history, but he's writing a close reflection of it.  You can rest assured that when Shaara describes a battle or an event, it actually happened or is closely representative of what actually happened (as Shaara has gleaned from his research) - not that the event was made up from whole cloth."The Fateful Lightning" focuses on Sherman's notorious march to the sea following the burning of Atlanta.  This is the march that broke the back of the Confederacy and left scars that lasted for generations.  As a result, "Lightning" is not an easy read - this is one of the ugliest chapters in America's military history, and Shaara does not sugarcoat it.But Sherman's march is a major American event, and its story needs to be told and understood.  High marks to Shaara for telling it, and telling it well.

This cooler was exactly what I expected.First off, what I measured; Current draw at 13.5 Volts was about 4.7 Amperes. At 12.2 Volts the current draw was about 3.5 Amperes. The manual says 3.5 to 4.8 Amperes, The manual agrees with my measurements.Secondly, this is a thermoelectric cooler.  It uses about 40 - 60 Watts of energy so it will not cool down a load of warm soda in a few hours. The manual recommends running this for a few hours prior to adding your material. If you put warm sodas in this, expect to wait 20-25 (or more) hours for them to get cold. If you put in cold sodas, this will keep them very cold while running.Regarding the cord heating problems that others have stated. I connected this to a 'motorcycle' DC receptacle that I had purchased years ago. My receptacle got quite warm while this cooler was running. This was not a problem with the cooler's plug. It was my receptacle not being able to handle the current draw. If you have a good quality receptacle, this device will work good, without heat problems. My plug did not get hot or melt. If you have a worn receptacle it could get hot.The plug on this device has a built in (removable) 7.5 Ampere fuse. I would not recommend running this with on a vehicle with the motor off as it would probably run your battery down in after a few hours, there is no low voltage shut off built in.

It is 12 Gauge. I ordered two 100 foot rolls for some long-wire antenna projects I have planned. The same gauge costs quite a bit more at the local hardware store. The HW store wire probably has much better insulation quality. For a HAM radio dipole, I just do not care that much about the insulation. I would not be afraid of using this wire as 12V primary in a car. I am happy with this buy. Who-hoo!

This works as advertised with my HF rig, switching between two antenna. I don't know about db loss, my S meter reads the same noise level on both antenna with or without this switch hooked up (not scientific, could easily have 1db loss and not notice it on the meter). The SWR also measures the same hooked up or not (that is the important part for me). For me this is a useful device. I have used it at 100 Watts for 20 minute (two-way) QSOs on 20 and 10 meters without noticing any problems or heat build up. It works on 40 meters also, I just have not used much there for any long QSO.For the record: If I could afford a KW amplifier, I could also afford a better switch, enough said there.For the price, on the 100W HF FT-450D I have, it is well worth the money.

Mine arrived with one switch position inoperative and the other intermittent. One of the internal contacts was bent and easily fixable. The other problem was a loose set screw on one of the connectors making a poor ground. It is now working fine with my 100 watt HF rig. I was not expecting a 'project' when I purchased this. I would guess the factory needs to tighten up some on the QA.I will keep it and use it, as it works for my purposes. I would not recommend trying to run 1000 Watts through it. If you got one with a bent contact you would stand a good chance of melting some parts with a KW. Also there is a sort of neutral center position where both antenna connections could be active, just something to be aware of.
