Most things are HDMI than Display Ports; getting this adapter was the solution to be able to connect a fourth monitor to my graphics card, making use of that DisplayPort and not collect dust.

Not sure what the deal is with the negative reviews. I've known Kinivo from previously owning their bluetooth speakers; I needed a bluetooth adapter for my PC, since it didn't have it.First thing I did was install the latest drivers from the website (it was pretty large at over 100MB!) - during installation, it asked to connect the device in order to proceed with the installation. After connecting the dongle, it proceeded with the installation and it successfully finished. I got the bluetooth configuration show up on my taskbar. I searched for my speakers and it connected perfectly.Finally, I get really great sound without dealing with any wires to my surround sound speakers from my PC.I'm on Windows 8.1. I was a little hesitant about ordering this, but I'm really glad I did and everything worked the way I wanted!

I've been obsessed with 3D movies and games on my projector, and this is one of those games that is HIGHLY recommended if you want to demo some amazing 3D gameplay.I'm really impressed. It is quite challenging because Sonic runs at light speed, but the 3D experience is quite incredible.There is so much 3D depth in this, I really feel like I'm in a new world with Sonic.I also love that this game offers voice narrative in several languages, including Japanese voices, and not just English!If you're looking for 3D content for your 3D home theater experience, this is definitely a must-have. This game was definitely made for 3D in mind! I wish they would make use of 3D in more games; it's quite an immersive experience!PS3 will not die! I wish PS4 would support 3D too, although they seem to be going the virtual reality route.

Motorstorm is an exciting racing game, but my review is more on the 3D aspect.I've been getting into 3D gaming and I've heard recommendations about Pacific Rift being great 3D game... however, I found out the hard way that this full Pacific Rift game does NOT even have the 3D option!There is a standalone dowloadable only on the PS Network called Motorstorm 3D Rift (you have to pay $10), which has less tracks than this full game -- but it has 3D support.I think that's very confusing and ridiculous; Sony should just give a patch update on this Pacific Rift full game to have 3D support!

I finally had a chance to watch Life of Pi in 3D. This film is definitely a must-see experience in 3D.Be warned, the aspect ratio will change twice during the film on certain scenes - THIS IS NORMAL. Although if you're not forewarned, you will find it odd and annoying when it changes, not knowing the story behind it. The director purposely wanted to play/change the aspect ratio (CinemaScope) during the film (it has nothing to do with IMAX conversion) - you will get black bars; the director did this so that the fishes go out into the black borders, making it seem like they're popping out of the screen. This film was meant to be seen in 3D.Visually, the 3D and cinematography is impressive. But it doesn't just end there.I've been collecting 3D films lately, and I haven't had a film that made me jump yet UNTIL THIS ONE. The scene where the tiger first lashes out in the boat literally made me jump; surround sound also helps! Very intense.The flying fishes was also an exciting 3D scene.This is a film that makes you think on deeper levels. It does involve religion and faith, but I love how the film brings that full circle and importance in the movie regardless what religion or non-religious you are.Are you a realist rational thinker or a believer? I love how this film challenges and questions those ideas.The actors are excellent, both young and older Pi. I really felt for the characters. Even the CG tiger is so lovable... Richard Parker.It's an excellent must-see touching film, an unforgettable 3D experience that goes beyond just superficial 3D. The 3D completely enhances the film.For me, Avatar is just to show off 3D with the most generic cliche storyline. Life of Pi uses 3D to enhance a deep philosophical touching story. The film Gravity has impressive 3D, but the story just isn't there for that either. Life of Pi is the complete package 3D/storyline.If you want a film open to many discussions, this is it.

I give it a 4 being generous. There are 3 modes. If you're imagining getting glamour hairstyle blowing with this, you may be disappointed. The maximum speed is just way too loud for me, considering the output of the wind.I also found it strange how you have to attach the bottom base yourself, but what confused me was how the left/right feet are attached together; I wasn't sure if I was supposed to snap it off since there were no instructions.It does have that recycled plastic feel and presentation. Am I blown away? No. However, it is what it is and is a light to transport around the room.

This is a two-in-one device; I really like the portable steam feature; it's great for easy cleaning of sink mildew or other gunk that needs to wiped with less effort.The manual stated it includes a cup to pour water into the pod, but I didn't receive one.The product photos are also misleading: there is NO MEDIUM mode button - instead, it is a ON/OFF button there, with LO and HIGH buttons on the sides.There is no TRIGGER to squirt the steam only when you want it; once you select the LO or HIGH button, steam will continuously come out until you hit the OFF button. High mode does put out a lot of angry steam, so you want to be careful. You must place it horizontally when setting it down, using the portable handheld.I never had a steam mop/cleaner, so this is a nice addition to my arsenal to keep places even more OCD clean.

It ended up clogging up and useless fast.... so there was no way I was going to order and get this one again. The second one, I tried the Loctite 234796 10-Gram Bottle Super Glue Liquid and that one is in a better design/packaging and it actually does not clog and lasts!

I originally tried the Krazy Glue brand, even though that one had positive reviews too, it ended up clogging up after a few uses... had to throw it away.This one does not clog up and it actually lasts! The long neck also gives you better precision. I highly recommend this one. I bought another one... my searching days for the right super glue is over.

First of all, I'm actually a Canon guy... I own a 5D Mark III, 6D, T4i, but when you're traveling and want to actually ENJOY your vacation, the last thing you want is having to carry tons of baggage with you...I took my DSLR camera, but most of the time, it was just left in the hotel and I just ended up relying on the Sony RX100 III for stills AND video (I also had a Sony HDR-PJ650 with me, but the RX actually is quite impressive for video too). I even also had a NEX with me, but even that felt like a hassle to carry with me.  Trust me, the best camera is the one you will always be taking with you and using the most. (I always carry my smartphone too, but features on it just don't cut it)Don't be fooled by the body size; you get DSLR quality on a compact size. I know some people just judge by the body and want a DSLR just because it LOOKS professional. For example, the Sony DSCH300 may look like it has an impressive body/zoom to a layman, but that is a CHEAP camera that takes horrible pictures... Yes, don't judge a book by its cover certainly applies here.Mega pixels mean nothing. Do not buy a camera just going by that too. The sensor size is what is more important. The RX100 has a 1" sensor, much bigger than tiny cellphone sensors (even if some claim their latest cellphone has 300 Megalpixel or something ridiculous, it really doesn't matter) or point and shoot.I also owned the first RX100. The RX100 III (Mark III... Version 3... whatever you want to call it.. the third one) is definitely a worthy upgrade!I'm glad I skipped Version II because honestly, who needs a hotshoe since the whole point of owning this is to be compact and not having to carry extra accessories! No need for the OLED viewfinder either since this already has it built in... that accessory alone costs half the cost of this camera!I like how the "Zeiss" logo on the corner of the camera is actually embedded, whereas the first version was just a cheap sticker.The official Sony case for the RX100 III is the LCJ-RXF. The old first RX100 case is LCJ-RXC.Pros:- Compact size- Tiltable screen for "selfies" is a must have these days... perfect for dates and friends... very difficult to do with DSLRs. It has default built-in selfie self-timer countdown, but you can disable it too.- Pop-up OLED Viewfinder (This is an amazing useful feature; this accessory alone costs more than half of this camera if you were to buy it separately on the older model); this is perfect for those super bright blinding sun when you have trouble seeing the LCD viewfinder; it's also perfect for stealth shooting too, so people around can't see exactly what you're focusing on.- Being discreet without people knowing you are actually getting really great photos (DSLR just screams so much attention and are banned in some places)- Neutral Density Filter (this was not available on the older models - turn this on and you can achieve shallow depth of field during daytime outdoors)- 24mm Wider Lens at 1.8! and 2.8F... great for low light shooting. Great significant upgrade from the first version!- The bounceable flash is centered now, as opposed to being on the left side for the RX100, since that is where the OLED viewfinder is now.- Charge through micro USB (just like cellphones... so many portable powerbanks are available!)- Lens retract/open much quickly than the first one.- I love the NFC/WIFI - it's such an useful feature! Easily transfer pictures to my smartphone and I can share right away while on location! Very very cool and convenient.Cons:- When you push down the OLED viewfinder, it automatically turns the camera off; this is not always a convenience, so they should have added an option for this. (they added this option on the new IV model)- For high angle shots, I wish it could tilt more degrees- It's annoying when there are some restrictions "This is not available in this mode" message- Needs a built-in sensor cleaning (My first RX100 ended up with one minor dust inside, didn't even take it near dusty areas!, and there is no way for me to remove it unless I take everything apart... very frustrating!)- If you're looking for lots of zoom, this is not for you. Unfortunately, you can't have everything.... if you want extreme zoom but inferior image quality, then there are other alternatives.I also looked at the Canon G7, which is a competition to Sony's RX100 series, but I prefer the OLED Viewfinder over touchscreen, better video, and smoother ring (loud clicky on the Canon), high-angle tilt (although I wish it could tilt more), bounceable flash, etc. If you're trying to decide between the first RX100 or the RX100 III, it's easily worth the upgrade.If you're going on any trips, this is definitely just one camera to have with you. The convenience and stealth shooting (people thinking you're just shooting with a cheap point-and-shoot, but you're actually getting stunning results) is well worth it than having to carry expensive lenses/DSLR with you.

0:27 MinsWow, this is very very fascinating (and a little frightening) when you see this in action/results.All the instructions are conveniently written on the bag. Vacuum out the air through the suction hole and watch magic happen. I will add a video.This is a must have when going on a vacation to save A LOT of space for your luggage!You get two large bags and a travel size. The travel size one does not have the vacuum suction hole; it's made so that you essentially fold the bag manually and try to let the air out of the bottom slits (make sure it's not stuck or bent/blocking underneath because I had issues at first with no air releasing out of there)The manual folding/push air out method definitely takes way more effort -- and you will NOT achieve the compression that a vacuum is capable of. You need to keep that in mind because on your trip back, you probably wouldn't have access to a vacuum for the large size bags... you can do the same method folding and pressing all the access air out, just like the small travel bag... maybe do some practice tests at home before the trip.. or on your way back, you could hassle the hotel housekeeping, or where ever you're staying at, to borrow a vacuum... haha...Pros:- Magic! Lots of compression and save so much space!Cons:- Not having access to a vacuum will require way more effort/no full compression. I would love it if Ziploc could provide some simple cheap travel manual air sucking pump, even if that would take a little longer than a vacuum, as long as if it can provide full compression. If a compression like this could be achieved without a vacuum, that would be double black magic!

I have to totally agree with the other critical review... these earbuds are NOT "one-size fits all"... what were they thinking? I don't see how they can even advertise it as being comfortble because it's EXTREMELY UNCOMFORTABLE in my ear. I'm seriously shocked.Like the other review mentioned, it does not fit in my ear unless I hold it against my ear further more into my ear canal to get better optimal sound (including bass), but even then, the sound is still unimpressive - I can assure you, there is NO clarity at all.I am so disappointed in this. I guess I couldn't expect much from the price, but I honestly expected more from Panasonic.Honestly, forget these and get the Soundpeats Qy7 V4.1 Bluetooth Mini Lightweight Wireless Stereo Sports Bluetooth Earbuds Headphones (Black/green) instead.... that one has WAY BETTER DESIGN (flat cable, no tangling, easy to store/carry!), WAY BETTER SOUND QUALITY, and it's even BLUETOOTH. Funny, it's also available in the same green color! The QY7 also is a real earcanal phones, so they go deep in your earcanal, thus isolates outside noise.Cons:- Very uncomfortable, poorly designed earbuds; does not fit properly; NO adjustments.- Disappointing sound quality - no clarity!Of course I'd prefer Panasonic than some unknown Chinese company like Soundpeats, but this just shows brand names aren't everything.... No doubt in my mind, the Soundpeats QY7 kills these earphones in every department... you'll thank me later.

I also tried the Soundpeats Q2 model and this QY7 is night/day miles improvement! The sound is way more clearer and satisfying (the Q2 sounds quite muffeled).I was quite impressed just looking at the design of this, the colors are nice with the flat cable, as opposed to to the thicker cables on the Q2.Although this should be obvious to most, these are ear canal earphones... they're supposed to go deep into your ear canal/not simply rest in your ear like the cheap iPod earphones. (Make sure you have clean ears and no wax build up, or you may end up pushing them deeper in and possibly affect your hearing)Pros:- Unbeatable value. Easily a steal for its price.- Perfect for working out with or for main casual listening.- Good satisfying sound. Way better/clearer than the Q2 model- Nice design, doesn't tangle, can hang/rest behind your neck, love how compact/easy to carry.- Comes with case and charging cable too.- Bluetooth!- the controls on the side/main function actually controls the volume first, and holding it will skip tracks (some other headphones/speakers switch this function!)Cons:- If I had to mention a con, I would say it's a little difficult to open the micro USB charging cover... But I figured it out... you need to stick your nail on the side and flick. If you don't have nails or larger fingers, you may have more trouble.I highly recommend these for the price. You can't go wrong with these. What more could you ask for? It's bluetooth, great sound, portable, very well designed. I own many headphones/earphones already costing hundreds, but this has become one of my favorites for its size and convenience.

I was fortunate enough to try this Q2 and QY7 models. The QY7 is FAR SUPERIOR to the Q2 model.The audio quality is night and day miles better. The Q2 sounds too muffled to me and I was disappointed. There is more clarity and depth with the QY7 model.Also, with the QY7 model, pressing the + - button's main function on the side controls the VOLUME (as it should!); and to skip/back tracks, you would need to HOLD the buttons.However, with this Q2 mode, the default function of the + - buttons skips tracks instead, and for controlling volume, you would have to do the opposite by holding.  Personally, I don't skip tracks that often, so I prefer it's main function (pressing just once) to control the volume.The straps on this Q2 is shorter and thicker that it actually wraps right on my head that it feels like it acts as a head support; with the QY7, it is a thin flat cable. While the Q2 ends up being more discreet for me (it hides under my hair, wheras the QY7 straps can clearly be see hanging behind my back), with full confidence, the QY7 blows the Q2 away.Overall, I easily recommend getting the QY7 model! They're both made by Soundpeats.

First of all, there seems to be TWO versions of the X8 - one packaging already has the propellers attached and comes in a longer rectangular box; there's another X8 in a square shape box where you must attach the propellers yourself.- There's also TWO totally different type of battery connectors for the X8: one version has a round shaped end, whereas another version has a "T" shape end - you need to be careful which spare battery to buy depending on what unit you get. (the one I received was T shaped connector)- The manual wasn't very helpful because it's written in Chinese-English. I was so confused on how to connect the propellers when I first received it. After inserting the propellers, you need to insert the plastic holders with the tiny rod - You basically twist it clockwise to lock and it snaps in place; when you twist it counter-clockwise with your fingers, it should unlock and then you have to nudge the rod out to remove.When you consider price, it seems pretty hard to beat... it looks similar to the DJI Phantom design... However, it is what it is...I first got the Syma x5, loved it and got addicted to flying... (it really is an addicting hobby!) But I wanted to step up to the next level - while still staying on budget - especially since I wanted it to be able to lift a Mobius camera.It is able to lift a Mobius; I even lifted a Contour Roam (that thing is heavy!) and Sony Actioncam, but for a limited amount of time... it seems to struggle now to even lift a Mobius for me, so I ended up removing the legs completely; this way, the legs won't get in the footage, as well as being able to lift/fly better because added weight makes it struggle/stress the motors. Of course I have to launch and land grabbing it with my own hands. (Oh how I wish I could own a DJI Inspire where the landing gear would rise - so envious and cool!)The built-in camera is obviously junk, so I just unscrewed part of the camera while still using the mount/tilt and strapped a Mobius on there. Your footage will most likely suffer from the inevitable dreaded "JELLO" CMOS effect - I even did the custom cheap DIY anti-vibration damper using two credit cards and zip ties, which helped a little, but it still won't eliminate completely. I HATE that Jello curse.....If you are a beginner, don't even think about starting out with this... start with the x5 because you will definitely crash a lot (you can play it indoors too... the X8 is much louder). The x5, being small, can handle quite of bit of crashes. Even when you feel you've mastered the controls indoors, when you fly this thing outside and wind comes into play, it is a whole new ball game... it will get even more difficult fighting against the wind. It can get REALLY SCARY because it will drag the drone than how you exactly want the drone to move. I understand you have to dance with the wind/flow, but it just feels like there's some drift going on. Higher end drones seems to be able to handle flying near beach wind speeds just fine.  The X8 will drag a lot against the wind.The X8 has a "HEADLESS MODE" where it will eliminate worrying about the orientation having it face forward all the time; this is a nice feature, but if you don't set it up right in the beginning or RESET (dragging both controls to far left) then you will have a major disaster. Make sure you test it low flying near the ground first before you start changing directions/rotating while in headless mode. I just don't trust the reliability in Headless mode at all, since it does not use GPS to know its orientation.I can't imagine flying this thing out FAR - it's just way too risky. The only way I would fly pretty high is if it had a GPS/back to home/safety feature/FPV.When considering those premium features and better ACTUAL HD cameras, GIMBAL stabilization, First Person View monitor, etc. You realize you are really getting what you pay for with those drones that cost hundreds more. Moreover, I believe the X8 is actually more challenging to operate than those premium drones that practically makes it dumb-proof for anyone to fly with the built-in GPS/view etc. The X8 is like driving a manual transmission, while the premium ones are like driving automatic cars with training wheels.While I was super excited when I first got this, flying a "full-size" quadcopter/drone, whatever you want to call it, it's very exciting, but I soon realized for serious flying high/reliability/aerial photography, you get what you pay for.I am definitely going to invest on a Yuneec Typhoon Q500+ 4K or DJI Phantom Professional series. I am worried, though, with drones becoming so prevalent, there will be strict laws coming our way... I mean, already, police seems to be cracking down even wanting to just fly it at the park.I give the Syma X8 a 3.5/5 stars.Pros:- Full size (people have mounted GoPros on it)- Spare propellers included- Headless mode (but with cons too)- Competitive pricingCons:- Seems to have multiple X8 versions - why didn't they just have one standard battery, etc? adds more confusion.- The charger included in mine was a European plug, so you must attach an Euro-US plug adapter.- Not the easiest to operate - Don't even think about flying this thing way high up.- No premium features- Headless mode feels unreliable, scary.- Junk camera

When you first get it, pressing the power button once will not keep the unit on; the manual states you must activate/register the device via online or by phone (enter email address/serial address) - I'm not sure how the device would know that it registered unless it connects via satellite or whatever, so I don't think it's really necessary... it seems like you just need to know the "secret method" to "activate" the device, which is not explained in the manual; therefore, after registering, it just gave additional "secret instructions" on how to get the device to work, which is by holding onto the power button (it must be unplugged from charger) until it gets to COUNT 5 and that's when you must release the power button (if you go over count 5 and release, it won't activate) then it'll make a successful beep (ta-dah sound), and now it will stay on after pressing the power button. (By the way, Tria needs to fix the video tutorial that shows up after registration because the video is linked to YouTube, but it's set to private and is unviewable)This product is definitely NOT for everyone. There are MANY restrictions that you must be aware of before trying or purchasing.Reading the manual properly for a device like this should obviously be required and would help... using the device is much simpler than going through the manual.There is one reviewer complaining about using it on their tattoo... it clearly states you can't use it on areas with tattoos! Also, NOT for moles, freckles, dark brown areas.If you have dark skin tone, I'm sorry, but you're out of luck! It sounds a bit racist, but it says if you're African, Indian, Pacific Islander... dark skin tones, you're just out of luck...Not only skintone that you must worry about, but it works only on natural brown or black hair - NOT for white, grey, blonde, or red hair.This is also NOT for using on men's beard/jaw as it is too dense. It is also NOT for genitals, even if you're a forest down there, or near eyes!This is NOT for under 18 years of age (not tested on children). NOT for pregnant women.There is a "sensor skin" on the bottom of the base, which you put over your skin, and if it believes your skin is a safe color to treat, it will "unlock" and you may begin using it.There is only one button on the device to worry about. Holding turns it OFF. If you press the power button while it's on, it will cycle through different levels/intensity (up to 5) of the laser. Many state it can end up feeling like "rubber band snapping against the skin", which sounds frightening, but I tried level 5, and to me, it had more of a burning sensation; others describe as tingling, itching, warm... it definitely burns at its highest, but tolerable. I don't recommend jumping to level 5 immediately. Gradually increase. You can't expect not feeling anything... I mean it's LASER and trying to kill your hair follicles, so that, ideally, it won't permanently grow there. No pain no gain! I'm sure it's less pain for most people than getting a wax. Obviously, lower the setting means, more treatment time will be required.When using the device, the cooling fan will go off and on -- this is NORMAL. When charging, if you want it to go to QUIET mode, where it charges without the cooling fan, you just HOLD the power button - but it will take longer to charge.It recommends treating every 2 weeks for up to 3 months. You will NOT get immediate results... your hairs aren't going to fall out right away. This is not an instant removal device. Patience is required.These are rough recommendations for treatments:Upper lip - 25 pulses (2-3 minutes)Underarms - 100 pulses per side (4-5 minutes)Bikini line - 200 pulses (8-10 minutes)Upper leg - 600 pulses (25-30 minutes)Knee - 600 pulses (25-30 minutes)Pros:- Do it at the comfort of your home- Very easy to operate- Pretty cool features- FDA approvedCons:- Expensive (although some believe it to be a lot cheaper than going to a treatment center)- Many limitations/skin tone/area/etc. (although understandably)- Small surface area

Well, I guess it is appropriately named "Dream House", the interior design are mostly what you would expect from a "rich mansion" or 5-star hotel rooms -- mostly are influnced by Victorian European style. If you actually google "Victorian interior design" you get pretty similar results of what you would see in this book.Personally, I would have found it to be more interesting if there was a BEFORE/AFTER picture... I mean, that's part of the fun... seeing the comparison than seeing just the end results. However, this is more of a simple clean portfolio of the interior designer.I got this book because I mainly have interest in interior photography, but I do have some interest in interior design as it seems like it can be a fun hobby for me. Although I would probably never be able to afford homes like these, I could steal ideas from it; no matter how small the room is, the fun thing about interior designing is how you can manipulate it by furniture, mirrors, and color scheme to make it feel larger or nicer than it is.Although I like the Victorian style, it still feels like confined luxury hotel rooms to me. Yes, art is subjective and it's all on the eye of the beholder. I think my dremhouse will be more modern "futuristic" style (whatever that means), which this book does not have. I think it would be more exciting if there was a book filled with futuristic concept interior design ideas.Some useless opinion of mine:pg 108 New York couple living in Paris... I feel like it's Aladdin's palace... seems heavy and overkill, definitely not for me, but I guess the clients are happy.pg. 175 Cosmopolitan Cool that one seemed to be the most refreshing to me, maybe because I just got tired of looking at brown/red/yellow colors... but it's simple... I've actually stayed at a hotel that looks very similar to that.If you're into classic old Victorian style designs and would like some inspiration in that (and feel some envy), this book is for you. If you're expecting more, you may be disappointed.3 stars means it's okay. Now, I will move some furnitures around and put some nice towels on the table...

My AC Adapter that came with my ASUS Laptop is so huge, it's not very convenient to carry it together. I was really excited to get this because this is so compact, I can easily carry it with my laptop. I like how the plugs fold in/out and it's not always sticking out.This is a great secondary adapter to have, but I have been using it as my primary charger for my ASUS laptop because of the convenient size/not having to carry my original brick size charger.I would have given 5 stars if it had an adapter to be able to charge my Acer Tablet, but none of them would fit it. I hope they provide more options than the ones that are included in this. All the adapters are stuck on a rubber piece, which is a simple nice way to keep it organized than having all the pieces everywhere.Also, I would have liked it if the tips had the manufacture name on it (ie; ASUS, Sony, Toshiba) instead of just generic "FSP" on it... I mean, you could refer to the guide or just trial and error seeing if each one fits properly, but having the actual brand names on it would have made things a bit faster.Overall, if your original charger is a major brick size, you'll be happy just for the size!

I am quite a car phone mount freak... I own so many of them and tried several different styles (phone/tablet mounts/gooseneck mounts/magnetic, etc). This Belkin looks better than most clamp mounts out there, but I don't believe it to be the best.What I look for in a good car mount:- aesthetics; if I'm going to be mounting it somewhere and need to always see it out in the open, I don't want it to look ugly!- how well it holds the device- how easy it is to mount and remove the device (one handed operation is a major plus!)- how versatile/rotation/angles it can achieveIn the end, I just got tired of the old "clamp" method (what this Belkin is) and just decided to go all cradle-free magnetic instead; I love how it gives a floating/clean look and easy removable (I constantly need to remove my phone/tablets from the mount). Again, right behind aesthetics, easy removable is very important to me. However, of course, there is also a trade-off with magnetic mounts where you would have to sacrifice sticking the other magnetic side on your phone/tablet (I wish manufactures would just add that feature it in, so that you can easily mount it anywhere on magnetic surfaces)Although most of my mounts are magnetic now, I still use the popular iOttie Easy One Touch 2 Car Mount Holder for my Galaxy Note phone; that's one of the nicest clamp type holders out there. (I love the extension arm and one handed mounting)I was first surprised by the price tag of this Belkin mount and wondered why it costs so much. After I received it though, some material does feel quite high quality compared to most mounts out there.Pros:- It has a nice easy twist securing for the suction cup (with lock and unlock easily identifiable as well).- The clamp pull-out is like metallic and feels solidCons:- The rubber sides on the clamp seems to pop out way too easily; this part is very poorly designed; it's annoying that it won't stay flush, especially when you mount/remove a device.- I don't like how there is some restrictions in the rotation; you can tilt down several degrees (when it's face up) but it won't allow more degrees tilting up because the ballhead hits the restricted neck; I need more flexibility.- Despite the ballhead being stiff, there is no real locking/screw adjustments to really secure that position.- No one handed removableI wish the large circular part of this Belkin was magnetic and without the clamps, or perhaps be able to have both options.Aesthetically, it is pleasing for a clamp style mount and the metallic clamp that pulls out makes it feel like high quality. However, functionality, I still prefer the iOttie Easy One Touch and magnetic mounts more. Considering I've gone through many mounts, I'm a lot harsher rating this; I feel this product is a 3.5 stars.

I have two other memory foams where it's really firm, and another one that is somewhat firm but still get some sinking... this shredded pillow is just pure fluffiness. If you prefer having some solid head support, then this probably isn't for you. Pillows are like headphones and you have to take reviews with a grain of salt because we all have difference preferences. Again like headphones/speakers, pillows also need break-in periods to really be comfortable to its full potential.There is actually some minor odor.It almost feels like you're not sleeping on anything; this can be good or bad.. sometimes, it's nice to have some firm feel rather than nothing where your head just feels like it's floating, and you may not get that rest if that makes any sense... I feel this pillow is better for the head than the neck.Overall, though, it's a good size and I like it after using it for several weeks.

When I think of memory foam, I imagined VERY VERY SOFT and fluffy like marshmallow... (not that I would sleep on that)I was really excited to try this out... presentation was nice... so far so good, but when I laid on it, I was surprised how STIFF it felt! I thought I was going to get that "sinking down" cloud feel... but I wasn't getting it... I'm not surprised by one of the reviews writing how it felt like a rock... I mean, it did feel rock solid...  it's pretty SOLID support; I understand that is also a preference compared to some than fluffy softness.I also have SHREDDED memory foam pillow and that one is very fluffy; if you're looking for that then shredded is the way to go. HOWEVER, if you're looking for/prefer a solid/firm head/neck support, then this is what you'd want to try.I've had this for several weeks now, and it feels like it's a little softer than when I first received it. I guess like most things, there is a break-in period and it gets better the more times you sleep on it.Sometimes, I like the very fluffy pillow feel, and other times I'd like a harder/solid support for my head. I like having different options/feel. It actually wasn't big as I thought it would be; I wish it was bigger, especially the width.Overall, it's good but expect it to be firm support than being fluffy/no support feel; it all depends on your mood/preference. I believe this pillow shines more as neck support than head.

While this may be obvious to some, keep in mind, this is a "IP5" rated Splashproof speaker - it is NOT waterproof where you can SUBMERGE in a swimming pool, so don't do that.I was surprised by how good these speakers sound for its size. Sound quality is definitely the main purpose of speakers, and it definitely does not disappoint; I would say it is the highlight of the SE90 Splashproof speaker. It really is impressive when you consider the size/wireless - technology has come a long way (and prices! wow). It has a good balance and soothing bass (not just those garbled overblown muffled lows); you won't be disappointed with the sound quality - as long as you know it's limitations - obviously it only has 2 drivers, but surround sound is definitely there. I've listened to all kinds of music; rock, rap/hip-hop, classical, retro, oldies, techno, pop... it all sounds good. Great for personal listening at a desk or a group of people.Pros:- Impressive sound for its size; you won't be disappointed; soothing bass/good balance/surround sound, despite having just two drivers. Quite satisfying.- Splashproof/Rugged; easy to carry; nice colors- Tripod screw on the bottom is a nice, unique touch; you can also get those gorillapods, screw this speaker on, and hang it on a tree or something (of course position/location of the speaker can make a BIG difference in sound experience!)- Micro USB to charge- Bargain PriceCons:- You have to HOLD to turn volume on/off - if you just press it once then it skips tracks instead; I would have preferred opposite because I would adjust volume more frequently than skipping tracks. It's odd because it has a - + sign, where the main function should be to control volume first, not a a secondary where you have to hold; it would make more sense if it at least had a >>> <<< sign instead to know its main function is skipping tracks.- Buttons requires somewhat a hard push, especially when having to hold on to it.- Must HOLD the POWER button for awhile to turn on- NFC did not work for me (I believe the sensor is supposed to be located on the top left of the speaker where there's a Z)) symbol but I tried putting two of my NFC enabled phone/tablet on it and it did nothing (NFC works with my other devices)- The back micro USB/Aux cover pops out way too easily; I would have preferred a much more secure locking mechanism considering this is supposed to be an "outdoor" rugged speaker.- Buttons itself could have used a more distinct color/black highlight to see its function; it blends too much orange that you have to look closely; I think that would have looked better too.If you're looking for a portable bluetooth speaker with satisfying sound, you can't go wrong with this - splashproof is a bonus.

3M recently added a video on youtube showing how to apply this on, which can be very helpful. Although, I would recommend putting this on the window glass first as opposed to laying it on a table for it to be much cleaner.The time and effort you first begin to clean your window first will result in much smoother process and less bubbles; if you get lots of bubbles no matter how hard you squeegee it, you probably didn't do a good job cleaning your windows.A lot of people seem to recommend spraying with mix of Johnson's baby shampoo/water for easier placement/squeegee effort.Trim the film 1" larger than the glass size. Start from the CENTER and you want to squeegee it OUTWARDS by pushing - not pulling.It's more forgiving than applying on a screen protector on your phone... You can actually reapply it if you get bubbles.You will need some patience, but it's a fun DIY project and you'll be happy and proud once you accomplish it. The kit comes with cutting and essential tools.Living in California and the harsh sun, I'm glad I was able to try this. Combining it with some insulated curtains and I can keep my room cooler even on a hot sunny day.

I own tons of these portable power bank chargers ranging from all sizes/designs... I mean, you can never have too much power on-the-go...Anker and Ravpower is commonly known in the market. I've never heard of TSST, but this company uses Samsung's SDI Polymer, which are high quality battery cells and slim form - and a good reason why they're advertising that part.The design of this reminds me of an Apple product. Actually, it feels like I'm caring a spare phone/iPhone or something instead of a charger. Aesthetically, it is pleasing than most power banks out there. There is a digital display to show how much charge there is left by pressing on the button on the right. When you're charging the power bank itself, it will automatically show the charging display.I would have been impressed if this had at least a 10,000mah with this form factor/slimness. This one is only 5000mah (which I feel is bare minimum these days, especially with more demanding tablets); it's thin, but it's a bit long. I own a 5000mah that is much smaller size.Pros:- Looks nice; seems like an Apple design/iPhone- Displays charging amount- two USB ports (1.0A and 2.4A)- ThinCons:- although it's thin, it's long like a phone size (would have been impressed with this size if it was 10,000mah)- only one cable is included- No flash light/extrasIf this was my first power bank, I probably would have given it a 5 stars, but considering I own many of these, I give it a 4.With 5000mah, which would give my Galaxy phone a full charge and little bit more to spare; My phone had about 10% charge left and I was able tor recharge it to 100% in about 2 and half hours with 25% left on the power bank. The display capacity was accurate.

This is pretty expensive for a nail clipper, especially when it doesn't snip that wide for toe nails, etc... it's not very versatile and more for specific use - mainly feels like it's for "fine-tuning" finger nails with occasional minimal tiny cuts; not for cutting long nails at all.It feels like I'm using a stapler; the snaps are sharp but feels very rough. The opening is not that wide.This is a small size. I believe the price is more due to it being a brand name. Overall, I think it's just okay. My cheaper generic nail clippers work better for me.

At first I got confused with this company with Mpow (I have their bluetooth receiver) - this is IPOW.I own so many mounts for my car, I thought I didn't need one anymore... yet this ended up replacing one of my main mounts and I'm happily always using it.Magnetic mounts are nothing new and there's many versions of them out now; however, this one includes a nice bendable long arm! I've been starting to replace all of my "claw/clamp" type mounts with magnetic mounts because it's so much more convenient to remove it easily and attach (although there is also a trade-off where you do have to stick the opposite end magnets on your devices)The arm is not flimsy at all and is quite durable - it even holds my Nexus 7 tablet!I like that the magnet part is clean/blank and does not have any ugly manufacture name on it; the magnet is the same as Teslan's magnet holder.For those that are paranoid about magnets, it is safe as they do not affect cellphone/memory/sim card.I'm actually not using it on a windshield; I bought one of those cup holders and attached this; now I have way better reach and flexibility to reach my device.

Update: down to 3 stars from 4.After using it more, I realized it doesn't help that much. If the sunshade was longer/bigger, it would probably actually create a shade, but I find that in most situations, I still get sun coming from above or in front and this sunshade hardly blocks it; covering with your hands still does a better job...I got this for my Garmin 7" NUVI 2757. As another review mentioned, the stock photo definitely shows it being used for the 5", having it cleanly fit on the OUTER edge of the GPS; however, the one they actually ship goes OVER the frame/border of the GPS and just slightly over the screen. It's a bit misleading. If you look closely at the stock photo, you can also see the words 'GPS' written on the top of the sunshade too - however, the actual product is blank.I guess it's good or bad depending on how you look at it... I mean, the border part of the GPS doesn't really matter anyway... it's just if you're very picky like me and wanting a perfect fit; having it slightly cover the edge of the screen might be bothersome for some people, but it's quite negligible.I uploaded some pictures to see how it looks.

I read the poor reviews before purchasing and decided to try it for myself anyway; I had my expectations low and wasn't even sure if it would fit over my car pedals...It doesn't come with any instructions, so you just have to figure it out yourself. These pedal covers go over your existing pedals. You screw it in so that the clips (which do not come assembled) grip the back of your pedals.The gas pedal covered fine, but it seems everyone will have issues with the brake pedal to fit because it's just too small!This is definitely NOT an universal design. I ended up clipping just the top part (since that was the only way for the brakes) and just duck taped the bottom part right on the pedal; it hasn't effected the performance, as far as I know for now...I do like the feel of the gas pedal having the cover on; it feels like I don't need to press on the gas as hard to gain speed right away.It's too bad they didn't design the brake pedal to be bigger to actually fit. If some company makes a cover with heavy duty metal and universal design/larger brake cover, I would love that.I couldn't find any pictures of these, let alone being on actual pedals, so I'll be the first to share; you can see the real colors too. You get what you pay for (perhaps maybe still overpriced).I'll see how long it holds up and update my review if things change.

Wow, this is getting some harsh rating by everyone... 1 star and saying it tastes like plastic is pretty harsh...This review is for the Fav Reds, not the original flavor packaging, which they also offer in this new minis.The Fav Reds contains 4 flavors: strawberry, fruit punch, cherry, watermelonThe fruit punch really taste like fruit punch to me. I'm not a fan of watermelon and cherry, but I can distinguish the flavors.However, the colors are what's really hard to distinguish for me; I keep thinking the lighter pink one is strawberry (the packaging even looks like the lighter pink is strawberry), but it's watermelon! the slighter darker pink one is strawberry.The dark red one is fruit punch. I wish the colors were more obvious to distinguish.It's funny how majority of people love the pink one the best (strawberry) and the yellow one doesn't get any love. Haha.I always love getting/eating the pink one too. It's nice that they're unwrapped, but I feel the regular size is much better to chew and really taste the flavors... these mini size really feel like you're losing out the full satisfaction. Even the strawberry pink one, I don't get that satisfaction that I get with the full size one.I wish they would make the original size starburst in a bag like this without having to unwrap - that will sell!I added some pictures; no, I did not feed my cat starburst or eat the penny - it's there for size comparison.

The advertising "romantic intimate motion in vehicle" part is hilarious; well, make sure your partner is slender and you have the emergency/side brake up....Not just that silly statement alone, but reading the manual, you'll clearly see that this is a Chinese product.The idea of having an inflatable bed in the car just seemed so cool, especially on long road trips. I just had to try this out.It comes with an air pump (no, that's not what it's used for...), the inflatable bed, two inflatable pillows, and a bag. I was pleasantly surprised how fast everything inflated easily.It's definitely nicer than just sleeping on a narrow car seat itself. Add a comfortable blanket and a really nice soft neck pillow (I know these include pillows, but it could use more comfort), and you'll have a better sleeping experience.Some of the cons, though - not entirely the fault of the product - but due to the design of how cars are made, you have to keep in mind, you'll still be scrunching to sleep due to the limited length wise (unless you leave your doors open, which would be unsafe and impractical); I know if I could extend my legs, I would be more comfortable on this airbed. You'll most likely will have to move your driver/passenger seat really forward for this to fit too.The cloth could be more softer; if you lay down too fast on it, you may give yourself an easy friction burn. I would cover it with a blanket/sheet.Pros:- 12v Air pump included (not as loud as I was expecting) - easy to inflate and quickly!- It is more comfortable than sleeping on the car seat itself (however, you'll still most likely be scrunching up because the limitation of the car seat)- Versatility; the "leg" support that fits to keep the bed up inflates separately, so you can use still use this bed on a flat surface; you can also inflate the leg part and flip the whole thing over and it turns into a mini couch too.- Deflates easily and store away- Pretty cool to have/show off.Cons:- You will most likely have to adjust the driver/passenger seats really forward for this to fit properly (which means having one person drive while another person sleeping in the back with this not ideal)- Be careful of getting friction burn due to the cloth material.

Wow, I wish I had these sooner! I'm amazed how dark my room is now after putting these on. Perfect for sleeping in and using my projector during daytime! This is exactly what I wanted!In fact, at night, I went to see how the window would look with the lights on - from the outside - and now it's not clearly obvious I have it even on! (Yes! Now I don't have to hide and be in the dark during Halloween :P)I received the CHOCOLATE color one. Depending on the color, you'll probably receive different results.I personally probably wouldn't choose this color myself, but it looks pretty stylish... it feels more like a theater room for me now. It definitely looks like chocolate color!I would get an even extra longer length, so that it will eliminate even that tiny light leak if you're picky - that is if you want total darkness.I'm very impressed with this and highly recommend these curtains for blocking out sunlight, especially the chocolate color.Now, I shall go back for more blood... I mean, sleep.

I never knew this film even existed. I bought this not knowing anything about it...If you're looking for a thought-provoking film with dialogue "Which came first? Chicken or the egg? Snake that eats its own tail..."), not mindless action, with some impressive performances, from Leonardo DiCaprio... I mean, look alike (no, he's actually not in it, sorry), haha... this is for you. It makes Inception feel so simple, elementary thinking.If you are just expecting explosions and major action type film like Looper, or have low attention span, this is DEFINITELY NOT for you.First 50 minutes is heavy dialogue and major build up before they do any kind of time traveling or where you see it start to go somewhere - if you don't have the patience for that, again, this film is NOT for you.Half the movie, you'll be thinking to yourself, why are we just listening to these two characters talk in the bar?? Why aren't they going after the Fizzle Bomber?! I was starting to doubt, how did this film received such high praise... I will tell you, the story/buildup in the beginning is worth the investment for the major shock value towards the ending. I don't mean to over-hype it, but I love endings that just really blows you away, like the movie Se7en.When people say it's "mindblowing", yeah... it's just crazy how someone could come up with a story like this. This film involves a paradox, so it may end up hurting your brain thinking about it too much. I have not seen many movies this complex and insane.The movie plot is simply described as a time traveling agent going after a terrorist bomber to prevent it before happening... However, this makes people, or at least, it made me think it was going to be more action-type film like Minority Report -- it's NOT.  (I'm surprised by the "Editorial Review" on this Amazon page - it should be revised because there's an unnecessary information that gives WAY too much away there.)It should be confusing when you first watch it. This is a film that actually gets better with a second viewing.Ethan Hawke is an awesome actor. I'm a fan of him even more now after watching this film. I've never heard of Sarah Snook before, but she gives a versatile performance as well.Predestination may not be a high budget film/marketing like Looper, which may be the reason why it was so low-key, and it somewhat has an indie feel, I consider it a classic and quite powerful.If you want a film that leaves you with lots of discussion and enjoy analyzing, this film is for you. I watched a few days ago and I still can't stop thinking about it/discussing it.This film is actually quite depressing when you really think about it.Somewhat similar films (although these are more higher budget/involve more action):- Looper- Interstellar- Minority Report- Edge of Tomorrow- Oblivion- Shutter Island- Fight Club- Sixth Sense

First of all, this B40 / A118 model dashcam is a "generic" Chinese product rebranded many times under different vendors (Spy Tec, Auto-Vox).  However, the B40 dashcam has grown to be a well deserved popular dashcam. The B40 model I purchased was under the name 'Blueskysea' (that is what it displays when the camera first turns on); it's actually pretty funny the sound it makes when you first turn it on - it's a major exact rip off of Sony's Cybershot camera when it first turns on (sound and display can be disabled).It came in a very generic white box that says "Car DVR" on it; I mean that can be anything!Previously, I've been using a Sony Actioncam and Contour Roam as a dashcam; however, I later realized I needed a REAL dashcam... Biggest reasons are:1) After awhile, it becomes cumbersome having to press record button manually and I often forget to turn it off; a real dashcam should just do its own thing when you start the engine and off (automatically start recording when power is fed to it and stop when an external power source is no longer going to it.)2) Loop recording; previously, I had to remove/delete clips manually, or when the card became full, I obviously would no longer be able to record. With Loop recording feature, when the card becomes full, it will overwrite the older files. Dashcam cameras also records in increments, so if you have a certain accident, you'll just have a 3 or 5 minute clip of that moment instead of 1 large 2 hour file and having to find that moment; this makes sharing and uploading more convenient.3) Timestamp on the video; this is important in proving an exact moment/event (again, a feature not possible with actioncams). I really like the clean timestamp display on this B40 camera - it's large without being obtrusive and clean/professional looking. I have seen dashcams where it has some ugly font colors as the timestamp.4) Video quality. I've compared the quality of Sony Actioncam, Contour, and the B40... These dashcam/B40 camera seems to automatically put a major sharpness filter to the video; it does work to its advantage for dashcam footage, as I'm able to read license plate numbers a lot clearly (granted there's a good light source and you're right behind the car) a lot clearly. Night time is not the best, but acceptable and I still find it to be better than the Sony or Contour. I am actually impressed and prefer the sharpness filter when it comes to car footage than the Sony Actioncam/Contour.I don't believe the B40 is actual 170 degrees; the Sony and Contour shows way more field of view and they're rated at 170 degree FOV. The B40 is wide, but it's not extreme fisheye.What also interested me about the B40 camera was the form factor; it actually looks the best out of all the other dashcams I've seen, even more expensive ones and name brands; I love how discreet it is and one really can't tell unless they look closely as it hides perfectly in the shaded area of the windshield. Unfortunately, if you plan on placing this anywhere else out in the open, it wouldn't look as clean, especially with the visible tape.It's fantastic being be able to tilt and adjust the angle of the camera to get the best angle - the monitor is also very helpful! I also ordered the Mobius camera, which is also small, but I could not mount the Mobius and set the camera angle the way I wanted; not to mention there is no screen so it takes more trial and error to get the right angle.The B40 is very easy to setup - the Mobius camera is a lot more complicated and definitely not as user-friendly for a beginner (you really need to read the manual for that one and understand how the LED colors mean)Pros:- Love the Form Factor - Looks very cool and professional - very discreet/stealth - Perfect to mount it on the shaded part of the windshield- You can adjust the camera angle! Many other dashcams require no angle adjustments or require large mounts.- Display monitor- Nice, clean, professional looking timestamp- Auto start/end- Loop recording- Supports 64GB microSD- Easy set-up.- Audio recording is not bad- Price (Amazing value for the price)Cons:- Night time is not the best (however, most cameras don't perform well in low light; it is still better than the Sony/Contour)- Battery does not last long without external power source- Adhesive should be clear or black.- A polarizing filter would be nice - it will reflect your windshield.One thing to be aware is B40 dashcam also comes as a Capacitor Edition where there is no battery, which is suppose to be more ideal for those living in hot/extreme climates; I got the battery version and I live in hot California weather, so I'm hoping this camera will last me. The nice thing about the battery version is that it doesn't shut down immediately and it actually keeps recording/delay even when the power source is disconnected/engine turned off.I'm very happy I decided to get a real dashcam and not have to use my Sony Actioncam/Contour; I can really just drive and forget about it. It's so discreet it looks seamless along with the rearview mirror. I love it.

I first learned about magnetic mounting from owning a Mountek nGroove product and thereafter, I've seen many magnetic mounts come out.As with all of them, the magnetic mounts, as opposed to those regular claw gripping ones are the convenience of removal and attachment, as well as aesthetics since there won't be any ugly frames gripping your device and it looks like it is floating.The only con/trade-off is having to permanently stick these opposite magnets on your device unless you're using a case cover or if your phone even has space/able to close having the plates inserted internally without physically sticking it on.Well, I took the convenience route and sacrificed just permanently sticking the magnet on a lot of my devices/tablets (I'm not really happy with that), since I own quite of these magnetic mounts. I don't regret my decision to replace my old mounts with this magnetic as it looks better (well, when it's mounted... not the plates attached to my devices now) and it's just so nice to be able to remove/attach easily with some minor force. It's great when you constantly need to attach/remove, such as getting out of the car and taking the device with you.This mount holds up my Nexus 7 and my 7" Garmin GPS nicely. I just stuck the suction cup on my dashboard and it's staying nicely; I'll see how long it will hold because my other mount's suction cup would sometimes come off when I'm parked with excessive heat.I would like to see these plates be able to stick on in a non permanent way.I've come to known the brand name Arkon now, as they seem to make every single kind of mounts out there! It is a quality mount brand you can trust.

After you install this, all you need left is to put on Bill Conti's Gonna Fly Now and you're all set for a great workout... to reach the ceiling...Having this addition increased my workout routine and motivation; this is the way to go and looks professional and reliable than the doorway ones.It's a simple packaging with one sheet of paper for instruction.I'm glad the support bracket were painted white, as it blends in well with the ceiling.The bar is nothing fancy, as it's just well... a bar... there's no special grip, but I guess it's a nice workout for your hands to get tougher too.

First of all, I USED TO BE in one of those crowds that argued what's the point of standalone GPS units when we have smartphones now with much superior processors along with detailed Google Maps/other apps like Waze available... I do use my 10" and 7" tablets with my phone as a hotspot. Some may think 7" screen is overkill, but these days, just like smartphones, bigger display is just becoming the norm now.I was sure standalone GPS units would be obsolete by now... However, I'll tell you why I still decided to buy this Garmin and find it superior than Magellan, Tom Tom, and other brands out there.What sold me the most and what I'm impressed with:- With the Garmin, it actually tells you SPECIFICALLY which recognizable building for an upcoming turn (ie: "Turn right after you pass McDonald's") - Very cool!- The "PhotoReal Junction" feature where it split screens and shows a DETAILED still image similar to the sign/surrounding, not just a generic one like other GPS units may have, of the actual exit - THIS IS EXTREMELY HELPFUL and impressive. This feature really sold me the most where I have not seen with any other GPS units.- Lane assist; I like that it tells you which exact lane to stay on and the split view again makes it very helpful.- Speed limit display / warns when nearby school zones- I like that it displays the upcoming street name on the top.- It keeps a log of where you've driven and stopped, which is kind of scary, but can be useful (you can disable it if you go under Settings - Device - and uncheck Travel History).If you go to Settings - Map & Vehicle - Map Layers - and check Trip Log - it will highlight the roads you've driven before on the map.- Interestingly, the Garmin unit itself takes power via micro USB (more common/standard now) from the bottom; however, with the cradle mount attachment on the back that connects via Garmin's proprietary pins, the power connection takes the older mini USB cable from the side.Con:- It needs a screen calibration feature; I'm not sure if I got a faulty one, but the reason I can't give it 5 stars is because when especially using the keyboard where the buttons are really close to each other, it is off and can be really frustrating (My Mio GPS has a calibration feature, so I don't have this problem regardless being the same inferior resistive screen) if you need to press/type fast. I have this issue quite often, and I have to be VERY careful using the tip of my finger or adjust slightly off than I would like to type/press the keys or else it ends up registering the wrong key. Of course, most older GPS units, including this model, has a resistive touch screen, inferior to smartphone's capacitive screen, so it's not as responsive. There is no pinch zooming or rotating. Screen also is not as vivid/clear compared to the Magellan.- After awhile, Garmin's myTrends feature kicks in, where I noticed without even inputting/starting navigation, it will know your previous route/saved locations and it will automatically display an estimated time and the name of that location on the top, as opposed to the upcoming street names it usually displays (which I would rather see!). What's annoying is there is no way to simply CANCEL this when it predicts the trend/place it thinks you're about to head to, besides disabling the entire myTrends/Travel history/log. Why they couldn't simply add a cancel feature or at least prompt you to ask if that is where you're actually heading to (app like Waze even prompts if I'm heading home first/allowing me to cancel!), I just can't understand. I'm sure they were thinking this myTrends feature would be a convenience, but I don't want it to be displaying "Home" and ETA the entire route even if I may or may not be heading towards my home. I don't want to lose my history log either, so disabling the myTrends feature isn't really a workaround... please fix this, Garmin.- 1 hour battery life does not seem impressive; however, I hardwired it directly to my car, so it will turn on when turning on the engine and display that it will turn off when external power is removed.- I'm surprised it does not have a QUICK 2D/3D camera switch - Please add that on an update, Garmin! - it is so cumbersome having to go to settings and map just to change that! I would also love a quick way to switch to North Up/etc/Quick sky view, etc. More camera angles! Garmin should utilize the split screen feature more - I would love to be able to show 2D and 3D views simultaneously when you're just cruising (and also be able to adjust camera height for both individually)I did find, though, that you can press somewhere off the map and you can press one of the icons on the top left corner and it will show a higher view facing North Up; I use this feature when I'm in 3D mode and need to quickly get a better view of the surroundings.- They should add a fast forward/speed up for simulation mode - who wants to sit through all that?! Other GPS simulation have that feature.- Direction/Calculations not as smart/good as Google.- Would like a ring/beep sound to indicate when to turn/manuver.I also own the 7" Magellan RoadMate Commercial Truck GPS Navigator 9270T-LM, which has the same 800x480 resolution, but the display looks much better and clearer on the Magellan. Also, there's more detailed road names display even when you're in a higher view. Despite those pros on the Magellan, I find the Garmin superior on interface, speed, and everything else.I found that on long road trips, it's much better to have a standalone GPS since- it will not eat up your phone mobile data or battery, not be distracted from other apps/calls taking over the screen- better reliability/GPS signal- with the Garmin, the detailed lane assist/display/voice really comes in handy and find it superior than what phone app navigation or other GPS offers.I've used GPS units from Magellan, Tom Tom, Mio/iGo8/Primo (I really like how fast Mio GPS operates and iGo has many features I like that I wish Garmin would include too), Sygic, and I'm still impressed with what Garmin has. Ideally, it would be nice to have one unit that is capable of having everything, but they all have their pros/cons.I purchased the 2757 model, which lacks voice recognition, Bluetooth and traffic; however, I don't need them because for real-time traffic, I still rely on Waze. I still also like relying on Google Maps to get a better view of the wide surroundings (so much more clear and easy to see detail and faster than sluggish GPS units). However, when it comes to actually inputting navigation, I will be using this Garmin.I also downloaded the latest free map and software updates, which can take awhile, but you have to be patient. You can also download more custom 3D vehicles like something ridiculous like Star War's X-Wing.If you're looking for a good standalone GPS unit, even if you already have a smartphone, I would consider the Garmin over other brands.

While my network does not have the latest AC router running right now, I still see the benefits of this wireless adapter card, as it is backwards compatible with all previous bands, including N. Possibly because of the 3 antennas, I am getting stronger, consistent bars with this now.If you are thinking about streaming HD content, especially higher than 1080p video, then you need this or else you will have lots of inconvenient stuttering experience.I prefer having this built into my system than going the USB route for better stability, as well as freeing up USB connections.The added heatsink is nice touch; however, it kind of sticks out so it may or may not interfere with some plugs/wires below if your PCI-e x1 slot is near below.I've become familiar with and trust the TP-Link name now.

First of all, I am a huge 1987 original Robocop fan. Back in the day, all we had was a totally inaccurate red visor Kenner Robocop...28 years later and we FINALLY get a GOOD Robocop figure. Is it PERFECT? No. But it's definitely the best one out there.When I saw the pre-release photos of this figure, it looked so unbelievably movie accurate, I just had to have it... The figure was frustratingly delayed for months than the expected release date, but the figure is finally available.The prototype looked like it used all diecast parts, but the final release is NOT all diecast. The side arms are partially diecast, but it is still mostly plastic. However, there is still a good amount of weight to the figure.I feel sorry for those that own the previous Hot Toy's 2012 version of Robocop (MMS10) - that bobblehead looking, horrible proportion Robocop looks so laughable in comparison; even if that figure were selling really cheap, I would never buy that one. It just looks so BAD! I can't believe how bad that one looks. However, Hot Toys really took it seriously this time and to another level. It's about time we get a good Robocop figure!I uploaded some photos of my figure; It looks incredibly dead-on accurate. Manufactures from all these years could NEVER get Peter Weller's jawline right in their figures, but Hot Toys finally got it right with this one.However, I still feel Hot Toys made Robocop too silver. Almost all Robocop figures being made by everyone makes Robocop too silver. Robocop is NOT completely silver and it's not because of the lighting in the film. Robocop has a purplish/blue shade to him. However, with some blue lighting setup, you can kind of get by it.The holster can be opened and pulled out. It comes with a detailed plastic Auto-9 gun (to make him hold it) and a less detailed diecast gun (this one would go in the holster)The sound effects are good, but the "Drop the gun you are under arrest" and "Thank you for your cooperation, good night" still has the background noise/TV sound from the film.I almost thought about buying Enterbay's Robocop, but after watching and hearing many reviews from others, Hot Toys is more accurate and better value. Why would anyone want to be reminded of that horrible Robocop 3 and want junk Jetpack accessory?!Pros:- Most accurate Robocop figure out there today.- Range of the sound effect remote is quite impressive - does not even have to be pointing at the figure.- ArticulationsCons:- Having to remove the back plate and toggling the on-switch - VERY inconvenient, especially when it's already in a display case.- Battery for the remote is included; however, battery for the Robocop is NOT included. It requires two N size LR-1 battery.- Wish they stepped it up even more and added some purple shade to it - being really knit-picky - it is too silver.- At this price, quality control should be perfect - mine had some minor scratches and being extremely picky, it bugged me a lot...If you're a Robocop fan, a movie figure collector, this is the best Robocop figure out there.Looking forward for the battle damaged version with the helmet off expected to be released later this year (although I wouldn't be surprised if it's delayed again) resembling so much of Peter Weller. That one looks incredible!

Pros:- No assembly required. Just unstrap and unfold.- Easy to set up. It won't tangle.- Nylon straps and plastic material makes easier to carry/prevent injury/kid friendly. (comes with storage case)- Attach as many ladders with the strap.It includes some warm-up training exercise tip guide.Price seems pretty hefty, personally, but if you are serious about your work outs then this may be worth your investment, especially if you consider the convenience and safety; no need to be looking for sticks or objects via poorman's way.Great for indoors and outdoors.

We all typically hear differently and have different taste in what is "good sound" (more bass, less bass, more treble.. etc); it's especially difficult when it comes to earbuds that go into your ear canal because if one doesn't have it inserted properly, they would assume the sound is awful/lack bass or whatnot - these are supposed to go deep into your ear canal; it will sound different if you insert a larger/smaller plugs into your ear. The deeper it goes into your ear canal, the deeper sound experience you will have, obviously. If you don't like that, then these aren't for you.If this was a Sony or some other major brand, I'm sure more people will flock to this item without hesitation... However, not everything that cost a lot equals better amazing sound; one would think you get what you pay for looking at this earphone, but in this case, I feel the price is an amazing value. Most things are manufactured in China anyway even if it has a major brand name slapped on it.The packaging is like very similar to what I have seen when I bought an Anker power bank and whatnot - they must all use similar packaging companies or design. From reading the manual, you can clearly tell it is a Chinese company product.- You get two extra smaller size ear hooks- You get two extra ear plugs- You get a dual micro USB-USB cable- micro-USB cable (for connecting right/ear phones together)I have many earphones/headphones that cost way more than this -- and lack bluetooth --where these sound just as good, if not, better than those. Bass is there, but again, since these are designed to go into your ear canal, depending on the sizes of your ear/plugs and your hearing, a lot of people will have different experiences - ultimately, you would need to try it yourself. Personally, I'm happy with the sound - and it's especially impressive when considering the price.I used this with my Android phone as well as a Sony Playstation Vita portable gaming system.All the controls are on the right earphone - Hold onto the power button and you will see red/blue lights flashing to indicate sync mode. You should see "S530" on your bluetooth capable device.Pros:- Great for exercising/moving around.- Price - Quite impressive for sound and bluetooth- You can skip track/rewind control volume up/down- I like that some of the ear plug insert is differently color coded so it's easier to match.Cons:- You must connect with a micro-USB to the left earphone to listen to both - it would be amazing and great if both were completely wireless! When I first got them, I had no idea you had to connect to the left earphone via micro USB. Bummer.- Earhooks could be more flexible/better fit for smaller earsOverall, I believe you get more than what you pay for here at an amazing value - heck... even the dual micro-USB charging cable/micro USB cable extras alone are nice to have and some places charges a lot for those!

"Wow, I can see the world in high definition!"Have you seen that cheesy infomercial? Seeing the world in high definition... like what does that even mean?? huh?? It totally made me laugh, but when I went driving with this on, it reminded me of that commercial... like it kind of felt "HD" to me... I mean, things felt like it was magnified and definitely clearer and easy to see.I'm not sure if all polarized lenses act the same way, but it completely blacks out the screen when looking at my tablet/smartphone from an angle. Polarization is definitely there. However, there was no issue with my Samsung Galaxy Tab S tablet; I believe because the screen is AMOLED.I was hoping to always use this while driving, but I can't see my navigation screen (tablet), so it's a bit of a bummer for me.- Made from polycarbonate and nylon.- The tips are rubbery/snake-like.- Stylish looking/large lens- Won't fall off even looking down/move around and still have comfort.- Glasses do not fold completely compact. No case included.

I was surprised how nice the quality of the keyboard press/feedback feel was. It has a good slight amount of mushy feel to it when you type on it; cheap keyboards to me just has a horrible clicky feel to it.I also like the amount of tilt it provides.This keyboard is nothing fancy; it has no backlighting or special features other than being bluetooth and allowing you to connect to another input via USB. It would be great if it could handle multiple bluetooth connections.This keyboard is mostly ideal for Windows and Android.If you're looking for a good basic quality keyboard, I would give this a try.

I was really excited to try this out and was expecting some major accuracy, considering it's marketed as a "fine point".However, in practicality, it's more like pseudo-fine point... as in, it's actually more of this huge clear DISC-SHAPE TIP that has to be on the surface. I really wish they could have made an actual thin soft tip without needing that annoying disc, as it really gets in the way for me - regardless it being transparent.If the disc part comes off, then it will become completely useless too! You need to be careful not to drop/hit something and realize it not being attached later on. The disc came off on my mine once, but I was able to snap it back on. It's a good thing it has a cap for the tip. When you're using it, you can screw the cap on the back of the stylus.I have a Samsung Galaxy phone, and maybe I've been spoiled by the S-Pen, but the S-Pen is far superior than this as there is no annoying clear disc involved; it's just a real natural writing experiencing - the plastic tip "fine point" on the S-Pen makes more sense to me.Again, an actual fine point pen/pencil we use on regular paper is, obviously, VERY different when it comes to a digital world; it doesn't work the same. In the digital world, you can be using a very fat soft stylus tip, but depending on the software/app, you can adjust accordingly depending the digital thickness you select. The advantage of a small tip on a stylus is so it can be easier to SEE (not actual writing because that's all dependent  on the app/virtual world) when you want to write more precisely. With that being said, I find the disc to be bothersome when I'm writing.I can't agree with the high ratings.Pros:- Seems solid.- Clip- Cap; can also be screwed on the back of the stylusCons:- The whole clear disc-shape tip design. Why? Is it really necessary? It gets in the way. Awkward. I hate it.- If you lose the clear-disc on the tip, the stylus will become useless.

I'm not sure why there's so many complaining about how to use this... it's not difficult at all and I'm not even a handy guy. You can remove it quickly and quietly with this -- but it does require some strength when pulling the lever up.To use this, the longer lever (top one) needs to be ALL THE WAY UP and you sit this device right on the wine, while you squeeze it with the shorter lever -- to grip the wine securely (the shorter lever is simply for gripping the bottle); you then push the long lever all the way down for the screw to go in; then pull the lever back up (this is where it will require some strength) -- and make sure you still squeeze/grip the lower lever on the bottle while putting the lever up.Once the lever is back up, you can release the grip/lower lever and the cork should pop right out. The cork will still be stuck on the screw once you remove it, so all you have to do at this point is push it down and pull the lever up again and it should just fall/drop right out of the screw.If you're still confused, just look up "rabbit lever wine opener" or something similar on YouTube and you'll get the idea.It does require a little more effort than an electric wine opener, but you also don't need to worry about charging or loud electric motor sounds, and you can remove it at your own pace (if you're quick, it's a lot faster than using electric wine openers). Personally, I like this way better than using the popular Oster Electric Wine Bottle Opener; I hate that one because I always end up having pieces of the cork drop and it's just loud. With this Rabbit Lever, I can consistently open wines without any pieces of cork falling, which is VERY IMPORTANT.However, if you want zero effort/no strength at all and don't mind going electric, I recommend the Skybar FPSKBW8216 Electric Wine Opener - this one kills the Oster and it's much nicer.Pros:- Fun to use.- Unique.
