Looks somewhat fancy.- No cork pieces that will end up falling- No need to charge/no annoying motor sounds (the Oster is super loud and annoying!)/can be faster (just push down/pop out/after you're done, releasing the lever just makes the cork drop right out of the screw versus having to wait for the motor screw to release on electric wine openers.- Extra screw includedCons:- Somewhat bulky/case storage- When pulling the lever back up, it does require some strength/gripping/squeezing securely (if you want ZERO effort/strength, then I'd go with the Skybar)I was worried reading some reviews early on how this may be difficult to use, but after receiving it and using it myself on multiple wines, I personally love it.

I have to frequently open lots of wine (not that I'm the one drinking all of them) and I've been using the well-known Oster Electric Wine Opener before receiving this one. This SKYBAR kills the Oster in every way! Build quality/looks and functions!I ended up dreading using the cheap Oster one as it was very difficult to keep the cork going down perfectly straight without it jamming awkwardly to the side -- and most often, also have pieces of the cork fall! That's the worst! I absolutely hated that! It was just always hit or miss with the Oster...With this Skybar, it was literally a breath of fresh air! Just on my first try, it was such a pleasure and major difference. It's just always accurate and smooth!First of all, the motor sound is less loud and annoying than the Oster and the speed that it rotates down has a more relaxing, comfortable ideal pacing that it's SO MUCH easier to keep the screw to go straight down -- not to mention the translucent BASE allows you to see the cork ACTUALLY moving up into the screw so effortlessly; I love that! It's so cool and fantastic!The method works the same way as the Oster where you put the screw on the cork and press down on the bottom button until it goes all the way, except it's just REALLY nice you can actually see the cork rise up. Once the cork is removed, you can press the top button for the cork to come out.Pros:- Translucent window allows you to see the cork actually moving up! VERY COOL!- Quieter than the Oster- Nice comfortable rotation speed - (The Oster tries to dig in the screw too fast)- No loose pieces of the cork falling! YAY (I hate the Oster ending up leaving loose pieces because I can't see what's going on, plus it's more difficult to keep it straight due to the way of the Oster's motor's rotation speed)- Sleek stainless steel body and lookAlthough the charging base and design may seem similar to the Oster, the Skybar kills the Oster in every way - It is an easily noticeable premium, upgraded, luxury version.Yes, it is more expensive than the Oster but you DEFINITELY really get what you pay for! Not only the obvious superior build quality with its stainless steel body, but the way it functions is just night and day - no loose pieces of the cork falling and great visual/fun to see the cork actually being removed with its translucent window!I highly recommend this. I've used the Oster one enough times to know right away how much I appreciate this one way more.

2:04 MinsOk, I'm really surprised the main selling point for this safe is the fingerprint scanner, yet the instruction manual included in this one has ABSOLUTELY NOTHING written about that feature!!I mean, the manual itself is a generic one that tries to cover different models including the ones with a dial (which this model does not even have). Luckily, I searched the internet and found one explaining for a different safe/model... (I mean if they have it explained for a different biometric model, why didn't they update/include a manual for this safe?)To program your fingerprint(s):------------you need to press the "P" (program) buttonand then enter the 5-digit FACTORY code (located on the back of your manual)The sensor should be blinkingMake sure you peel the cover on the scanner and then swipe your finger in a downward direction overWhen you get multiple successful reads (you must do it several times) then the green light will flash three timesTo delete a user fingerprint, press the "P" button, enter 5 digit facory code, and then press "C" (CLEAR). You can program 2 fingerprints.------------* There is a factory 5-digit code located on the back of the included manual - THIS CODE CANNOT BE CHANGED OR DELETED - what you get is what you get!* You can program/add 2 additional user codes* You get 2 physical keys, which is ONLY for double-security to prevent the safe from opening even if you enter the correct key code; before I received and saw there was a keyhole to this safe, I thought the keys were another way to open the safe/override the keypad, but that's NOT what it does. Therefore, I just leave the key turned to unlock side.* Replacing batteries is really easy - it just slides out located behind the keypad (this can also be a con!). It takes 4 AAA batteries.* The sound of the buttons remind me of a microwave sounds - it can be turned off if you wish (The manual says to press 0, P, and 1 to turn off the sound and 0, P, 2 to turn it on -- after several tries I was able to turn it on/off once, but I can't seem to consistently do that right away; I'm wondering if entering the factory code prior to pressing those buttons are required or not... I wish it can be more consistent or the manual to be more clear about that)* If you enter an incorrect code 3 times in a row then it will enter DELAY mode and you'll be locked out for 2 minutes.Pros- Fingerprint scanner makes accessing/unlocking very fast and convenient (your mileage may vary depending on your fingers/sweat/etc); I thought it would be a gimmicky feature, but I really LOVE having this! It's very high-tech and cool. It totally beats having to turn the dial on my other safe - having the fingerprint scanner makes storing and removing things frequently possible.- Cool blue keypad lights; I feel like a secret agent along with the fingerprint scanner. (Red led to indicate access denial and green for granted)- Sound can be activated/deactivated- This one does come with built-in LED lights inside the door, so it lights up the inside when you open it (you can program the duration to 30 seconds, 60 seconds, or completely off) - both the LED lights on the keypad and inside makes accessing this safe possible even at night/in the dark! There's no way I can open my other safe with the dial unless the room is lit.- 4 AAA batteries easily removable (manual says they're not included, but there were already 4 of them in mine) -- however, this can also be a con!Cons:- Mine came with a huge dent on the back (I actually noticed my other SentrySafe with the dial also had a dent too); I'm surprised something that feels/look this solid can have a large dent like it got crushed by some massive hit. It seems other reviews share the same issue whether from during shipping or from the manufacture.- If someone was around and wanted to mess with you, they could remove the battery compartment and you would be locked out of your own safe!- Of course with anything digital, there is a greater risk if it fails (although I totally love the convenience of keypad/scanner than having to turn the dial clockwise/counter clockwise) I thought the included physical keys were for override, but again, it is just for extra locking.- This safe should be called Medium size, but the company refers it as X-Large. They refer to their actual large size as 2X-Large.I also own and reviewed the SentrySafe SFW205CWB Water-Resistant Combination Safe, 2X-Large; that one is a dial only and weighs a TON! I wouldn't worry about that one being walked away by anyone.This safe being "X-Large" size is a bit more manageable and a more ideal size; two adults can definitely pick it up and walk away with it. I suppose a heavy lifter can lift this alone, but it is heavy.I definitely prefer this X-Large size and fingerprint scanner/keypad a lot more than the combination dial; they both have their advantages/disadvantages, but for fast convenience and cool factor, this safe wins.

Update: I just had a long road trip with this and I love it even more seeing how really effective this device is on a long trip/highway. I got Ka alert miles away and I always saw state trooper somewhere. When it was night time, I could barely see other cars on the road and I see Ka goes off for a long time - I later see flashing lights and see a truck get pulled over.I bought this because it seemed to be the best bang for your buck; I didn't want to settle for something cheap like the Cobra or generic - I mean... you get what you pay for.I originally wanted the Escort Passport 9500ix (and may eventually upgrade in the future), which is also highly rated, but I also can't justify paying twice as much for it right now, especially when it comes to detecting the same bands, this radar does it equally well. When the price is right, I will upgrade and well... the price for the RX65 was just right, so I jumped on it. The RX65 and 9500ix have been around for years! It's not like the iPhone where it gets replaced every year, so it's not a bad investment unless all police start using lasers.Beltronics's parent company is actually ESCORT - the smartcord/power plug can actually be interchangeable, which is nice when I plan on upgrading. (unlike the 9500ix, the power plug on the RX65 is located on the right side)If you're new to radar detectors,  there are different frequency bands that police use for their radar known as X, K, Ka, and laser. Many have said to just disable X band because it is no longer being used.If you get hit with a laser, it will be too late to slow down. Sometimes, when the sun is pointed directly at the radar, you may end up with a false laser warning.A lot of super markets automated sensor doors use K band frequency, so you will get LOTS of false alerts when you drive by; trust me, if you're in the city and around stores, you will get lots of K band warnings; you can either disable it completely, or you'll have to press the mute button on the device whenever you hear it. If you know that will be too much of a hassle for you, the extra premium to get a radar detector, such as the ESCORT 9500ix with it's AutoLearn memory capability may be more beneficial to you. The RX does NOT have that ability or GPS. You do not want to disable Ka - that is what you really want to keep on eye on or be listening to.By default when the radar starts up, you'll get like a R2D2 sound of all alert sounds; if you find this annoying, you can disable it which is what I did.Some people who are new to radar detectors have a misconception of thinking these will detect every police out there. This is not a police detector - it's a radar detector; if the police doesn't have their radar turned on, it's not going to let you know anything. Also, just because you have a radar detector doesn't mean you become invincible and start being a speed racer. It's just another device to help you become more cautious of your surroundings and be more alert. Your eyes are always the best look out. One day, I also saw a police, on a bike on the side street, pointing a radar gun at cars pointed at my direction, but my detector didn't tell me anything; I believe he was using laser. There is no guarantee. There are other times where I hear Ka band goes off and I do see a police nearby.I hardwired mine and mounted it right under my rearview mirror for a really clean look - I love it way more now; I'd hate to have an ugly cord dangling and making it obvious when I'm driving.Pros:- Looks nice, clean look (I have the Red display; my car interior gauge/radio is mostly blue, but the blue display costs a lot more!)- Large mute button for easy access- Different alarm/tone for different radar detection (I hear the K band beep so many times, it has annoyed me... it is so refreshing to hear a different chirping alert when Ka gets detected!)- You can switch to dark mode with minimal display- Ability to disable bands- Sensitive/Good range.- Best bang for your buckCons:- No learning feature, so you will have to ignore the false alerts every time you drive the same route or disable completely; going through the menu is a bit cumbersome.- No GPS for speed traps, etc (which is fine, since I use other Apps)- The buttons do feel cheap plastic and the device itself is very light (I guess that's a good thing); it would scratch easily if you don't take good care of it.Like any radar, if it saves you one ticket then it pays for itself. Combine this radar and app like Waze and you'll have a pretty nice setup.Also check that the FCCID has M4 - that is the newer one with the TSR anti-falsing installed; if it has S7 then it is the older based RX65 model.

Move over Dr. Dre... Bob Marley is in the house.....Ok, sorry, that was cheesy. Yes. So Unlike Dr. Dre's flashy "bling" looking headphones and overly exaggerated bass/super high treble, we have House of Marley Liberate headphones that is stylish in a completely different nature: "natural" (wooden fabric) with a mature calm look that would still be able to grab attention.Overall, the sound is pleasing and pretty balanced, especially impressive considering it's wireless; however, in a confined way... if that makes any sense; the earcups are rather on the smaller side - it's a little claustrophobic feeling for me; I don't think my head is that big and it's pretty tight. Personally, I feel a bit further away from the music, more of a DIRECT studio recording sound - not a concert feeling with major separation that I've been spoiled by my other headphones like the Sennheiser 595/600, but that is to be expected considering the price/style. Just don't expect major separation in the vocals and instrumentals and breathing space. With that being said, you still get the luxury of being wireless and travel friendly collapsible design.Right side of the headphones have the volume up/down and skip track/back and pause/play and power button... I'm sure some will argue it's not hard to memorize the location of the buttons, but honestly, when I'm zoned into a music, it's a bit difficult for me to QUICKLY realize which button does which again... I want to turn the volume, but usually forget if it's the skip track button instead, especially since they're pretty close together to one another; it would have been nicer if the buttons had a different texture feel or have only the volume controls on the left side of the headphones or make it a scroll wheel.The manual states you can seek/rewind music (not skipping track) by holding on to the button, but it did not work for me; I tried it on a iPod Touch and Android phone!Pros:- Bluetooth - no wires! (aux input also available)- Collapsible; excellent for travel- Music Control/Volume buttons on the right side of the headphone- Very mature stylish- Good sound considering it's totally wireless/bluetooth - in a confined way.Cons:- Headphones cannot be adjusted inward/outward for better comfort (fixed)- Seeking the music did not work by holding on the buttno; it only completely skipped/back a track (tried on iPod Touch and Android phone)- Lots of buttons on the right side of the earphones (would have liked the buttons to be more separated/obvious/different texture)- Somewhat small earcups; these won't cover your entire ear/have a major concert feeling.If you're really picky with sound and that's your main priority then these aren't for you; if you need wireless bluetooth, you like the wood/fabric style look, need something for travel, don't need massive earcups to cover your entire ear, then give these a try.

I don't really do Yoga, but just having this set makes me want to start doing it. I mean, I can use the towel/mat for other sports and working out as well as it absorbs sweat, doesn't slide around, and prevents odor bacteria growth.This combo set includes the mat towel that measures 27x70" long and a face/body towel that measures 12x32".The towel states it's 80% polyester and 20% polyamide.There are anti-skid dots on one side of the mat, so it won't slide around.I like the thought of knowing how this towel has an "antimicrobial technology" to prevent the growth of odor causing bacteria.This set of blue colors just really feel like "workout" and going to the gym to me.Maybe a small string included to tie it around would have been nice. Overall, it's a nice set for anyone wanting to work out or yoga!

I like that the keyboard has a very slight mushy key press feedback to it; I've used really cheap keyboards before where it's just clicky and well... feels cheap.However, I was a bit disappointed with the slippery plastic feel of the keys; maybe I have high expectations, but I was kind of expecting the keys itself to be a little more higher quality like on the Apple laptop, or at least I wish the keyboard buttons would have been the same aluminum texture/feel as the back of the keyboard.It does not have to be clipped for the keyboard to work. After all, it is a bluetooth keyboard. On the side of the keyboard, there is a micro-USB port for charging, on/off switch, and pairing button. In fact, a bonus for me was how the keyboard even works with Android tablets - the volume, media keys too! I can even put a Nexus 7 2nd generation tablet on the stand in landscape too (of course, it's not made for it, so tilting at different degree of angles will not work)There is one flap, after you remove the sticky tape, where you slide your iPad and it magnetically attaches. The stand hinge allows you to tilt to various angles like a laptop.Pros:- Has a slight mushy key press feedback- Various multi-angle degree- Acts as a cover (of course, it will not protect the back side of your iPad)- Keyboard shortcuts work with Android too/it can also make a Nexus 7 2nd generation sit on the stand (not various angles)Cons:- Keys feel a bit plasticky/slippery for my taste; I wish it had a more solid feel to it/aluminum like the back casing.I really like the innovative design/casing/keyboard combo. I hate having bulky cases/carrying keyboard, but this case solves both problems.Logitech, please make the same design/keyboard for the Samsung Galaxy Tab S too; I would buy it in a heartbeat!

I'm a bit disappointed mine arrived with the plastic hook to lock the lever was completely chipped off on one side. Everything else seems to be heavy duty and durable, yet that part being cheap plastic, it should have been metal or something; it wouldn't be so fragile during heavy transportation bumps or whatnot.  Thankfully, regardless having the hook or not, the table is still able to securely lock.There are two levers on each side of the legs, when you pull the lever on one side, the legs can be folded out - you then have to push the lever ALL THE WAY DOWN, it will require some bit of strength and force, flat right underneath the table to lock securely and completely.The table is REALLY tall, which is good or bad depending on what you're expecting; for permanent use, it's nice to be able to put a cabinet or storage box underneath the table.I uploaded a picture of the table with a SAMSUNG UN55H6350 HDTV on it so you get a better idea of the size.Pros:- Heavy duty, nice build- Easy storage- Very tall- Surface feels niceCons:- The plastic hook on one side arrived broken.

It was a perfect time for me to review this because my old wipers totally needed to be replaced (I haven't replaced them for years, but I was finally reaching danger point... I could barely see in the rain/streaking...never clear... it was so dangerous!),  So yeah, I was really excited to try this out...I have never replaced wipers before, so I had to look up many videos on youtube (lol)... but honestly, it was still very confusing because not everyone has the same type of hook, and the explanations were lacking or had horrible camera angles.I'm sure it should only take a few minutes to swap it out, but it took me a little longer. The difficult part for me was trying to figure out how to remove it. Installing it was a lot simpler just by snapping it in and then lock.The driver side should usually be larger than the passenger side; my car for the driver side takes this 26" and my passenger side takes 19" blades. I was so happy to be able to get both sizes. If your enter your vehicle on Amazon, it should let you know if it works for your car or not.I wish the instructions had some wording on it for more clear directions - it's just pictures and arrows... it's not so obvious for a beginner. The instruction actually shows for different types of wiper hooks, which I was overwhelmed by before I realized they weren't relevant to me.The part where it says "Bosch", you need to pinch, which was a bit difficult for me, and flip open; after you slide it in, you will lock it back.These wipers look a lot more "tough"/thicker than your average/stock wipers. It may be a minor pet peeve for some people, but when you're inside the car, you will notice the wipers more in your view, since they are thicker.On the driver side, it wipes everything clean. Of course, on the passenger side, since it's shorter, it will leave some areas in the corner, but that's to be expected and it's fine.I will update my review if I encounter any problems. I'm proud of myself for being able to install this on my own and happy with the look and performance of these wipers... I see the forecast is going to rain this week - bring it on!!Pros:- Looks tough/thick wipers (not puny looking like the stock wipers)- Wipes cleanCons:- Instructions could be more detailed with written text - not just ambiguous arrows.

Sabre is really the only brand to trust when it comes to pepper sprays. Law Enforcement also use it and is a trusted brand.If these go on your skin or clothing indirectly, it will be contaminated and you will feel a burning feeling. (one time, I had one in my pocket and it triggered by accident, so I actually know from experience...). If these go directly into the eyes, I can't imagine how painful it would be. Many people claim being pepper sprayed is far worse than being tazered.I own several pepper sprays from Sabre and the canister for this is on the larger size, which is nice.This is advertised as a Dog Spray, but it can be just as effective on humans.Unlike the "SABRE RED Stop Strap Pepper Spray", the flip cover does not "lock/snap" - it's a spring-flap cover, so you just slide your thumb so it's ready for immediate use; with the other peppers sprays, one would have to flick to expose the nozzle or whatnot.I'm not sure if it's intended for the clip to be adjusted, but with some force, I was able to slightly adjust the positioning of the clip because the way it came made holding the canister a bit awkward for me.This is great to carry and gives you a peace of mind when going jogging/hiking for some protection.The one I received states it expires 01/2019!

This thing is seriously REALLY loud!! If you don't wake up from this, you must be in a coma...I covered the speakers to test it first and even then it hurt my ears so much... when my hands uncovered it, it was just insane. The piercing noise is really painful... this can be a torture device... I thought releasing the metal contact immediately would stop the alarm, but it did not... I had to press the switch to OFF.You have to unscrew the bottom battery cover to insert a 9v battery.I think this can actually come in handy besides doors... you could maybe carry it with you or keep it in your car  when you need attention, just press against the metal switch (having the switch to on) and you will definitely get people's attention.This is the perfect accessory to have when you go traveling and end up having to stay in somewhat shady motels or even nice looking hotels - definitely gives extra comfort!! I will definitely have this with me.I think it would be great if they add deluxe version with a wireless remote to stop the alarm in cases of false alarms, so you don't have to get out of bed and turn the switch off.Pros:- SUPER loud / piercing painful noise... definitely will drive anyone nuts/scare them.- Prevents door from opening all the way- Gives you extra comfort safety- Low battery indicatorCons:- 9v battery not included

After using compression socks and the KT Tape, I can say if you need ankle/leg support, it's a better investment and results having compression socks. For other areas on your body, this may be an alternative to whatever other method you're using or the only option.This version is uncut, so you need to use scissors. I was previously offered the pre-cut version and I find that one more convenient; these things stretch, so it's not necessary to cut it really long. The Uncut version may seem like it gives you more flexibility and freedom, but you need to also factor in the stretch/strength amount.The YouTube tutorial videos the company offers is definitely worth checking out and gives you a better idea of how these tapes are used.Depending on the area, you'll need assistance from another person to attach it on you or require multiple attachment of these; it's nice to have different color so it's easier to distinguish the anchor points.Ultimately, this is something you have to try yourself if it's right for you or not. From my personal experience, I prefer investing in compression socks than using these tapes.

I'm a guy and my friends laughed at me for owning a pepper spray (I've personally bought the 1/2 oz SABRE RED Pepper Spray - Police Strength and the 0.75 oz SABRE Pepper Spray - Advanced 3-In-1 Police Strength) and having it attached to my key chain; they think pepper sprays are only for girls to carry... silly! If they were to have this sprayed in them, they would not be laughing... (not that I did that... that would be improper use 0=) I know they would be crying and vomiting.I don't care if you're Bruce Lee or Hulk or feel invincible... protection is protection. You never know.It's better to be safe than sorry. Fortunately, I never had a situation where I had to use this.However, I can share with you that these things are no joke, and I have a funny story to share with the one I had on my key chain...I would actually carry a bunch of my keys and the Sabre attached in my back pocket; that Sabre requires to twist the trigger towards the open end to expose the spray... well, one day, I seem to have been moving around more than usual and somehow it twist/turned on its own and it sprayed/leaked in my pants!!I didn't realize it until I felt a irritating burn on my butt... and that wasn't the end of it. When I removed my contact lens and put them back in that day, it burned so much... somehow a small amount of it must have still been on my fingers, even when I have washed my hands. What was supposed to be something to protect myself ended up giving me pain and backfiring... friendly fire...Anyway, that was my slight painful experience and that wasn't even directly or even actually being sprayed in the eyes...Speaking of butt....Johnny Knoxville and the bright folks from the show "JACKASS" experimented pepper spraying themselves (Sabre brand) and being tazered; not only him, but everyone else who have actually experienced both being pepper sprayed and tazered state how being pepper sprayed is way more painful than anything.There is no twisting/turning with this one; the top cover snaps when it is completely closed; when you feel like you need to use it, you can unsnap it up and lift it up slightly so you can slide your thumb on to the trigger, or just raise the lid cover completely.There are two really tiny small windows on the side where if it shows green then it's ready to fire. If you remove the bottom ball-joint strap out of the spray then the window turns red and it will not fire; I believe this is a safety feature they added in case someone ends up snapping this off your hands/strap, then they won't be able to use it on you.You probably don't want the ball joint too loose that it would easily end up snapping off. I received mine being really tight so it was difficult to remove/put it back in. There is a standard screw showing a minus sign, turning it counterclockwise to loosen, and plus sign to turn clockwise to tighten the ball-joint hole; you need to adjust it to whatever is comfortable - you don't want it too loose or too tight. It would be better to be tighter than loose since if it comes off the ball joint then the spray will become totally useless. I think for easier adjustments, the whole balljoint/screw design could be improved to something else.I like the look of the grip - it looks more "professional" and law enforcement-like than just the canister by itself.The flip up lid and triggering system feels like a safety feature they put on triggering a demolition or bomb.Law Enforcement use Sabre Brand. I would not trust generic pepper sprays. This is more expensive than the other sprays Sabre offers. If you don't want that accidental twist happening, a better grip/look, and trigger disabling from being taken away from your wrist/balljoint, then the extra cost might be better for you.

The printer is a bit on the larger size, considering it does not have a scanner or anything else; however, it's not too heavy to transport.You need to first remove all the orange plastic pieces and tape.The instructions are all mostly pictures, so it may be a bit confusing sometimes. And then the LCD is pretty tiny and you have to wait for it to scroll some instructions/text so that can be a bit annoying.I own several printers, but inserting the ink for this one was a bit different than I'm used to. You insert each ink one at a time and then press OK, and then the machine moves a slot each time for you to be able to insert the ink next to it.There are 4 inks: BLACK, YELLOW, CYAN, MAGENTA (uses PGI-2200)When you first set it up, it takes 7 minutes for ink cleaning and 3 minutes for paper alignment testing.It's easiest to set up the wireless printing using USB cable and connecting it to a computer - unfortunately, you will need to have a printer cable (not included) for this.You have to adjust/extend the cartridge to A4 for putting in a standard paper. When you do this, the trays will stick out of the printer - for some reason, I thought the tray was suppose to go all the way in... Maybe I'm stupid but I'm like what's going on?!?! But then you basically pull out the output tray that ends up covering the top. I think it would have been nicer, considering the size of this things, for the paper trays to be completely flush inside even for those standard paper size.I like how fast it prints - it feels like laser. The printer itself doesn't cost much, but of course the inks are what will add up. Definitely ALWAYS use OEM Canon brand inks - NEVER USE THIRD PARTY (unless you don't care about the printer head breaking in the long run); I've learned my lesson the hard way before and never again do I trust third party inks. Ever.I just wish it had a smaller footprint.Update: This thing takes awhile to "warm up" - a bit frustrating...

As a former political appointee SES for the Bush (43) administration and subsequently a contractor in Iraq for 14 months, the author has a unique, bird's eye perspective of everything that went so horribly wrong after we invaded Iraq in 2003.  The current book is his testimony as to just how many more problems we created for the world and just how few problems we solved with our decision to "engage" (as Jeb Bush would say!).The author describes the reconstruction project in Iraq as being filled with conflicting priorities, dysfunctional agencies, corruption, laziness, simple-mindedness and a general misunderstanding of what the mission was as well as confusion about sundry aspects of Iraqi culture.  This goes for all parties involved, be they military leaders, military advisors, State department personnel or contractors.  There is plenty of blame to go around in how things turned-out in spite of our magnanimous intentions towards the people of Iraq.Even the most naive amongst us are well aware that war profiteering has been a big business since 9/11.  It has been widely documented how companies such as Halliburton, Blackwater and others have "gamed the system" to rake in $$.  Their methods range from price gouging, exaggerating their services and sometimes falsifying reports on the services that they were supposed to deliver.  None of this is new.  What is new, according to Michael O'Brien is that it's even worse than that.  Even when contractors TRY to do their jobs & have a positive impact, they are frequently ignored and shunned by the military types while at the same time they are told to "keep quiet" by their parent company.  The author concedes that, in spite of his desire to have a positive impact on the reconstruction of Iraq, in the end he was used as a pawn by his organization to turn a buck.  This is a truly sobering indictment of our efforts which ended up resulting in mass chaos.With a background as an Army officer and a graduate of West Point, O'Brien points of the flaws of Rumsfeld's invasion plan.  Rumsfeld daydreamed of a "lighter, more mobile" military force.  As such, we invaded Iraq with too few troops.  Rumsfeld believed that our superior technology could bridge the gap.  He was right about that ~ sort of.  While technology can be used to win battles & wipe out bad guys, technology has very limited capabilities when it comes to occupying territory.  As the author alludes to, this was the Achilles heel of our ambitions:  we simply didn't have the manpower to achieve the objective.The author also discusses how the Bush (43) administration reverse engineered the intelligence community to cherry pick what they wanted to hear about the possible presence of WMDs in Iraq whilst ignoring everything they didn't want to hear.  The politics involved in the planning of the invasion were reprehensible.  The discussion the author presents is compelling in its breadth of just how costly it was to us as a country in Dubya's decision to surround himself with sycophants.On the downside, the author tends to paint with a wide brush which leads to over-generalizations.  On page 42 he writes "Today's soldiers, most of them good and decent people, are bought and paid for.  The majority of those in the service today - other than true combat forces who really want to serve their country - are there because it's the closest alternative to being unemployed."  I could not disagree more with this statement.  First off, combat jobs are not the only hazardous occupations in the military.  It takes courage to be a submariner as all of your eggs are in one basket if something goes wrong.  Working on the deck of an aircraft carrier is one of the most dangerous jobs in the world.Furthermore, this is a slap-in-the-face to people who joined the military since 9/11.  People who joined the Army & Marines, in particular, deserve better than this as it was obvious that someone who joined either of these services had a high probability of being deployed to the Middle East if they signed-up post-9/11.  Beyond that, in this day & age there are no longer "front lines" so to speak as there were in WWII.  A cook or a truck mechanic can easily be deployed to a forward operating base (FOB) with not much in the way of protection from the bad guys.The author also misses the mark when it comes to remarks about political leanings.  On page 326 he writes "Liberals will never like a Republican president, no matter how good a job he does."  Are there liberals who will never like a Republican president?  Goodness, gracious, yes!  Likewise, there are conservatives who will never like a Democratic president, regardless of how well he or she performs.  This comes out as a wash.The point is this:  I would like to think there are enough free thinking liberals & conservatives to maintain an objectivity that is altogether lacking today inside the beltway.  The whole notion of "Republicans are always right, Democrats are always wrong" (or vice versa) is precisely why we're in the political pickle we find ourselves in today.  For myself, I am a liberal and yet my all-time favorite president is Teddy Roosevelt ~ a Republican (gasp!).  I call 'em like I see 'em.  There are other liberals out there like myself, and I'm certain there are conservatives who are like that as well.  While pacificists and Neocons will never find common ground, it doesn't mean that the rest of us can't.Lastly, the author reveals himself to ascribe to the birther conspiracy, which downgrades his credibility.  The Whitehouse released President Obama's birth certificate, they have corroborated his birth in Hawaii with several witnesses AND investigators produced a newspaper from the day he was born which announced Obama's birth.  So, did someone way back in the early 1960s plant a fake story JUST in case Obama might grow up to be President?  Really?  As humans, we often disregard evidence that runs contrary to what we already believe.  Unfortunately, the author has succumbed to this tendency.All of that said, this is a remarkable book written from the perspective of what is "behind the curtain" of our decision to invade as well as the subsequent egregious decisions we made (such as Paul Bremer's directive to disband the Iraqi army ~ way to go Paul!).  Sun Tzu warned that nothing drains a state's treasury faster than a siege.  In an unconventional way, our occupation of Iraq has been precisely that:  an unorthodox siege.  In Star Trek terminology we violated the Prime Directive by trying to mold the Iraqi people into our own image.  The results have been nothing short of disastrous.For further reading / viewing on our missteps & adventures in the Middle East I would recommend Rage Company: A Marine's Baptism By Fire,  W.and The Wrong Enemy: America in Afghanistan, 2001-2014.  For an inquiry into the atrocities that we(!) as a nation have commited since 9/11 I would suggest Inside Iraq The Untold Stories, Battle For Haditha and http://www.amazon.com/Taxi-Dark-Side-Alex-Gibney/dp/B001BEK8FQ/ref=sr_1_1_twi_dvd_1?s=movies-tv&ie=UTF8&qid=1447888069&sr=1-1&keywords=taxi++dark+side.  For the perils of outsourcing work that is inherently governmental in nature, check out http://www.amazon.com/Fox-Henhouse-Privatization-Threatens-Democracy-ebook/dp/B005LY2DT6/ref=sr_1_2?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1447888347&sr=1-2&keywords=fox+in+the+henhouse.  Finally, for those who want to read an illuminating historical fiction novel about the origin of Islam, check out http://www.amazon.com/Prophets-Scribe-Osman-Kartal/dp/1467950505/ref=sr_1_1_twi_pap_2?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1447888496&sr=1-1&keywords=prophet%27s+scribe+osman.

Cougar locker room fantasy!Cassandra is a beautiful 38 year old fitness instructor who has been hired on as the conditioning coach for the football team of a small college. She inspires the team not only with pep talks, but she has a "built in advantage" over other coaches in that the players are all mesmerized by her and they want to ingratiate themselves to her good graces. As coaching jobs go, this makes her job relatively easy!After winning a championship, Cassandra finds herself in the locker room to congratulate the team. While there was nothing insidious about her original intentions, one thing leads to another, and that leads to several other things. After all, a bunch of buffed up naked jocks + a smokin' hot middle aged woman all together in a locker room can be quite an erotic combination!!One of the "keys" to erotica is to have a story that is believable & happens naturally rather than a tale that is obviously contrived or far fetched. On this point, the current short story "nails" this aspect. It's altogether conceivable that a coach (even a female coach) would be in or near a team's locker room after a big win. One could see how things could quickly get out of hand when the football players notice their gorgeous conditioning coach in their midst. It's also more than plausible that a woman who is pushing 40 would be flattered to garner so much attention from dozens of young studs.As you may have guessed, Cassandra ends up getting "crazy" with the team. She also gets a mini-bukkake, which I admit is my #1 turn-on. The author, Tori Westwood, does a great job of taking the reader "inside the locker room" where both a Cougar as well as the football players engage in taking more than a few bites of "forbidden fruit." My one criticism is that the details of the bukkake could have been a little more specific. Oh, well.If multiple man / 1 woman fantasies are your gig, then this short story is a must to add to your collection! It's always more arousing when erotica is written by women, and we get a bird's eye view of an erotic encounter fom a woman's point-of-view.

Ana is a beautiful young Iraqi born American who has had a rough life.  Born in Iraq, her father was unjustly executed by the regime of Saddam Hussein.  After she & her mother fled to the United States, Ana wanted to be a force for good and honor her late father.  As a result, she ended up joining the Marines and ascended to becoming a Marine scout sniper.  In a twist-of-fate, she found herself back in her homeland, this time as an invader.Inadvertently, her actions lead to the death of an Iraqi boy.  It is a PR disaster for the Marine corps and she is court martialed for committing a war crime & dereliction of duty.  She is found guilty, sentenced to 5yrs in a military prison and dishonorably discharged from the Marines.  After getting out, she finds few options for work that match her skill set.  About the only occupation that "fits" is becoming a  mercenary working for a Mexican drug cartel.Such is the backdrop of Ana's story.  It is both compelling and heart wrenching as she finds herself wrestling with guilt & the ghost of the boy haunts her constantly.  While this is a story of fiction, it is nonetheless a metaphor of how the actions of the United States warped the Middle East into an unrecognizable shape.  NOT ONLY did our good intentions backfire, but they backfired in the worst possible way.  The agony & anguish caused ever since the opening salvo of Rumsfeld's "shock & awe" have been immeasurable for the Iraqi people.  {I always cringe whenever I hear Jeb Bush try to defend his brother as both Jeb & Dubya are totally oblivious to this point}If you're looking for an unconventional ghost story, this just may fill the bill.  It is not the type of ghost story that you tell around a campfire:  it's a totally different animal.  It is, rather, a story about guilt & remorse and how we as a country cannot undo what we have done.  Somehow, good intentions, $$ and resources were not nearly enough for us to save the people of Iraq.  Ana is but a pawn in the bigger picture, but her story is emblematic of what a morass that post-invasion Iraq has become.  It is also symbolic of the guilt that lives with us as a nation.
Waste of time.  Don't be fooled by the title: bukkake is just in the title as a bait & switch type of a red herring.

Full disclosure:  I am not a snow boarder or a skier.  That said, I am still in the market for thermal socks as a season ticket holder to Michigan State football games.  I wore my ski socks for the 1st time last Saturday;  the weather was rainy & nasty and it was just the test necessary for this product.  The socks delivered perfectly!  They are very comfortable, have a snug fit and they kept my feet dry & warm while the rest of me got soaked in a downpour.  I would highly recommend them to other people who have a requirement for insulated socks.

It is an exciting time to be alive.  Just in the past 15 years, exoplanets have been discovered to exist.  While it was always assumed they were out there in other star systems, it is only recently that their existence was confirmed.  At first, astronomers could only detect super huge planet (like Jupiter or several times the size of Jupiter).  In the last decade or so, refined techniques have allowed astronomers to locate much smaller / rocky planets.  In short, planets that are Earth-like.  Recently, they found one that most closely resembles Earth of all the planets found thus far:  a mere 1,400 light years away from us.  Future generations will look back on us in a similar way in which we look in retrospect on Galileo's exuberance at discovering the moons of Jupiter.The present novel entertains the idea of how exploring an Earth-like exoplanet might look.  The author is creative in his vision of the future, and one could even say that his inferences are plausible.  In the story, a group of astronauts are sent to study an exoplanet that has 2 dominant species:  the Hyanka and the Threck.  Both species are intellient:  they use verbal language, use tools and have a societal structure.  Neither, however, is technologically advanced.  Instead of making contact with the species, the explorers study the planet and all of its species from orbit.The main character is a beautiful young (well, so long as you don't count her transit time in suspended animation!) woman named Minerva (Minnie for short).  She has an inquisitive mind but she has some personality idiosyncrasies which other crew members find perterbing.  She is also most likely the smartest in the group.  Her name is fitting as Minerva is the Latin counterpart to the Greek goddess of wisdom (Athena).As one might get, things go kahooey for our astronaut friends & they need to jettison themselves to the surface of the planet in escape pods to get away from their doomed space station (hence the title of the book).  While the pods are supposed to all land at a predetermined rally point, the technology does not work as planned.  The pods end up scattered, and one of them ends up on an entirely different continent altogether.  Uh oh!As such, the astronauts find themselves in the cosmic sense like zoologists who are trapped on a massive wild game preserve.  Suddenly, their study of the planet takes a back seat to basic survival & trying to regroup with their friends.  Along the way they have to cope with alien religions, alien culture, alien caste systems, alien racism and general alien nuances in 1st contact proceedings.One of the most fascinating parts of the story is how the iPhone finds its next incarnation.  The astronauts have an artificial eye (which they call their 'fone') which they use to look up data and observe their surroundings.  They can zoom-in like a camera lens and they can view their surroundings using thermal & infra-red features.  They can also use their fone to "text" another astronaut, sort of like an artifical form of telepathy.  Lastly, the fone is also used to record events and it monitors the health status of its owner.For people who are interested in the future of space travel, this book is a must see.  Traveling to an exoplanet will not happen in our lifetimes, but this book could be a glimpse of the far future, just as Jules Verne's books were a glimpse into the 20th century.  People who enjoy this book may also wish to peruse Mariner Valley.  MV envisions the colonization of a planet far closer to home:  Mars.

As a general rule, the reality show genre is not my gig.  This Blu Ray  disc would easily qualify as an exception to that rule.  It is about 2 brothers who set off to circumnavigate China on motorcycles.  It isn't any kind of a race, nor are there any contrived tasks for them to perform.  Rather, it is simply about 2 brothers who embark on a 65 day odyssey to explore regions of China that few people from the west have ever seen.  The journey includes drive-bys of China's borders with North Korea, Pakistan & Nepal.For myself, I have been to Shanghai, which is both the starting point & the ending point of their journey.  Westerners who go to China typically hit the hot spots such as the Forbidden City, Tibet and the Great Wall.  While the latter 2 are explored by the brothers, they also travel to far more remote places in the country.  As it turns out, China has an amazingly diverse topography that most people (including myself) are not aware of.  They go from parts of the Gobi desert to high altitude mountainous regions to forested parts & scenic riverways.  All along the journey we experience the pitfalls such as culture shock / red tape, motorcycle wipeouts, vehicle breakdowns and foul weather.For anyone who has a passing interest in China as a country or in the myriad locations therein, this disc is highly recommended.  People who enjoy TOUGH RIDES may also be inclined to peruse Sihpromatum: I Grew My Boobs in China (Volume 1) and Why China Will Never Rule the World: Travels in the Two Chinas.

If you're looking for a semi-plausible plot where the pretty blonde receptionist takes on the whole crew working @ a car dealership, then this one is worth a look.  You may never think about "customer service" in quite the same way again!

Welcome to the 1950s:  the utopia of the Republican party.  It was back when "standard" social mores were accepted, before the mass marketing of porn, and back when homosexuality was treated with electro-shock therapy.  Ah, yes, those were the days.  In the 1960s, the genie got out of the bottle in the form of the sexual revolution.  Ever since then, Conservatives have tried desperately to put the genie back in the bottle ~ to no avail.When I 1st hear about this series, I assumed it would be a biographical docudrama of Alfred Kinsey.  Kinsey's pioneering research on sex related topics occured during the same time period;  he founded the Kinsey Institute @ the university of Indiana.  Instead. the main character is a fellow named Bill Masters (Mike Sheen) who seems to be based on Kinsey to some degree.People who assume this series is thrown together as an excuse for lots of nudity are sure to be surprised by the depth of issues that the show delves into, such as cancer, women's health issues, the demonization of homosexuality, problems with efforts to conceive a child and the tragedy of infant mortality.  To be sure, there is a good amount of naked bodies (THANK YOU Lizzy Caplan!) but there are also entire episodes w/out any nudity whatsoever.  On the whole, the SPARTACUS series actually had a lot more scintillating scenes than MASTERS OF SEX.The acting is impeccable.  Mike Sheen delivers a fine performance as a "mad scientist" type of OB/GYN who is both eccentric & stoic.  Bill Masters has a gorgeous wife, and yet he has little else but apathy for her physically.  He is obsessed with studying sex, and yet he is disinterested in having intercourse with his beautiful bride.  That's odd.  Lizzy Caplan is wonderful as his trusted assistant, Virginia.  Lizzy has an all-American girl-next-door beauty & she's built like a cheerleader, which makes her PERFECT for this part!If you are looking for a series that is daring and has both beauty & brains, then this is a series that is worth looking into!  If you want to see the 1950s as depicted in LEAVE IT TO BEAVER then it's best to leave this series alone as you're not gonna like what you see.

Napoleon  once said "Amateurs talk strategy.  Professionals talk logistics."  Alexander of Macedon once said that if he ever lost a battle, the 1st people he would execute would be his logisticians.  Typically, logistics officers are not household names as they're not deemed as "sexy" as combat officers on the front lines.  Nevertheless, to win wars, the loggies (as they're called) always play a very important role.The current book is the story of a supply officer named Howard Peckham, who was a 2 star general during World War II.  As the biggest conflict the world has ever seen (by far & away!), the logistics of moving armies and ships around was staggering.  Ultimately, superior logistics was one of the main factors which secured a victory for the allies in the war over the empires of Germany & Japan.This is the biography of the general who was tasked with the logistics of delivering fuel & lubricants to front line combat divisions during the war.  It is a remarkable "behind the scenes" view of the moving parts which contributed to allied forces landing victories on the battlefield and at sea.  By definition, loggies are an under appreciated lot;  anyone who peruses general Peckham's story is sure to have their opinion of logistics officers upgraded.The book is written by general Peckham's daughter, Jean.  In her position as the daughter of a military VIP, Jean describes how her family rubbed shoulders with such notable personages as George Patton, Omar Bradley, Dwight D. Eisenhower, Leslie Groves and Secretary of War Henry Stimson (among others).  One gets a fascinating & intimate view of the lives of famous flag officers & their families during the crisis of an entire world at war.The reader also gets a glimpse of postwar Europe from ground level as Jean traveled with her father in the latter's efforts at reconstruction & stabilization of western Europe after the defeat of the Nazis.  One of the most notable contributions of her father was the organization and establishment of 10 cemeteries across Europe which would serve as the final resting place of some 60,000 fallen soldiers, Marines & sailors.  The recovery of American war dead and many times their disinterment from local cemeteries and reinterment in military cemeteries was an arduous task taken up by the capable hands of general Peckham.This book is highly recommended for people who have an interest in WWII, especially people who are in the field of military logistics.  Furthermore, people with a basic curiosity in the history of the United States will benefit from general Peckham's story as well.  Loggies of the world are bound to find a great many things to like in his tale!

Fans of SHOWTIME's The Tudors will be encouraged to pick up this series as quickly as possible as it is a prequel of sorts to it.  White Queen goes back a generation to the War of the Roses and tells the tale of the rise of Henry VII (although he's not the main character in this story).  It details just how complicated and convoluted British history is with all of the twists & turns, shifting alliances and betrayals.The ensemble cast is impeccable with Max Irons as a jolly fellow who does his best to be a good & just king (Edward IV) who marries a commoner.  Rebecca Ferguson is stunning as Elizabeth, the commoner who becomes queen of England.  Tudors alumni James Frain once more dons his medieval garb and portrays Warrick, the sinister brother of Edward.Like The Tudors, this series has a genuine didactic feature;  I learned a lot from both series about an epoch in British history that I knew precious little about.  Both series are uncensored & uninhibited and do a fabulous job of taking the viewer back to the Middle Ages.  For lovers of history (like myself) this is a can't miss.  Who were Edward IV, Elizabeth Grey, Richard III and Henry VII?  Watch this series and by golly you'll find out.  Can't wait for season 2!!

In his 1st leading role since stepping down as the governator, this movie was nevertheless released with little fanfare and did not do much @ the box office.  As such, I really was not expecting much, but figured it was a great price for an action flick.  Truth be told, I was surprised by how entertaining I found this film to be.Arnie plays Ray Owens, a cop who saw a lot of "action" when he served on a narcotics task force for the LAPD.  After a violent career, Ray decided he wanted to settle down and finish out his law enforcement days as the sheriff of a remote town in Arizona, right next to the Mexican border.  About his biggest police duty is to write out a parking ticket in this small town.His plan for an easy twilight of his working days is working great until the leader of a Mexican drug cartel (played by Eduardo Noriega) gets away from the FBI.  The cartel leader is similar to the real-life El Chapo who escaped from a Mexican prison by riding a motorcyle through a custom built tunnel underneath his prison.  Instead of a motorcycle, this guy drives a souped-up Corvette to get away.  As he is a race car driver as well as a kingpin, the "fun begins" when he gets behind the wheel.  He chooses to cross the border in Ray's small town, and the cavalry is too far away to help poor Ray & his deputies deal with thugs hired by the cartel.Such is the outline of the plot.  It's the first time I have seen Forrest Whitaker in awhile and was good to see him again.  Jamie Alexander portrays the loveliest deputy I've seen in quite some time!  The Arnie of today is not the intimidating presence of Arnie of the 80s, nor does he claim to be.  In fact, Arnie wears a long sleeve shirt throughout the entire film and does not take off his shirt a single time.  Hence, people who are wondering how buffed up he  is these days are apt to be disappointed.  While Arnie in his prime would have made mincemeat of the villain in this film, the thug is more than a challenge for his persona of the aging Sheriff.All in all, a fun movie.  Not a "can't miss" but it's way better than I thought it would be and well worth the price of admission.

With his friend Scarlett at his side, Pax is dying of a rare disease.  He is in his final days and there seems to be no hope for recovery when these mysterious beings from another dimension (known as the 'astral plane') take pity on him and decide to save him.  Scarlett interferes with their efforts and finds herself roped-into the same astral powers that are granted to Pax.  From there, the law of unintended consequences kicks in and seemingly everything goes awry.Scarlett & Pax can sense these worm like entities of negative energy which are cloaked to "normal" folk.  They then begin dueling with the negative energy creatures, with varied results.  As such, this story is something akin to a science fiction version of the invisible war between the Seraphim & Cherubim vs. Satan's demons which the Catholics believe is going on all around us.  To complicate matters, there are subplots galore about the true intentions of the astral beings.This is a very strange story.  That does not mean it is bad, but it for sure is quite far fetched.  People who are fans of unconventional sci-fi may take an interest in this story.  For myself, it was fun while it lasted but I don't intend to continue to read of the adventures of Pax & Scarlett.

This is certainly the best Disney movie of the past 10yrs & is one of the best Disney movies of all time.  It puts an unexpected twist on a tale that we were all told as children about the wicked Maleficent who shows up uninvited and places a curse on the innocent royal baby, Aurora.  We all know the story:  only love's true kiss will be able to awaken the young lady.  Is such a thing even possible anymore?  Even in the imaginary world of a fairy tale?Angelina Jolie turns in one of the most powerful performances of her illustrious career as she "nails" the part of the magical creature who is more human than she would care to admit.  Elle Fanning makes the most of her opportunity to play out every teenage girl's dream:  to play the part of a fairy tale princess.  While the story is quite different than the 1 we all grew up knowing, it is congruent with the fairy tale motif and keeps from becoming far fetched.If you need a movie that will make you nostalgic for the fantasy stories of your youth, this is it.  If you're looking for a family friendly movie to watch on a Friday night, this is it.  If you think all fairy tales are silly & juvenile, I would urge you to give this 1 a whirl. It may just surprise you on how sophisticated a child's tale can be!

Erwin Schroedinger was one of the most landmark physicists of the 20th century.  If you have ever used a microwave oven, GPS, a CD / DVD player, computer or cell phone, then you can thank Schroedinger, Heisenberg, von Neumann, Turing and so many others.  That these are not household names is a sad reflection on the state of our educational system (thank you anti-science Right Wingers!).The current book offers two essays written by Schroedinger.  The 1st is on the enormous debt that modern day scientists owe to the ancient Greeks.  Way back then, philosophers and physicists were one-in-the-same.  Naturally, Schroedinger pays homage to one of the 1st atomists, Democritus.  In fact, it was Democritus who coined the term atom (literally, the Greek word means "unsplittable").  Coincidentally, in a more recent book, Leon Lederman sings the praises of Democritus in The God Particle: If the Universe Is the Answer, What Is the Question? and shows the nexus between his system of thought and that of experimental physicists in the present age.  While it is something of an encomium on the Greeks, Schroedinger also discusses possible disadvantages of being indoctrinated into the scientific paradigm as devised by the pre-Socratics.In the second essay, Schroedinger lists his thoughts on the haunting fear of a deterministic universe that so many philosophers of science have feared for the past few centuries.  Is free will just an illusion?  Or do we have control over our own fates?  Do independent spheres of science have any intrinsic value if they are not used towards a more comprehensive view of nature?  This is the introspective study that the great scientist engages in.This book is a must-have for all fans of the Austrian physicist.  For those who are curious about his life & times I would recommend the biography Schrödinger: Life and Thought.

Anne Frank was a precocious teenager who was going through puberty.  Her body was changing and she had her 1st boyfriend.  She dreamed of becoming a journalist one day.  She was remarkably well read for her age.  She was just like any other teenage girl, with one tragic exception:  as a Jewish girl during World War II, she had to live in hiding (in what she called the "Secret Annexe") from the Nazis.Along with her family and friends, Anne dealt with the threat of being discovered as well as food shortages and the general boredom which coincides with being cooped up for years.  Indirectly, while the Nazis cut her life short (eventually, the Secret Annexe was found out), they could not stop her from being a journalist.  She documented WWII from ground level in her place of hiding.  Her diary lists many major events during the war such as the fall of Mussolini, D-Day and much more.In the midst of the historical events is a young lady with an inquisitive mind.  She wrote "It's an odd idea for someone like me to keep a diary,  not only because I have never done so before, but because it seems to me that neither I - nor for that matter anyone else - will be interested in the unbosomings of a thirteen year old schoolgirl."  (Page 2)  She could not have been more wrong.  Little did she know that her diary would become one of the most important books ever written.Anne's story is tragic in 2 aspects.  First is the obvious:  this book is the memoir of a girl who didn't make it to the end of the war.  Secondly, she & her family came SO close to being able to return to normalcy.  D-Day raised the hopes of the clan, but the Franks (with the exception of her father, Otto) were among the last Jews to die in concentration camp.If there are any bigots out there who read this book, if Anne's story does not reverse their bigotry then nothing will.  The reason we have the DELTA FORCE, Navy SEALs and the rest is to ensure that there will never again be any people who suffer from persecution.  The motto of the Green Berets is "To free the oppressed."Obviously, it is an unattainable goal, but it is a noble one.  Sadly, as I write this review there are Anne Franks living in fear across the Middle East in ISIS controlled territories.  100 years from now there will be Anne Franks living in other crises in different parts of the globe.  Best we can do is not to forget Anne, and not forget them.  If you want to know what the face of genocide looks like, then read this book.

Aurora Reagan is a proud alumni of Michigan State University.  As such, she encapsulates the epitome of Spartan beauty:  she is elegant, stunningly beautiful and she's built like a cheerleader.  She has the brains to match as she is an accomplished businesswoman and a CEO of a top tier fashion company.  At her side is her adoring boyfriend, Nicholas.  She is the type of person who has everything going for her.As they're watching a bukkake porn one night, Aurora is repulsed and she becomes angry that her boyfriend is turned-on by the spectacle.  They have a big fight and she is resentful of his attitude towards the bukkake concept.  She begins to wonder about this boyfriend who had up to that point been the perfect match for her.Surprisingly, over time, she finds herself becoming aroused by the idea of being a bukkake girl.  Just as people don't go to see concert pianists play "Chopsticks," so too do people not attend bukkakes for plain Janes.  Shooters are only interested in bukkakes that feature pretty girls.  The fact that she would have that kind of power over a room full of men is something that she finds intoxicating.The problem, of course, is that she has a high profile and cannot afford  a tabloid scandal.  It will have to be, so to speak, a "confidential bukkake."  But how does she go about that?The erotic thing about this story is that it's a fully developed character who finds herself entranced by the notion of doing  a bukkake girl.  Aurora is NOT doing it for $$.  In fact, her net worth is more than all of the shooters combined!  Rather, she is doing it for HER own sake.  It will be HER confidential bukkake.While short stories such as Bukkake Girl, Cover Me: A Blonde Bukkake Fantasy and COLLEGE DORM BUKKAKE: Piper Gets Painted are all well & good, they are like fast food.  By contrast, the present fantasy is like a full course meal at a 5 star restaurant.  We get to actually KNOW the bukkake girl as opposed to her being a cut-out character.On top of that, Cara Addison does the best job of describing what a real bukkake would be like.  Bukkakes are erotica's counterpart to sharks engaged in a feeding-frenzy, and Cara is able to capture that aspect wonderfully.This is a ground-breaking book and is highly recommended for anyone who is intrigued by the genres of extreme erotica and / or bukkakes.  The rhythm of the book actually mimics a bukkake with its slow crescendo to sexual tension and ultimate release.  Even more than being about experiencing a bukkake, this book is all about relishing life, being alive.....and walking on the wild side!

Robert Elliot Burns was a soldier who fought in World War I.  After his return from the Great War he suffered from shell shock (what is commonly referred to these days as PTSD).  He was restless and spent some time aimlessly wandering about the country.  To his misfortune, one of the places he visited was Atlanta, GA.While in Georgia he was roped into a hare brained robbery which netted < $6.  He, the ringleader and another accomplice were quickly apprehended.  In spite of his military service + the fact that he had no prior criminal history, Burns was sentenced to 6-10 yrs on the infamous Georgia chain gang.Burns eventually escaped to Chicago where he married and became a successful businessman.  His fortunes turned when his spiteful, jealous & vindictive wife reported his whereabouts to the Georgia department of corrections.  Illinois was reluctant to extradite him as he was a model citizen in Chicago.  Ultimately, a deal was reached:  he would serve 90 days on the chain gang & then be set free.Georgia was embarrassed that a Yankee had escaped its penal system, so they pulled a classic bait & switch.  The feigned ignorance to the agreed upon 90 days chain gang duty.  In his attempts to have his parole granted, Burns ran into delay after delay.  He resolved to escape from the chain gang again ~ and he succeeded.None of the above is "spoiler material" as it's all spelled-out in the foreward to the book.  The "meat" of the story is the horrific details that he discloses about the medieval corporal punishment inflicted on the malefactors of the chain gang.  From the start, Burns never got a fair shake as he was an outsider to the state of Georgia as well as a Yankee.  The present book was written after his second escape while he was still on-the-run.As such, the most remarkable part of his tale, the denouement, is omitted from the pages of this book.  Eventually he was discovered once again while in hiding in New Jersey.  Once more, Georgia requested extradition.  This time, something unprecedented happened: the state of New Jersey declined Georgia's request and set Burns free.  Burns still wanted to square matters with Georgia and finally had his sentence commuted to time already served in 1945.  This allowed him to roam freely throughout the country without fear of being extradited back to GA.  Again, none of the above is in the storyline of the book as it happened > the novel was written.In our "enlightened" period, we face two ends of the spectrum to be avoided when it comes to incarceration.  The first is making prisons a "Club Med" experience, and the second is to not succumbing to crafting prisons / penal codes that are designed to wreck a man or woman's soul.  Also, unusually lengthy sentences should be avoided for minor transgressions.  As Marcus Tullius Cicero said, "The punishment should fit the crime."Here is a story of the need for justice being usurped by a motive for vengeance by the Georgia corrections agency.  It is a "red flag" case of what should be avoided.  Before reading this book, I was unaware that Georgia didn't even HAVE a regular prison until 1938 (its last men's prison having closed in 1874).  In the interim, the chain gang was the sole punitive option used to mete out justice.  In fact, this very book may well have had a hand in the state of Georgia reforming its justice system and building the new prison!This is an enjoyable read, a quick read and it has a very quick pace.  The reader is able to "dive right into" the turmoil that the veteran soldier found himself in after making a single ill advised decision.  Nietzsche once wrote:  "Distrust all in whom the impulse to punish is powerful."  Here is the epitome of what can happen when there is overreach on the side of the criminal justice system and the authority figures who prefer sadism to just sentences.

e most people, I am aware of the Jewish insurrection which transpired in the first century CE.  It ended with the Romans, under the emperor Vespasian, put Jerusalem under siege.  The city burned and ultimately many Jews who survived the siege ended up trying to hold out @ Masada (albeit unsuccessfully).  While these episodes are familiar with most people who are acquainted with Roman and / or Jewish history, the present book is a "deep dive" into these events.  The retaliation of the Romans is told in an exquisite 1st person detail.  As such, the events are brought to life once more after lying dormant on the pages of history books for the past 2,000 yrs.The central figure in the book is a Jewish priest / Rabbi by the name of Jacob.  Jacob holds a seething hatred for the Romans, but finds himself powerless to resist them.  He miraculously survives the destruction of Jerusalem and ends up wandering around the Roman controlled colonies, all the while having strange visions of a Messiah.  His life is a Shakespearian tragedy squared with the continual losses he must deal with.Along the way, Jacob interacts with historical figures such as the Jewish historian Josephus, the emperor Titus and Tiberius Julius Alexander.  Jacob finds himself endlessly searching for meaning in a world that has fallen apart.  From his visions, he begins to wonder if the time might be right for a new religion to emerge, one that will ultimately undercut the hegemony of the Roman empire.Such is the framework of the current story.  As a disclaimer, it should be noted that this book is not geared towards  ardent Christians who wish to augment or increase their faith.  Rather, the target audience would be people like myself who have an intellectual curiosity about comparative religion and / or the Roman empire.  For people who are believers, this is the type of book that will showcase how your religious / historical sausage is made.LOGOS does for the origin of Christianity what The Prophet's Scribe does for the birth of Islam.  Both books are remarkable in their approach to their respective religions, and both take the readers back to ground-zero of the rise of Christianity & Islam.  Man, the storytelling animal, has for so long aggrandized the lives of what Hegel would call  "World historic individuals."  Such is the making of myth.  Such is the birth of religions.
A bait & switch.  Random photos;  it's not what you think

Books such as No Easy Day: The Autobiography of a Navy Seal: The Firsthand Account of the Mission That Killed Osama Bin Laden by Owen, Mark, Maurer, Kevin (2012) Hardcover, American Sniper [Movie Tie-in Edition]: The Autobiography of the Most Lethal Sniper in U.S. Military History, SEAL Team Six: Memoirs of an Elite Navy SEAL Sniper and Lone Survivor: The Eyewitness Account of Operation Redwing and the Lost Heroes of SEAL Team 10 by Luttrell, Marcus (2007) Hardcover all detail the personal  experiences, adventures & missions of the individual Navy SEALs who authored them.  The present work is a bit different.  Instead of focusing on an individual SEAL or SEAL Team, it offers 1st hand accounts of Navy Surface Warfare groups of the past 75 or so years.The story begins with the Underwater Demolition Teams & Frogmen of World War II.  The book does a "deep dive" (pun intended!) into their gallant contributions to the ability of Marines & soldiers to establish beach-heads @ Normandy and islands during the Pacific island hopping campaign.  They would clear out booby-traps and detonate underwater mines (among other missions).In the early 1960s, under the administration of John F. Kennedy,  the UDT / Frogmen teams made the transition to SEALs who could also engage in combat missions that were inland as well as underwater sorties.  I was surprised that then Chief of Naval Operations, the legendary WWII admiral Arleigh Burke, had a HUGE hand in championing the cause of Naval Special Operations.  Burke had always been known as a "Destroyer man" (which is why he has an entire Destroyer class named after him!) so this was unexpected.  Interesting.The book proceeds to cover SEAL missions through Vietnam & up to their present day anti-terrorism missions.  The "untold stories" include missions that went off flawlessly as well as other missions that didn't go so well at all.  It does have a refreshing honesty about the latter category.A common thread between this book and other Special Forces books is simply this:  all too often the greatest enemy of a SEAL / Green Beret / Delta Force Commando or Marine Recon type is not his adversary on the battlefield.  Rather, the biggest threat he faces comes from either faulty military intelligence or members of the Pentagon Brass who have no clue what they're doing.  Sadly, those 2 factors can get an elite operative killed faster than anything else!This is a thrilling read for people who have either a fascination for Special Forces (like me) or a general interest in the SF community.  It is filled with exciting stories as well as sobering tales of what happens when things don't go like clockwork on an SF mission.  All in all, a very worthwhile endeavor into the secret lives of perhaps the most admired and respected fighting force on planet Earth:  the United States Navy SEALs.

Bucky is an I.T. specialist from New York who finds himself moving up the corporate ladder.  From the Big Apple, he is to relocate to London with a hefty promotion.  The world is his oyster and his life is coming into focus.....or so he thinks.  Unfortunately, things don't always work out the way we plan them to.  As Heisenberg would say, there's always a certain amount of uncertainty in play.Bucky accidentally finds himself in the milieu of prostitution as he finds himself an I.T. worker for a cathouse.  He does a great job and even comes up with a SMARTPHONE app which allows the patrons to order everything on the salacious menu with a push of a button.  Still, poor Bucky does not seem to appreciate the gravity of the situation he's gotten himself into.Everyone is aware of prostitutes who have fallen on hard times;  the streetwalkers who are addicted to drugs and who are beaten by their pimps.  There are also those who are sold into sex trafficking, as depicted in the "TAKEN" movie series.On the other hand, there are women who work for High Society escort firms of their own volition.  Frequently, they have college degrees ~ sometimes advanced degrees.  At the high end, there are women who only have 1-2 clients who are millionaires or billionaires.  These women have birthday wishlists in which they ask for a Ferrari, a $500,000 diamond necklace and a weekend @ the Hamptons.  Oh, and by the way ~ they're apt to get all 3 from their Sugar Daddy clientele.Such is the gap of the ambiguous profession of prostitution.  Bucky believes that he is involved in the more "legitimate" latter type.  Little does he know that there is a nexus between the two ends of the courtesan spectrum that he's unaware of.The downside of being in a capitalistic society is that we tend to place too much focus on a person's net worth & believe there is a nexus between it & the individual's worth as a person.  Like the rest of us, Bucky finds himself guilty of this.  There are subtle allusions in the story to Hinduism, which is a religion that emphasizes how one should "play one's role" in life and not move up or down the socio-economic ladder.  This way, of course, the poor will always be under-the-thumb of the rich.Americans & the British, of course, frequently practice the teachings of Hinduism without practicing the religion itself.  In the story, Bucky finds that there are a great many rich people who are like Mitt Romney:  arrogant, elitist and born without an operational soul.  On the other hand, he finds a great many "everyday" people who are erudite, profound and capable of unbounded kindess.Such is the backdrop of this novel.  At times it is humorous and other times it is somber.  Occasionally it is erotic and it is always intriguing.  If you're unsure whether a book about an I.T. professional can be fun  & engaging, give this one a try.  Bucky will be pleased if you do!

In the summer of 1947, SOMETHING happened @ Roswell, New Mexico.  On that, all parties agree.  What the "something" was is a matter for debate to this day.  The official government story is that a weather balloon crash landed.  Government cospiracy theorists, however, are convinced that an alien spacecraft crash landed.  Subsequently, so the story goes, the alien lifeforms and spacecraft was taken to the infamous AREA 51.Like [[ASIN:ASIN INDEPENDENCE DAY]], the current novel delves into the mythology surrounding Roswell & AREA 51.  Come to find out, a super secret sector of the government has, in fact, taken aliens and alien hardware to the remote outpost in the Mojave desert.  This sector is known as the SAINT MARY'S PROJECT.  For the past 6 decades they have done genetic experiments, splicing together human & alien DNA and they have also attempted to reverse-engineer the alien technology.  Of course, the military has also been searching for vulnerabilities in the alien technology that could be exploited should an interstellar conflict ensue.Such is the backdrop of the storyline.
