I long ago abandoned religion in favor of logic & have never turned back.  The author's assumption that his life story is part of some divine cosmic plan is groundless.  He also overlooks the myriad fallacies, contradictions and omissions that exist in the Holy Bibble.In short, there was no "cosmic plan" behind the people on 9/11 who had to make the horrifying choice between being burned alive & leaping to their deaths (over 20 people chose the latter).  Nor was there a cosmic plan behind hundreds of thousands of heretics being tortured and burned @ the stake by the likes of Justinian, the Spainish Inquisition, Queen Mary & so many more.  Nor was there a divine agenda behind the holocaust.  Life is what it is, for better or for worse.While religion can offer comfort to life's travails, it is ultimately a counterfeit comfort.  This is what Karl Marx meant when he said "Religion is the opium of the people."  It makes you feel good, but it simply isn't true.Nevertheless, I cannot give this intimate self-portrait anything other than 5 stars.  The impetus for the book was the famous speech he gave @ the Big 10 pre-season conference just < his senior yr.  The video of his speech went viral on YOUTUBE and has since been used by other schools (and even entire conferences!) to use as a freshman orientation tool for their student athletes.  It was referred to time & again during telecasts of MSU football games that season, including the OUTBACK Bowl vs. UGA.Of course, for we MSU fans, it only reinforced what we already knew:  we had an outstanding player who was also a class-act as a person.  So many times in sports, you either get a class act whose talent rates between mediocre & bench-warmer, OR you get an all-world prospect who is an arrogant jerk.  It's rare to find someone who is both a good guy and a good player.  In Captain Kirk Cousins, we Michigan State fans were able to enjoy the presence of a man who possessed both attributes!

Larry Cartford was a Lutheran pastor who tried to demonstrate an unconventional premise.  He believed that the language of theology could be expressed via the actions of Christians, thereby providing a "proof" of God's influence on the world.  Ultimately, he was forced to abandon this paradigm as he found out first hand just how vindictive, narcissistic, petty and irrational that religious zealots can be.  This ultimately drove him away from religion altogether, where he found a peace he never knew with atheism.His stories of the infighting within his congregation reminded me of the Baptist church where I was indoctrinated as a Christian while growing up in Michigan.  After I graduated from high school, consternation within the church was the impetus to spawn a brand new church as pragmatic and theological issues could not be reconciled.  I have not given any thought to this in decades, but it is curious that it would appear that this sort of thing goes on  a lot more than I would have guessed.As a former pastor, Cartford is in a unique position to discern the "mind control" strategies of religions across the world.  When I was a boy, I once received in Sunday School a paper with a sketch of Jesus that said "David is glad Jesus loves him."  I thought to myself "Wait a second.  When did I ever admit to either of these things being true?"  Point is, the church wanted submission 1st and everything else would fall into place later.  It's for this reason that religions want to prey on the minds of the most vulnerable persons:  young children who don't know any better.Looking back, this to me is a bit terrifying to think about.  The author shares my concerns of religions that sponser a rejection of reason & close mindedness and extols people who want to question the veracity of the bible / sacred teachings.My criticisms of the book are few & minor.  The biggest shortcoming is not in the content but, rather, the fact that the book could summon the services of an editor / proofreader.Content wise, there are a few places where the former pastor tends to misunderstand Islam.  On page 90 he writes:  "The tribal god of the Muslims dominates a large portion of today's world....In some countries this god has an aversion to female flesh.  Women cannot be seen without their bodies covered."This is not exactly true.  Yes, in most Islamic countries, women must wear veils / headscarves or even a burka.  This is true.  However, the impetus of this practice goes back to a rather amusing story regarding one of Mohammed's wives, Aisha.  {For those who would seek to learn the story as well as understand what the Muslims believe & why they believe it, I would recommend The Prophet's Scribe.This is an excellent book for people who have been religious all of their lives but are beginning to have their doubts about the truth of what they believe.  Another similar book like the present one is Hope after Faith: An Ex-Pastor's Journey from Belief to Atheism.  While the present book is a terse nuts & bolts look at the factors that compelled the author to leave the ministry for atheism, HOPE AFTER FAITH is much more of an autobiographical look at the journey.In any case, many people who have "crossed over" from religion to skepticism / atheism will find the tenets of both books to be quite familiar.  For myself, I tend to pull my hair out these days when people say stuff like "Don't worry:  everything happens for a reason."  The implication is that an omnipotent being is in charge of everything.  I reject that notion whole-heartedly and see religion itself as a rejection of life for it follows the confused narrative of "IF we cannot live forever, then we should not live @ all."  Such is  a paradigm of life that I left long ago & have no intentions of ever going back to.

This is an entertaining story about the post-war environment of the far future.  Following an intergalactic war, the galaxy is in shambles as myriad planets try to rebuild from the rubble of the conflict.  While there was a definitive "winner" in the struggle, it becomes unclear as to what has been gained as chaos & confusion abounds.  What's worse is that the triumphant force is unable to transform the conquered beings into their own image.As such, the story has a great many allusions to what has transpired in the Middle East over the last decade.  Sure, the United States "won" the wars in Afghanistan & Iraq, but what precisely does that mean if we're unable to shape the future of those two countries?  The same holds true in this tale, only on a much broader scale.  The story also deals with other all-too-common issues of war such as PTSD,  Machiavellian  tactics and the human (and in this case, alien) costs of warfare.The book also zeros in on a another  phenomenon:  the necessity (as well as sometimes the nuisance) of private security firms.  While their involvement is supposed to simplify things, they can frequently make things much more complicated.  One of the factors that led to the fall of the Roman empire was the fact that they outsourced their defense to mercenary armies that eventually turned on them.So, if you're interested in science fiction as well as how some things seemingly never change (from ancient battles to battles fought in the far future) then this book is worth a look.  It contains elements of The Bourne Identity and Star Wars Trilogy (A New Hope / The Empire Strikes Back / Return of the Jedi) (Widescreen Edition with Bonus Disc).

This is a pictorial history of the football program of Michigan State University.  It includes some of the oldest pictures, dating back to the Michigan Agricultural College (MAC) teams coached by MSU's 1st coach, Henry Keep.  The book extends through the MAC becoming Michigan State College (MSC) and ultimately MSU.  It leaves off with the inaugural season of John L. Smith.The book showcases the great players, coaches & personalities that were involved with the football program over the yrs.  It includes the story of President John Hannah, who moved heaven & earth to get MSU into the Big 10 > the university of Chicago pulled the plug on its football program in 1939 & ultimately departed the conference.Perhaps most importantly for MSU fans, Grinczel's work covers the Golden Age of Michigan State football, which went from 1950-1971.  These were the eras of Biggie Munn, Duffy Daughtery as coaches & Jack Breslin as the Athletic Director.  Of course, no book of this type would be complete without pix from the heralded 1966 "Game of the century" against Notre Dame.The most unfortunate thing about the book is the timing.  In other words, where it leaves off.  The book ends with the 1st year of John L Smith's disastrous coaching tenure in East Lansing.  Smith was arguably the single worst hire in program history.  Sure, Denny Stoltz & Bobby Williams were in over their heads, but it's always an unknown quantity when you promote someone to the position.  Muddy Waters was a terrible hire, but at least he was an MSU alumni who coached under Duffy.JLS, on the other hand, was a complete outside-the-box (and I would argue outside-common-sense) hire who had no business walking the sidelines @ Spartan Stadium.  During his tenure, it struck me as funny that a team that called themselves the Spartans would install a wimpy, finesse passing offense instead of playing the physical football it was always known for.  {Arch rival Michigan didn't learn from MSU's gaffe & they repeated the same mistake when they hired Rich Rodriguez}Smith's failure was a double-whammy for MSU.  When A.D. Merritt Norvell & MSU Prez Peter McPherson drove Nick Saban out of town, it set the program back 10yrs.  After firing Bobby Williams, hiring JLS was a slap-in-the-face to season ticket holders.  Meanwhile, Saban has since won 3 National Championships @ LSU & 'Bama.It would've been much better had the book left off with the victory over Georgia in the OUTBACK Bowl 2yrs ago.  Obviously, books always have to come out @ some point, but the final page of this book is likely to leave a lousy taste in the mouth of die hard MSU fans.

This is a rather unconventional book in the realm of religious apologetics.  The author critiques BOTH fundamentalist Christianity as well as Darwinian evolution.  Beth Houston believes in microevolution (evolution within the species), but not macroevolution (intra-species evolution).  As a Deist, she also rejects the Bible as literal fact.  In doing so, the author sets up her encampment just outside the range of artillery of intellectual atheists such as Christopher Hitchens & Richard Dawkins.  Their primary targets, after all, are fundamentalists who reject Darwinian evolution outright.I have no quarrel with her criticisms of the inaccuracies, inconsistencies, logical fallacies and contradictions which can be found within the Holy Bible.  Similar attacks on the Bible may be found in Religulous, FROM PASTOR TO ATHEIST: A Non-god Way of Life and Hope after Faith: An Ex-Pastor's Journey from Belief to Atheism (as well as myriad other books & DVDs).Houston attacks the Conservative movement, claiming that it perpetuates intolerance, misogyny, elitism, tax breaks for the rich / big corporations, pollution, theocracy  and (last but not least)  pseudo-science.  On all of these points, I wholly concur.  I cringe at the notion of the utopia dreamed of by little minds such as Mitt Romney & Paul Ryan, where 1% of the population possesses 99% of society's wealth, property & assets.  I am also SO sick of the much-repeated mantra of the Republican Party: "If ONLY we could screw the poor a little more than we have, and coddle the rich a little more than we have, then everything else will work itself out!"The problem with the author's chapters in which she goes after the injustices & hypocrisy of the Right wingers lies not with her polemics.  Rather, the problem I had was finding a nexus between her arguments as justification for the existence of a Creator.  In my mind, she resembled a trapeze artist who was hurling from one suspended bar to another 50 feet in the air.The biggest issue with this book, however, is her critique of Darwinian evolution.  She states that there is no evidence for macroevolution.  I would not concur with this.  There appears to be quite a bit of evidence that birds descended from dinosaurs.  It's also a fact that paleontology has only been a serious discipline for the past 200yrs or so.  We've learned quite a bit about our past during that time.  That we don't know EVERYTHING should not be construed as evidence of a Creator.Beyond that, there are contradictions on the impetus of life that the author has put forth.  On page 274, she writes: "God is good in being consistent;  God is consistent because he is good.  Therefore, miracles, in the sense of transgressions of natural law are preposterous (i.e.:  impossible)."OK, fine.  However, on page 289 she writes:  "The Creator not only creates;  the Creator perpetually creates, meaning perpetually creates newness.  Addition is creation itself."Well, which is it?  For her paradigm to "work," it would seem to be that the latter must be the case.  Per Houston, she has no problem with the biological "explosion" of the Cambrian Period.  However, per her paradigm, there does not exist a nexus between the Cambrian Period & the 1st humans (who came much later).  That means that God "created" the pre-Cambrian organisms, then "created" the organisms of the Cambrian period, then "created" the dinosaurs and eventually "created" humans sometime > the asteroid that wiped out the dinosaurs hit the Yucatan peninsula.  For myself, I find such assertions dogmatic & very messy (to say the least).  And, as the impetus for life must lie in the supernatural realm (in Houston's view), then the Creator most certainly DID transgress the laws of physics each time He / She let new creatures escape from his cosmic laboratory.On the other hand, if you ask a scientist where the laws of physics came from, he would point back to the Planck epoch, which is 10^(-43) seconds > the Big Bang (or call it what you will).  It was in this instant that the laws of physics & chemistry (as we know & love them) came into being.  After all, astronomers believe Max Planck created the universe (that was a joke!).  Seriously:  if you were to ask a cosmologist "Gee, what came before the Planck epoch, exactly?" then the answer rendered by any astute cosmologist would be as follows:  "I dunno."  One can project a Creator beyond the Planck epoch if one wants to.  However, there's precisely as much evidence for a Creator as there is for a pink polka-dotted unicorn.Here we see the dichotomy between Creationists (be they fundamentalists, Deists or whatever) and scientists.  For Creationists, there always must be something that happened outside the realm of the laws of physics for us to be here.  For the scientist, a lot of highly improbable things happened since the Planck epoch which led to our being here (collectively called the "Anthropic Principle" as coined by Brandon Carter).Houston invokes the "big numbers" argument to argue in favor of the former.  While I used to buy into such arguments, I no longer do.  Here is a thought experiment to understand why my view has changed.Let's say that I were to get in my vehicle & drive from my home state of Michigan to the great state of Texas.  Somewhere in Oklahoma, I run into a rainstorm.  Now, so far, this story is unremarkable.  It's hardly the stuff you would see as a "headline story" on CNN, and ONLY those people who believe that everything is a miracle would describe my encounter with a storm as a miracle.Now, think of this.  Pick a random raindrop that collides with my windshield.  After the fact, let's work out the odds of that INDIVIDUAL raindrop dropping at JUST the right time to hit my windshield.  The odds would be astronomical.  Now, let's measure the odds of my hitting another random raindrop  a few miles later.  Now, let's calculate the odds of BOTH of those raindrops falling on my windshield.  Then, let's say there is a delay because of an accident that lasts 30 minutes.  After starting back up, we calculate the odds of a 3rd random raindrop hitting my windshield 13 minutes & 32 seconds later.  What are the odds that I would leave MI & collide will all three of these random raindrops in OK?  We must be up to one in a quadrillion by now!  And so on.The upshot is this:  our beloved earth has been around for 4 & 1/2 billion yrs.  Stuff happens.  Our universe has been around for nearly 14 billion yrs.  Stuff happens, even highly improbable stuff.  Of course, the Creationist is free to counter that it's simply impossible for me to encounter a rainstorm in Oklahoma ~ that would take care of all of the details in one swoop.This is a thoughtful book, to be sure, but it fell short of converting me to being a Deist.  Even if Houston is right and this mysterious / Deistic Creator exists, then what we're left with is something that resembles the "Prime Mover" of Aristotle or the God of Einstein.  That is to say, an impersonal deity that started the universe & got things rolling......but has been surfing in Tahiti ever since then.  For all I know, the entity exists & is the cause of all things......but I doubt it.

This is a pair of docu-dramas which re-enact two stellar incidents in the history of Rome.  Coincidentally, both occurred during the reign of Titus (son of Vespasian).The first depicts the final day of the doomed city of Pompeii.  Using archeological data as well as the writings of Pliny the younger,  the makers of the DVD walk us through the individual lives of some of the denizens of the city who perished on that fateful day.  To be sure, some conjecture is involved, but the conjecture is based upon the best-available evidence.  Historical figures who are otherwise long-since-forgotten are brought back to life to "tell" us about their last day on the planet (nearly 2,000 yrs in the past).The second docu-drama recounts the inaugural games of the Flavian Ampitheater (nicknamed the Colosseum as it was built on the spot where there was a statue from Nero's Golden House < the Romans razed it).  We get an inside glimpse into the construction of the massive structure as well as the very 1st combatants to perform there from the memoirs of a gladiator who was involved in the building project and was also a man who fought on that first day.  He earned his freedom that day, symbolized by a wooden sword (known as a Rudis) that he received from the emperor Titus.There are also historical accounts from Roman historians who were there.  As the viewer will see, not everything went according to plans that day!This is a must-see DVD for people who have an interest in the life & times of average Romans during the days of Pax Romana.

Sophia is a lawyer from Rio de Janeiro who is residing in London while on  extended business.  She is a beautiful brunette, captivating, mysterious, strong-willed, intelligent, alluring and (above all else) a survivor.  She is an advocate for abused women & children and she lives a life that's not exactly bereft of danger.While in England, her life weaves in & out of the lives of two men:  Ethan & Alistair.  Both men are nearly clones.  They're both handsome, well dressed,  ultra wealthy, neurotic, domineering, controling, prone to jealousy and used to buying whatever it is in life that they want ~ including companionship.The book is overflowing with references to fine wines, fancy cars, high fashion clothing, ornate jewelry, expensive watches and 5 star accommodations.  The incessant references to the above will leave a lot of readers with a sense of awe and saying to themselves "ooooh" and "aaaaah."  That is fine, and it's certainly what was intended.For myself, however, I found the litany of ritzy things to get annoying after awhile.  It seemed to me that the characters in the story were incapable of appreciating the simple things in life, like a sunset over a body of water.  Unless something cost a zillion $$, in their eyes it was useless.  Other readers will be apt to get a different impression, but for me the characters seemed to care for little else beyond $$.Sophia is certainly the most relatable in the book, and the love she has for her daughter is touching.  For me, the best scenes in the entire novel were the interactions between Sophia & her offspring.  During these episodes, I thought to myself "Finally, something human that is not dependent on wealth & capital!"The biggest downside to the book, in my mind, was the characterizations of Ethan & Alistair.  I found both to be unremarkable little boys trapped in the bodies of grown men.  They both reminded me of Mitt Romney:  arrogant, uber rich, pretentious, misanthropic and without so much as a clue about what this thing called being alive is all about.The demographics who will find this book appealing would be of the following 3 camps:1:  People who enjoy Romance novels that have uninhibited sex scenes2:  People who are infatuated with what goes on in high society circles3:  People who are interested in the BDSM lifestyleFor people such as myself, this story is simply too highbrow & hoity toity to be enjoyable.

Growing up in a conservative home, I was always taught that sex / erotica were things that men alone liked.  We were not supposed to like them, but we did anyway.  Women disliked them.  Everything was all about suppressing my inhibitions & desires to have some naughty fun.Thankfully, as a (nowadays) very liberal adult male, it's good to see that these precepts have by & large been napalmed in the 21st century.  The present book is a refreshing taste of feminine erotica which erases these false "rules" entirely.Elizabeth Woodham has written a scintillating set of short stories for eros minded men & women.  My favorite one was the story about the candy store;  it makes sex & chocolate go together as naturally as peanut butter & jelly!  The author has a creative writing style with myriad original erotic images & metaphors.  Some of the passages are downright poet.  {This latter point is only fitting, given that she is from the land of poets: England}My least favorite story was the one about Tarot card reading.  This has less to do with the sexual parts of the tale than it has to do with the fact that astrology is a major intellectual turn-off for me as I've never given a 2nd thought as to the veracity of fortune tellers.All in all, for people who have a real zest for life, this is a book that will be found to have something to offer almost everyone in the aforesaid demographic.  To lust, to life and to feminine erotica!

NORTH & SOUTH is, arguably, one of the finest made-for-TV miniseries ever made.  Its scope is exceptional & it is divided into 3 sections.  Book I is about the antebellum south & the industrial north in the final decades that lead up to the civil war.  Book II details the war itself, from the firing on Fort Sumter to the surrender of the south @ Appomattox courthouse.  Book III centers around the postwar reconstruction of the ravaged south.Book IThe story begins in 1842, when a southerner named Orry Main (portrayed by the late Patrick Swayze) and a Yankee named George Hazard (James Read) become fast friends @ West Point.  While their views on slavery are different, they maintain a tight bond and serve together in battle during the war against Mexico. Most importantly, both men are likable and they're men who possess integrity & honor.  The final scene of Book I is one of the most powerful scenes I've ever viewed.  Orry travels south from Pennsylvania to serve with the confederacy, leaving his friend George behind.  His journey is symbolic as well as literal.The cast of the production is impeccable, and it was my 1st introduction to a young Patrick Swayze.  I still recall my initial reaction to him back in the mid-80s:  "Wow, a guy who looks like he just stepped out of the pages of GQ who has charisma & bona-fide acting skills!"  In watching N & S via the box set, it didn't take me long to recall to mind why I had a huge crush on Genie Francis way-back-when.  She epitomizes the sweet southern belle.  It appears Jonathan Frakes & I share the same taste in women as he ended up marrying her after meeting her on the set of N & S!The soundtrack, courtesy of Bill Conti, is top notch & memorable.  The wardrobe is elaborate & elegant, as it should be for a story such as this.  The actresses get to show off the ostentatious dresses that American women wore in the 19th century.  Obviously pragmatism wasn't on the minds of women back then!Book IIThe second book covers the civil war itself.  Remarkably, the Hazard & Main families remain woven together even in the midst of the war.  Aside from the thrust of the story, we observe unfortunate issues which plague this country in conflicts as recent as the wars in Afghanistan & Iraq:  soldiers who suffer from post traumatic stress syndrome, the horrific wounds suffered in battle, conterfeit parts being sent to the war machine, and good old-fashioned war profiteering.  No matter how much the technology & mechanisms of war change, these things always tend to stay the same.On the upside, it is heartwarming to see how Orry & George both married women who mirror each other.  Their wives are both kind hearted, beautiful and good Samaritan types.  They are similar in spirit just as Orry & George are similar in how they're both men of noble character.Book IIIUnfortunately, I found Book III to be rather half-baked.  For starters, it disinters some holes in the plot as opposed to being a continuation of Book II.  Also, there were some cast changes between Book I & Book II and they were seamless.  In fact, plugging in Parker Stevenson as Billy Hazard was a genuine upgrade!  As for the cast changes in Book III, these were (in my opinion) a significant downgrade.Most importantly, the storyline of Book III meanders a bit & paints with too wide a brush.  In fact, one could call Book III "East & West" as it delves into postwar issues such as pioneers / western expansion and the Indian wars.  To be sure, these were pivotal topics in this country's history, but it's for that reason that they deserve to have their own movies & books made/written about them.Nevertheless, the aspects of Part III which did detail the south were on the $$.  Part III portrayed how white southerners tried to keep black people in bondage (even though they were no longer slaves) as well as the latter's attempts to break out of lives of servitude.  It also focuses on the rise of the abysmal intolerant cult known as the Ku Klux Klan.All in all, this box set is a can't miss for civil war enthusiasts.  For persons who have even a passing curiosity about the history of this country, N & S is highly recommended.  The war-between-the-states was the single darkest chapter in the history of the United States.  It was also perhaps the single most important chapter;  its effects are still being felt to the present day.

Savannah Grace is a lovely young Canadian lass who pieced together Sihpromatum from the journals of her travels to Hong Kong, China & Mongolia.  Her journey was something that "just happened" when her mother had the outlandish idea of traveling the world.  And, with that, mom, Savannah, her sister Bree & her brother Ammon hopped on an airplane to Hong Kong to begin their odyssey.Having been to Hong Kong & China myself while I was in the Navy, this book was of particular interest to me.  I got to see a great deal of Hong Kong over several visits, but only saw the interior of Shanghai when it came to mainland China.  Savannah & company went all through the country & saw a great deal more of Chinese locales & culture than I had a chance to see.  Still, her observations of just how many modern day conveniences that are missing in China (conveniences that we westerners take for granted) caused me to reminisce about my brief sojourn in Shanghai.One thing that this book is NOT would be a story of a relative of, say, Mitt Romney or Paris Hilton.  I would imagine such a book being a shallow comparison of the amenities & buffet tables of 5 Star hotels across the globe.  Readers who seek a book such as that may as well look elsewhere as that's not what this book is about.Rather, to say that the family "roughs" it would be quite an understatement.  What is fascinating is that the family is run-of-the-mill Middle Class in stature;  they are no where near wealthy.  They frequently live on just a couple of bucks a day & their location (which changes daily) dictates where they eat & sleep.  As such, the book is filled with both adventures & misadventures, including the family being stranded out in the middle of the Gobi desert ~ one of the most desolate places on the planet.Due to the fact that the family is unafraid of getting "down & dirty," the reader is given an unvarnished look at the locales, landscapes & denizens of China & Mongolia.  To that end, if there were ever such a thing as a teenage girl version of the historian Herodotus, this book would exemplify it in the incarnation of the author.  The awe & wonder in which Savannah details to us the Great Wall of China, various Buddist monastaries and the austere beauty of Mongolia brings to mind the way Herodotus marveled @ the Great Pyramids in The Histories, Revised (Penguin Classics).So, if you're looking for a sincere book centered on an unexpected detour that a young woman & her family  chose to undertake, then this is a book that is well worth reading.  It is gritty, charming & downright comical in places.  So, give this book a read & fall under Savannah's spell!

Okay...I know the rules, authors shouldn't review other authors, but seriously...I read waaaay more than I write. Sometimes, you just have to. In this case, I've been a rabid fan of the Violet series since the first volume. I like this character so much I named a character in my books after her, so yeah, huge fan.And here we are, at the end of the series. I confess, my greedy hands were itching for this to come out, but at the same time, I dreaded it because I knew it was going to be the end of the series. I just couldn't bear not having more of it. Still, as soon as that pretty golden fingerprint showed up on my Kindle, I was all over it.What a satisfying and truly emotional conclusion! I can't say much because it would be total spoiler territory and I don't want the author to hate me, but the way it ended was really the only proper way for it to end. This volume opens up into incredible character dialog and action. They are genuine and totally alive on the page. Absolutely beautiful.And I very much enjoyed the development of the two characters we were introduced to in the previous volume into fully realized and vibrant members of Team Violet. What I'd really like is to get this whole series on audiobook...and yes, that's a hint to the author.

I got this because I've got a big book event coming up and I needed to make 750 magnet cards for the book to go into bags. Pricing all over the net, this lot was the best deal. Not just in price, but also in shipping. Magnets are heavy! I got them right one time, but the box was a little worse for wear and ripped up. That's not entirely unexpected given that it looks relatively small yet it horrendously heavy. Heavy is a good thing when it comes to magents for cards.Like others have said on other lots, putting your cards on the magnet takes practice to get right, but once you do, working with these was a breeze. They came on sheets that snapped apart easily and with smooth edges, and the backing paper came right off. The magnets are the good, thick kind and the adhesive is super strong.Out of the lot, I did have a couple of sheets that seemed to be cut slightly wrong, making one side of the sheet (and three cards on those) slightly smaller.But out of two thousand cards, that's not bad at all. Comes as 100 sheets with 20 cards per sheet.

This stuff is amazing...rich flavors and easy to use.I'm no chef, but I do like to make food that tastes good without a bunch of extra gunk I can't pronounce in it. I got this based on recommendations and have already used it three times. In love!In a spicy thai chicken soup (basically fancy ramen) adapted from a Blue Apron recipe, a tablespoon of this brings it into heavenly territory. Making a sauce with it is super easy, ditto with standard gravy. You don't have to be a fancy mc-fancy pants to use this wonderful glace with excellent results. Don't be intimidated, just go for it.
Cute little game. Requires friends and really pushes sales though.
Fun little game
Just started, but it seems like a fun little time wasted.
There were a few rough edges on some of these, but overall, nice and sturdy.
I really love this case...but I did add a velcro wrap around it for when I brought it places for a touch of extra security.
Only time I've ever had mouse elbow and I got it a month after getting this mouse. Had to replace it since I've just got the one right arm.

If you've not used this, you're missing out. I love it! I've got a couple of herniated disks that I used to get traction and physical therapy for. Once I got a little better, I was sent home with other exercises and this as a recommendation. It works like a champ! If you've got a lower back issue, put this on your phone and show the picture to your doc. It might be just right for you, too. It's also great for overall stretching and this little gadget is now quite popular at my house.

Finding infinity charms is shockingly difficult! I can't understand it. You can get charms for almost everything...except infinity. Anyway, I need these for book charms and these were some of the few I could actually find, so I took a chance. I like them! They work great for the book charm bookmarks.

Since I went full time as an author, I did not learn my lesson in terms of pacing myself. I gave myself a major case of carpel and mouse elbow by writing two books in two months. (Yeah, not smart, I know.) The brace I got from the doctor was a huge pain and terribly uncomfortable, so I took a chance on this one and I love it. I sort of wish they came in different colors because the dove gray of this one will show dirt around the palm quickly. It's easy to clean, though, and dries quick.I need a few more. And please, make them in cool colors like red, blue and green. Even purple!

I got this for making author swag. All those tiny book charms and such were straining my eyes to see, so I figured this might help. It's wonderful! The two LEDs are nice and bright and the magnifier is just right for me. The lamp isn't too huge, the neck flexes really well and stays where you flex it. Excellent purchase for the price!
This stuff is like iron...seriously. White dries a very bright white, so if you're looking for clear, this doesn't dry that way. Sticks fast, so be ready with your pieces right away.

I use this to punch out one-inch images to put in bottle cap magnets. It works splendidly on the really thick glossy photo paper and 65 pound card stock, but it leaves a tag on any thin paper. So, this is more heavy duty. The cut is nice and clean, too.

Oh, these are strong ones. I was really torn on which magnets to buy after reading such wildly varying reviews, so I opted for these. They cost more but they are super strong and consistent in manufacture. Used them to back some Bottle Cap Magnets and they work like a charm. Storing them once the caps are all put together was a challenge because the magnets were so strong. The mass turned into something of an abstract sculpture, but that's a good thing.

Love, love, love these! I'm making magnets with these that have an image from one of my books inside, sealed and shined with DuraGloss and then backed by a magnet. Super fun to do and these were very consistent in quality. Not all scratched up, none of them bent. Hope they keep these in stock!

NOTE: This seems to vary in price a whole bunch. When I bought it, it was at a good price, not much higher than the 12 ounce multi-packs. Mine was fresh, very pliable and just what I needed since I mix a lot of my own colors.

I've been experimenting in the territory of making "author swag", which is just stuff for reader giveaways and such. Bookcharms, magnets and all of that stuff. I tried *so* many different finishes that I began to think I just couldn't do that sort of crafty stuff. Then I took a chance on this one and have already ordered another bottle because I love it.Unlike the diamond coat or any of those others, this is thinner so you have more control. And *no* bubbles! Instead of one huge thick glob of the thick stuff and hoping no more bubbles appear in the middle of drying, I do several thin coats of this stuff and never have a bubble at all.

This definitely has a much lighter scent than the other cocoa butter I buy (which I love) that isn't deodorized. That said, there is *some* cocoa scent to it. It's very easily worked and fits in perfectly with the lotions and creams I make at home for family use. Love this stuff. For those that wonder, this came in a one pound plastic tub with a screw on lid and a tamper seal inside the lid.

It's a scale, not much more to say about it, but I do like it immensely. I suppose my only issue is that when measuring very small quantities, you need to be sure you tare the scale with some weight on it and then make sure you put whatever you're measuring as close to the center as possible.That said, it cleans up well, has bright lights, is super easy to use and is kid friendly on top of that.

I can't see that it did anything at all. I finally wound up making my own and that finally did the trick. This was too greasy feeling, yet also not very absorbant and then didn't stay long once it did.

I use this for making lotions and creams and it's a delight. It does have the strong cocoa smell, but once blended with other oils and all of that, the smell is faint and mild. Here's a hint: if you scent your finished product with just a touch of orange essential oil, it smells like old-fashioned chocolates (those kind with oranges inside). It's not overpowering but it sure does make it easier to get a kid with dry skin to put on their lotion. :)

I got this to replace an ultrasonic and a heated one and it's incredible. It is a bit noisy on high, but it doesn't stay on high after it reaches your set humidity. Also, you can force it to stay on low, which is whisper quiet, as well. None of that wet mist on the floor like in ultrasonics. This one really spreads the moisture around in the air. Fantastic. I only wish it had an auto shut-off when it's empty.
I used this for making my own lotions and creams and I have to say, I love this one. Product was clean, pure and wonderful to use. You should feel it in a good winter body cream. Like heaven!
I use this in formulating my own lotion and it is tops! Measures very true with consistent results every time. Can't beat it!

Works awesome at cleaning my humidifiers (the kind that heat the water). I'd been struggling with vinegar and this stuff works like a champ. Mix some up with water, leave it to set on the element (with power off) for half an hour then clean all the minerals right off. Awesome!

These were not like the springy sort of feeling bookmark blanks that you get other places. These have zero give. A good many came severely bent, so when I tried to flex one gently back a bit straight, it broke apart. No kidding. A few of them came already broken at the eye, so they can't be used to fashion bookmarks. They are also quite thick. Overall, there were only 3 out of two orders of them that were both straight enough for use and unbroken. I went back to the regular steel blanks. They cost more, but at least they come usable.

I absolutely love this series! I'm a huge anti-fan of putting spoilers of any kind in reviews, but suffice it to say that we get to tag along with Violet and Thomas as they reap the rewards from book one and then, boom...the fun really starts.The characters in this series are wonderfully conveyed and the atmosphere sucks the reader right in. It's one of my favorite serials ever. So...write faster!

Tom Carver is a man still looking for love, for that last bit of his life that is missing. One day, during a phone call hears the voice that makes it all click home. Obsession and longing turns to a deep and abiding love, even though he's never even seen her face.When Eve and Tom finally do meet, sparks fly and the world turns upside down. Facing danger and finding each other, we get to follow along their exciting adventure.Logan struck a perfect chord in this story. It's longer than the estimated page count would suggest and really made up the perfect hour of reading. Science fiction, a bit of fire between two characters and a surprising amount of growth for our characters happens for a short (but not really short) story.Well worth the read and I want more of these two!

Don't believe all the hype. Like every other "new/old" thing out there that is rediscovered to be the best thing ever, argan oil has been purported to be able to do many miraculous things. I don't believe that and didn't base my purchase on that type of hype. What I did buy it for is for what it is supposed to do..and for that, this particular brand is absolute tops!Argan oil, which is simply the oil of the nut of the argan tree, is a lot like olive oil in many ways and the less high quality argan oils are more like olive oil than the higher quality ones. Where the differences are at between a good high quality argan and a lesser argan is in the very things that make argan superior to olive for the skin and hair.Cold pressed organic oil like this has a more delicate scent, greater absorbability, is a little thinner and works for a whole lot longer. If you've had an experience with argan oil where you looked at yourself and thought you would have done better to just rub cooking oil on yourself then you likely got some that was heated when pressed or came from inferior fruits.This particular Argan oil is just that...pure Argan oil with nothing in it. No fragrance. No additives. Nada. So it has a light, slightly nutty smell that I find heavenly.Where this oil really shows its benefits is in aging skin or very dry skin. It takes about 6 drops to moisturize my entire lower leg. Face...2 drops. Hair treatment..2 drops. Whole body, about 1 dropper full. It soaks in very fast and leaves a very slight sheen on the skin that isn't an oily one, but rather a glowy one. It lasts beyond a day. Even after a day, including showering, you can skip it if you're in a hurry and not get dry skin.I use it every day on my legs and arms. Every few days I do the whole body. Once a week I use it on my face after a facial and in my hair once a week to keep it sleek. If you're a teen with unruly skin prone to acne and oily hair then I would test it first to be sure it is okay with your skin and hair. For everyone else, it is a delight and highly recommended.

I'm in my mid 40s...okay, 46...and I've been stepping up my game so I don't look it. This means a bit more maintenance but also making smarter choices on how the skin is treated. It needs things but it starts to need different things as it ages in order to look good and keep that glow.My travels took me to Turkey where I experienced real Turkish baths. It was awesome, yes, but it's also a bit strange for a westerner. The two little pot bellied men that did the washing...yes, men...in one of the baths used a glove like this and the weirdest thing happened. Your skin just comes off. At first I freaked but they said it was okay. The ladies used Moroccan soap on us first and then afterward, other ladies rubbed us down with argan oil.I was still a little bit weirded out by the time I left after the first Turkish bath but then I saw my skin when I went outside. It was glowing and soft and like a brand new baby except shinier. Amazing. I went to more of them but never had that same level of exfoliation because it was just maintaining it rather than starting from scratch.It turns out that this glove does a type of exfoliation we just don't do often in the west and that was all the semi-detached and dying skin cells still stuck to other live skin. Gross.Anyway, in my quest to recreate that skin, I've gone through a bunch of products and several less than satisfactory gloves. This is the best glove of them all. Hands down.For best results use ELMA&SANA® Moroccan Black Soap eucalyptus-9oz(250gr) this before hand and let your skin steam in the shower so it will release easier when you use the glove. Afterwards, use ELMA&SANA Golden Argan Oil ® 100 Cold Pressed Virgin Organic Certified By Ecocert -1oz(30ml) to add more glow and give the skin something good to drink in. The instructions are included. Follow it and you'll should have remarkable results.Caveat: If you are a good exfoliator of your skin, then you might not have the same crazy shedding others report, but that is good. It means you were doing a good job even before. You'll still see some though. You're not gross. It's supposed to happen.

Lately I've been taking greater care of my skin. I'm 46 and don't look it and don't intend to, so that means more maintenance. During my travels I went to Turkey and there had real Turkish baths. Out of all the things I did there the glow and softness of my skin after those is the thing I remember most, so I decided to figure out how that happened and begin replicating it if possible. And no, I do not work for these people nor have I received anything for this review. I just really like their stuff.So, my search began.In the end, I did find exactly the right things to do it and it does, in fact, still make the skin glow like I rolled in shimmer powder and soft like the proverbial baby bottom. One key element is true Moroccan black soap. And this is the real thing.For best possible results, combine using this with Chaacoca Moroccan Exfoliating Mitt, or with a similar product. Then finish it off with ELMA&SANA Golden Argan Oil ® 100 Cold Pressed Virgin Organic Certified By Ecocert -1oz(30ml) or another argan oil of your choice.But what is this Moroccan soap stuff, you might ask? The bottom line is that it is a combination of olive oils and solid olive pastes combined in a special way to create a cleansing and moisturing hard gel. Most include essential oils of one sort or another to create their own signature scent or whatnot, but mostly what you want is one with minimal additives. This version has a light helping of Eucalyptus Oil in it, which is very nice and complements the naturally nutty smell of it.To use this, you need only a smidgeon. I take a blob about the size of a coin and then divide it in half and press one half into each palm and then rub it in. That is enough for a whole body if you're body is fairly regular sized. Turn the shower off while you do that and let it soak in while you condition your hair or something.Rinse it off and then use the glove to exfoliate, rinse and get out. While you're skin is still warm, rub in argan oil and you're done. It works and it works well.I don't necessarily recommend this for teens who still have unruly skin that secretes too much oil unless they are cautious and test it first. It is an oil based soap and while it moisturizes well, I can't attest to what it will do to very oily or acne prone skin.For anyone outside that, very highly recommended for moisturizing, cleansing and overall experience.

I purchased this and another product, Fake Bake Fair Lotion, 6-Ounce, intending to try both and see which one worked best but I liked the Nature's Gate so well I've put off trying the other one.I have fair...as in so white it is like a dead fish belly...skin. I only need this for my legs so I can wear skirts and shorts without being scary. I have the naturally fair undertones of pink and blue. I *can* tan, but after spending the 80s as brown as a walnut, I do try to avoid naturally tanning now.This lotion isn't meant to make you brown, only to add some natural looking sun inspired color. If you are looking for more than that, then you'll be best served with one of the more aggressive products.This looks just like regular lotion in the bottle and smells like a pretty standard lotion too. You simply rub it in like regular lotion and then wait until it is fully soaked in. Dress like normal and within 24 hours you'll see a hint of color.In reality, you'll want to put regular lotion on your hands first so the skin on your hands won't soak up this lotion. Then when you put on the Glow lotion, be more careful than you otherwise would to get a pretty even coat but go lightly over the knees and ankles, since those areas tend to soak up more lotion in general and therefore, will get darker. Then sit around for about 20 minutes just to be sure you're all absorbed and dress. I like to do this after work so I can just wear my loungewear and not risk nice clothing, though I have seen no proof that it comes off on clothes at all.Right after application, wash your hands vigorously and thoroughly and use a washcloth or something rough.As to results, I noticed a light tan by the next morning after first usage. That's about 16 hours of time. I used it again that night and it was darker the next day. I did that again for 2 more days and on the 5th day I woke to the dreaded color ORANGE.That wore off after a couple of days and I was back to glow.The lesson is that you won't need to use this for many days to get the max it will give to a very fair skinned person. More after that point is not better.Trial and error has shown me that I need to apply it every third day after I reach peak in order to mostly maintain the color. After a couple of weeks I'll go two days in a row to get the color back up to peak, and then back to every third day.Given how fast it works, this bottle will last a long time.Highly recommended for people who will not naturally tan, either because they want to preserve their skin or because they burn and who embrace their fairness but want enough color to blend in with the world. Not recommended for people with very yellow undertones in their skin because they will likely turn orange faster. Not recommended for people who are super fair but want to get a fake dark tan.

For the past 20 years or more, I've been getting my hands moisturized and when dunked in hot wax to make it absorb more. It's a great way to overcome the many damaging things we do to the skin of our hands. BUT, over the last few years I've become increasingly sensitive to the wax and now I really can't use it at all. Not to mention that it isn't very environmentally friendly to just keep tossing wads of petroleum derived wax in the trash every week.Mitts were recommended to me and I spent a good amount of time researching them. They have some that are more meant for longer heat therapy, such as with arthritis, but I wanted something that I could keep very clean since I would be using it with lotion.I selected these and they did arrive quickly and well packed. There was no instruction packet with it, which I found odd, but they are pretty self explanatory. There are three heat settings as well as an off setting and that is pretty much it.The lowest setting was more than enough for me. I just globbed on a bunch of lotion, put my hands in baggies and then stuck them in the mitts for 15 minutes. When I'm done I rub in the remaining lotion or wipe it off and voila, very soft and smooth hands.The mitts are NOT big enough to do most feet, but they weren't meant to, I don't think. Those are usually foot shaped. If I could ask for anything, it would be that the pockets were large enough for that.Highly recommended as a better, and far less messy, replacement for the hot wax moisturing treatment for hands.

In my review for this authors other book, Retro Makeup: Techniques for Applying the Vintage Look, I went into some detail as to why I went this direction as a 46 year old woman. Unlike many faithful retro-lovers, I wasn't looking to duplicate styles. Instead I wanted to try to find a new look for myself that didn't just include trying to look unobtrusive in order to disguise flegling lines or other effects of aging.One's hair helps define their face. Bottom line. You can put on a perfectly neat Mad Men face, but if your hair doesn't reflect that intention, you'll just look strange. So, for me, this book was a necessity.I read it cover to cover and discovered a great many things about hair that I simply didn't know before. Things that make you say, Huh. I also discovered that my astonishing array of expensive hair goos were entirely wrong. And finally, I discovered that these styles are surprisingly easy to pull off, even for a total amateur, if you have patience.Since I wasn't looking for a completely authentic retro style but rather an impression or accent to a specific clean look, I needed to combine some styles and enhance or dampen some elements to fit in and look good without being obvious. Again, just one practice session and I had a winner.The results of this hair and makeup were surprising and involved many enounters while shopping that were pleasant or embarrassing or both. I loved it.The book is organized so that it isn't just a linear progression of a style and then how to do it, it gives opening chapters that show the tools and how to use them in the context of the book. It also gives a good illustration of things like a basic set and what it means to be on or off angle, etc. Super informative while entertaining. Again, just from a brief reading I was able to pull off one of the more complicated styles with minimal tools (though you will need the right ones) and a bit of patience.Highly recommended for any age. Very customizable for those trying to define or redefine their own personal style. Also nice for anyone who wants to really go authentically retro and look perfectly done.

I'm no spring chicken. The freedom to be retro passed me by when my age might have made it more appropriate, but there were no internet sellers of "anything and everything" in the 80s. Full disclosure: I'm 46.But I'm not dead yet! And for those in their 40s or whatever age that might be in the same boat I was, read on.At some point in life you start to fix your hair and face in the morning with a sort of resigned outlook. For me, it was doing things as unobtrusively as possible so that age wasn't enhanced. But doing it to actually look worthy of a second look, well, that was in the past, I figured. I had my day in the sun, so to speak. But I wasn't at all happy with it. I decided to start exploring my options and find what might work for me.Enter this book and the hair book (Vintage Hairstyling: Retro Styles with Step-by-Step Techniques)by the same author as well as a few well respected retro clothing lines. I've always liked the retro look but it is often used with a heavy hand that simply wouldn't look right on a woman in her mid-40s. At the same time, watch any old movie and note how elegant a woman in her 40s can appear...sometimes even better than the younger ones. Somehow I needed to find that middle ground.I got this book and the matching hair one and read it cover to cover. I went through my make up cabinet (and who doesn't have buckets of the stuff) and tossed out things that didn't make the grade and went shopping.With a little trial and error and just two practice runs, I was able to come up with a face I couldn't believe was me. And it didn't look like I walked out of the past or didn't belong in my skin or anything.This book does go into great and pictoral detail on how to get the faces of many eras and styles, yes. But it also shows you the hows and whys and "what fors" of doing things certain ways. That gives the reader remarkable freedom to customize for exactly the right look for their age and personal style.I loved this book so much that I bought another copy of it and the hair book to give as a gift to someone else. That alone should tell you how high my recommendation is for this book.Now, to the results. What happened that makes me so sure this worked? I'm not going to lie, I enjoyed a lot of attention in my youth but that tapered away as time went on and I had simply forgotten what that was like. I got reminded.My first test in public, while shopping, resulted in some surprising and occasionally embarrassing encounters. The woman who said, much too loudly, from another line that I was so pretty and asked what ethnicity I was was a little embarassing but the random males who kept wanting to lift things for me was nice, if strange.Am I saying that this book will magically make you attract random strangers who will want to lift your gallons of milk for you? No, but it does happen. If you have a pretty good base in your features and are willing to take the time, you can remake yourself so that all that you have that is good is shown to best effect and in a way that speaks "classic" beauty.For women like me who have reached that point where they aren't quite sure what to do with their faces now that they've reached that in between time where they aren't old but have to be careful of fledgling lines and make-up, then this is an excellent tool. Combine with the hair book and you'll have a whole new look to rock.

I really wanted to like this book. It was one of those suggestions that scroll across when you buy something related in your kindle and I didn't read the reviews first. I should have then I wouldn't be struggling to write this review. And I am struggling here because I love Indie fiction and don't want to dampen anyone's fire to write but I really do feel like this is a bad book.Another review expressed some of what I found at length but I also found those significant flaws to be show stoppers and I have to express my own views.Facts are Facts: In fiction the world can be played with in creative ways but there are Rubicons that shouldn't be crossed except in very special circumstances.-In genetics, (and I hit another author on this pretty hard so it is a problem other Indie authors share), there are rules and the rules are almost immutable. If you tweak X you will get Y...you will not get Z, A, B or D. You will always get Y when you tweak X and only X. If you remove something, there will be consequences. Extras are not good. And so on and so forth. Too many people who are potential readers are well versed in genetics nowadays to try to pull fast ones with the 'knowns' of the science.-Antibiotics don't cause inherited immune system flatlining. Period. While I understand what the author was perhaps trying to say, the way she expressed it was contrary to science. It is common for people to say things that imply our use of antibacterials and antibiotics are making us weak, that isn't quite the same as saying people are being born without immune systems from one too many Z-Pacs being prescribed to their parents. A little research is needed before writing.-Leaders are not defined by a single rung on the ladder that is our DNA. Even if the tendency toward behavior associated with leadership potential could be ever linked to any DNA, it would probably be a cluster and it would be a tendency and not an ID card defining the person. Most often, great leaders have offspring which are troubled and far less talented in the leadership arena. If it were genetic, then version 2.0 should inherit it at least 50% of the time. And defining a cluster that does anything is very, very difficult because of the quadrillions of possible combinations that can be made if our entire DNA strand is taken into account.-Exposure as a way to build immunity via heridity? Listen, if they can find and do all that they are purported to be doing with DNA then they can tell who has an immune system or not at birth rather than wasting resources for 8 years and then letting them suffer in absolute agony getting disease after disease. That's just stupid.Aside from the fact problem, there is the writing style. It is simplistic to the point of madness and makes many of the characters seem like they are reading description cards from some text based game from the 1980s. The characters are also not consistent within themselves, becoming something different at the drop of the hat. I actually thought perhaps the author had mixed up the personalities of Neklema and Kim for a bit it was so drastic.And let's not forget the logic. There is none. The motivations for the various actions make no sense no matter how much suspension of disbelief the reader engages in. It's just wasteful and stupid and no one would do it. Why on earth would anyone invest like whole groups of people did in terms of time, resources and their own lives when they knew it was stupid to do so, had no purpose and wasn't a cause they believed in. They wouldn't.I hate giving bad reviews. I really, truly do. But the author in this case simply needs to pull the book entirely. Pull it, do a good bit of research and then re-write it. There are core elements that can be re-used in a new version.

Before I review the story I must address the editing remarked on in other reviews. Perhaps the author has already done some of it and reloaded the edited version because I didn't see the same error rate that some others reported. What it does look like is that there was some discontinuity in the format from the original to the Kindle processing. It took away a half star from my review.Hickory is our main character and is just a youngster really. He goes to school, hangs out with his friends and such a person is of limited interest to us adult readers as a general rule. So what made Hickory such fun to read? His world and the way he lives in it, of course!In the world Hickory lives in, a long distant future version of our own, things are not at all what most of us hope the future world of our descendants will be like. Instead of glittering cities in the sky with a perfect natural world below (or whatever we might wish for) the world is a primitive place, devoid of technology and actively seeking *not* to learn what we once took for granted. The only link they really have from the city of Porta to the long past is a single half burned journal written by a man who angrily blamed technology for the straits he found himself in at the end of the world.Awesome.Hickory, however, is just like his father in some ways. Intensely curious, not nearly respectful enough of the rules against digging for the past and with a thirst to connect with the world around him no matter how strange. This can only lead to trouble...or maybe just change...or maybe troubling changes. Actually, it is all three.I really enjoyed this book and was entranced by the world the author constructed so painstakingly for us. In some ways it reminded me of the first Harry Potter books, before each volume became a way to churn out another 50 million bucks, when it was a charming tale full of dark and light elements and almost like a long tale spun for the longest bedtime story in history. It has that same flavor, so to speak, and that same knack for inserting surprising new elements that pop up and tweak the story just so.I'm loathe to delve too deeply in many of the elements I liked best because it gives away some of those tweaks and it would diminish the pleasure of future readers. So I'll touch on those elements lightly. Mystical elements do appear in the story such as ghosts, even more in the next book, but not in a way that I could entirely be sure were mystical. Technology advanced enough from a viewer's perspective is often labeled magic and I wasn't sure we weren't being led down this road. I won't reveal that, but I will say that the ghost added a wonderful element to the story that is only enhanced further in the next book and leads to some interesting revelations.Hickory and his interactions with those around him are not quite those of a typical younger teen so we adults reading it aren't completely alienated but we are at times somewhat distant from the adult actions that might be more approachable to us. It is a refreshing point of view however and will bring more than one smile to parents of teens while reading.I've read the follow on and yes, while I do think it is not perfectly edited, it is a great story and well worth the reading. It's got huge potential as far as the world building and characters go and I hope the author will continue the series and expand it.

If one threw an infinity of slips of paper, each slip with one interesting concept to write about on it and then picked out a few and decided to write about those random picks, I doubt they could have come up with a more unlikely set of circumstances than this one. That said, this combo works together in such a way that I simply couldn't stop reading until the very end and I wanted more. Lucky for me the sequels were out already so I could have more.Chris and Livvy are new partners in a special detective squad that investigates with a free hand the crimes associated with neural enhancement and artificially increased longevity. Chris is an old hand at this, having spent 75 years in the business using his own legally enhanced longevity to stay young. Livvy, a fresh faced newbie to the team with extralegal enhancements and more than a half century of life under her belt, isn't the partner he would have chosen for himself. Add a dog with a few neural tweaks of his own and you have a fascinating crime fighting trio.The story revolves around the particular problems of having a legal system that governs the use of enhancing longevity. There are rules and the rules are both unbendable and entirely necessary. But when the laws put limits on what could easily provide true immortality, there will be lawbreakers. This is what Chris, Livvy and now Louie, fight each day. In this case, the crime is particularly heinous and the stakes high.This story is a non-stop ride yet it does it without skipping the depth it needs or by glossing over the details of this world the author created. It is simply well done and it resonates with the reader in two ways: as a reader rooting for the protagonist and as a reader who might be equally tempted by the chance at immortality. It's a nice balance and thoroughly enjoyable.Oh, and Louie the dog is totally adorably written. I love a well crafted canine character.Recommended for those who like general science fiction, near future dystopic/utopic fiction or fast paced adventure mysteries with a twist.

Seeing the end of the Wooliverse looming from the point of Hugh Howey's pen (or keyboard), I did what most of the other fans from the beginning have done: seek more! Initially leery of fanfic because it can butcher the original world, I have been absolutely astounded at the amazing quality of the work available. Greatfall is, in my opinion, the pinnacle of those offerings to date. I'm hooked and I like it.Greatfall is the first part of the story of a Silo gone by the wayside. One of the mysterious dark Silo's, it is assumed to be dead. It's a valid assumption but eventually the powers that remain decide to send someone to verify it and find what they can find. After all, knowing why a Silo goes dark might help them avoid the same happening to another Silo.Enter Silo 23. It isn't dark meaning an absence of light. It is Dark as in deeply disturbed. I don't want to give spoilers because the story absolutely deserves to unroll as the author intended without me giving you all the punchline. That said, one has to say something, right? In this case, it is a given that there is no story if the Silo is dead so you know it's not. It's also a given that whatever and whoever remains in the Silo has been disconnected from that which gave it structure and kept it on a course for generations. What kind of culture might arise from the ashes of the twisted world without sunlight that is the Silo? You get to find out in this story.Isaac, a touching character who is drawn deeply into the doings of adults very suddenly and without expecting to, is the primary character. He undergoes a right of passage like every other child his age but never expects to survive it, as many before him have not. At best, he expects to live a life of no particular renown if he does survive. But Silo 23 may have something else entirely in mind for him and his journey is one any Wool/Shift fan will want to ride along on.Highly recommended for any fan of the Wool/Shift series by Hugh Howey. Not really recommended for those who aren't familiar with it because the basic premises in the book won't make sense. If that is you, then immediately search for "Wool" and put this one on your wishlist. Believe me, you'll want it later.Oh, and to the author, HURRY UP and WRITE!

As a huge fan of Hugh Howey and an early reader of the magic that is the Wool Universe (yes, I do have a T-shirt!), I was a little hesitant to delve into the fan fiction that began cropping up for fear of it skewing the near perfect world as yet created by the original author. But with the end coming soon in the Hugh Howey offerings, I decided to give it a go. So far, I certainly haven't regretted it and this is a fine addition to the Wooliverse.Karma, as she is known now, isn't really named Karma at all. But then again, we know from Hugh's books that things certainly are never what they seem in the worlds of Silo. Karma finds herself pregnant and then remembering, much like another pivotal character in Hugh's work starts to remember. Of course there are consequences to remembering and Karma finds herself wondering who she can trust and how much she can trust them. She's stronger than she seems (particularly when reading about her as a side character in Hugh's stories) and we get the first installment of how it has all played out from her point of view.Sorry, so very sorry, to be cryptic like that but if I say even just one word more I'll ruin it for any Wool fan who has read all the books. You'll figure out who it is. So, if you're a Wool reader take this advice: Buy it, read it, fill in a gap you know has been missing and be happy you did so.Excellent first part of the tale that is exceptionally well written and flows very nicely. The writing style is different from Hugh's which is actually a good thing. It makes this character, one that didn't get full treatment in any Wool/Shift book, really come to life and in her own way. It works.I suppose there are one or two questions that I have lingering, which is pretty standard for any Wool/Shift book, but I remain hopeful that this is addressed in later installments. Primarily, if the water (and we all know what they did to the water) is possibly dangerous for the unborn, then wouldn't there be problems with babies and children? That tends to be a fairly common trend with medicine and I would have expected it to be particularly true given the *type* of treatment included in the water. Also, why weren't pregnant people watched more closely or did this one occur so quickly that they simply didn't know the effects were as complete as they were?Regardless, I really enjoyed this and was sad to see it end. I'll be keeping my eyes peeled for the next installment, you can be sure of that. Highly recommended for fans and previous readers of Hugh Howey's Wool/Shift series but not for those not already familiar with that series.

When I hit the click to get this book, I did it because it was on a free day for the book. I admit it. I'm in a different sort of reading groove right now and this genre wasn't what I was looking for. I'm so very glad I clicked.I read this in two marathon sessions and did almost nothing else so I could keep reading. It was that good.Imhotep is a figure of mystery in history. His tomb has never been found and he excelled at some many different fields he is almost bigger than life. He also made huge leaps in knowledge, at least based on his work that appears to be true, and so the mystery around him is even deeper. This novel gives us a wonderfully imaginative romp through time to find him.Tim, our main protagonist, is a man at the nadir of his life. He has suffered a senseless and devastating loss and is now alone in Egypt carrying out the trip he was supposed to take with his beloved. He sees something odd while visiting a tomb and finds himself in the distant past along with two other modern age people. The adventure that ensues forms the basis for our time and secures the rise of the great civilization of Ancient Egypt.The amount of research the author must have done for this book is staggering. Every single aspect, from the food to the climate to the way in which the people are portrayed is incredibly detailed and, I believe, astonishing in accuracy. Based on all that one can read or discern from historians and anthropologists and archaeologists has been wonderfully distilled into a fast moving and intelligent story.The cast of characters is large but each is very unique and easy to tell apart. Despite Tim being our central character, it is another character...let's call him Apy...who really steals the heart.Super enjoyable and recommended for those who like a mix of alternate history type science fiction, historical novels, smart fiction and even mysteries.

This one took me by surprise. Absolutely and totally grabbed me and shook me and entertained me all the way through. Now that I've given the praise, let's talk about the story.In this dystopic future, women are in charge but not all women are equal to other women and most of the people of this world lack any semblance of control over their lives or destinies. Vika is one such. Though her mother held a position of some merit, the lack of emotional connection required of their world means that does little to help her and she is just another young woman without healthy offspring and therefore, entirely disposable. Her chance comes when she is assigned a husband. If all goes well then she will have a child and be one of those chosen to travel to the distant land of China where the last remaining good land lies and the hope of a new civilization. Of course, nothing ever goes well in dystopias, does it?I'll end the synopsis there because more would start spoiling the story. Overall, I really liked Vika but more importantly, I could get into her skin and her character felt fully realized. The world that is the setting for the story is so well fleshed that it is almost another character and one that is malevolent at that.The words flow well and the story does too. The imagery is evocative and the setting extremely well realized from inception. In a way it is like someone took their favorite elements of 1984, Fahrenheit 451, The Handmaid's Tale and The Gate to Women's Country and made a new world that has enough punch to easily join that group.For all my praise, there are a few hiccups in the book that I put down to a young writer. One deals with the physics of fallout on a global scale. There is almost no likelihood...by that I mean a vanishingly small chance...that China would not be as significantly impacted as every other landmass. It would have been MORE believable had we a clear idea that Amana is North America and the promised land was Australia or New Zealand or something like that. That might have worked better. If there is some further deeper mystery that is revealed in the second book about "China" not being what they've all believed, then a hint that this is so would be better in the first book.Also, there is the idea that girls are being raped in the place where defectives are. If women control this world, then why is that happening. It is a jarring note of discord.But other than that, I found no real flaws. Instead, I found a developed dystopia with intriguing and unique elements that I enjoyed thoroughly. Highly recommended!

This story, a prequel for a full length novel, is a short story about a little girl and her mother in a world going to hell in a handbasket. Young, small and so very vulnerable, Sunni is also a hopeful little girl who enjoys dressing as a ballerina and dancing. When things go badly and she winds up alone, there will be no more dancing.It's just so very sad and tragic and all too imaginable in a world like the one we live in now.The story is well written and flows beautifully with characters very well fleshed for a short story. It is very easy to sink into the story and relate to the characters despite the brevity of the work. This is a disturbing story though and not at all suitable for the young. Ensure you can be alone afterwards if you have a tendency to be soft hearted.

Like a lot of people, I need it dark to sleep. I've also noticed the coolness creeping around the curtains in my bedroom when I walk past them more this winter. So, even though I love my curtains, I needed to buy new ones.While I was browsing around for new ones, with none of them striking my fancy, I came across this item in my search results. It seemed a no brainer for me to give these a try and then be able to keep my curtains.They arrived quickly and well packed, of course, and it took me only a few minutes to put them up behind my other curtains. I used the same rod and just put these on in between the slots for my curtains. I bought the pins recommended just in case, but didn't need them.As soon as I got these on I knew it was perfect. I closed the curtains and it went full dark. By that night, I also noticed that the creeping coolness near the window wasn't there anymore either. Since I put them up, my bedroom has been much warmer overall. With so many windows in the bedroom, it's easy to lose heat, but these appear to have stopped a whole lot of that.Do note that this is for one panel only. You'll need to measure and get multiple panels. In my case, they match the size of my curtains so one panel of these per curtain panel. Also, the back side of the panel is an off white so that is what will show outside the windows. Very convenient for those who live in a HOA where white is required visible at the street.

I really, really liked this story despite myself. It isn't the genre I normally read and it is a very different sort of story. Thomas was just a young boy when he disappeared suddenly from his family's life. And, like so many other unfortunate families whose children go missing, these parents never know for certain the fate of their child. While they know in their hearts he was taken and that he was almost certainly killed by whoever took him, there is always that spark of hope.Well, hope sometimes isn't in vain. But all is not what it appears and fear and love can become terribly intertwined. Thomas is the true hero of the story and his life is both beautiful and sad.This is a rather short book, more of a novella, and one should be able to read through it in one satisfying sitting. It isn't perfect in terms of the emotional content, but it is heart felt and understandable and enjoyable. Highly recommended to those who like supernatural stories, family stories and just beautiful fiction with heart.

At some point, I may get tired of pandemic based end of the world stories. Until then, I just keep clicking and reading and enjoying. As a big fan of indie fiction, I haunt the lists on an almost daily basis for anything that tickles my fancy. This one was a recommendation that showed up when I finished another piece of indie fiction on my Kindle Fired HD. I grabbed it up and thoroughly enjoyed the story.To be fair, there are some grammar mistakes and a misspelling or two in there. Nothing egregious, but they are there.The story revolves around a couple, Mike and Liz, who are awfully lucky to miss the first pass on a new disease.
