SO then I thought, maybe I'll try to jump in - but let me tell you, what I read from the first book had me desperately wanting to get my hands on it.  So I did.  I dove into Renegade that night and, upon finishing it, immediately moved on to Revelations.I loved Renegade, folks.  It was filled with brainwashing and utopias (or not), and mad escapes, and thrilling moments.  It made me want to walk around my house reading.  I was reminded of what it was like to be reading a really fun, engrossing young adult novel.  I loved it.  So I went into Revelations thinking that would continue.  And, while I might have enjoyed Revelations more had I not read Renegade first (although I would have been seriously lost in the story), I just thought it fell flat of the first book.  Let me explain why.First - the action. It's too fast paced.  Too much ground is covered and too much information revealed for just one book in this series.  I cannot be expected to believe in the scaryness and vastness of the world Souders has created if it can be covered in just a few pages.  Furthermore, I cannot be convinced of scary, deadly creatures if they are easily outrun or survived.Secondly, don't force a romance issue - even if it's just to instill a sense of tension and doesn't really exist.  Not only did the romance between Evie and Gavin feel forced and unnatural (she doesn't remember anything but somehow manages to be just as in love with him?), but the idea of someone else falling for Evie and barely knowing her just doesn't work.I felt like Souders had a great idea with this series and that Renegade was plotted well, but that she just bit off more than she could chew with the follow-up.  Quite a few things could have been removed to make the story more cohesive, but instead - I felt like I got a case of bookish whiplash from all the back and forth traveling in Revelations.

I have a fascination with King Richard III.  As many people know, his skeleton was recently found (near a parking garage) and, as a result, we are able to know more today about what this famous man looked like - in addition to knowing more about his deeds.  Richard III was the monarch connected with the two princes, if you have heard that story.  He's also known as the "Evil Crouchback," due to his having scoliosis, we have since learned.  Richard III was the last monarch before the uniting of the York and Lancaster Houses - two houses who had been at war for 100 years in the War of the Roses.  But Elizabeth of York is clearly not about Richard III - it's about Elizabeth.  However, Weir understands that in order to fully understand Elizabeth we have to understand how she grew up, what influenced her, and most importantly, what the evidence has indicated about the person she was.Elizabeth of York holds a place by proxy to some of the most famous figures in British history.  Her son was Henry VIII.  Her brothers were the famous princes who were murdered (allegedly) by Richard III.  Her mother was the famous Elizabeth Wydeville, the "Slandered Queen," who supposedly "seduced" Edward IV.  Elizabeth I was also the grandmother to the beloved Queen Elizabeth, the "Virgin Queen."  Add on top of that, Elizabeth's part in uniting the houses of Lancaster and York, as well as having a powerhouse of a mother-in-law, Margaret Beaufort, and you have quite a group of people surrounding this queen.But that's all of the people around Elizabeth.  What about Elizabeth herself?  Her teenage years were fraught with fear, yet she ended up in a marriage that, for all accounts, was not only amiable, but also one of fondness, if not love.  She gave birth to a brood of children, as all good Queens were expected to do, and she managed to be a favorite of the people, placing a face of kindness on the monarchy in spite of her husband, who - while a good King - was also distrustful of most people due to his own upbringing.Alison Weir does a fantastically thorough job of pulling together all of the research and arranging it in a way that not only makes sense, but lays out a great story in the process.  At times, Weir gets a little wordy and at times a little forward with her assumptions of how certain figures might have felt, but it never goes too far overboard for me and her assumptions make sense.I loved reading Elizabeth of York and I loved seeing Elizabeth I finally pushed to the forefront.  As a Queen, she was the epitome of grace and beauty and she was able, even while submissive and dealt some really crappy cards in life, to pull off a life that is worth admiring.

I am a pansy when it comes to scary stories.  I will readily admit that.  The book can be even not well written and I'll still be pansy.  Add pictures into the mix and yeah, I'll be sleeping with my light on for at least 2-3 nights after finishing the book (and sometimes during if I just can't finish the book in one setting).  Asylum was one of those books - I was so tired and haunted by the images in the book that it was a two night read for me...and the result was I spent a few nights restless in my sleep due to having to have my light on.I don't know about you, but the idea of an old mental asylum is only second to an abandoned carnival ground on a terror-ranking list.  When I was in my late teens, I accompanied a boyfriend and my sister to an abandoned penitentiary in eastern Wyoming.  It was Halloween and the workers had a blast filling each room with re-enactments of terrible things that may have happened.  Asylum provoked the memory of that experience through the medium of the included photos.  Not to mention - anytime I see a picture with eyes scratched out on it I get massive heebie-jeebies.That's not to say that Roux wrote a story that could have creeped me out.  In fact, without the addition of the pictures, I think I might have been a bit bored by the story.  It was a pretty typical one - group of kids get locked up, essentially, in a creepy old building and start investigating its history.  I got some massive Scooby Doo vibes from it.  But Roux did take it a step darker, which was necessary, with the inclusion of the photos.  The photos (and their credits are included at the back of the book) are a story in themselves.  So much horror contained in each, it is worth picking up the book just to examine them.I don't know of many kids that could handle the level of creepy that Asylum boasted - the photos might just have been a little over the top.  But I leave that judgment up to the parents.  For me, those photos were enough and I won't be able to get through a night in the near future without having that one little thought in the back of my mind that something might just happen once I click my light off for the night.

Over and over and over again in my reviews over the last several years I've found myself having to talk about using a gimmick to sell a book.  That gimmick could be anything from touching on curiosity that a reader might have on seeing things from a villains point of view to exploiting some sort of disability in an effort to sell the book.  J.M. Harvey has added yet another gimmick to my list of things to dislike: that of putting a story where there isn't a story in order to tell a completely different story.  Sisters of the Bruce was not a book about the sisters, it was a book telling the history of Scotland in the 13th century through the medium of women's letters and, to a lesser extent, their lives.The issue that Harvey, I'm sure, ran across is that there is little actual documentation on what the sisters lives must have been like.  Isabelle and Kirsty compose the majority of letters that provide an introduction into the book and those letters are full of politics, movements of the war, and other information that i highly doubt was made readily available to the women - through their brothers, husbands, or even other means.  Instead of getting an inside look into their actual lives, I was forced to endure a lengthy history lesson about the movements of different armies and the struggles for power - basically, instead of a book about women, Sisters of the Bruce was a book about men and the women were simply used as a tool to tell that story.While I doubt there is enough material to make a lengthy story about this bunch of sisters, I do think there is enough material to have made a short, more concise, but interesting look at the lives of the women of Scotland in the 13th century.  I understand, according to the summary, that Harvey has been influenced by some of my favorite female historians - but I think that his story development and his method of telling that story could use a nice long look.  Penman, for example, does not exploit characters in order to tell her story - instead, she focuses on specific characters, fleshing out their thoughts and reasoning behind their actions.I was really hoping to read a good, solid book with historical background - instead, I got a book on history with very little to do with the title, or the actual summary of the book.  If you are interested in good historical fiction, check out Sharon Kay Penman, Alison Weir, or even Nicola Griffith's newest book, Hild, for actual character development.

Religious abuse is not a pretty subject.  The fear that can be instilled in a child is chilling; horrifying to think about.  My family once adopted a puppy from our local shelter and when we brought him home we watched as he cowered from the men in our family.  You see, he had been horrifically abused by men in the home that had him before and so it was only natural that when a masculine figure approached him, his tail would go between his legs and his eyes would take on that look - you know the one I'm talking about.  Now, magnify that picture in your head and replace the dog with that of a child.  Imagine the fear that child would deal with each time their parent arrives home.  There is no joy, no happiness, no skipping to the door to receive a hug and a kiss; there is only fear. Watch How We Walk by Jennifer LoveGrove tackles this incredibly complex and painful subject in a way that tore me apart.This is not a book for the faint of heart.  Not every story has a happy ending and not every character lives with hope or a figure who will somehow swoop in and save the day.  Emily, the child in this family of Jehovah's Witnesses, believes she may have that figure in her Uncle Tyler, her uncle who has not yet come out of the closet and accepted what the church will lay down on him as a result.  Imagine, even seeing the adult in your life who is a voice for you and dealing with the same type of fear - imagine what kind of life that would be.Watch How We Walk is aptly named.  There is a lot of talk in various religions of not just talking the talk, but walking the walk, and Emily's family is laid bare before the reader and we are able to see every intimate aspect of their walk.  Emily's own actions are heartbreaking and...well, like I said, this is not a story for the faint of heart.This would be a book I would recommend to people who are struggling to understand how religious abuse can take such a grip on a persons mind; or those who do not understand the impact that fanatic religious beliefs have on others around them.  It's the children who suffer the most; entire childhoods ripped away and can never be restored.  Watch How We Walk is a good, hard reality check and an important book as a result.

There are times I will pick up a book, read it, and then sit for a long time afterward, thinking about what I want to say about it.  It's now December and I am still thinking about The Crooked Maid over three months after I finishing reading it.  I'm extremely torn on what I want to say, because - as so often happens with literary fiction, what I hoped for and what I got were two very different things.  The Crooked Maid deals with the time in Germany spent after the end of WWII - during the de-Nazification of Germany.  It's such an unusual setting and I was looking forward to reading about it, but what I got in Vyleta's story was something a bit more confusing.I understand that a story about this time period is automatically something that is hard to understand.  It's a subject matter that people don't often deal with in their lives, and really never deal with on a day to day basis (I'm casting a wide net here; that's not to say there are not things that are happening in the world today that are similar, but generally speaking, we aren't dealing with this particular re-building set during this time period).  And while I understood that a story had to be told along with it, to show what that rebuilding actually meant, the story ended up being one that left me feeling dissatisfied - like Vyleta had tried for something out of his grasp and ended up with a warped version of it.I think part of the problem was that I just didn't give two figs for Anna Beer.  I wanted to sympathize with her, she was undertaking a terrible journey and her path was one that was not easy - but frankly, I just didn't care.  The same with Robert Seidel.  Being described as a  schoolboy and, as a result, seeing the dynamics between him and Anna just left me feeling a bit sick to my stomach.  Then, there's the hunchbacked young servant - a character that the book was actually named after but one who plays a secondary role to Anna.  I just didn't care for any of them and, without caring for them, you can imagine how it was when I tried to care about what happened to them.  It made reading The Crooked Maid a bit of a chore.Vyleta has a beautiful way with description, and that's just about the only thing that really redeemed this book for me.  But, books are not all about beautiful descriptions and insightful thoughts - there has to be someone or something that the reader can connect to, so the result was that I read some beautiful words put together in pretty sentences but, like I often am when I hear a pretty piece of music on the radio, I am left with feeling like I've been robbed a bit when I found out the substance wasn't worth the packaging.The Crooked Maid is just another book that has me wonder about the awards process.  For longlists and shortlists, are various award committees looking at the packaging or are they really looking at the story?  Then again - it may just boil down to a matter of taste, and my taste just didn't extend to enjoying this one.

I really like this desk lamp. The different intensities and spectra of light are wonderful, and the flexibility of the articulations (i.e., 360 rotation, the 180-degree and, what, 110-degree elbow joints?) make this a winner of a desk lamp. Plus it's LED, so I don't feel guilty about having an extra lamp on my desk. I don't even use the phone charger option on it, though perhaps I should start doing so.

After having bad experiences with "the cheapest" option on various cables, bricks, chargers, and other products, I finally bought one Anker product. Then I bought another. Now, I only buy Anker products for my charging and cable needs. They may cost marginally more than "the cheapest" option, but they're durable and reliable. I particularly like being able to get various sizes, lengths, and numbers of ports on these products. Keep up the great work, Anker.

After having bad experiences with "the cheapest" option on various cables, bricks, chargers, and other products, I finally bought one Anker product. Then I bought another. Now, I only buy Anker products for my charging and cable needs. They may cost marginally more than "the cheapest" option, but they're durable and reliable. I particularly like being able to get various sizes, lengths, and numbers of ports on these products. Keep up the great work, Anker.

All movie references aside, this is actually a pretty awesome stapler. I got it because of the movie thing, but I really like it as a stapler. It's heavy and stays in place, it staples well, and it's quite distinctive. If anyone moves it to their desk, I'll know who took it.Let's just establish this, too: Swingline IS better than Boston.

It's a totally functional lightning cable. I like Anker products, because I can count on them working and being durable. I only buy their cables, bricks, and chargers. Having been burned by substandard products in the past, I'm willing to spend a little more on products that work the first time every time. Bravo, Anker. Keep up the good work.
Do you want a 13-food grounded extension cord with a three-outlet end? And do you want a flat-plug design for indoor use? Then go ahead and get this one. It'll do the job.

As a car deodorizer, it's pretty good. Not amazing, but pretty good. I like that the smell is pretty subtle and that there's nothing to spill or leak anywhere. In short, it's a pretty awesome product. Nothing will get certain smells out of your car, really, but ozium is a pretty good start for basic car freshness.

I wanted a way to organize my pencils, pens, scissors, etc. This is a good way to do that. The little drawer is good, I guess, but mostly I use the taller slots. It's sturdy and stays in place -- plastic versions of this product tend to skitter around the desk when you try to put things in or take them out. This mesh metal version stays in place.

As a bald man who spends time outside in the summer, this hat is a godsend. It's a little more formal than a bandana or headsweats beanie, and it breathes much better than a typical straw hat. The white color is great for reflecting heat, and the fit is exactly what I expected.

As a phone case and belt-holster, this is just about perfect. You can rotate the clip 90 degrees and wear the phone sideways on your belt, which means that the case/phone don't dig into your side very much. I absolutely love the kickstand option, too. I'm not sure how amazing it is at protecting my phone, but it definitely does make carrying my phone convenient.
Leather is thicker than I expected. Fit is normal. I bought a size down, having heard that they tend to be larger than you expect. They are, in fact, true to size, if not a bit smaller.

What I really wanted was a dairy-free soy-free nut-free protein substance to add to smoothies, which would hopefully add no flavor. Well, the egg powder adds plenty of flavor, and none of it is pleasant. That said, you are indeed purchasing powdered whole eggs. I just don't like their flavor.

I won't belabor any of the points made by far more eloquent and informed reviewers. I wanted relaxing and interesting music to listen to while stressed out. That's exactly what I got. I'll say that it reminds me a bit of when the Kronos Quartet does Philip Glass's work.

I'm no kind of expert, but for my purposes (extended storage in a Galaxy Note 4), this sd card does the trick just fine. I've had good luck with the brand and with this line of microSD cards. This is my third, and all three are still kicking.

I'm totally done with moisturizing balms that are overpriced. I'm done with fancy aftershaves and things like that. Stick to the basics -- there's a reason most barbers use this stuff. It's great. A good clean smell, without being overpowering or cloying. It's refreshing, and a good value.

I don't know why, but my dog goes nuts for this toy. It's her new favorite. She can be rough on plush toys sometimes, but she seems to be satisfied to just nibble on this one, rather than try to tear it apart. I ordered the "regular" size, and it's bigger than I expected.
For the price, these are fun. I wear them when I want to look a little smarter in meetings. They're a little on the small side, but I have sort of a big head.

I get a lot of compliments on this tie. It's a good width (a little on the wider side of ties these days), and the length is standard. Vivid colors, nice sharp clarity, and very cool. I like that it can go with both earth tones and neutrals (Grays/whites/blacks).

It's a little on the thin side for a tie, but it's not a skinny tie. I have a little difficulty figuring out what colors to wear it with, but it's really nice-looking! The width is a little less wide than a standard tie, but the length is just fine.

I don't like the lactose content of half and half, and I don't like the soy/filler content of powdered coffee creamer. I want cream and sugar -- so I mix this in a 1-to-1 ratio with powdered sugar and get a delicious, natural cream-and-sugar flavor in my coffee. For some reason, it seems to dissolve better when I mix it with powdered sugar? I don't know why that would be, or if it's even true, but that's my perception.

These are wonderful seamless pants, the seams are even hidden on the inside, so extra comfortable and no indention on your skin left behind. The color is more matte, than shiny because they're less spandex and more cotton. They feel a bit more breathable than my other yoga pants, but not hugely.  They have that snug, holding you together feel that is great for exercising in. I like that they don't spread thin over my booty so no sheer parts, although I'm not one to wear them anywhere but the gym, you could wear these hiking or wherever you like and feel comfortable that your parts aren't showing through. These are a higher quality pant than the yoga pants I've gotten at Target, which don't last long and are cheaply made. I feel comfortable recommending these pants to compliment your work out, yoga, pilates, experience.

Compact laser projection on the wall is so fun for my kids. You just plug it in and turn it either onto spinning through the pictures, or to where it pulses with music beat or clapping sounds. The projection is GREEN and RED. There are shapes like soccer balls, I heart you, Christmas trees,  a hand doing a peace sign, etc. You can not change the order or take any of the images out, it only works in one order. It covers a large wall for projecting - we have one room that is about 15 feet wide and it covers the entire wall floor to ceiling.You can't look towards the projection machine as the laser is so bright it hurts your eyes (and says not to look at it). The motor is really sensitive, it either is almost stopped or the images change super fast, there's not an in between speed.  We have only used it for about 15 minutes at a time - that's enough for my kids, but you can use it up to two hours at a time. Would be awesome for a party, especially if holiday themed, although it doesn't have to be. The machine has not gotten hot and it's easy to transport from room to room.

Coming of age and Falling in love = Thea and Calder journey.  I enjoyed their charming backstory and how the characters evolved. He makes her want to be a better person, which was refreshing outlook since it's usually the girl trying to "fix" a guy. I enjoyed the easy moving dialogue and storyline. I would read the rest of the sister series.

These smell wonderful but not over the top fake scent. It's more subtle, which I love. Not overwhelming like lush bath bombs can be for me. There are six golf ball sized bath bombs, two of each Christmas flavor, in a small egg carton. All of mine arrived individually wrapped and intact.They work upon dropping hem into the tub and again smell divine and cheery. Candy cane mint=yum.  They do not stain my tub like some other bath bombs have in the past, so score.I will order other scents.

My previous Guide to Literary Agents was from 2011, so it was time for an upgrade. This book is solid packed full of info, from query letter examples, industry advice, and agents. The index is in tiny print and I've just recently gotten glasses so it's especially hard to use. I get wanting more to save paper but geez!  That said, the agent info is gold and it's an excellent reference for writers. My friends and I use together to find agents that are interested in our specific genres.

Smells like Tropicana Sun Oil - remember that yummy scent. Coconut and Lime. It's my favorite scent so I'm particularly favorable of this spray. If you don't like coconut tropical smell - this is not for you.I've figured out that three sprays is the best for me. Remember to spray BEFORE you go to the bathroom. Lean in low so you're not just spraying the toilet seat and trash can, it will make a film over the toilet water. Then, do you business while the smell of Pina Coladas permeates your bathroom. It's like pooping in Hawaii:-)When you're done, and have flushed, you will only smell Coconuts, leaving a tropical paradise in the bathroom behind you instead of that awful fecal matter odor. Such a nice trail to leave behind for the next bathroom user.We leave ours in our guest bathroom so no one is embarrassed if they have to poop while visiting. It's become the outhouse of choice in our home for us that live there too.I'm not sure what it is made of, but it does say organic so that makes me happy. It doesn't leave that hairspray smell that makes you gag because it gets in your mouth and then everything you eat afterwards tastes like Aqua Net. This is a scent that lingers in the air and not your body.I don't know how they do it, but I love it. I recommend everyone keeps these in their bathroom, the packaging is nice and you can keep it by candles or hand towels. If I was working, I'd bring a bottle to work with me. I remember how awful it was to leave a dreadful bomb in the bathroom and have to smile as you wash your hands next to your co-workers.Happy to answer any questions. TMI - Ladies it also covers period smell (sorry, I know that's a lot of info!)  I was sent MASK for free in exchange for an honest review, and honestly, I really like it.

My son is in love with this toy. He likes manipulating the lever and opening the hatch. His imagination is going wild.The transforming rescue bot is blue and is a ship and a robot. This is blowing his mind and he's been carrying around this cool transforming dude who is about 4 inches high, perfect for his little hands. Is this High Tide, I'm not sure, we have not gotten into the show yet. I'm sure that is coming!It's made of sturdy plastic and it's easily transportable. Nothing on it makes noise which I like, but my son would prefer it made rescue siren noise or something.Once it's out together it doesn't come apart. Except the life preserver that ties on and the crane has come off.There are two cardboard cut out characters that my son has no interest in whatsoever.

Like most nursing moms, I've tried a lot of different nursing bras. I really like this one! Why? Because it's a soft cotton fabric, there is support WITHOUT a wire! It's actually comfortable and I can wear it for long periods of time. It has padding! A lot of the bras I got at Walmart and Target did not have padding, so I appreciated the extra umph. This old grey mare just ain't what she used to be, so I'll take any help I can get. I know this is TMI - but I'm passed the leaking phase, but for anyone still there, you should probably still use nursing pads so that the milk doesn't soak into the padding of the bra, so you can still use it after you're through that stage.The pattern is cute and so is the lace on the front. It opens on each side easily and has not stretched out for me. I've learned to hand wash all my bras, or they don't last as long, so I've been doing that with this one as well.  And I hang dry.  It is for a machine wash, but that's your choice.And the price is awesome! I was fortunate to receive a free bra for an honest review and I feel comfortable recommending this product. It's the same quality as Walmart and Target and listed as very inexpensive. Plus I love the wide shoulder straps (they're adjustable in the back). I'm happy to answer any questions if you have any fellow moms.

This book is very different, meaning it doesn't necessarily follow the romantic formula. I was pulled in by the opening story of 12 year old love, but then I kept waiting while the book takes you on a completely different ride than expected. That is why it gets 4 stars from me. I was not expecting the turns it took and had to find out where it was going. That said, there are a lot of characters to follow.  A LOT. and I did like how much the friends were there for each other, but again, I asked myself more than a few times, "Where is this going?!?!?" I'm happy to report that I stuck with it to the end and the conclusion was satisfying for this reader (my personal opinion). Creative? Yes. Formulaic? No. It could be more of a journey of a woman finding herself than a romance novel.

I was hesitant to purchase this, but I'm quite fond of it! The colors are brighter than in the picture, more red and purple and bold. Not soft colors like the photo. I've been wearing it with a lace tank under and it's super flattering. I thought I might look like Mrs. Roper (you have to have watched 3s company to get that reference) but I've been getting compliments on it and people asking where I got it. I always am worried that I look fat, but this is actually pretty flattering. I've worn it with tight black pants and skinny jeans (I'm not), and it's flowy and forgiving. For my body type, this really works well and I'm digging it.Note that it's a lot of fabric, super big. I typically wear a woman's size L and this is big on me, which I like. It's like a pretty tent that falls nicely. There is colorful trim on both the neck and at the end of the sleeves.

Outdoor adventure Vest Awesomeness!  My son went ape over this best.  It's cute and he runs hot, so it's nice that the back is all mesh (and shoulders).  There is a sturdy black zipper down the middle that my son can manipulate once I get it started.  There are four pockets on the front of the vest, so lots of room for supplies, and collections like rocks and shells, depending on where you wear it.  This really puts my son in the adventure mood, he loves it.  He's small for his age, so it's a big big on him and sizing is so hard with everyone being such different body shapes, but this is could fit a toddler up to the early years of elementary (depending on your child's size).  It's sturdy and we've thrown it in the wash after some spills and it's fine (a little more worn looking, but the stitching stayed in tact and the pocket flaps are still laying down.  Overall, I like it.  It's fun and cute and my kiddos loves it.

These are fabulous megaphones. My sons have been playing with them constantly for the past few weeks and they're sparking their imaginations. And they're LOUD! But there is a volume dial at the bottom that turns the volume all the way off all the way to very very loud. My kids like it loud, but I prefer it to be quiet as to not upset the neighbors. There is a Fire siren that turns on and off by the left side button. It's easy to manipulate. On the right is the power button. You have to be pretty close to speak into the megaphone (there's a small slit where the speaker is), and my kids like to keep their mouths pressed on it to talk.These are nice quality megaphones. I've had cheaper, not as nice models before that broke right away. These will last until you're kids grow out of them. Great for imagination play and for costumes. They require 4 batteries that are easy to put in (AA). Quite a nice toy.

These are fabulous megaphones.  My sons have been playing with them constantly for the past few weeks and they're sparking their imaginations.  And they're LOUD!  But there is a volume dial at the bottom that turns the volume all the way off all the way to very very loud.  My kids like it loud, but I prefer it to be quiet as to not upset the neighbors.  There is a Police siren that turns on and off by the left side button.  It's easy to manipulate.  On the right is the power button.  You have to be pretty close to speak into the megaphone (there's a small slit where the speaker is), and my kids like to keep their mouths pressed on it to talk.These are nice quality megaphones.  I've had cheaper, not as nice models before that broke right away.  These will last until you're kids grow out of them.  Great for imagination play and for costumes.  They require 4 batteries that are easy to put in (AA).  Quite a nice toy.

We seem to go through tons of ear buds in our home, so when I get a good pair like this, I hide them in my purse, away from my kids.  These Creative Aurvana in-Ear2 earphones are comfy in my ears and snug.  They have three size covers to choose from, but I like the medium ones that came on the pieces.  The shape of these suits my ears better than the iPhone standard white earbuds that are particular to which ear you use.  While these have set ears as well, I didn't notice a crazy difference if I had them in the "wrong" ear.  The audio on these from my iPhone is wonderful.  I could watch an episode of TV with my baby sleeping on me.  I didn't wake him up and I wasn't disturbed by the constant leaf blowers outside my windows (seriously, it's beyond awful) so thank you creative aurvana for helping remove their offensive noise.  I like the volume control and power on the cord, they're easy to use and work well.  The plug fits in my phone nice with a secure snap in, and also on my computer.  The case is convenient, and so far the ear buds have not slipped out of their packet.  As far as earphones go, these are one of the better sets I have reviewed.  Believe me, some really suck and break easily and are a hard plastic that hurt your ears.  These are better than that.  I'm confident that these will suit many customers.

Very attractive, nice set of fins, snorkel, mask and mesh bag.  I received size Small/Medium and they fit both me and my teenage son perfectly (I'm women's shoe 8 and he's men's shoe 6 1/2).  The Fins are awesome and once you're used to the flapping movement in the water, quite powerful.  The Mask fits snug and so far has been excellent at keeping water out, and not fogging up too often.  I've been using masks my whole life and this one is one of the better ones with a nice seal and suction to your face.  The snorkel fits in my mouth nice and I'm able to keep a solid grip while swimming and breathing.  The bag is handy to keep it all together and for travel.  I'm happy with this set and would purchase another one when I don't want to share!

This is one of those toys that arrives in a big box and kids go crazy with anticipation of opening it.  My son about died the horse walks on it's own, he loves this.  Okay, the Barbie included is pretty and a regular size Barbie, with a soft feel.  The newer Barbie's I've gotten, this one included, are much softer in appearance than our harsh Barbies I grew up with and loved.  And I mean softer in appearance, not texture.  She's got on a cute riding outfit and equestrian hat and gloves, with boots.  She's just awesome.  And the horse is light brown, blue eyes, and a dark brown mane and tail (Not soft hair, it's all plastic).  She has a pink saddle and reins.  The horse has an on button disguised as bangs (mane) on it's head to make it go.  ANd on the side of the mane is a pink button where Barbie's hand goes before she's put on the horse.  It's fascinating and does work at times, but my kids mostly just put her on the horse themselves.  Overall, I'm quite impressed with this toy set.  It's cute and would make a great gift.  I've had other Barbie products that I didn't love, so that's why I'm gushing over this one.  It's awesome.

Watched with my 13 year old son.  We both liked the cast, and he thought the base player was really funny.  I liked them living on the miniature golf course, that could be cool!  My son liked how the band comes together and that it's not slapstick like a lot of teen shows.  I appreciated that it's not overly dark or edgy.  A nice medium for kids and parents.  While I've seen this theme before, this is a story that can be fresh for this generation.  We look forward to the series.

2015 Holiday Barbie is pretty and sophisticated.  Her best feature is her long blonde hair with soft curls (much better then the usually rough hair).  Her dress is burgundy with silver under with and matchin burgundy nail polish.  The earrings are 5 tiered bling that are a bit much for me.  Her dress bodies piece is also a silver flowered diamond piece that adds a fancy flare.Overall, she's an attractive, modernized, Moviestar perfection doll.  Surely she would delight Barbie lovers young and old.

These are quality pants that are lightweight, but built sturdy.  I'm pretty tall and these pants were long on me, so they should be able for most size 12 to wear, but they may need to roll up the bottoms or take them in on the length.  The waist fits comfortably above my belly button, so no butt crack when you squat down to pick anything up.  There are belt loops in case you want to wear a belt (I don't wear with these).  The fabric is light but not see through - no one can see the color of your underwear.  The legs are straight, so it depends on your body type to fill them out.  They were comfortable, slightly baggy on me, which I liked.  The front pockets are almost big enough for my hand, but not big enough to leave them in there.  Their is a pocket on each side in the back, it's a slit with reinforced seams, that a cell phone or something will fit in, but it's not closed so things can fall out.  I find them to be more decorative.  The stitching is industrial and strong.  And wash and wear!  Super easy maintenance.

My family only uses Mr. Sketch washable scented markers.  First off, they last a long time if you keep the caps on properly.  Second, they're washable.  And third, they smell fun, which is a bonus.  They've got load of flavors, but this particular case comes with:CherryOrangeBananaMintBlueberryGrapeVery traditional scents and their strong, so it's not like you're left wondering which is which.  You can tell - and the color of the marker gives it away.These are bright markers, and are 3 line widths, meaning their not skinny, lean more towards a fat, bigger marker (not so much in grip, but mark on the page).  These provide a nice grip for both children and adults.  I find these to be of wonderful quality.

This is now the paddle everyone wants to use in my house.  Our other paddles are just crappy in comparison (came with paddle game, and another set that came with our table).  So far, the grip has been nice for me and my hand fits comfortably.  The quality does seem to make my game slightly better, but I'm no pro, we play for fun and since the weathers nice, we play a lot!  My son can be obsessive and he's quite fond of this paddle.  I'll update as time goes on with any concerns, but for now we are quite happy with ours.

My son loves this men's face lotion with sunscreen.  He has sensitive skin, that's dry, so it soaks this up quickly without leaving a shine.  It's light and spreads easily.  There is a faint sunscreen smell.  As far as sunscreen protection, it works for commutes in the car and light sun exposure.  It is not for swimming or water sports days.  I'd reapply in afternoon for more sun exposure if your first application was in the morning.

I am pleasantly surprised at the power of such a small devise.  The Calily diffuser has exceeded my expectations.  It puts off more steam than my Vicks humidifier.This compact circular piece is plugged in (cord has cut out piece to fit into so that the siffuser is level regardless of cord). It starts working immediately and gets hot super fast so follow the proper safety rules.  There are four levels of steam distribution.  I have used peppermint and eucalyptus and my entire bedroom is dented in minutes.  It's wonderful!There is also a light that can change colors or remain in one color.Overall this is a wonderful product that I use daily and will give as a gift.

I'm quite happy with these bottles of Olive Oil.  Since I only use Olive Oil and Coconut Oil, I have tried quite a few brands and this one is excellent.  Why?  It's got a real olive taste.  Some olive oils are subtle and not watered down, but have less flavor.  These bottles have a very OLIVE kick.  Sorry, hard to describe tastes!  The bottles each have their own particular flavor.  I did a taste test back to back and their distinct, but again, hard to describe and I love them both.Cooking with these olive oils is divine.  They heat nicely (I know you're not supposed to get olive oil too hot), but I made a turkey sauce and it was wonderful..  I use them to make homemade salad dressing and I prefer these bottles over my Costco brand.  The quality of these oils seems high.  I will def. keep these in stock!

I've always been a fan of proactiv products, using them exclusively through my 30's.  I tried this product on both myself and my son.  It goes on grease less and soaks in quickly.  Though a gentle product, it still irritated my skin (in 40s), but worked wonderfully on my teenage son.  So, if you have sensitive skin, this may not be for you, but if you're a teenager or don't have sensitive skin, it has cleared up an onery patch of acne off my son's temple.  Hooray!  This is a pretty large bottle and since you don't use it all over your face, just on problem areas, it should last a long time.  It says 3 months, but I think it will last longer for our usage.

This is an attractive rolling pin, that's heavy and solid, with adjustable measuring discs for the sides so you can roll out your dough to exactly the correct height.  I thought that was a super cool feature as I'm not much of a baker and any precision helps!  My teenage son is learning to bake and is high functioning autistic, so the exact measurements were a big selling point for him.  4 stars instead of 5 because I'm used to rolling the pin around all over in every direction.  With the measurement discs on the side, you have to use a smaller amount of dough at a time and don't have the flexibility to roll it around or it will put huge disc marks in your dough.  My son is new to rolling, so this wasn't an issue with him - because it was all he's ever known.  So new bakers might prefer this rolling pin, while old school dough all over the counter bakers will not.  Again, it's attractive and solid, so as long as I keep enough flour on hand, it's a no stick, fabulous, pin.  I'd recommend to an up-and-coming baker.

Book:  Dads of DisabilityCollected and Edited by Gary DietzAdditional Editing by Beth Gallob Poetry selected by Marly YoumansDads of Disability takes the reader inside the hearts and minds of men.  While so much love shines through each page, it is not sappy.  These men are brave, some are angry, they are fighting, and sometimes they break down.  The common thread is a raw and vulnerable honesty, the men do not hold back and their truth is appreciated.A plethora of special needs are showcased including PKU, Autism, Schizophrenia, Sensory Processing Disorder, Downs Syndrome, Epilepsy, Cerebral Palsy, and Behavior Disorders, and ODD, which is informative, but not in the typical fashion.  Instead of reading about symptoms, the reader is drawn into the lives of these families and the learning is insidious rather than explained.  There is keen insight throughout.The book is told by several dads using poems, short stories, and  vignettes.  The editor keeps it moving, with no repetitive stories or themes.  At one point the women take over and talk about the men.  It's not all warm and fuzzy, but again honest and sometimes blunt. As a special needs mom, I resonated with these women.A segment by Jeffrey P. Howe was a nice surprise, having read his popular article in Money Magazine.  Reading about the article's backlash I hadn't heard about and his continued transformation was a highlight for me.  But, this doesn't take from any of the other stories. Each left their impact.Gary Dietz has a few personal stories planted throughout and doubles as editor.  As every movement needs a fearless leader, Gary puts himself out there, tears and all, which I imagine created the safety net for the others to follow suit.Some notable highlights:•How having a special needs child affects working relationships and your career. What not to say to a special needs child.  An example of a well meaning stranger with the best of intentions ruins a child's day.•The stress that will affect your marriage can make you stronger together or rip you apart.•That men have their breaking points to.•It's not about only the inspirational memes that are portrayed in the media.  These are real, everyday people with sometimes extreme daily challenges.  Not just the one minute hero moments to make everyone feel good.•Support is key.  While disabilities can create isolation, a common thread is the support from others.  Family, friends, a new girlfriend, a stranger, or even a yearly support retreat.  Support is vital.•These dads do not take the backseat.  It's a new generation and they are stepping up.  It's nice to hear the warrior dads roar.I recommend Dads of Disability for the mothers of special needs children to better understand their partners (or exes).  Grandparents should read to deepen their understanding.  This should be given to every father upon joining the special needs dad club (it would make a beautiful gift for those that don't know what to say).  And therapists and/or anyone who works with special needs families can gain a new perspective within these pages.  An enjoyable and important read.

Belinda Jones is now my new favorite author and I'm reading through her entire catalog.  Why?  She's funny.  Really, super, laughing that stays with you, smile on your face funny.  Her humor is very quirky and out there at times, but I don't want t true story, I want and escape from all reality and she delivers. It's not a documentary people, it's fantasy!  Her lead character is a girl's girl, with great girlfriends.  There are many characters, but I could tell them apart easily.  It's sometimes ridiculous, but I loved the ride and enjoyed every minute of it.If you've ever harbored love for an old flame, or an old friend who was never a flame, this is your book.  Though I don't have that issue, I still enjoyed her journey to love and all the many, many, many twists and turns to get there.  The characters all learn life lessons and everyone grows.  Two thumbs up from me.  Hope you love it too:-)

Just Add Water: A Surfing Savant’s Journey with Asperger’s is the follow up book to the Quicksilver sponsored documentary of the same name (Just Add Water 2008).  Clay’s mom, Jill, begins the journey with Clay’s overdue birth and his early start in the water at just 2  weeks old.  Her and Clay’s story is all too common these days, with his turbulent school experience and struggles with social and emotional development.  The book is told by surfing author Robert Yehling, who takes you deep into Clay’s surfing world, waves, competitions, and travels, and snippets into Clay Marzo’s world by Clay himself, his journals from childhood, and perspectives of his family members, friends, and fellow surfers (and videographer and manager).  There are a few notable pictures included and some stand out Aspergers information from Dr. Tony Atwood and Clay’s behavior specialist Carolyn Jackson.As an Asperger’s mom to a teenage boy, I’m thrilled to have found this emotional and informative book, and to have someone like Clay in the public eye that my son can relate too.  While everyone say’s Einstein had autism, and that’s great, he’s not exactly someone my son wants to emulate, Clay is.The book is an honest portrayal into Clay’s life, his family’s struggles, and his current situation.  Yes, life continued after his legendary documentary, and Clay is now an adult.  They share how he’s dealing as a surfer presently, interacting with family, and how he manages to have a long time girlfriend, Jade.  It’s not all peachy and sugar coated and I enormously appreciate their openness and vulnerability.  The amount of awareness and educating this book does, while being entertaining, is as epic as Clay’s surfing.While surfing is a huge part of Clay’s life, the book examines all facets, including the importance of providing flexible learning environments for kids on the spectrum.  All teachers should read how much impact teachers had on Clay.  The traditional old-school, take away recess as a punishment, kind of teachers hurt Clay tremendously, while the progressive, kind and creative teachers brought out his amazing ability at creative writing.  Mary Anna Waldrop Enriquez was one of Clay’s champion teachers, and she made all the difference in his life.Clay shares his extraordinary outlook and the inner workings of his mind. Much like Temple Grandin who catalogs pictures in her memory, Clay memorizes each wave he rides.  He makes stimming cool (rubbing his hands together excitedly) , and he’s sharing his passion for surfing with other autistic individuals through his work with Surfer’s Healing.  He’s an inspiration, who isn’t on a pedestal, and an amazing athlete.  What’s not to love?This book will delight all parents (especially fellow warrior autism moms!), surf enthusiasts, teachers, and anyone curious about Aspergerg’s syndrome (or high functioning autism as listed by the DSM-5).

Authors Scott Banks and Joe Kraynak have a new fan in me, having written a very thorough and comprehensive guide to Natural Cures.  If you're not into a natural lifestyle, this isn't the book for you, as it's about a completely natural lifestyle and not just quick fixes.  If you're interested in becoming more natural, this will help you take those steps from diet to sleep and exercise and avoiding Pharmageddon pitfalls.Part 2 covers most ailments I could think of from mental health to fertility to hair, skin and nail issues.  He tackles sleepIssues, adrenal and thyroid issues, and common kiddie health issues.  The remedies are mostly vitamins and or supplement recommendations as well as what may causing issues.  For example, for cataracts he suggests trying N-acetylcarnosine eye drops, triphala eye wash, dusty miller, and pascalite, all of which are available at health food stores and online (quality of all products matters).  Although the only cure for cataracts is surgery.Overall, I find the information to be helpful and I'm happy to have it on hand to reference and things come up with my family.  it's a reference book, but Ive found myself reading it all because it's interesting and informative.  My favorite Dummies book to date.

Classic Trouble - just add Minions.  My kids love the popping of the dice.  The minions are adorable.  One piece is a fully decorated minion (Siren Bob Minion), the other four are molded minions of different colors (blue, yellow, green, and orange).  The Minion element adds a chase and almost human (maybe because of the characters) aspect which my kids like.  Pieces are small (almost tiny) so for kids 5 plus only! 2 players minimum to play, 4 maximum.  Entire game can be played in around twenty minutes.

Arrived in cool packaging, folded in triangle boxes (my kids flipped). Directions are easy to follow to lock into upright position.  Beautiful blue body with matching rubber grip-no slip handlebars.  These really helped steady my little guy who went from zero to as fast as he could go in two seconds flat.  Box reads 3 years old plus.There is a lot of give and the steering is easier than the old school all metal scooters.  As you lean into the direction you want to turn, the suspension is more responsive and takes bumps and terrain with ease.Impressive quality, as my boys are BamBams and throw everything around.  Built to last and are a total favorite.  Already have withstood a CA rainstorm and still look and ride great.I was lucky to review the Tackedoo kids scooter and we will continue to get a lot of use out of this awesome product.  I will update with any issues or concerns over time.

Arrived in cool packaging, folded in triangle boxes (my teenager flipped).  Wrench (little hook one) included.  Directions are easy to follow to lock into upright position. It did not lock into place at first, but on the third try it clicked and has been fine ever since.It's an attractive, rugged, "cool" looking scooter that my son is proud to show off. His balance isn't great, so the shock absorption is helpful.  The adjustable height for the handlebars is a nice feature as he outgrew his razor scooter (he's tall).There is a lot of give and the steering is easier than the old school all metal scooters.  As you lean into the direction you want to turn, the suspension is more responsive and takes bumps and terrain with ease.Impressive quality, as my boys are BamBams and throw everything around.  Built to last and are a total favorite.  Already have withstood a CA rainstorm and still look and ride great.I was lucky to be able to try out this awesome Tackedoo scooter for teens and adults.  We are very happy with ours. I will update if we have any issues or concerns.

This is a very gentle shampoo and conditioner that does not tingle or sting your scalp.  It does not have the tar in it that the neutropenia dandruff soaps have, it's much more mild. It helped my dry scalp to stop itching after about a weeks use.  The smell is light fake berry-ish, nothing potent.  I have long hair and can brush it out easily after washing with this, no crazy tangles.  Overall, it's smooth and silky and I like it.  No complaints.

This is a short book, 123 pages, that is packed with information.  The book starts with excerpts from Dr. Temple Grandin’s speaking engagements.  She’s typical no nonsense Temple, with sound advice in each segment.  Advice that is applicable into your own or your child’s life.  There’s also brain scans and explanations to how the brain with autism works and WHY people with autism think the way that they do.The emphasis in these segments is on:•Behaviors and learning•Manners and social skills•Anger management•Autistics working/career development•Sensory development (multi-sensory activities)•And the autism brain (including fear box differences)The book then switches into question and answer format.  The questions are taken from Dr. Temple Grandin’s previous books including The Way I See It, Thinking In Pictures, and The Autistic Brain, and from questions asked at conferences and to Temple directly via email.  They cover the gamut of both sensory and autism specific questions.  She goes into her personal history, which inspires and educates simultaneously.Question Examples are:1. How do you feel about children’s book apps?  Are these better for learning?2. What should teachers keep in mind when teaching kids with autism?3.  How do you deal with teasing in high school?And many more questions, which are quite long and detailed from a variety of sources, but too long to list.Some important take-aways for me!•Teaching interaction with others.  I’m always shocked at the moms who tell me their kids don’t want to be social, so they don’t put them in activities.  Temple writes about the importance to socialize, especially if your kids don’t want to.•Learning to control anger.  This is big in the autism community.  She’s got great advice and personal experience.•Attention-Shifting Slowness.  Eye opening and should be mandatory reading for everyone who has autism or is around people with autism.•The fear box.  An ah-ha moment for me.  Helps me understand why my child is so fearful all the time.But that’s just a glimpse of what’s inside Temple Talks…about Autism and Sensory Issues.The audience for Temple Talks is parents who are overwhelmed and are weeding through massive amounts of information.  This book is useful because it’s divided into short bits that a parent can digest at their leisure.  It’s also great for a teachers, caregivers, or family member to understand the important things about autism and sensory needs. Sort of a cheat sheet for those without time to read temples library of work.And for the Temple fan, like myself, I always enjoy re-reading her advice, a reminder of how my child’s brain works.  And I always discover something new, or maybe I had glossed over before because it didn’t pertain to me at the time.My only criticism would be the lack of organization in regards to theme, but I think that's hard when there are so many questions about a million different subjects.  Just don't be expecting it to be sorted except for her talks and then questions and answers.

We have two extremely happy felines at the moment who are obsessed with these tunnels.  First, they're so colorful and happy looking, even I get happy looking at them.  Second, they're build well and the fabric is strong.  They each have a hanging toy that is like cat crack.  One of the tunnels is shorter and my cats like to hide in it and then dart out.  The second one can be kept in a circle type shape or opened to be long, so it's versatile.  It also has a hole on top for the cats to pounce out of.  The tunnels colapse a big if the cats spring on them, but then get back into their shape.  My toddler loves them too, but that's another story.  Oh and they're noisy.  My nocturnal loves enjoy waking me up with the paper crinkly noise, so keep them away from your bedroom if you're a light sleeper.  I love them! Great tunnels.

Our Baby Alive Lil' Sips Baby Has a Tea Party Doll has been quite loved at our home.  She's a hard doll (plastic, not soft) and her hair is plastic too (not the brushable kind).  Her arms, legs and head move at their main joints.  She's pretty and my kids swooped her up immediately.  Her dress is cute with gummi bears and cupcakes on it.The teapot and teacups (with screw on lids) have been the biggest hit.  They sort of change color when full of cold water, but they really like to pour the tea into the cup.  And then the cup lid fits perfectly into the dolls mouth and she drinks it...and then pees.  So now the diaper.  I have one kid still in diapers so I wasn't thrilled at the thought of buying diapers for a doll.  I found a pack of 6 diapers at Target for 6 dollars (NOT INCLUDED).  1 diaper is included in this set.  But the good news, if you put the diapers outside, they dry and you can use them again as long as the tape isn't totally ruined.  We have used our own tape on a few.  If your child really loves this diaper feature, be prepared to purchase diapers, but the novelty has worn out in my house, so we're good.The directions say to not put her in the tub.  Yeah, my kids could not grasp that concept and she went swimming with us and she had a bubble bath - she's fine and still works.  Probably not a good idea, but I'm just being honest here.  Maybe once she fills up with water outside of her drinking/pee system it messes her up.  So far, we've been lucky.  And just an FYI - my kids also put food coloring in her water to make her pee different colors.  Yes, kids are entertaining.Overall, especially since she's been through so much in our home, including a day of tattoos drawn on her ankle (hey big kids playing with the little ones - I'l take what I can get) , this doll is sturdy, pretty, functional, entertaining, educational, and all around fun.  She'd make a great gift for any small child, notice I didn't say girl because I have boys and my toddler has carried this around for the last few weeks (when he wasn't playing with trains and cars).  Great doll.

This is a nice gadget for our kitchen for a few reasons.  While I personally don't love it as much as I wanted to, my teenager that is learning to cook does.  Since french fries and fried foods are high on his must eat list, this allows him the freedom to kind of re-heat frozen french fries in this contraption, and I like that it turns itself off when done (since my teenager is forgetful).  He thought he was super cool when he made his own chicken wings.  And I tasted them, they were good.  I'll update as we try to more items.As far as looks, it is a cross between a toaster and coffee pot and takes up counter space, but at least it's being used.  It's easy to clean out the fryer portion and wipe down the rest.  It smelled bad when we first opened it, but it is fine now.

They're relatively small, circle pills, that crack if you bite into them and are chaulky.  I swallow mine, but my son chews them.  He says they taste gross, but he does it anyways with water.  I'd say as long as you or your child can swallow small pills these are fine.We started these right before my son went on Spring Break, so I could monitor if there were any changes.  I didn't notice anything for about 10 days, but he said he felt good and had energy.  Almost 3 weeks in, he told me he didn't have autism anymore (not true! he still does!!!).  I asked why and he said, "He doesn't feel like anything is wrong."  So, I ordered another bottle.  Who is to say what is making him feel better, but this vitamin is the only change that we've added to his intake.  I doubt everyone would have the same results, but they seem to be working for him.  So, I'm taking them now too and so is my mom.  I don't feel any side effects and I have felt a bit more energized in the afternoons when I usually want to nap.  I certainly don't want to say they're miracle vitamins, so please don't misunderstand my review, I just wanted to share our experience.  I do like them and my entire family is taking them.  We are all being tested for the MTHFR gene mutation this summer, so maybe that has something to do with it.  My understanding is that these are made from Folate and not Folic acid, which is why we purchased them in the first place.  I'm not a doctor, just a mom.  So, please take this info as you will.I will add an update if there are any changes to report.

This tea beyond tea combo is fantastic!  First, my family and I enjoyed watching the tea buds open into flowers.  It's just fun.  They're not nearly as bright as the packaging photos, but they're more earthy and pretty.  The best thing about the tea though, besides the flowers, is the taste.  Even when steeping for too long, the teas are subtle and remind me of my favorite Chinese food restaurant as a child.  Simply tasty and smooth.  Sometimes teas can be hard on my system and make it hard to sleep, but none of these teas kept me up all night.These are lovely and memorable, which makes a really nice gift.  I'm very fond of these teas.

The words "The Great American Novel" can only be applied to a few books, but choosing a single one is impossible.  Among those that come to my mind are "Huckleberry Finn", "The Great Gatsby", "Point of No Return" (J.P. Marquand), "Sister Carrie", "Dodsworth" and at least a couple by William Faulkner.  Out of the latter's fabulous bequest to literature, I would definitely choose LIGHT IN AUGUST as one.  ("Absalom, Absalom" and "Wild Palms" are two others.)  Violence, sex, love, hate, religion, race, and the inescapable weight of the past fill this novel along with beautiful, sometimes even mystic, language.  While the story and atmosphere belong indubitably to Mississippi, the combination of all the elements is distinctly American and in some way, universal.  It was Faulkner's genius that made it so.  The central character, Joe Christmas, embodies the violence and ambiguity that slavery and subsequent race relations have imprinted on America.  He is marginally black, can pass for white, and maintains no set identity.  Joe Christmas has fallen through the cracks.  Yet such was the virulence of our racism (and maybe the past tense is not entirely appropriate) that many could construe his very existence as a crime.  There is a murder: the murderer is caught.  An abandoned, pregnant woman comes looking for her absconding man and finds another one.  A former minister can't rid himself of the Civil War ghosts of his father and grandfather.  The complexity of the plot is not what will hold you---rather it will be the masterly depiction of psychological forces, of personality, the past and how it continually echoes in the present.  Also it will be the way the whole story unfolds in slow majesty, revealing everything in due course.  If you have never read Faulkner, you might start with a shorter book, but this is probably his masterpiece.  I cannot think of a more powerful work of literature.

Some may hail him as a master of 20th century literature, but I found these four long stories pretty tough going and not always interesting.  There is very little description of people, places, or the times when the action takes place.  Many characters don't even have names; known only by police rank.  Without much knowledge of the author, whom I had not encountered before, I would say that he wrote more for himself than many other writers do.  He writes in an always-intellectual style on political, moral, and legal topics that interested him, whether readers share these concerns or not.  The phrase "investigative essay" has been used to describe Sciascia's writings and I think it's a fair term.  The third piece in the book, "A Straightforward Tale" most resembles a story in the usual sense of the word, though it is delightfully not straightforward at all.  All four parts of OPEN DOORS concern murder, the death penalty,  justice, and the question of whether it's really possible to understand the nature of crime, though of course we know when one has been committed.  "Open Doors", the title piece, harks back to political twists in 1937, the Fascist period in Italy.  "Death and the Knight" takes place in 1989, the year the author died, and deals with terrorism.  "A Straightforward Tale", already mentioned, is most Sicilian, connecting police, the courts, the church and the Mafia without ever mentioning that last organization.  "1912+1" also deals with a murder case, this a real one in 1913, in which a countess shoots dead a young lover---but why?  All the stories are interlaced with countless literary references and philosophical wanderings.  OPEN DOORS is definitely not beach reading, but thoughtful and illustrative of an interesting mind and a top writer.  It's not surprising that he doesn't have a mass following.  If Sciascia had not chosen to write in this genre, he might have gotten a Nobel Prize.

Life is certainly made up of mostly trivial events and repeated patterns which are in themselves uninteresting.  Even death, success, failure, and love can be lost in an overwhelming mass of trivial events.  "I got up, I brushed my teeth, I ate a piece of toast with apricot jam, I put on my clothes and didn't put my pajamas away, I went out, saw a yellow Volvo heading down the street, then my brother called me on my cell phone and told me that our mother died."  If this sort of narration interests you, you will like THE SMELL OF IT.  The ambience is Cairo/Egypt of the 1960s, not one which would be familiar to English readers of today.  That is an interesting plus.  The author spent five years in prison for political reasons, so his experiences and attitude are reflected in the writing too.  The five stories in this collection have a sad atmosphere which surrounds the tales of lower middle class Egyptian life of the time---an ex-prisoner's alienation, a fear of open spaces and raw nature, a child's view of divorce and war, an isolated family vs. the world.  All of these stories are embedded in a mass of trivia that indeed does surround us, but may or may not constitute satisfactory reading material for you.The author took this minimalist style in this, his early work.  Later he wrote more directly political material.  He is one of the important Egyptian writers, but not much translated into English.

A callow youth spends some days in the English countryside at an estate presided over by a gray, unflappable host with an eccentric, colorful wife.  His other companions are a deaf girl, a cherubic girl who wants to try "it", a cynical bore with a speech for every occasion or topic, and not forgetting a lovely young thing who's a bit of a tease.  For awhile we also meet a youthful ladykiller with a yellow car.  Our callow youth dreams of romance with the lovely young thing but can't quite manage it.  He comes close once, but ah.....  Humorous and satirical, CROME YELLOW is full of Huxley's various philosophizings and you can definitely note the seeds of the idea for "Brave New World" that came later.  Crome is the name of the estate, and there is a paint color called "chrome yellow" I believe, but except for the ladykiller's car, there's nothing particularly yellow about this novel.  I confess to have missed something.  This is a light read.  The cover notes tell us that this novel shocked Europe in its day.  Well, that may have been, but it's totally innocuous by today's standards.  People who liked "Brideshead Revisited" will certainly like CROME YELLOW....it's not an action novel, but a lightweight satire of manners, of youth, and of those now-long past days.

Oscar Lewis, in a brilliant series of books on Mexico and Puerto Rico, argued that poor people live in a special "culture of poverty".  It seemed to me when I read them that there were some flaws in this argument, though for sure poverty means the same thing all over the world.  It means you don't have everything you need.  It means more struggle, more worries, and odds against everything---proper health, education, housing, etc.  It means that generosity is more prized and unkindness more often remembered.  If you read about the lives of the Moroccan family in Munson's book, you will certainly recall Lewis' work too.  However, village life in Morocco probably resembles village life in Mexico or India more than it does urban slum life in the same country.  Urban slum dwellers everywhere face similar problems.  The middle class, ditto, the rich class, ditto.  And people can move from one class to another, often changing their behavior accordingly.  They keep their religious affiliations, even if the strictness of their observance may slacken. And they maintain their ties to the people back in their former way of life....sometimes quitting one milieu for another.  Some move up the ladder and return only as visitors..  So I am not sure that you can speak about "a culture of poverty".  It is enough to say that people with similar economic circumstances may face similar problems and come up with similar solutions.  They may behave in similar ways.  This is a family history, told through two members of the clan, a lower class man of strong, conservative beliefs and a woman who, through education and chance, moved to Europe, then America, marrying an American professor.  They both comment in turn upon all their relatives and tell the family history.  The research was done around 1980, thus dating the book somewhat.  However, as a rare insight into the details of Moroccan family life in unvarnished detail, it's a valuable study.  Though Westerners think of Muslim societies as strict and puritanical, the amount of philandering in lower class Moroccan society shown here calls that into question.  A case of ideals being overrun by reality.  People even in the same family follow entirely different economic, moral, and behavioral paths.  The difficulty of generalizing is so apparent when reading a book like this.  Readers may also be interested in "A Life Full of Holes" by Paul Bowles in cooperation with an illiterate Moroccan, Driss ben Hamed Charhadi, as well as Elizabeth Fernea's "A Street in Marrakesh".

In the late 19th century, before the French finally occupied Morocco (calling it a "protectorate"), there were no roads or railways in the country.  The Sultans could not control the outlying areas.  They tried to do so through local caids who had their own armies and made continual raids into the large, rugged areas beyond central control.  The fortunes of these subordinate rulers waxed and waned.  Maxwell's book is about the most successful family of these in the 20th century, a family based in the Atlas Mountains, which divide Morocco more or less down the middle.  In competition with two other of these local caids, the Glaoui family cast its fortune with the French and became the most powerful in the whole country.  They commanded an army of Berber warriors who gradually got modern arms.  They plotted and planned and got their relatives into all the important positions in much of the country.  The Glaoui family became so powerful as to get the sultan dethroned and exiled to Madagascar.  They called the shots---but only for a short while.  The tide of history changed.  Colonialism became too expensive and politically untenable.  The nationalist movement (Istiqlal) grew stronger, taking the exiled Sultan as its symbolic leader.  The French saw the writing on the wall; they were fighting a vicious war in neighboring Algeria.  They caved in.  The Sultan returned and the Glaoui fell from power.  T'hami El Glaoui died in early 1956 and Morocco regained its independence in the same year.  Today the once-mighty forts erected by the Glaoui family sit crumbling in the mountains.  How all this happened is a fascinating story, very well told in this book.  While it might not be academic history, you don't get a chance to read about these events and these characters in many places.  Give it a try.

WHISH !  THUD!  That's the sound of the bus driver's head falling to the bus floor in Chapter 1.  Some terrorists have taken control and are whisking a group of American tourists out of sight, to be held for a huge ransom.  But one slips away.BOING !  It dawns on us.  Hey, we've seen this guy before.  Actually he had the major role in Bill Thompson's previous thriller "the Relic of the King".  It's Slava Sergeenko, a.k.a Juan Carlos Sebastian, a.k.a Roberto Maas, a man it's hard to keep down.  He escaped from an ancient Roman tunnel in downtown London only to re-appear here as "Paul Silver".  We might call him "Quicksilver" because this dude is really on top of things, a James Bond sort of guy.ARGGH!  Not only some tourists, but some of the bad guys get snuffed.  Which ones?  Hey, you've gotta read the book.  How does it happen?  Ditto.  When you do, you're going to run into a very eclectic group of characters, ranging all the way back to Pharaonic Egypt.  Need I say more?  Secret caves, esoteric knowledge of long-vanished civilizations, unsuspected contacts between continents....a lot of imagination here.AHH! and assorted satisfied gasps from the characters in a certain steamy sex scene.  Yes, this book has a variety of things to offer.RUMBLE---BOOM!  A cave-in is going to leave you in suspense.  How are the heroes going to get out of this one?  You're going to be waiting for Bill's next volume.WHIZZZ!  That's the sound of you turning the pages in this extremely fast-paced, action-packed thriller.and fnally ZZZZ.  That's definitely NOT you as you read THE CRYPT OF THE ANCIENTS which is full of unexpected twists and turns.  I wonder if Bill is getting into the realm of science fiction.  Why?  Hey, check it out. If you can't enjoy this book, then I reckon you're ready to take up croquet.

Melville Herskovits, who died in 1963, is not the most famous anthropologist ever, but he was the first white man to tell the world to wake up and smell the coffee.  That is, that African cultures were rich and varied, that they had been brought by slaves to the New World and still lived on, though mixed with European and Native American-derived elements.  He founded the first African Studies department in the US and a great library at Northwestern University.  His many studies of African cultures in West Africa, Haiti, Surinam, and Brazil showed the way to many others.  In the racist society of his day, it took a white man to open the door, through which many scholars of many races have followed.  It was not news to people of African descent.Herskovits also tried to show how cultures mix and meld, how it is impossible to divide a society like Haiti's into European and African sectors---everyone lived in both sectors.  At a time when "voodoo" and "zombies" were the stuff of comic books and horror tales, he attempted to describe Haitian vodun accurately, with no sensationalism, and link it to West African religion.  LIFE IN A HAITIAN VALLEY is a lengthy compendium of all the details of many aspects of life that he and his wife were able to amass in some three months of intensive field work.  In my opinion, that was not enough time to do a thorough job, but as one who has never set foot in Haiti, I'm not in a position to criticize his observations or comments.  This is ethnology in the mid-20th century style---trying to cover in a single book life cycle, economic life, religion, magic, and the arts as well as trying to link the whole to a wider African culture.  There is no link to any individual; the observed don't speak, only the observers.  As I said, this was the prevailing style, so it's not a real criticism.  I think the value of Herskovits' work is in a) the ties he draws very well to West Africa, b) the comments he makes about the relevance of his work to the USA and African-Americans (he uses the word "Negro"), c) the down-to-earth approach to Haitian religion.  Maya Deren's work "Divine Horsemen" covers similar ground but plunges into the depths of the matter so quickly that it doesn't provide much of a learning experience, d) his comments on the mixing of cultures, which after all, is almost a human universal, whether you like it or not, and e) in providing us today a social history of Haiti 80 years ago.  If you want basic knowledge about Haiti, and are willing to read research done in 1934, this could be your book.

This is a collection of badly-translated essays written by two gentlemen of Japan back in the late '80s.  One was the chairman of Sony Corp., Morita Akio, and the other, a rather unsavory right-wing politician, Ishihara Shintaro, who later became Governor of Tokyo for 13 years.  While I think it would be positive if Japan stood up to the US against some of our more dubious activities, the "Japan That Can Say No" takes a narrow, nationalistic tack backed by some doubtful facts as well.  That the two authors failed to see that Japan's bubble of the 1980s would someday burst and that that day would come sooner rather than later speaks loudly of the "wisdom" of their comments.  That Mr. Ishihara thinks that Korea and Taiwan benefitted from Japanese colonialism may be true in the same way that India, Vietnam, or Indonesia "benefitted" from European colonial rule.  But when he suggests that Singapore (under Japanese military occupation for four years) also owes its later prosperity to Japanese tutelage, I just had to laugh.  Americans behave like mad dogs, they are shifty, they are doomed....yeah, well, OK, how y'all doin' ?  I wouldn't claim any "knight in shining armor" role for the US, but Japan's role on the world stage before 1945 was not marked by much altruism.  The most telling point to be made about this book is that Mr. Morita, to his credit, disavowed his participation later on.  THE JAPAN THAT CAN SAY "NO" created a minor splash at the time, but I think that today it can be forgotten.  If you are looking for a good book on Japan's situation up to the mid-1990s, you should take a look at "The Emptiness of Japanese Affluence" by Gavan McCormick.  That book could be subtitled, "The Japan That Should Have Said No."

The American media has always liked to delineate "sides" in any conflict.  We come to think of "good guys" and "bad guys", aggressors and defenders.  But in many situations, it's not so simple.  Look at the Middle East today.  I'm not going to go into that.  But the situation in Poland, as World War II drew to a close, was at least as chaotic as today's conflicts in the Arab world.  You had Nazis, you had German civilians beginning to flee west before the oncoming Soviet army.
